editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Liber hic cui titulus, The ANATOMY of Humane Bodies Epitomized, IMPRIMATUR.

Daniel Whitler Elector and Cenor.

list.head: Cenors.

John Downes,
Charles Goodall,

div.p: THE ANATOMY Of Humane Bodies EPITOMIZED.
WHEREIN All the Parts of Man's Body, WITH Their ACTIONS and USES, ARE Succinctly decribed, according to the newet doctrine of the mot accurate and learned Modern Anatomits.
By a Fellow of the College of Phyicians, London.
LONDON, Printed by M. Fleher for T. Fleher, at the Angel and Crown in St. Paul's Church-Yard. MDCLXXXII.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p: IN relation to this Treatie I think my elf obliged to account for two things; Firt, why I publih any thing of this nature; econdly, why in Englih.

As to the firt; I mut confes it was not any Ambition to become an Author that put me upon it; but another occaion. The Bookeller for whom this is printed, (my particular Friend) thinking to make a new Impreion of a Book intituled The Manual of the Anatomy or Diection of the Body of Man, written by Dr. Alexander Read, a Fellow of the College of Phyicians, London, deired me to perue it, and if in any place I oberved it erroneous, to alter it. ndertanding that the Book had been writ many years agoe, (that which was brought to me being the fifth Impreion, and that printed in 55.) I was unwilling to meddle with it, upecting that
there mut needs be very coniderable Errors in it, o many new things in Anatomy having been dicovered ince that time. However at his importunity I undertook it: and before I had lookt over a Sheet, I aw I was not deceived. For though I had reolved to give my elf no further trouble than was neceary, yet I found that if I would mend all that was amis, I mut in effect write a new Book. Which I have really done, as any one will find that will take the pains to compare this with that writ by Dr. Read, for he will ee very little of that retained except the method, which indeed is but little alter'd; for though it differ pretty much from the modern, yet I think 'tis every whit as convenient.

As to the econd, Why I hould write it in Englih; I have two things to alledge: Firt, The example of him that has gone before me, who was a peron (as I am informed) eminent in his time. Secondly, to avoid the injury of a paltry Tranlator, if it hould be well accepted. For we ee there is no Man that publihes any thing in the Latin tongue, that is received with any applaue, but preently ome progging Bookeller or other finds out an indigent Hackney cribler to render it into Englih. But with what di-reputation and abue to the worthy Authors, every learned peron cannot but oberve. So that he that hall think to redeem the noble
faculty and art of Phyick out of the hands of the Mechanical Quacking Tribe by publihing every thing in a language above their undertanding, will not only fail of his end, but find himelf abued and digraced into the bargain.

And now as to the Work it elf, the main deign of it is to pleaure thoe that are entring upon the tudy of Phyick; for herein they may ee in hort, what afterwards they hall find more largely treated of in other Authors. And perhaps it may not be altogether unuefull even for uch as have made ome proficiency in that tudy; for it will erve at leat as an Index to bring to their remembrance what they have read more fully elewhere; and will ave them the labour to make uch a Compendium for their own ue. There is little that is new in Anatomy, but the Reader will find a tate of it here. Which he will the rather expect to meet with, when he undertands that mot of thee following learned Anatomits are in ome meaure Epitomiz'd in it.

list.head: Authors made ue of in this Treatie.

—Anatomia Hepatis.
Dr. Charlton's Enquiries into Humane Nature in IV. Anatomick Prelections in the New Theatre of the Royal College of Phyicians in London.

—Exercitationes de Generatione Animalium.
Malpighius de Vicerum tructura.

Dr. Grew's Comparative Anatomy of Stomachs and Guts, ubjoined to his Mueum Regalis Societatis.

div.p: With everal others.

div.head: OF THE LOWEST CAVITY, CALLED ABDOMEN.
CHAP. I.
Of the diviion of the parts of the Body of Man in general.
div.p: ANATOMY is an artificial eparation of the parts of the Body by ection,The decription of Anatomy. practied to attain to the knowledge of the frame of it, and the ue of each part.
In Anatomical exercies, firt the whole Carcae doth offer it elf, then the parts.
The whole hath four Regions,The Regions of the whole. to wit, the fore and back parts, and the lateral, which are the right and left.

I call the whole that which containeth the parts,What the whole and a part ignifie. and a part that which is contained in the whole, according to the mot ample acception of the term part; for in a more trict acception that is called a part, which partakes of the form and life of the whole; and is defined to be a body olid cohering with the whole, endued with life, and framed to perform ome function.
A part then mut be firt olid: Things required in a part being trictly taken. humours then cannot be numbred amongt the parts, becaue they are fluid.

Secondly, it mut have life and o the excrements of hairs and nails are not to be accounted
parts.
Thirdly, one part mut not nourih another: and o the bloud, fat, and pirits are not parts.
Fourthly, it mut have a circumcription.
Fifthly, it mut be united with the whole, both in repect of matter and form.
Sixthly, it mut have ome function, or ue.
The principal differences of parts are taken either from their matter, The differences of the parts. or end. From their matter, parts are aid to be either imilar, or diimilar.
A imilar part is that whoe particles are of the ame ubtance and denomination with the whole:What a imilar part is. as every portion of a bone is bone. It is otherwie called a imple part.

Of imple parts there are ten in number The number of imple parts. to wit, The skin, a membrane, the fleh, a fibre, a vein, an artery, a nerve, a ligament, a cartilage, a bone: they are comprehended in thee two veres.

q.p: Vena, ligamentum, cutis, os, lentiima fibra.

div.p: To thee a tendon, Of a tendon. which is the principal part of the mucle, may be added; for the ubtance of it is imple, without any compoition.

Of the former imple parts,The differences of imple parts. ome are imple indeed, and thee are in number even; the skin, a membrane, the fleh, a fibre, a ligament, a cartilage, a bone. The ret are onely imple to the eye or ene, and not to reaon; for a nerve (for example) is compoed of many filaments, covered with a double membrane, made of the dura, and pia mater.

Of the imple parts ome are called permatical, as a bone, a cartilage, a ligament, a membrane, a fibre, a nerve, an artery, a vein; thee being made of the eed, if they be cut in two, or broke, are not regenerated, nor can truly be again united; but are onely joyn'd by a callus. Others are anguineous, being uppos'd to be made of bloud, and thee are regenerated, uch is all the mucular fleh. As for the skin, it eems to be partly permatical and partly anguineous; for though in grown men a wound in it is healed onely with a cicatrix, yet in boys it has been oberved to be cloed with a true and proper skin. But of its nature ee more in the next chapter.

A diimilar part is that whoe portions are neither of the ame ubtance,What a diimilar part is. nor the ame denomination; as a mucle, in the which are fleh, nervous fibres, and a tendon. It is otherwie called a compound part, and an organical part.

In an organical part four particles are commonly found;Things to be oberved in an organical part. as in the Eye, there is firt, the chief particle, by which the action, namely viion, is performed, which is the crytallin humour.
Secondly, that particle, without which the action cannot be performed, as the optick nerve.
Thirdly, that which furthereth the action, as the membranes and mucles.
Fourthly, that by which the action is preerved, as the eye-lids.
Of organical parts there are four degrees. The degrees of an organical part.
The firt is made onely of the imilars, as a mucle.
The econd receiveth the firt kind of organical parts, and other imilars, as a finger.
The third admitteth thoe of the econd degree, as the hand.
The fourth is made of the third and other parts, as the arm.
Parts from their end are ditinguihed into principal, The differences of parts taken from their end. and les principal or minitring.
The principal are the Liver, Stomach, Heart, Brain.
The minitring are either neceary, or not.
The neceary are thoe without which the Animal cannot live. So the Lungs miniter to the Heart, the Guts to the Stomach.
The not neceary are imple fleh, &c. in repect of other parts: for in conumptive perons 'tis almot wholly pent; and Inects, according to Aritotle, have none.
There are alo other diviions of the parts of the Body, as into parts containing, parts contained, and the pirits, expres'd by < in non-Latin alphabet > , or impetum facientes, by Hippocrates.

Fernelius divides the Body alo into publick and private Regions. The private are uch as the brain, reins, womb, &c. The publick are three. The firt hath the Vena portae, and all the parts whither
its branches reach. The econd begins at the roots of the Cava, and ends in the mall veins before they become capillary. The third hath the mucles, bones, and the bulk of the Body, terminating with the skin. But this diviion is only of ue in Phyick.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Of the circumcription, regions, and parts of the Abdomen.
div.p: OF all the parts of the Body we are to begin Diection with the Cavities: Firt, becaue they offer themelves to the view in the fore region of the Body. Secondly, becaue they being moit, and apt to receive the impreion of the external heat, oonet putrefie and end out noiom mells.

The Cavities are appointed to receive the principal parts, and thoe which miniter unto them. Wherefore there are three Cavities, according to the number of the principal parts. The Head is for the Brain, the Breat is for the Heart, and the Belly for the Liver. And becaue this lat Cavity is mot ubject to putrefaction, you are to begin at it.
Now three things concerning it offer themelves. Firt the circumcription or bounds of it. Secondly, the regions of it. Thirdly, the pecial parts of it.

As concerning the circumcription of it,The circumcription of the Abdomen. it is evered within from the Breat by the Midriff. It is bounded above by the cartilago eniformis, or the Heart-pit, and beneath by the Share-bones.
The regions of it are three,The regions of it. the uppermot, middlemot, and lowermot.

The uppermot, which is bounded between the mucronita cartilago, and three inches above the Navel, about the ending of the hort Ribs, hath three parts: The two lateral, which are called hypochondria, or ubcartilaginea, becaue they lie under the cartilages of the hort Ribs. In the right hypochondrium lieth the greatet part of the Liver, and part of the Stomach, but in the left the Spleen, and a greater part of the Stomach. The third part is that which before lieth between the two lateral parts, and is properly called epigatrium, becaue the Stomach lieth under it. In this part remarkable is the Pit of the Breat, which is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , or crobiculus cordis, by the modern Writers.

The middlemot region extendeth it elf from three inches above the Navel, to three inches under it. The fore part is where the Navel is, from whence it is called regio umbilicalis. The two lateral parts are called by Aritotle
< in non-Latin alphabet > , either from their laxity, or from < in non-Latin alphabet > , alacitas, becaue they are the eat of lut; by Galen
< in non-Latin alphabet > , becaue being placed between the hanch-bones and Ribs they are lank and eem to contain nothing. They are called by Dr. Glion epiçolicae, becaue on each ide, this region inveteth the lateral parts of the Gut Colon. The hindermot parts parallel to thee are called lumbi, the Loins, in the right whereof is the right Kidney, and in the left, the left.

The lowet region is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , hypogatrium. This region hath three parts, the two lateral, and the middlemot: The lateral are bounded by the
• a Ilia, o called becaue a great part of the Ilium intetinum lieth under them on each ide. Beides this, in the right part are placed the beginning of the Colon, and the caecum intetinum, which latter is joyned as an appendage betwixt the Ilium and Colon. In the left part are contained the ending of the Colon, and the intetinum rectum.

The fore-part of the Hypogatrium by Aritot. lib. 1. Hit. animal. 3. is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , which Gaza calleth Abdomen and Sumen. Under it lieth the pubes, which word ignifieth both the hairs, and the place where the hairs grow, which appear to bud in Girls the twelfth year, but in Boys the fourteenth year, when way is made for the monthly coures, and eed begins to be generated. At the ides of the pubes appear < in non-Latin alphabet > , or Inguina, the Groins. Under this lowet region in its middle are contained the Bladder, and the Matrix in Women.
Behind, it is terminated by the os acrum.

div.head: CHAP. III.
Of the common containing parts of the Belly.
div.p: THE common containing parts of the Belly are four, the skarf-skin, the skin, the fat, and the membrana carnoa.

The skin in a Man is called cutis, but in Beats aluta; in Greek it is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , and < in non-Latin alphabet > ; either
< in non-Latin alphabet > , becaue it is eaily flea'd off; or from < in non-Latin alphabet > , eeing it is the end and uperficies of the whole Body. Of all the membranes of the Body it is the thicket.

It hath a double ubtance;1. Cuticula, or skarf-skin. the one is external, called < in non-Latin alphabet > , becaue it is placed upon the Skin as a cover. It is termed cuticula in Latine, and is as large as the Skin, and more compact; for waterih harp humours, paing through the Skin, are tayed by the thicknes of this, and o putules are caued. In Man it is as the peeling of an Onion. It is without bloud and without feeling.

The material caue of it is a vicous and oleous vapour of the bloud, raied by the natural heat of the ubjacent parts, and dried and condened by the external cold, as mot Anatomits have taught; but Dr. Glion not improbably thinks it to be a oft, lippery, vicid and tranparent juice (like the white of an Egge) iuing out of the capillary extremities of the Nerves which end in the outer uperficies of the true Skin, where it is coagulated, and by its vicoity ticketh upon it like glue, o that it can hardly be eparated therefrom
by a knife, but eaily in living creatures by a veicatory, and in dead perons by fire, or calding hot water. It ometimes alo almot wholly peels off in burning fevers, and the mall pox; but a new one preently ucceeds it.

The ue of it is Firt,Its ues. to defend the Skin, which is of an exquiite ene, from external immoderate either heat or cold. In cold weather it breaketh the cold, that the perpiration hould not be altogether hindred: In hot weather by its compactnes it hindreth too great perpiration.
Secondly, to be a middle between the Skin and the object to be felt; for when it is rubb'd off, the true Skin cannot endure the touch of other Bodies without pain.
Thirdly, to tay the ichorous ubtance from iuing from the Arteries; for this we ee when the cuticula is rubbed off by any means.

Fourthly, to make the Body more beautifull; which it does by moothing the aperities of the true Skin, and inducing a comely colour of white and red. Whitenes is natural to this part, and the rednes is owing to the bloud that is affus'd to the outward uperficies of the true Skin; which being een through the Skarf-skin makes that florid colour.

The true skin is ix times thicker than the Skarf-skin:2. The true skin. in Children, Women, and thoe which are born in hot Countries, it is thinner; but in Men, and in thoe who inhabit cold Countries, it is thicker.

It is naturally white,Its colour. as other membranes; but in living and healthfull perons, and uch as live in a temperate or omewhat cold climate, from the afflux of the bloud towards it, it is of a
reddih roie colour. But in thoe that live under the Aequinoctial Line and in exceively hot climates it appears black in the outer uperficies, becaue they having a ofter Skin, and large pores and looe, many vapours of the adut humours are raied with the weat; the groer ubtance whereof, (being topt by the Scarf-skin, and) by reaon of the exceive heat, being dried and burned, caueth that blacknes; for their infants are not born black but reddih.

It is made up of nervous fibres very cloely interwoven one with another, and of a parenchyma that fills up the intertices and inequalities thereof. That it has uch a parenchyma may appear by this, that when a Sheep-skin (for intance) has been ome while teept in water, one may with an ivory knife or the like crape a great deal of mucous limy matter off it, whereby it becomes much lighter, thinner and in ome meaure tranparent, as we ee in Parchment.

The Skin in the Fore-head and Sides is thin, thinner yet in the palm of the Hand, but thinnet of all in the Lips and Cods. In the Head, Back, and under the Heel it is thicket. Under the Heel the cuticula in ome will be as thick as a barley corn, and may more truly be called a callus than a cuticula; and uch it is in the palms of the Hands of uch as much handle hard things, as Smiths, and the like. It is thinner in Children and in Women than in Men; in thoe that live in hot Countries, than thoe that live in cold. And this (as Spigelius oberves) is the reaon why thoe that are born in cold Countries, when they come under the Aequinoctial Line, are often taken with fevers; becaue that great heat that is
there excited in the Body by the outward air, cannot exhale through the too thick Skin, but being retained induces a preternatural heat, and o a fever.
The pores will appear in the Skin in the winter time, it being bared; for where they are, the cuticula will appear as a Gooes Skin.
The Skin hath an action,Its action. to wit, the ene of feeling.

Its ue is,Its ues. firt, to cloath the whole Body, and defend it from injuries. Secondly, to be a general vent or emunctory to the Body, by which all its exhalations may fitly tranpire. Which whether it be done onely through its pores, as mot Anatomits have affirmed; or alo through its very ubtance, as Dr. Glion has of late aerted, is a controverie hardly worth the initing on.

In the next place appears the fat, 3. Fat. which is commonly taken to be omething ditinct from the membrana carnoa that lies under it; but is indeed onely a part of it: for in its outer part it is full of membranous cells, which are fill'd with a yellowih fat. But however having noted this errour, we hall peak after the manner of former Anatomits, and conider it as eparate, and o define it to be an oleous humour of the Body elevated by the moderate heat of the parts lying under it, and concreted betwixt the carnous membrane and the Skin in membranous cells. Now though in Men this fat is immediately next to the Skin, yet in Beats the membrana carnoa comes between, and is indeed muculous, and o cloe joyned to the Skin that by the help of it they can (many of them) move the Skin o as to hake off flies or any thing that offends them: but it is not o in Men in any
place ave the Fore-head, which therefore they can move in like manner.

This Fat is properly called pinguedo, whereas that of the Caul, &c. is called evum, Suet or Tallow. And they differ in this, that pinguedo is eaily melted, but not o eaily congealed; but evum is not eaily melted, but is eaily congealed. Beides, pinguedo is not brittle, but evum is.
The ues of it are thee:Its ues. Firt, it defendeth the Body from the air; o Apothecaries, when they mean to preerve juices, pour oyl upon them.
Secondly, it preerveth the natural heat.
Thirdly, it furthereth beauty by filling up the wrinkles of the Skin.

Fourthly, in the Mucles it filleth up the empty places, rendreth the motion thereof more glib and eaie, (o it do not abound too much) and keepeth all the parts from drines, or breaking. Hence it bemears the extremities of the Cartilages, the joyntings of the greater Bones, and the Veels that they may pas afely.

Fifthly, in a pecial manner it helpeth the concoction of the Stomach; whence the Caul being taken out, there follow flatus and belchings; and in uch cae it is neceary to fence the Stomach extraordinarily with outward warmth.

Membrana carnoa, 4 Membrana carnoa. or < in non-Latin alphabet > , o called in Man; not that it is in him flehy, (but nervous, and o hould rather be called Nervea;) but becaue in Beats, which the Ancients ued mot commonly to diect, it is endued with flehy Fibres. In the birth it is red, but in thoe of ripe age white; in the Fore-head and Neck it is more flehy. Within it is bedewed with a vicous humour, to further the motion of the Mucles by
keeping the uperficies of them from deiccation; which otherwie might fall out by reaon of their motion. It is of an exquiite ene, wherefore when it is pricked with harp humours, it caueth hiverings, uch as are felt in the beginning of Ague-fits.
Firt it preerveth the heat of the internal parts.Its ues. Secondly, it furthereth the gathering of the fat. Thirdly, it trengtheneth the Veels which pas between it and the Skin.

In the next place (according to the uual method of Anatomits) we hould come to peak of the Mucles of the Abdomen with their Membranes, &c. But we have thought it more convenient to treat of the Mucles of the whole Body in a particular Book, and o hall but onely name the Mucles of the lower Belly here, as they appear one after another to the diector. And firt there hew themelves the obliquely decending pair; econdly, the obliquely acending; thirdly, the Recti; fourthly, the pyramidal; and latly, the tranvere. All thee being removed, there appears the peritonaeum, of which in the next Chapter.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
Of the proper containing parts.
div.p: THE proper containing parts are the Mucles of the Belly, and the Peritonaeum. Of thee Mucles we hall peak Book 5. Chap. 17.

The Peritonaeum or inmot coat of the Belly (derived < in non-Latin alphabet > , from its office of encompaing) is tied above to the Midriff, below to the Share and Flank-bones; in the fore-part firmly to the tranvere Mucles, but chiefly to their Tendons about the Linea alba; behind to the flehly heads of thee Mucles looely. The end of this firm connexion is to pres equally the Belly, for the expulion of the Ordure, and for repiration. If this connexion had not been, the Peritonaeum would have become wrinkled, the Mucles being contracted. If it had not been looe tied to the flehly parts, the contraction of them in the compreion of the Belly had been hindred.

Its figure is oval; its ubtance is membranous; the inner uperficies of it, which repects the Guts, is mooth, equal and lippery, bedewed with a kind of watery humour contained in the Abdomen: but the outer uperficies, whereby it cleaves to the Mucles of the lower Belly, is rough and unequal.

As for the origine of it, Fallopius will have it to proceed from that trong plexus of Nerves, from whence the Meenterium is aid to have its beginning. Some will have it to proceed from the Ligaments by which the vert • brae of the Loins and of O • s acrum are tied together. Picolhomineus will have it to be framed of thoe Nerves which pring out of the pinalis medulla, about the firt and third Vertebrae of the Loins. But Fallopius's opinion eems the mot probable; for there it cannot be eparated without tearing, and is very thick.

It is double every where, but appears o to be
chiefly about the vertebrae of the Loins, where between the duplications lie the Vena cava, the Aorta and the Kidneys. In the Hypogatrium two Tunicles are alo apparently een, between which the Bladder and Matrix lie. The umbilical Veels alo are placed in the duplicature of the Peritonaeum, that they may march the more afely. Above, where it is tied to the Midriff, it has three faramina or holes; the firt on the right ide, whereby the acending trunk of the Vena cava paes; the econd on the left ide, for the Gullet (with the Nerves inerted into the mouth of the Stomach) to decend by; the third, by which the great Artery or Aorta, and the Nerve of the ixth pair may pas. Below, it has paages for the trait Gut, for the neck of the Bladder, and in Women for the neck of the Womb; alo for the Veins, Arteries and Nerves that pas down to the Thighs. Before, in the foetus for the umbilical Veels and the rachus.

But the mot remarkable are its two procees, placed before near the os pubis, on each ide one. They are certain oblong productions of its outer Membrane paing through the holes of the Tendons of the oblique and tranvere Mucles, and depending into the Cod, there betowing one Tunicle on the Stones. There are alo two procees in Women, but they reach onely to the inguina or Groins, and terminate in the upper part of the Privity or the fat of mons Veneris. The inner Membrane of the peritonaeum (in Men) reaches but to the very holes, which it makes very trait; but being either relaxed or broken, the outer gives way, and o there follows a rupture, either the Caul, or the Guts, or both decending thereby. By the holes of the procees there decend
in Men the Veels preparing the eed, and the Mucles called cremateres, and by them acend the Veels bringing back the eed. In Women there pas by them the round ligaments of the Womb, which after growing omewhat broadih, are joyned to the clitoris, or ele terminate in the fat of Mons Veneris.

The peritonaeum is thicket below the Navel, for that when one either its or tands, his Intetines bear down heavy on that part, o that unles it were there tronger than ordinary, it would be in danger of breaking. In Women with child alo, it is very much extended in this region. And thus far of the parts containing.

list.head: The Explication of the Figure.
list.item: AA The coverings of the Abdomen diected, and turned back, that the inner parts may come to view.
B The word-pointed Gritle, or cartilago eniformis.
CC The gibbous part of the Liver.
DD The Stomach.
EE Part of the Colon placed under the Stomach.
FFFF The upper membrane of the Omentum knit to the bottom of the Stomach.
G The Navel.
HH The umbilical Vein.
II The two umbilical Arteries.
K The rachus.
L The Bladder.
aaa The gatroepiploical Veels dipered through the Caul and Stomach.
MM The Intetines.

div.head: CHAP. V.
Of the Omentum.
div.p: THE parts contained erve either for nutrition, Of the parts contained in the lower belly. or procreation. As for the parts erving for nutrition, they either erve for chylification, or anguification. The principal efficient caue of chylification, is the Stomach; but the adjuvants are the Caul, and the Pancreas.

The principal efficient caues of anguification, have been held to be the Liver and Spleen, and the other parts to be adjuvant caues. But ince it has been dicover'd that none of the venae lacteae pas to the Liver, but that the whole chyle is conveyed by the ductus thoracicus to the Heart and o into the mas of Bloud, they are dicharged from the task of anguification; though they do contribute to the refining and perfecting of the Bloud already made.

The excrements of the chylification are received by the Guts. The excrements of the anguification have been taught to be two, viz. choler, and the erous humour. The thin choler is received by the veica fellea; but the thicker by the meatus cholidochus. The erous humour is turned to the Kidneys, and from thence to the Bladder by the Ureters.
The parts appointed for procreation, are the Genitals, both in Men and Women.

Next then to the Peritonaeum is the Omentum, The caul. or Caul, in Greek it is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , becaue it eemeth to wim above the up-upper
Guts. The Arabians call it Zirbus.
It is compoed of two Membranes,Its ubtance. of Veels, Glands and Fat.
The uppermot Membrane doth pring from the bottom of the Stomach,Its connexion or origine. and is tied to the hollow part of the Liver and Spleen.

The inner or lowermot doth pring from the Peritonaeum, immediately under the Midriff towards the Back, and is tied to that part of the Gut Colon that paeth under the Stomach lengthways, to the Pancreas or Sweetbread, to the Midriff, and to the Duodenum intetinum.
Its lower part doth hang looe and reacheth in mot below the Navel, but in ome that are fat to the very os pubis. Its bottom is cloe and united, o that it is itly compared to a pouch.

From its double origine there arieth betwixt its partitions a notable cavity, which ome very weakly have detin'd to divers ues; but indeed it reults onely accidentally, and was not for its own ake framed by Nature. For (as Dr. Glion reaoneth) whilt Nature is olicitous about providing a fit deputy for the Meentery (and that membranous) and tuffing it with fat, through which Veels may be carried to the Stomach, Liver, Spleen, Pancreas and Colon, and whereby he may joyn all thoe parts after a due manner; and moreover whilt he takes care that it hang down looely, and bemear both the Stomach and Intetines with its unctuounes; and in the mean while be every where continuous to it elf: I ay, whilt he diligently propoes all thee ends, if he will obtain them, he mut needs make the Caul hollow as it is above decribed, and its propending part
mut needs imitate the bottom of a pouch. Thus he.

The Omentum aboundeth with Veels of everal orts;Its veels. we hall begin with the Arteries,1. Arteries. and tranlate hither the account that the above named Doctor gives of them, which is very exact. Its Arteries are propagated from the coeliaca; or rather the inner Leaf (as he calls it) of this Membrane, near its origine, receives and upholds this Artery, (as oon as it paes out of the Aorta) betwixt its Membranes. It is divided into two branches, the right and left. The right being joyned to the vena porta in the pancreas, and fenced with the Membranes of the omentum, is carried into the cava of the Liver: but it firt ends forth thee branches; the pyloricus, to the hinder ide of the right orifice of the Stomach; the arteriae cyticae gemellae, the epiplois dextra, a portion whereof is dipened to the Gut colon; the intetinalis carried to the duodenum and beginning of the jejunum; the gatro-epiplois dextra, which is ditributed into the right bottom of the Stomach—The left branch of the coeliaca, called plenicus, is greater than the right, and being included within the Membranes of the hinder Leaf of the omentum is carried directly left-ways to the uture of the Spleen under the bottom of the Stomach. In its paage it ends forth many branches: pwards one notable one called arteria gatrica, which waheth the bottom and ides of the Stomach and its upper orifice, and there gets the name of coronaria; alo a econd called gatroepiplois initra, whereof one portion is dipered into the bottom of the left part of the Stomach,
and both its fore and hinder parts, and the remainder is pent on the fore Leaf of the omentum; it ends forth a third alo, that famous branch called vas breve arterioum, which is inerted into the left part of the left orifice of the Stomach. Downwards alo it hoots forth ome branches, as the epiploe initra, which being divided into two rivulets waters partly the hinder Leaf of the omentum, and partly the colon it elf; alo another little branch, which is wholly pent on the left part of the hinder Leaf of the Caul.

p.q: The Veins that anwer to the aid Arteries rie almot all from the plenick branch,2. Veins. the trunk of which Veins after it is joyned with the tem of the plenick Artery, puts forth branches exactly anwering and proportioned to thoe of the aid Artery; and all the branches of both Veels are dipened to the ame repective parts, and are denominated from them, o that 'twould be needles to tay longer on their ditribution: only the branch that goes to the right orifice of the Ventricle, called of ome pyloricus, takes its rie from the trunk of the porta before 'tis divided.

div.p: It has but very mall nerves proceeding from a double branch of the ixth pair:3. Nerves. and thee, as the Veins, accompanying the Arteries, and having the ame names, we hall not take the pains to trace.

But beides thee Veels formerly known,4. Vaa adipoa. there are ome that think they have dicovered another ort called adipoa; amongt whom Malpighius is a leading man: whether there be uch or no, I leave the curious with their glaes to inquire; for,
for my own part, I could never dicern any uch by the naked eye, or uch glaes as I have made ue of.

Dr. Wharton in his Book de Glandulis, 5. Venae lacteae. cap. 12. declares, that he has oberved ome venae lacteae ariing out of the bottom of the Stomach, to be received into the omentum, which being inerted into a pretty large gland do from thence pring again, and are carried obliquely downwards, croing the right extremity of the pancreas: one would think, aith he, at the firt ight, that they enter'd into the pancreas, but they do in truth pas by it, and make towards the common receptacle of the Chyle, into which they unload themelves.

The ame learned Phyician does in the ame place give an account of two Glands that are naturally found in it.Its glands. One greater near its being joyned unto the pylorus, and into this it is that the lacteae are inerted; another omewhat les placed towards the Spleen, and this he has oberved ometimes double, triple, yea manifold. Preternaturally it has ometimes many more.

The fat is about the Veins and Arteries,Its fat. to trengthen them, and to keep them from being compreed by the repletion of the Belly, and other motions. When the Stomach is full, and the Guts empty, the upper Membrane of the Caul is raied, the lower remaining in its own place; but if the Guts be full, and the Stomach empty, then the lower Membrane rieth up, the upper remaining in its own place; for which end its lower end is free and untied, that ometimes the upper, ometimes the lower Membrane might rie up, aith Spigelius.
The ues of it are thee:Its ues. Firt, it cheriheth the internal heat of the lower part of the Stomach, and of the Intetines.
Secondly, it minitreth nourihment to the parts in the time of famine, Galen. de u. part. l. 2. c. 11.
Thirdly, like the Meentery, it erves to convey afely the Veels to other parts, as to the Stomach, Colon, Duodenum, &c.
Fourthly, it keeps the outer uperficies of the Guts moit and glib, that they may the better perform their peritaltick motion.
Creatures which have no Caul,An obervation. help concoction by doubling their hinder Legs, and reting their Belly upon them, as Hares and Conies.

They who have had a portion of it cut off,Another. becaue it was corrupted by reaon of a wound received in the abdomen, have afterward a weak concoction, and are enforced to cover the Belly well. See Galen. lib. 4. de uu part. 9. where he proveth this by example.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
Of the Gula.
div.p: THE Gullet being as it were the pipe or funnel of the Stomach, though it be eated in the thorax, and o hould be conidered in the next Book, yet becaue of its relation to the Stomach, being but an appendage of it, we hall treat of it here.

It is an organical part,Its origine & decent. round and hollow, beginning
at the root of the Tongue, behind the larynx and Windpipe (where it is called pharynx) and paeth from thence directly between the Windpipe, the vertebrae of the Neck, and the four firt vertebrae of the thorax, upon the which it reteth; but when it is come to the fifth vertebra, it giveth way to the trunk of the great Artery decending, by turning a little to the right ide: afterward accompanying the Artery to the ninth vertebra, there it turns a little to the left again, and is raied up, by means of the Membranes, from the vertebra, and marching above the Artery, it paeth through the nervous body of the Midriff at a hole ditinct from that of the great Artery, and is inerted into the left orifice of the ventricle, about the eleventh vertebra of the Breat.

It is properly called
< in non-Latin alphabet > ,The names of it. quai < in non-Latin alphabet > , angutus & longus: ee Aritot. 1. hitor. animal. 16. It is alo called
< in non-Latin alphabet > , quòd cibum ad ventriculum vehat.

It is framed of three Membranes.Its tructure. The firt is the uttermot and common, compaing the two proper; this it hath either from the peritonaeum, according to ome, or from the pleura, or from the ligaments of the vertebrae of the Neck and Breat upon which it reteth. The econd is the middlemot, and it is flehy and thick, for it conits of two ranks of flehy Fibres, (what Fibres are ee B. 5. ch. 1.) which acend and decend obliquely, and do mutually decuate one another. This hath been held by many (not improbably) to be a kind of Mucle, becaue it is ometimes affected with Convulions and Palies. The third is the innermot, and it is membranous;
and hath onely mall and traight Fibres. It is continued to that Membrane that covereth the Palate, Mouth, Jaws and Lips; whence the lower Lip uually trembleth, when one is going to vomit; and (according to Dr. Willis) it decends three fingers breadth below the mouth of the Stomach.

It hath Veins in the Neck from the Jugulars, in the thorax from the vena ine pari; Veels. but where it is joyned to the Ventricle, it hath ome twigs from the ramus coronarius, which proceedeth from the porta.
Nerves it hath from the ixth pair, which are carried obliquely, for afety, as Galen noteth, l. 6. de uu part. 6. and are very many.

It hath four Glandules; Glandules. two in the Throat, which are called Tonillae, or Almonds, common to the Gullet and the Larynx, which prepare and eparate the pituitous humour to moiten them; other two it hath about the middle of it, towards the Back, about the fifth vertebra of the thorax, namely, where it gives way to the trunk of the aorta, and turns omewhat to the right ide, or at that place where the apera arteria is divided into two branches.

The Gullet erveth as a funnel to carry meat and drink to the Stomach;The ue of it. for it receiveth them by dilating its proper internal coat, and turneth them down by the contriction of the middle coat, and the Mucles of the Pharynx. But concerning its action, and in what manner, and by what help wallowing is performed, ee more fully and particularly
in the fifth Book, Of the Mucles, chap. 12.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
Of the Ventriculus or Stomach.
div.p:
THAT part which we term the Stomach in Englih,Its denomination. in Latin is called Ventriculus, without any addition, to ditinguih it from the other Ventricles, which have always ome other word added to determine the ignification, as ventriculus cordis, ventriculus cerebri. In Greek it is called
< in non-Latin alphabet > , and < in non-Latin alphabet > , from its Cavity.

In Man it is but one;Number. but uch quadrupeds as chew the Cud, epecially all that are horned, have four Stomachs; the firt whereof is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , in Englih the Paunch; the econd < in non-Latin alphabet > , in Latin reticulus; the third < in non-Latin alphabet > , omaus, in Englih the Feck; the fourth < in non-Latin alphabet > , abomaus, in Englih the Read. Such Fowl alo as live upon Corn have two Stomachs; the firt membranous, called ingluvies, the crop; the econd carnous, called ventriculus carnous, in Englih the Gizard. Betwixt thee two ome name a third called echinus, but it eems rather a paage only betwixt thee two than it elf a ditinct one. But this is not a place to be particular as to the differences of number or hape, &c. of the Stomachs of everal Animals, having deigned only a uccinct Anatomy of Man. But the inquiitive may atisfie themelves in the learned Dr. Charleton's econd prelection
before the College of Phyicians, entituled Hitoria Ventriculi; or more fully in the ingenious Dr. Grew's comparative Anatomy of Stomachs and Guts, publihed with his Mueum Regalis Societatis.

It is placed immediately under the Midriff,Situation. which it toucheth; wherefore if it be too full it caueth a difficulty of breathing, by hindring the motion of it. In the forepart on the right ide, it is covered with the hollow part of the Liver; on the left ide it is touched by the Spleen; towards the Back by the aorta, the vena cava, and under it backwards by the pancreas: all which further its heat.

The bignes of it is commonly uch, as is capable to receive o much food at one time, as is ufficient for nutrition. It is les in Women than in Men, to give way to the ditention of the Matrix. They who have wide Mouths, have large Stomachs.

It is joyned with the gula on the left ide,Connexion. where its upper orifice is: it is tied to the duodenum, where the lower orifice is, on the right ide. The bottom in the whole length of it is joyned to the upper part of the Caul, by whoe mediation it is joyned to the Liver, Back, Spleen, Colon and Pancreas.

The ubtance of it is membranous,Subtance. that it might admit ditention and contraction. It hath three Membranes. The firt is common, which it hath from the peritonaeum or the Diaphragm about the upper orifice; it is the thicket of all thoe which pring from the peritonaeum; the Fibres of it being nervous are traight, running from one orifice to the other, and encompaing
both its bottom and ides in their whole longitude. Near the orifices and towards the bottom of the Stomach, they are far thicker than in the middle, inomuch as there they eem in a manner carnous and motory. Thee nervous Fibres of this Membrane do cros at right angles the carnous ones lying next under them.
The econd is flehy, and the Fibres of it are tranvere, under which a few oblique, and thoe flehy, lie. This Coat is believed by ome to be mucular.
The third is nervous, endued with all kinds of Fibres; traight, oblique and tranvere; but the traight are mot conpicuous and plentifull.
It is omething wrinkled, and its inner uperficies is pulpous, porous and oft. It is always moitened with a limy flegmatick humour, that ticks o cloe to it, as if it were omething that grew out of it.

Beides thee Membranes with their Fibres it hath alo a parenchyma, but that not anguineous, but of a peculiar ort. For without a parenchyma how hould the inequalities, that pring from the texture of the Fibres, be filled up? And what hould that be, which thoe that make trings for muical Intruments, crape from the Guts, if not it? for we ee after uch craping they have lot nothing of their trength, which they owe to the Fibres and Membranes. And 'tis apparent that the ubtance of the Guts and Stomach is the ame. Some there are that think this parenchyma that I plead for, to be almot wholly glandulous.
It hath alo two orifices. Orifices.

The one is in the left ide, called initrum,
wider than that in the right, that meat not well chewed might the better pas. It is called in Greek < in non-Latin alphabet >
cor, from whence the region of the Stomach under the cartilago eniformis is called crobiculus cordis, or Heart-pit; and hence alo the pains which happen in it are called < in non-Latin alphabet > , and < in non-Latin alphabet > , becaue there is a great conent between it and the Heart, by reaon that the twigs of Nerves which proceed from the ame branch, pringing from the ixth pair, communicate to both; o that one being affected primarily, the other mut uffer by conent.

This hath orbicular Fibres, that the meat and drink being once received within the capacity of the Stomach, it might be exactly hut, let fumes and the heat hould break out, which might hinder concoction, and annoy the Head.

The other by the Grecians is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , janitor, or door-keeper, becaue it, as a Porter, doth make way for the Chylus to decend to the duodenum: It is not o wide as the other orifice, becaue it was only to tranmit the elaborate Chylus. Here the inmot nervous Coat is very full of wrinkles; the middle, which is carnous, hath here alo two ranks of Fibres; tranvere or anular, to traiten this paage; and econdly traight, viz. uch as running lengthways do gather up and draw the ret of the Stomach towards this door, for the ditribution of the Chyle after it has been ufficiently concocted in the Stomach.

It hath Veins,Its veins. firt, from the trunk of vena porta, and this is pyloricus ramus; or, econdly, from the branches of the ame, for o from ramus plenicus it hath gatrica minor, and gatrica major (the larget Vein of the Stomach) from whence
coronaria pringeth; gatro-epiplois initra, and vas breve: from the ramus meentericus, before it be divided, it hath gatro-epiplois dextra. All thee Veins, (as the ret of the Body) erve only to convey back again (towards the Heart) the remains of the arterial Bloud which in the circulation is not pent on the refection and nourihment of the part; though ome learned modern Anatomits think they do beides the arterial Bloud receive ome of the more ubtile part of the Chyle for its readier conveyance into the mas of Bloud, and thence draw a reaon of the very quick refrehment that hungry and faint perons receive by eating or drinking.
It hath its Arteries from ramus coeliacus, Its arteries. which do accompany every Vein, and have the ame denomination with them.

It hath Nerves from the par vagum, Its nerves. o • the ixth pair (Dr. Willis's eighth) whoe trunks paing down (below the pneumonick branch) by the ides of the Gullet are each divided into two branches, the outer and inner. Both the inner branches bending to one another grow into one, which paing with the Gullet through the Midriff goes on the outer part of the orifice of the Stomach, and preads it elf in its bottom. The two outer branches in like manner inclining to each other unite into one, which decending to the Stomach by the oeophagus, and arriving at the inner part of its orifice, there turns back and creeps through its upper part. The inner and outer branches as they come one on one ide, and another on the other ide of the upper orifice of the Stomach, end forth many mall twigs, which mutually inoculating make there the plexus nerveus like a net.
From this multitude of Nerves interwoven in the mouth of the Stomach proceeds that great conent betwixt it and the Head. (So that in any great concuion of the Head there follows a vomiting, and from the foulnes of the Stomach the Head-ach, &c.) Here at this upper orifice, from the ame reaon, is the ene of hunger mot urgent.

And this is a proper place to reolve the quetion,The caues of hunger. What is the true caue of hunger? To which I hall give Diemerbroeck's anwer as the mot probable. It is caued from fermentaceous (or diolving) particles partaking of acrimony, bred of pittle wallow'd and other altih or acid things eat or drunk, which ticking to the coats of the Stomach, and brought to ome acidity by it, or remaining in it after the Chyle is ent off, affix'd to its inmot wrinkled Membrane (epecially about its upper orifice) molet it by their twitching, which twitching being communicated to the Brain by the Nerves of the ixth pair, an imagination of taking meat is excited to awage that troubleome corroion.] He that doubts of the truth of this opinion, may find it evinc'd at large in his Anatome corporis humani, cap. 6. p. 39, &c.

The action of the Stomach is Chylification. Its action. Now Chylus is a white juice reaonable thick,Chylus. like Barley cream, made out of the aliments taken; the manner whereof is well expret by the ame Author. While the meat is chewing in the Mouth it is mix'd with the aliva, which not onely oftens it, but endows it with a certain fermentative quality, unto which contributes alo the drink, (whether Beer, or Wine, or
ome other) which often contains in it acrimonious particles and fermentaceous pirits. The Stomach by the help of its Fibres embraceth cloely the meat thus chew'd and wallow'd, and mixeth therewith pecifick fermentaceous juices, bred in its inner coat, and impregnated with the aliva. Then by a convenient heat there is made a mixture and eliquation of all; for that the fermentaceous particles entring into the pores of the meat, do pas through, agitate, and eliquate its particles, diolving the purer from the cras, and making them more fluid, o that they make another form of mixture, and unite among themelves into the reemblance of a milky cream: after which, together with the thicker mas, in which they are as yet involv'd by the contriction of the Stomach they pas down to the Guts, where by the mixture of the bile and the pancreatick juice, they are by another manner of fermentation quite eparated from the thicker mas, and o are received by the lacteal Veels, as the thicker is ejected by tool.] See further hereof in Dr. Charleton's third prelection before the College of Phyicians, Sect. 6. p. 112.

Of figure, Its figure. it is round moderately; partly, that it hould not take too much room; partly, that it might receive much. It is omewhat long, and hath two orifices higher than the bottom, let if one hould have been in the bottom, the aliment hould have iued out of it unconcocted.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
Of the Intetines, or Guts.
div.p: THE Guts are called in Latin Intetina, Their name. in Greek < in non-Latin alphabet > , from their being placed within the Body.
They are oblong,Figure. membranous, hollow, round, diverly twited, continued from the pylorus to the podex, for conveying the Chyle, and the excrements of the firt concoction.

They are knit together by the Meentery,Connexion. by which and by the intervention of the Caul (to which, part of the Colon is affix'd) they are tied to the back, and fill the greater part of the Cavity of the Abdomen, being utained by the Cavities of the os ilium.

They are of a membranous ubtance like the Stomach,Subtance. thinner in the mall Guts and thicker in the great; and the nearer they come to an end, the thicker they are, as the end of Colon and the Rectum.

The length of the Guts is about ix times the parties length whoe they are.Their length. They are thus long (and winding) that the concocted aliments paing out of the Stomach, by their long tay in the Guts, might the more commodiouly be fermented by the admixture of the bile and pancreatick juice, and o the more ubtile chylous parts being eparated from the thicker mas, might be the better and more leiurely driven into the narrow orifices of the lacteal Veels, partly by the proper peritaltick motion of the Guts, and alo
by the impulion of the Mucles of the Abdomen moved in repiration. And hereby two great inconveniencies are avoided; the one of eating almot continually, which would have follow'd from the Chyles having not time enough to be elaborated and ditributed, before it would have arrived at the anus, whereby the Body mut needs receive but mall utenance from any thing eat or drunk; the other (for the ame reaon alo) of having almot a continual need of going to tool; as happens to uch voracious animals as have a treighter paage from the Stomach to the anus.

They have three coats,Coats. as the Stomach; one common and outermot from the Peritonaeum, but mediately; for in the Duodenum, and that part of the Colon which cleaveth to the Stomach, it proceedeth immediately from the lower membrane of the Caul; and in the jejunum, ileum, the ret of the Colon, caec •• m and rectum, it proceedeth from the membranes of the meenterium. It is all over bemear'd with fat, and is truly nervous.

They have two proper. The outer, being the middle of the three, is carnous. It has two ranks of moving Fibres, one lying under the other; The firt and inner rank is annular or tranvere, which encompaing the whole cavities of all the Intetines in very cloe order, is inerted into the hem or eam of the Meentery as into its Tendon. The other rank is of treight Fibres, which being pread above the former, and cutting them at right angles, reach along the whole length of the Intetines; and their Tendon eems to be the outmot coat, which being
wholly nervous, or as it were tendinous, is rolled about the whole rank of thee Fibres.

The innermot is nervous, although it eem to be flehy, by reaon of the cruty ubtance with which it is lined, which is framed of the excrements of the third concoction of the Guts themelves. This lining is called by Pecquet a pongy peritoma, by Bilius a woolly mos; it erves as a Filtre for the Chyle to trancolate through in order to its entrance into the venae lacteae; and beides, it hindreth excoriation, which might be caued when harp humours pas through the Guts. Some (as particularly Dr. Willis) take it for a ditinct coat, and call it glandulo atunica or villoa; but I think 'tis only an epiphyis or excrecence upon the other, caued as aboveaid.

This Membrane in the mall Guts, epecially the ileum, is full of wrinkles, to tay the chylus from paing too oon; which wrinkles are caued, for that this inmot coat if it be ever'd from the other and the wrinkles tretcht open, will be (according to Fallopius's obervation) thrice as long as it. And the ame Membrane is expanded in the Colon into little cells, for the lower paing of the faeces. It has all orts of Fibres, and contains the mouths of all the Veels both anguineous and lacteal, which are cover'd with that pongy crut before-mentioned.
What was aid of the Parenchyma of the Stomach in the foregoing Chapter, may without repeating it here, be applied to the Guts likewie.

As to their Veels,Veins. the Veins flow from the Porta, although not from the ame branch: For the duodenalis urculus is ent into the duodenum,
and the Haemorrhoidalis interna to the left part of the Colon near its ending, and thence running under the rectum is inerted into its end or anus; as the dexter meentericus is ent to the jejunum, ileum, caecum, and the right part of the colon. Epiplois potica is inerted into the middle part of the Colon, which marcheth tranverly under the Stomach: beides thee, a prig from the ramus hypogatricus of the vena cava is ent to the Mucles of the intetinum rectum, which maketh the external haemorrhoidal.

The ue of thee Veins inerted into the Intetines the Ancients thought to be, both to carry venal bloud to them for their nourihment, and alo to receive the chyle out of them and carry it to the Liver there to be turn'd into bloud. As to the firt ue, 'tis certain (by the circulation of the bloud) that thee Veins carry nothing to the Guts; but the bloud in them, is all received from the Arteries there, to be carried back towards the Liver and o to the Heart: but as to the latter, there are ome learned Anatomits that till think, though the greatet part of the chyle is received by the venae lacteae, yet that ome part is uckt in by thee Veins, o to be more readily convey'd into the mas of bloud. But this opinion is exploded by others as learned and more numerous, who deny any uch office to them, whom I believe to be in the right. Beides thee anguineous Veins there are another ort of Veins inerted (more or fewer) into all the Guts, called Lacteal, but of them we will treat in a ditinct Chapter.

The Arteries pring partly from ramus coeliacus intetinalis, Arteries. partly from both the meentericae. To
the duodenum, and the begining of jejunum, a prig is ent from the right ramus coeliacus: but to the ret of the jejunum, to ileum, caecum, and the right part of colon, meentericus uperior; to the left part of colon, and to the intetinum rectum, meentericus inferior is ent. This lat paing along the rectum to the podex, makes the internal haemorrhoidal Arteries, as ome branches from the arteria hypogatrica make the external. At the lat, epiplois potica, which rieth from the lower part of arteria plenica, which is the left branch of arteria coeliaca, is ent to the middle part of colon, which lieth under the Stomach. Their ue is to convey nourihment and warmth to the Guts; and when the Body is morboe, to carry thither the impurities of the bloud, upon a purge taken, or critically, o to pas out by tool.

Nerves they have from the inferiour ramifications of the intercotals. The nerves. The duodenum hath ome twigs from the upper branch of the ramus meentericus called tomachicus, which go alo to the pylorus. All except the rectum have many twigs from the plexus meentericus maximus, ariing from under the great gland of the Meentery; but the rectum, with the latter end of colon receive lips from that branch of the Intercotal that is called plexus abdominis infimus or minimus; and the utmot extremity of the Intercotal is inerted into the phincter ani, whither alo pas three or four that pring from the bottom of os acrum. Thee Nerves erve for the feeling, and the peritaltick or worm-like motion of the Guts; which though it be obcure and low, yet becaue it is continual, it had need of o great a number of Nerves or nervous Fibres as are betowed on the
Intetines. The learned and curious that would be further informed about the peritaltick motion, may conult Dr. Glion in cap. 15. of his Book de ventriculo & intetinis, or Dr. Charleton in Sect. 3. of his third prelection before the College of Phyicians.

Though the Guts be one continued Body from the pylorus to the anus, The diviion of the Guts. yet from the thicknes of their ubtance, alo from their magnitude, figure, and variety of office they are ditinguiht into everal by Anatomits, and firt into thin, and thick.

The thin poes the umbilical region and hypogatrium; The thin. and in repect of their figure, ituation, longitude and plenty of lacteal Veels, they are divided into three, viz. the duodenum, jejunum and ileon.

The firt is called duodenum, 1. Duodenum. becaue it is thought to have twelve inches in length. It doth pas from the pylorus under the Stomach towards the Spine, and is utained in its paage by the Membrane of the Caul, and not by the Meentery. It reaches as far as the left Kidney, to which and to the vertebrae of the Loins it is tied by membranous ligaments; and going a little lower it ends under the colon, where the anfractus or winding of the two following mall Guts begins. It is thicker in its Membranes, but its paage (becaue treight) is traiter than theirs. Towards its lower end, ometimes higher, ometimes lower, it has mot commonly two ducts leading obliquely into it; firt the ductus choledochus communis by which the bile from the Liver enters this Gut; and econdly a little below this, ductus pancreaticus (otherwie Wirtungianus) by which the pancreatick
juice paes hither from the Sweet-bread: though thee two ducts are ometimes joyned into one, and both open by one mouth into this Intetine. Sometimes, though rarely, they are inerted into the jejunum.

The econd is called jejunum, 2. Jejunum. or the hungry Gut; for it is for the mot part found empty; partly by reaon of the multitude of milky Veins that enter it; partly by reaon of the fermentation of the acrimonious choler with the pancreatick juice, which are both poured in jut before its beginning. In length it is twelve hand-breadths and three inches. It beginneth on the right ide, under the colon, where the duodenum endeth, and the Guts begin to be wreathed; and filling almot the whole umbilical region, epecially on the left ide, it tendeth into the ileum, from which it may be ditinguiht firt by its emptines; econdly by its greater number of Veins and Arteries, from which it looks reddih; thirdly from the nearnes of the folds or wrinkles of its inmot coat one to another, which are but about half an inch ditant, whereas in the ileum they are a whole inch or more.

The third is ileum,
• . Ileum. derived < in non-Latin alphabet > , à circumvolvendo, from its many turnings and windings. It hath thinner Membranes than the ret of the tenuia. It is eated under the Navel, and filleth both the Ilia. It is the longet of all the Guts, for in length it containeth 21 hand-breadths; but it is the narrowet of all, for it is not an inch in breadth. It hath fewer wrinkles than the jejunum, and leer, which about the lower end of it carcely appear.

It beginneth where both maller and fewer
Veins appear, and endeth about the place of the right Kidney, where it is joyned both with the intetinum caecum, & colon. It is eaily ditinguihable from the colon, for it is not joyn'd to it by a treight duct but tranvere. For the colon and caecum are o united as to make one continued canal, whoe lower ide the ileon acending pierceth, and into which its inner coat hangs looely the length of half an inch at leat, making the valve it elf of the colon, and is the very limit that divides the caecum from it.

This ileum oft falls down into the Cod, whence uch a rupture is called Intetinal. And in this Gut happens the ditemper called Volvulus or Iliaca paio, wherein there is often vomiting of the dungy excrement. This ditemper is caued herein, either when one part intrudes into another, or when 'tis twited and twined like a Rope, or when it is tufft with ome matter that obtructs it, or latly when it falls out of its place into the crotum, as was noted before. And thus much of the firt ort of Intetines, viz. the mall or thin.
Now follow the intetina craa, The thick Guts. the great Guts; they are three in number alo.

The firt is called caecum, 1. Cacum.
< in non-Latin alphabet > , the blind Gut, becaue one end of it is hut, o that at the ame orifice the chylus (or faeces rather) paeth, and returneth. In Man it is about as thick and but half as long as your larger earth-worms tretched out at length; but its mouth that opens towards the colon is pretty large. It owes its origine rather to the colon than the ileum, and eems to be as it were an appendage to it. It is bigger in an Infant than in a Man. It is not tied to the
meenterium; but being couched round, it is knit to the peritonaeum, and by its end it is joyned to the right Kidney, the peritonaeum coming between. In ound perons it is generally empty. In four-footed Beats it is always full of excrements. Apes have it larger than a Man, Dogs larger than Apes; but Conies, Squirrels and Rats, larget of all, if you conider the proportion of their Bodies. Its ue is very obcure in Men, being o very mall and commonly empty. But in grown foetus's or Infants new born it is full of excrement, for which it erves as a tore-houe till after the birth that they go to tool. And in uch Animals as have it large, (according to Dr Glion) it erves for a bag or econd Ventricle, wherein the prepared aliments may be tored up, and o long retained, till a richer, thicker and more nutritive juice may be drawn from them.

The econd is colon, 2. Colon.
< in non-Latin alphabet > , either quai
< in non-Latin alphabet >
cavum, becaue it is the hollowet or widet of the Guts; or ele < in non-Latin alphabet > , ab impediendo, becaue it detaineth the excrements. It hath its beginning from both the ileum and caecum, tranverely from the ileum, but directly from the caecum. It arieth at the os ileum on the right ide, and acending by its Spine it arrives at the right Kidney; to which parts it is annex'd by a membranous connexion. From thence bending leftways it creeps under the Liver by the Gali-bladder (which tinges it there a little yellowih) to the bottom of the Stomach; to the whole length whereof it is tied, only the Caul coming between, (as alo to the pancreas and Loins.) Then it comes to the lower part of the Spleen, and is knit
to it. Then touching the left Kidney, and adhering firmly to it by Fibres, it comes to the left os ileum; from which decending by the left Groin to the pelvis it embraceth the bottom of the Bladder behind on each ide. Afterwards it acends upwards by the right Groin near the place from whence it firt took its rie; and thence marching back again towards the left ide, and running it elf in betwixt the ileum and Backbone it reaches to the top of os acrum, and there unloads it elf into the rectum. Its length according to Dr. Glion is about even feet; others reckon it horter. It goeth almot quite about the abdomen next to the Mucles, that it may be the better compreed by them for avoidance of the excrements. Diemerbroeck has an ingenious reaon why it hould pas under the Stomach, viz. That as Chymits judge no digetion more natural than that which is performed by the heat of dung, o the heat of the excrements in the colon does help the coction of the Stomach.

It hath cells which pring from the internal Tunicle of it: Thee cells are kept in their figure by a Ligament half an inch broad, which paeth through the upper and middle part of it all along; this being broken or diolved, the cells tretch out and appear no more. Their ue is to hinder the flowing of the excrements into one place, which would compres the parts adjacent; as alo for the lower paage of the faeces, that we may not have a continual and haty need of going to tool. On its outide from its paing by the Spleen to its joyning to the rectum it has a great many fatty knots, which erve to moiten and lubricate it, that the faeces may pas the more glibly.
The rectum alo has uch like, for the ame reaon.

It hath a valve where it is joyned with ilium, Its valve. (as was noted before) like to the igmoides in the inus of the Heart, as Spigelius compares it. This valve o toppeth the hole which is common to the ileon and colon, that flatuoities cannot acend to the ilium, much les excrements regurgitate. If one would find this out, let him pour water into the intetinum rectum, and hold up the Guts: The water will tay when it comes to the valve, if it be ound. If this valve be relaxed or torn by any means, excrements may regurgitate, and be expelled by vomit, and clyters alo acend up to the Stomach, as hath often happened in the Iliacal paion.

The third is intetinum rectum, 3. Rectum. the treight Gut: it hath its beginning at the firt vertebra of the os acrum, where the colon endeth; and paeth treight downwards to the extremity of the coccyx, and is fat tied on its back-ide to both by the peritonaeum, to keep it from falling out; and on its fore-ide it grows in men to the neck of the Bladder, whence in the pain of the Stone there, there often happens a tenemus or continual inclination to go to tool; and in women to the neck of the Womb: but in both there is a muculous ubtance that comes between. It is a pan in length, not o wide as the colon, but its Membranes are thicker. The Mucle < in non-Latin alphabet > is at the end of it, which encompaing it round, pures it up cloe, o that nothing can pas out, unles it be relaxed voluntarily. This Gut (epecially its inner Membrane) uually bags a little out in training at tool, yea ometimes o much, that it requires an artificial putting up again.

As for the hemorrhoidal Veins and Arteries, that are inerted into the anus, we have given an account of them before in this Chapter; as we hall do of the Mucles belonging to it, in Book 5. of the Mucles, Chap. 19.

list.head: The Explication of the Figure.
list.item: A The Stomach.
B The Gullet or Oeophagus.
C The left and larger part of the Stomach.
D The upper orifice of the Stomach.
E The right external Nerve of the ixth pair (Dr. Willis's eighth) encompaing the orifice.
F The left external Nerve of the ame pair.
GG The gatrick Veels creeping along the bottom of the Stomach.
H The lower orifice of the Stomach, called Pylorus.
h The inertion of the Gall-paage into the Duodenum.
III The Jejunum and Ileum with the Veels creeping along them.
K The Caecum.
LLLL The Colon.
M The valve in the beginning of the Colon opened.
mmm The Ligament holding together the Cells of the Colon.
NN The Rectum.
O The Sphincter of the Anus.
PP The Mucles called Levatores Ani.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
Of the Meenterium.
div.p:
THE Meentery is o called from its ituation.Its denomination. For it has its Greek name < in non-Latin alphabet >
(from whence the Englih is derived) from its being placed < in non-Latin alphabet > , in the midt of the Intetines. And it is a membranous part, ituated in the middle of the lower Belly, erving not only for conveying ome Veels to the Intetines, and others from them, but alo it ties mot of the Guts together o artificially, that for all their manifold windings they are not entangled and confounded. Which may be much wondred at, how the Guts being about nine or ten yards long hould all but the duodenum and a piece of the rectum be comprehended by that circumference that is but a pan ditant from the centre; for no longer is the Meentery betwixt thoe bounds. But it is almot of a circular figure, which is mot capacious; and though it be narrow at its rie, (which is double, viz. at the firt and third vertebrae of the Loins) yet its circumference is wrinkled and enlarged into o many folds, as to be three ells in length, whereby it comes the nearer to anwer the length of the Guts, and to keep them within a mall compas and place likewie.

It is framed of two common Membranes,Subtance. which it has from the duplicature of the peritonaeum; and betwixt thee two it has a third Membrane that is proper, (which was firt dicover'd by
Dr. Wharton in a young Maid) and is thicker than either of the other two, wherein the glands are eated and by which the Veels are conducted.

The parts contained in the Meentery are either common or proper.Parts. The common are Veins, Arteries, Nerves and Lympheducts. The proper are Glands and the Venae lacteae. Of thee lat we hall peak in the next Chapter, of the ret here.

The Veins are called Mearaicae; Veins. thee pring from ramus meentericus dexter & initer, branches of the vena portae. (Their ue, as alo that of the Arteries, was hewn in the Chapter before, peaking of the Veels belonging to the Guts.)
It hath alo two Arteries, Arteries. the one uperior, the other inferior, branches of the arteria meenterica, which pas as the Veins do.

As for the Nerves, Nerves. Dr. Willis decribeth them very accurately in his Book de Cerebro, cap. 25. which take thus in hort. As oon as the intercotal pair is decended as low as over againt the bottom of the Stomach, it ends forth on each ide a large meenterick branch, each of which is again divided, and makes two plexus in each ide. In the middle of thee is the greatet plexus of all, which (as he peaks) is like the Sun amongt the Planets; from which twigs and numerous Fibres are dipered into all the parts of the Meentery, which accompanying the anguiferous Veels in their whole proces, do climb upon them and tie them about.] Others it hath from thoe which pring from the pinalis medulla, between the firt, econd, third and fourth vertebrae of the Loins, (as Spigelius affirmeth.)

Beides thee Veels known to the Ancients,Lympheducts. about 30 years agoe there were found out another ort by Tho. Bartholin (a learned Dane) and called by him vaa lymphatica, which he gives a large account of in Append. 3. to the libel. 1. de Venis, of which I hall give a compendium here, becaue the Meentery abounds with them.

They are of figure long and hollow like a Vein, but very mall and knotty, having very many valves which permit the lympha or water contained in them to pas to the chyliferous Veels (and many Veins) but hinder its return. They are of a pellucid and crytallin colour, like hydatides, coniting of a tranparent and mot thin skin, which being broken and the lympha flowing out, utterly diappears. Their number cannot be defin'd, for they are almot innumerable. As to their rie Bartholin peaks uncertainly, but Steno and Malpighius both declare that they always proceed from Glands. As to their inertion or ending, thoe under the Midriff do dicharge their liquor into the receptaculum chyli (to be poken of in the next Chapter.) Thoe in the thorax, immediately into the thoracick duct. And thoe of the Neck, Arms, &c. into the jugular vein. Bartholin thought they all dicharg'd themelves into thee three channels: but Diemerbroeck affirms they open alo into many other Veins; and quotes Steno noting that they empty themelves into the jugular and other Veins; and alo his Countryman Frederick Ruych writing that by ligature and tructure of the Valves he has plainly een, that all the lympheducts in the Lungs do dicharge their lympha into the ubclavian, axillar and jugular Veins. There has been much dipute
what this lympha which they carry, is. Bartholin thinks it to be the imple uperfluous erum of each part, brought thither by the Arteries. Glion, that it is a liquor condens'd from the halitus of the bloud (like dew) driven into thee Veels, and flowing back with the vehicle of the aliment brought by the Nerves. Segerus (and Sylvius) that it is the animal pirits, or is made of them, which after they are ditributed into all parts by the Nerves, are there partly conum'd and diipated, and are partly condens'd into this water. Diemerbroeck quotes more opinions beides thee, but rejects them all, and etabliheth this of his own: viz. That it is a fermentaceous liquor eparated from the erous part of the bloud in the conglobate Glands, yet not imple, but impregnated with much fus'd and volatile alt, and alo with ome ulphureous particles; which when it is conveyed to the vaa chylifera, makes the chyle thinner, and apt to dilate eaily in the Heart; and when to the Veins, prepares the venous bloud (now too thick) for a quick dilatation in the Heart.] This lympha, whatever it be, (or be for) differs from the erum; for if one gather a little of it in a poon, and let it tand, without etting it on the fire, it will turn to a gelly, which the erum will not doe. And thus much of the Lympheducts (with their lympha) in general; as to thoe particularly of the Meentery, ome only pas through it from other parts, as the Liver, &c. but many have their rie in it, and both the one and other are emptied into the receptaculum chyli.

It hath many little oftih Glands fix'd in its proper Membrane,Glandules. cover'd on each ide by the
two common ones, and beet with fat. In number they are very uncertain; in Man fewer than in other Creatures. The bigget by much is at the rie or center of the Meentery, (called by Aellius, pancreas) into which all the venae lacteae are inerted. Of its ue, as alo of the leer, we hall peak in the next Chapter, when we come to treat of the paage of the Lacteals. We will only note here, that when thee Glands grow cirrhous, or are any ways obtructed, o that the Chyle cannot trancolate through them, there follows a fluxus coeliacus, or chylous, which continuing there enues an Atrophy, and the party dies tabid.

The fat with which it is tufft betwixt its Membranes,Fat. though it happen naturally to it, yet ought not to be reputed a proper part of it. For not to mention that in Dogs, Cats, and uch like Animals this part is very thin and tranparent, even in humane Embryo's it is without fat; and in very lean Men there is but little, though in fat Men it be heaped up to o great a thicknes.
It is but one,Diviion. yet becaue of its different thicknes it is divided by ome into two parts.

The one they call Mearaeum,
< in non-Latin alphabet > , becaue it is placed < in non-Latin alphabet >
(ubaudi
< in non-Latin alphabet > ) in the midt of the mall Intetines, which it knits together; and this is the thicker part of it. The other being the thinner they call < in non-Latin alphabet > , being eated < in non-Latin alphabet > , in the midt of the colon, to which it is joyned in its whole length ave only in the colon's paage under the Stomach; and in its lowet border it adheres to the rectum.

Dieaes incident to this part are reckoned up by Dr. Wharton to be thee;Dieaes. thoe of intemperies,
traitnes or obtruction, tumours of whatoever kind, (Scirrhi, Scrophulae, Strumae) Inflammations, Abcees, Ulcers, and Tone vitiated. Of all which the Reader that deires fuller information, may be atisfied by the aid learned Author, in his Adenographia, cap. 11.

div.head: CHAP. X.
Of the Venae lacteae, Receptaculum Chyli, and ductus chyliferus Thoracicus.
div.p: VEnae lacteae, Their name. the Milky veins (o called from the white colour of the Chyle which they carry) were not dicover'd (as uch) till the year 1622. when Capar Aellius found them out in diecting a Live-dog well fed. But ince him many others have made a more accurate dicovery of them. They are lender pellucid Veels, having but a ingle Coat, dipered through the Meentery, infinite in number, appointed for the carrying of the Chyle.

They pring out of the Intetins,Rie. into whoe inmot Membrane their Mouths are inerted, which are hid under a kind of a pongy crut or mucus, through which by the preion of the Guts the Chyle is trained and received by the mouths of thee veels.
