Preently after their rie they aim to that nearet part of the Meentery, whereto the Intetin from which they arie, is knit. Then they go the readiet way to uch Glandules of the Meentery as are nearet to them: but in
their paage ometimes many little branches meeting grow into one great trunk; namely, before they ininuate themelves into the Gland, to which we aid they were going. But in their very entrance into the Glands, or a little before, this trunk eparates again into new branches, more and maller than the other, which are obliterated in the very ubtance of the Gland. Out of the Gland there pring again new capillary Veins, which by and by meeting together make one trunk again as before: which being carried towards the beginning of the Meentery, in their march joyn to themelves others of the ame kind meeting them, and o grow larger and larger, and at lat very many enter into the great or middle Gland of the Meentery (called improperly Pancreas) in the ame manner as they enter'd the maller, and ome pas by over its uperficies, and by and by they all empty themelves into the great or common receptacle of the Chyle, that lies under the aid Gland, thoe that were inerted into it riing out of it, as was before poken of the leer Glands.

p.U: ays that behind the great Gland there are three other maller (which he calls Lumbares) into which the Lacteals are inerted, but aents to Dr. Wharton, that from them they pas to the Receptaculum.

div.p:
This common Receptacle is called Receptaculum Chyli Pecquetianum, Receptaculum chyli. from Pecquet who firt found both it and the ductus Thoracicus (whoe beginning it is) about thirty years ago. It might as well be called receptaculum Lymphae, for that the Lympha paes not only with the Chyle, but after this is all ditributed, the Lympha till continues to
glide into it, and to acend by the ductus chyliferus Thoracicus, which might be called Lymphaticus for the ame reaon. This Receptacle is eated under the Coeliack artery and Emulgents at the vertebrae of the Loins, whence there prings a duct •
that preently enters the Diaphragm with the Arteria magna, where (being now enter'd the Thorax) it begins to be called ductus Thoracicus. And now though it be pat out of the Abdomen (of the contents whereof we are now treating) yet we will trace it through the middle Ventricle to the Heart whither it conveys its liquor, for the ame reaon that being to peak of the Stomach, we thought it bet to peak of the Gullet, which is an appendage to it, and by which the meat decends into it.

This Duct then having pat the Midriff,Ductus chyliferu • thoracicus. it marches further upward under the great Artery till about the fifth or ixth vertebra of the Thorax, where it turns a little aide from under the great Artery to the left hand; and o below the intercotal Arteries and Veins, under the Pleura and gland Thymus, it acends to the left ubclavian Vein, into whoe lower ide it opens, jut there where the left Jugular Vein enters into it on the upper ide, o that their Mouths face one another. But it opens not into this Vein with any large orifice, but by ix or even little ones, being all cover'd together in the interior Cavity of the Subclavia with one broad valve, looking towards the Cava from the Shoulder, whereby there is granted to the Chyle and Lympha a free paage out of the ductus Chyliferus into the Subclavia, but their return (or of Bloud with them) out of the Vein into the Duct is prevented. This Duct ending thus
in the ubclavian Vein, the Chyle that it conveys into it paes with the Bloud (returning by the Cava) into the right ventricle of the Heart, where we will leave it, and return to the Venae lacteae again; having only oberved, that this Duct has many Valves that hinder the acending Chyle and Lympha from returning down again which Valves are manifet by this, that the Chyle contained in the Duct may eaily by the inger be preed upwards, but by no means downwards; or if one make a hole in it, the liquor tending from beneath upwards will flow out at it, but that which is above it, is o topt by the Valves, that it cannot be made to decend by it. And now for the Venae lacteae of the Meentery.
They differ from the ordinary mearaical Veins,The difference between the Venae lacteae and the ordinary mearaical Veins.

Firt, in bignes; for thee are bigger, but thoe are more in number; for they are more than twice as many: for more Chylus mut pas by them, the way that has been poken, to make Bloud of, for the nourihment of the whole Body, than there can be Bloud remaining from the nourihment of the Intetins only to return by the Mearaicks to the Liver.

Secondly, they differ in colour, by reaon of the great difference in colour of their contained liquors. The Lacteals are white and limpid by reaon of the whitenes and clearnes of the Chyle which they contain; but the anguinary Veins are of a dusky blackih colour.
Thirdly, they differ in their inertion; for the Lacteals, as has been aid, are inerted into the great gland of the Meentery called Pancreas, but the Mearaicks all terminate in the Liver.

They have a pretty many Valves, but not o
many as the ductus Thoracicus. Their Valves. They may be dicover'd the ame ways as we intimated thoe of the Ductus might; viz. that if they be preed towards the great Gland, they are preently emptied; but if one pres them from the Gland towards the Intetins, the Chyle will top and cannot be driven thither.

That the Ancients did not find out thee Veins,Why the Ancients did not find thee out. the caue was, either becaue they only diected Beats after they were dead, or after that the Chylus was ditributed, or they did not preently take a view of the Meentery; but made ome tay about the inpection of ome other part.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
Of the Liver.
div.p: THE Liver is eated in the upper and chief place of the Abdomen; Its ituation. namely about a fingers breadth ditance from under the Midriff, in the right Hypochondre, (under the hort Ribs) which, being of a great bulk, it even fills, and reaches from thence towards the left ide, a little beyond the Cartilago eniformis, or pit of the Stomach. Its upper part is convex or round and mooth, the lower ide is hollow, lying on the right ide of the Stomach and Pylorus, &c. Its lower edge reaches below the hort Ribs (in a healthfull Man when he tands upright) and almot to the very Navel.

In Dogs and many other Brutes it is divided into divers Lobes,Lobes. but in Man it is continuous;
only there is a little protuberance in its hollow ide, whereby it is tied to the Caul, which Spigelius called a Lobe, and from him others, but it is improperly called o, and not at all like the Lobes in the Livers of Brutes.

It has three Ligaments (properly o called) which according to Dr. Glion (de Hepate) are thee.Ligaments. The firt is called Supenorium, for it ties up the Liver to the Diaphragm; it is broad, membranous and trong, ariing from the
• eritonaeum, and is not only fixed to the outer membrane of the Liver, but does indeed make it, and decends even into it, and is trongly fatned to the common heath or involucrum of the Vena cava (there where the umbilical Vein is continuous to it.) By this trong inertion it is the more able to bear up the great weight of the Liver.

The econd is the Vena umbilicalis, which after the birth, cloes up and hardens into a Ligament. It is directly oppoite to the former. It paes out of the fiure of the Liver and terminates in the Navel. By this the Liver is kept from acending upon the motion of the Diaphragm upwards in repiration.

The third is that whereby the Liver adheres to the Cartilago eniformis. This is thin and flaccid, but yet trong, broad and doubled, ariing from that Membrane wherewith the Liver is encompaed, (according to Spigelius) of which it is a duplicature (according to Dr. Glion.) This hinders it from fluctuating to one or t'other ide, or towards the Back.

Beides thee three Ligaments, it has everal other connexions to the neighbouring parts, but they would improperly be called Ligaments.
Thus it is connected to the Vena cava, and Porta, to the Caul, and to everal other parts either mediately or immediately.

It is covered with a very thin Membrane,Its Membrane. which pringeth from the firt Ligament, (as was aid before) which cleaveth firmly to the ubtance of the Liver. If it be eparate at any time by a watrih humour, iuing out of the capillary Lymphaticks, watrih Putules, by the Graecians called
< in non-Latin alphabet > , are ingendered. If thee break, the water falleth into the cavity of the Belly, and caueth that kind of Dropie called Acites.

Its ubtance or Parenchyma is red and oft,Subtance. almot like concreted bloud, and may, when it is boiled, be eaily crap'd or bruht off the veels. But though its Parenchyma look red, that is only from the great quantity of bloud that is poured into it from the Vena portae: for its proper colour is pale, a little yellowih, uch as the Liver is of when 'tis boil'd; and yet that yellowihnes eems to be caued by the Bile paing through it; o that Malpighius thinks white to be its proper colour, and gives a far different account of its Parenchyma from others, whoe obervations by the Microcope Diemerbroeck thus repreents (out of Malpig. lib. de Hepate, cap. 2.) That 1. The ubtance of the Liver in Man is framed of Lobules, and thee are compounded of little Glands like the tones of Raiins, which look like bunches of Grapes, and are cloathed with a proper circumambient Membrane—2. That the whole bulk of the Liver conits of thee little grape-tone-like Glands and divers orts of Veels; and hence, that they may perform together a common work, it is neceary that
there be a commerce betwixt thee Glands and Veels. 3. That the little branches of the veels of the Porta, Cava, and Porus bilarius, do run through all even the leat Lobules in an equal number; that the branches of the Porta do the office of Arteries, and that the Porta has o great ociety with the Porus bilarius, that both their twigs are traitly tied together in the ame cover. 4. That the hoots of the aid Veels are not joyned by Anatomoes, but that the grape-tone-like Glandules, making the chief ubtance of the Liver, are a medium between the importing and exporting Veels, o that by the interpoition of thee, the importers transfue their liquor into the exporters. From thee obervations he concludes the Liver to be a conglomerate Gland, eparating the Bile—and becaue it is uual for the conglomerate Glands to have, beides Arteries, Veins and Nerves, a proper excretory Veel (as in the Pancreas, &c.) dipered through their ubtance, and drawing out and carrying away the humour deigned for them, this kind of Veel in the Liver is the Porus bilarius with the Gall-bladder.] And this is a very probable account of it.

It hath two orts of Veins.Veins. In its upper part the Vena cava entreth into it, and preads it elf all through it in the lower as well as upper part. Into the lower ide the Vena porta is inerted, whoe branches likewie run through its whole Parenchyma. Of both thee Veins more fully in the two following Chapters.

It has but very mall and few Arteries,Arteries. for the Porta erves it for an Artery, bringing bloud to
it. Thoe which it has, do all arie from the right branch of the Arteria coeliaca, (called hepatica) there where it is joyned to the Vena portae, whence being utained by the coat of the Caul it acends to the hollow of the Liver jut by the Porta, on whoe coat, with the bilary Veels, and the membrane of the Liver, it is wholly pent. For as was aid, the Parenchyma is nourihed by the bloud brought by the Porta.

It has Nerves from the Intercotal pair,Nerves. namely one from the tomachical branch thereof, another from the meenterical (called hepaticus.) But the Nerves are extended only to the Membrane and veels of the Liver, (as the Arteries were) o that the Parenchyma has but a very dull ene.

Till the ductus Thoracicus Chyliferus was found out,Lympheducts. it was till believed that the Venae lacteae were inerted into the Liver, which was looked upon as the great organ of anguification; but now 'tis known for certain that no Lacteae at all go to the Liver, but that thoe veels which were taken for uch, are Lymphatick veels carrying from it a mot lympid and pellucid juice. That they are dipered in the Parenchyma of the Liver, has not yet been oberved; but it is very probable that they arie from its Glands, and coming out of its hollow or lower ide, with the Porta, they encompas it round as alo the ductus Communis, paing motly towards the Meentery; and under the Vena cava near the Pancreas (that is knit to the Stomach and Duodenum) a great many do pas over a certain Gland (ometimes two or three) lying under the Vena porta and often adhering to it, and from thence with many others paed by the Gland, they open themelves into
the receptaculum Chyli. That thee veels bring nothing to the Liver, and o cannot be Lacteals, is apparent; for if in a Live-creature you make a Ligature betwixt the Stomach and Liver, in that part of the Meentery that knits the Liver to the Stomach and Intetins (in which Ligature let the Vena portae and ductus Communis be comprehended) thee veels will preently well betwixt the Ligature and the Liver, but be empty on that ide towards the receptaculum Chyli; and the ame is evident from their Valves alo which open towards the aid Receptacle, but hinder any thing from coming back from thence to the Liver.
Concerning thee we hall forbear to peak here,The bilary Veels. deigning a particular Chapt. for them, viz. ch. 14.

Hippocrates in lib. 4. de Morb. ays,Whether the Liver anguifie. The fountain of bloud is the Heart, the place of Choler is in the Liver; This comes very near the truth, as hall appear hereafter. But from Galen downwards it was generally held that the Mearaick Veins received the Chyle from the Guts and brought it to the Liver, where it was turned into Bloud, and carried from thence into all the parts of the Body by the Veins. Yea and after the Venae lacteae were found out, they would needs have them to terminate in it, thinking it the ittet Bowel for anguification, and preuming that that task mut be performed by ome or other. It would be needles here to tand to confute thee opinions, now that all the world is convinc'd of their fality, and by what hath been already aid they may ufficiently appear to be erroneous, no Chyle at all coming to the Liver. How and where anguification is performed, we hall hew when we come to the Heart, and here we hall declare the true ue of the Liver.

The Liver then being dicharged from anguification,The action of the Liver. it erves to eparate the Bile from the Bloud brought plentifully to it by the Vena portae. Concerning the nature of this Bile there have been divers opinions. The Ancients (amongt whom was Aritotle) thought it to be a meer excrement, and to be of no other ue than by its acrimony to promote the excretion of the Guts. And this opinion prevail'd o long as it was believ'd that the Liver had a nobler action than to trancolate this Choler. But now it being found out that it has no other office, it is believ'd that o bulky a Bowel was never made for the eparation of a meer excrement, and therefore they think it to be a ferment for the Chyle and Bloud, whereby if they were not attenuated and prepared, they could not be enpirited in the Heart. This new doctrine I hall give entirely out of Diemerbroeck, p. 154. The venous Bloud flowing into the Liver by the Porta out of the Gatrick and Mearaick veins (and may be a little by the Hepatick artery) is mixed with an acrimonious, altih and ubacid juice, made in the pleen of the arterious bloud flowing thither by the Arteries, and of the animal pirits by the Nerves, which is brought into the Porta by the ramus Splenicus. Now both thee being entred the Liver by the branches of the Porta, by means of this aid acrimonious and acid juice, and the pecifick virtue or coction of the Liver, the pirituous particles, both ulphureous and alt, lying hid in the aid venous bloud, are diolved, attenuated, and become alo a little acrimonious and fermenting; a certain thinnet part whereof, like mot clear water, being
eparated from the other thicker mas of the Bloud by means of the conglobated Glands, plac'd motly in the hollow ide of the Liver, is carried from thence by many Lympheducts, as has been aid. But the fermentaceous pirits of greater acrimony, mixed with the thicker and more vicid ulphureous juices (for Sulphur is vicid) and more trongly boiling, whenas through the clammines of the juices in which they inhere, they cannot enter the conglobated Glands nor from them the Lympheducts, and through their fierce ebullition are eparated from the Bloud (as Yet from Beer) thee fermentaceous pirits I ay being ever'd with the juice in which they inhere, become bitter and are called Bile. Which Bile being trancolated through the grape-tone-like Glandules into the roots of the porus Bilarius and of the Gallbladder, paes through them by the ductus Communis into the Duodenum or Jejunum, wher •
it is preently mixed with the pancreatick juice, and both of them with the alimentary mas concocted in the Stomach, and now paing down this way, which it caues to ferment. And becaue at its firt entrance it is more acrimonious, and has its virtue entire, and o caues the greatet • bullition with the pancreatick juice, hence the milky juice contained in the mas concocted in the Stomach, is mot readily and in greatet quantity eparated in the Jejunum, and by innumerable Lacteal veels, (which are more numerous in this than the other Guts) it is mot quickly driven on towards the receptaculum Chyli, and this is the reaon that this Gut is always o empty. But in the following Guts
becaue the fermentaceous pirits are a little pall'd, the effervecency becomes lower and les efficacious, and the Chyle is more lowly eparated from the thicker mas, and therefore they have fewer Venae lacteae. At length what remains of this fermenting matter is mixed with the thick faeces in the thick Guts, where by its acrimony it irritates them to excretion.] Thus far that perpicacious and judicious Anatomit. And this I think is the bet account hereof that has been given.

div.head: CHAP. XII.
Of the Vena portae.
div.p: THough it be the method of Anatomits uually to deliver the doctrine of all the Veins in a ditinct Chapter or Book after the decription of the three Ventricles; yet eeing all the Veins eem (and by the Galenits have been affirmed) to have their root in the Liver, of which therefore we cannot but take notice; on this account we will alo decribe their branchings within the Abdomen, eeing they are parts contained in it. And we will begin with the Vena portae.

It is o called from the two eminences (called by Hippocrates
< in non-Latin alphabet > ,Its name. Portae, Gates) betwixt which it enters into the lower ide of the Liver.

Some think that the Vena umbilicalis ought to be accounted its root or original,Origine. becaue it is firt formed in the Foetus and inerted into the Porta. But this umbilical Vein after the birth ceaing
from the office of a Vein, and degenerating into a Ligament, though it might be accounted its root then, it cannot properly now. Others think, that becaue its branches every where inerted into the Intetins bring bloud from thence to the Liver, (and not vice vera) therefore thoe ought rather to be accounted its roots, and its diviions within the Liver its branches. And indeed trictly and properly they ought to be accounted o, but however we hall not think it aburd to peak with the Ancients, who becaue they thought the Porta carried bloud from the Liver to the Guts for their nourihment, uppos'd the Liver to be its root.

As it enters into the Liver, it is inveted with another Coat, which ome call Vagina portae, its Sheath, others Capula, its Cae, and Capula communis becaue the Porus bilarius is involved in it as well as the Porta. This outer Coat it has from the membrane of the Liver, (as that is from the Peritonaeum) that is, it is continued from it, though it be of a clear other ubtance, namely more dene and carnous. It is inveted with it in all its ramifications, and o having a double Coat is in that repect an Artery, as alo in that it brings bloud to the Liver for its nourihment as well as for other ues; and latly in that by means of the Arteria hepatica inerted into the Capula it has an obcure pulation (according to Doctor Glion.)

When it is enter'd about half an inch into the Liver,Branchings in the Liver. it is carried partly to the right hand, partly to the left, and o is hap'd into a Sinus as it were, and thence is divided into five large branches, four whereof are diffu'd all over the hollow ide of the Liver, but the fifth acends
treight to its upper ide where it diperes it elf. And the aid Sinus is more conpicuous in an Embryo, becaue the great influx of nutritious juice out of the Umbilical vein enlarges it much. Moreover in an Embryo you may eaily ee the Tubulus or Canalis venous paing directly out of this Sinus into the Cava (almot oppoite to the mouth of the Umbilical vein.) This Canalis or Pipe is of the ame ubtance and texture with a Vein, and enters into the Cava jut where it is knit to the Diaphragm; and there alo two other great branches out of the Liver are inerted into the Cava; and in the ame place this Pipe is alo knit to the upenory Ligament poken of before, and after the Child is born grows it elf into a Ligament, being in a manner oppoite to the umbilical Ligament. But to return to the diviions of the Porta. The Ancients taught that they were only pread in the imous or hollow part of the Liver, but Dr. Glion in his accurate Anatomy of it, affirms the Porta to be dipered very equally in all its parts, upper as well as lower. And whereas it has been a contant doctrine, that the branches of the Porta open by anatomoes into thoe of the Cava, the ame learned Author, and many others ince him, have oberved that there are no uch anatomoes at all, but that the bloud doth ouze through the glandulous Parenchyma of the Liver out of the Capillary veins of the Porta into thoe of the Cava. He that would be fullier informed hereof, may conult his mot accurate Book de Hepate. But we will now pas to the branches of the Porta gone out of the Liver.

This Trunk parting a little from the Liver,Its branches without the Liver. before it be evered into branches, puts forth
two twigs, out of its upper and fore-part, which are inerted into the Cytis fellea or Gall-bladder (and are from thence called Cyticae gemellae) about the neck of it, and pread by innumerable twigs, through the external coat of it.

A third twig alo that is bigger, but lower, pringeth from this ame fore-part, yet towards the right ide, and is inerted into the bottom of the Stomach: from hence it endeth many prigs toward the hinder-part of it, towards the Back. This is called Gatrica dextra.

Having ent forth thee three twigs, the Trunk paeth down, and bending a little towards the left ide, it is parted into two remarkable branches; whereof the one is called initer, or the left, eated above the right, but is the leer: the other is dexter, or the right, lower than the left, yet larger. The left is betowed upon the Stomach, the Omentum, a part of Colon, and the Spleen; the right is pread through the Guts, and the Meenterium: the left is called Vena plenica; but the right Vena meenterica.

The Vena plenica hath two branches before it come to the Spleen,Vena ple
• ica. the uperiour and the inferiour.

The uperiour is called Gatrica, or Ventricularis. This is betowed upon the Stomach; the middle twig compaing the left part of its orifice like a garland, is called Coronaria. From the inferiour branch two twigs do pring; The one is mall, and ends twigs to the right ide of the lower membrane of the Omentum, and to the Colon annexed to it. This is called Epiplois, or Omentalis dextra. The other is pent upon the lower membrane of the Omentum which tieth the
Colon to the Back, and upon that part of the Colon; it is called Epiplois, or Omentalis potica.

When the Ramus plenicus hath jut approached to the Spleen, it doth end out two other twigs, the uppermot and the lowermot. The uppermot is called vas breve, and is implanted into the left part of the bottom of the Stomach.

This Vein the Ancients believed to carry an acid juice from the Spleen to the Stomach to tir up appetite and to help the fermentation of the meat; but it is certain both by Ligature (whereby it filleth towards the Stomach and emptieth towards the Spleen) and alo by the general nature of Veins, whoe maller branches and twigs till receive the uperfluous arterial bloud from the part whereinto they are inerted, into the larger chanels, and conduct it towards the Heart; I ay it is certain from hence, that this ame vas breve carries nothing to the Stomach, but only brings from thence into the Ramus plenicus the remains of the arterial bloud.
From the lowermot two Twigs iue.
The firt is called Gatroepiplois initra; this is betowed upon the left part of the bottom of the Stomach, and the upper and left part of the Omentum.

The econd pringeth mot commonly from Ramus plenicus, but ometime from the left Meenterick vein; and paing along according to the length of the Intetinum rectum, it is inerted into the Anus, by many twigs. This is called Haemorrhoidalis interna, as that which pringeth from the Vena cava is called Haemorrhoidalis externa.
Now followeth Vena meenterica, Vena meenterica. or the right branch of Vena portae. Before it be divided into branches, it endeth forth two twigs.
The firt is called Gatroepiplois dextra; this is betowed upon the right part of the bottom of the Stomach, and the upper Membrane of the Caul.

The econd is called Intetinalis, or Duodena: It is inerted into the middle of the Duodenum, and the beginning of the Jejunum, and paeth according to the length of them: whence ome capillary twigs go to the Pancreas and the upper part of the Omentum.

After thee twigs are pat from it, it enters by one trunk into the Meentery, where preently it is divided into two branches, to wit Meenterica dextra, & initra. Meenterica dextra, placed in the right ide, is double, and endeth a number of branches to the Jejunum, Caecum, and the right part of the Colon, which is next to the right Kidney and to the Liver.

It hath fourteen remarkable though nameles branches; but innumerable mall twigs. One thing is to be noted, that the greater branches are upported by the greater Glandules, and the maller by the maller Glandules, though they enter not into them, for the Glands wait on the Venae lacteae.
Meenterica initra paeth through the middle of the Meenterium, to that part of Colon which paeth from the left part of the Stomach, and to the Intetinum rectum.

The ue of the Porta hath been held till of late to be for the carrying nourihment to the Intetins and other parts contained in the Abdomen, Its ue. and alo to bring back from the Guts the purer part of the Chyle to the Liver to make Bloud of, and a thicker feculent part of it to the Spleen, to be by it excocted into an acid juice, and then carried
to the Stomach by the vas breve venoum for the exciting of hunger. As for this lat opinion, it appears by Ligature that the vas breve carries its contents from the Stomach to the Ductus plenicus, and it is nothing but the Bloud remaining from the nutrition of the Stomach (that was brought thither by the Arteries) that is now a conveying back to the Liver and o to the Heart again in its circulation. And as for the Mearaicks carrying nourihment to the Guts, or bringing back Chyle, thoe errours have been ufficiently laid open before in the Chapters of the Venae lacteae and the Liver. And their true ue is only to bring back to the Liver from the Guts that Bloud which remains after their nutrition, and which was carried to them by the mearaick Arteries.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.
Of the Vena cava dipered within the Abdomen.
div.p: THE Vena cava is o called from its large Cavity,Its name. being the mot capacious of any Vein of the whole Body; for into it as into a River or Chanel do all the other Veins like Rivulets (excepting the Pulmonaria) empty themelves. Both within and without the Liver it hath but a ingle Coat.

Its root may very properly be aid to be in the Liver;Its rie. for by its Capillaries it receives the Bloud that is trancolated through the Parenchyma of the Liver from the Capillaries of the Porta,
and by its acending trunk conveys it to the Heart. Now thee roots may in ome regard be commodiouly enough alo called branches; for the roots of a Tree in the Earth, as well as its boughs in the Air are pread into many branches: only there is this difference, that roots bring juice to the trunk, but boughs carry it from the ame. However we hall call them indifferently roots or branches. The capillary branches then of the Cava are pread through the whole ubtance of the Liver, and not its upper or gibbous part only, as has formerly been taught; even as we aid before that the Capillaries of the Porta were indifferently dipers'd all over it. Betwixt thee Capillaries (much les betwixt their larger branches) there are no inoculations or anatomoes, but thoe of the Porta being quite obliterated in the glandulous Parenchyma of the Liver, thee of the Cava arie out of the ame, and whiles they pas towards the Cava many of them meeting together make a twig, as many twigs in like manner concurring make a branch, which till proceeding further by the acceion of new twigs and branches encreaeth its chanel, untill at length it dichargeth it elf into the Cava. And thus do all the roots of the Cava in the Liver. Wherein they do not all meet together in one common trunk as thoe of the Porta do, but empty themelves apart into the Cava without the Liver. And till the further ditance the Capillaries have their origine from the Cava, the larger their chanel comes to be at their arrival towards it. The maller twigs are innumerable; the larger roots joyning immediately to the Cava are commonly but three, though
two of them are preently (towards the Liver) divided into other two, as large each as themelves, o that one may account them to be five. Thee emptying all the Bloud exhauted out of the Liver into the Cava, it is preently divided into the Acending and Decending trunk. The Acending forthwith enters the Diaphragm and marches up the Thorax, where we hall leave it till we come thither, and only here peak of the Decending trunk as long as it continues in the Abdomen.

The Decending trunk is omewhat narrower than the Acending,Its dece •
ding tru • k. and paing down along with the great Artery it continues undivided till the fourth vertebra of the Loins. But in the mean time it ends forth divers lips from its trunk. As
1. The Venae adipoae, for the Coat and fat of the Kidneys; that on the left ide goes out firt.
2. The Emulgents, decending to the Kidneys by a hort and oblique paage; thee bring back that bloud to the Cava which the emulgent Arteries carried to the Kidneys with the Serum.
3. The Spermaticks called Vaa praeparantia. The right pringeth from the trunk of Vena cava a little below the Emulgent; but the left from the left Emulgent it elf. Of thee more in the 20th Chapter.
4. The Lumbares, ometimes two, ometimes three, carried to be tween four vertebrae of the Loins.

All thee Veins being ent forth of the trunk, by this time it is come to the fourth vertebra of the Loins, where it goes to behind the Arteria magna, above or before which it had thus far decended,
and is divided into two equal branches, called Iliaci, becaue they pas over the Os ileon, &c. as they go down to the Thighs.

Jut about the diviion there pring two Veins called, Mucula uperior, for the Peritonaeum and Mucles of the Loins and Abdomen; and Sacra, which is ometimes ingle, ometimes double, for the marrow of Os acrum.
Afterwards the Iliacal branches are again divided each into two other, the exteriour that is greater, and the interiour that is les.

From the interiour arie two Veins: Mucula media, for the Mucles of the Hip and Buttocks; and Hypogatrica, which is a notable one, ometimes double, for mot parts of the Hypogatrium, as the Mucles of the treight Gut, which are the external Hemorrhoidals; for the Bladder and its neck, the Yard, and the lower ide of the Womb and its neck, which lat are the Veins by which the Mentrues were believed to pas, before the circulation of the Bloud was found out; for ince, 'tis known that they pas by the Hypogatrick arteries, and what Bloud is not ent forth at thoe times, or at other times is not pent on the nutrition of the parts, returns by thee Veins to the Cava, and by it to the Heart.
From the exteriour, three: two before it goes out of the Peritonaeum, and one after.

1. Epigatrica, for the Peritonaeum and the Mucles of the Abdomen; the mot noted branch of it acends under the Muculi recti towards the Venae mammariae, with which they have been thought to inoculate about the Navel.
2. Pud • nda, for the Genitals in Men and Women; this goes tranverly to the middle of Os pubis.
3. Mucula inferior, for the Buttocks.
And now the decending branches of the Cava are pat out of the Abdomen into the Thigh, and begin to be called crural; and of them we hall dicoure when we come to the Limbs, in Book 4. cap. 4.

Now the ue of this Decending trunk of the Vena cava is not to carry any thing to any part from the Liver;Its ue. but whereoever its leer twigs end into Capillaries, from thence is Bloud received (being brought thither by the repective Arteries) and conveyed into the greater branches and by them into the trunk of the Cava, by which it acends to the right ventricle of the Heart, there to be anew inpirited, and from thence to be ent forth again by the Arteries, as hall be further explained when we come to the Heart.

For though the Decending trunk of the Aorta or great Artery pas down the Abdomen along with that of the Cava, and o is contained therein as well as it; yet becaue the Arteries have all of them their origine from the Heart, we will forbear to peak of them till we come to the Anatomy of it, in the next Book.

div.head: CHAP. XIV.
Of the Gall-bladder and Porus bilarius.
div.p: FOR the receiving and evacuating of Bile there are two veels or paages framed in the right and hollow ide of the Liver, namely the Gall-bladder, and Porus bilarius. By this latter there flows a thicker but milder, by the former a thinner, more acrimonious and fermentative Choler into the Intetins.

The Gall-bladder,Its name, and decription. called in Greek < in non-Latin alphabet > , in Latine Veica bilaria, or Folliculus fellis, is a hollow Bag placed in the hollow ide of the Liver, and in figure repreenteth a Pear.
It is about two inches in length,Its bignes. and one in breadth.

By its upper part it is tied to the Liver,Its c • nnexion. which doth afford it a hollownes to receive it; but the lower part which hangeth without the Liver, reteth upon the right ide of the Stomach, and the Colon, and doth often dye them both yellow.

It hath two Membranes,Its membranes. the one common, which is thin and exteriour, without Fibres. This pringing from the membrane of the Liver, only covereth that part which hangeth without the Liver. The other Membrane is proper.
This is thick and trong,The fibres of the proper membrane. and hath three orts of Fibres; the outermot are tranvere, the middlemot oblique, and the innermot treight.

Within, it hath a mucous ubtance or crut, engendred of the Excrements of the third concoction
of its Membrane, to withtand the acrimony of the Choler.
It hath two parts,The parts of it. the Neck and the Bottom.
The Neck is harder than the Bottom, and higher in ituation.

It from the bottom by degrees growing narrower and narrower, at lat endeth in the Ductus communis, or the common paage of the Choler, which is inerted into the beginning of the Jejunum, or the end of the Duodenum.
This elongation of the neck of the Veica fellea, is called Meatus cyticus, becaue it pringeth from the Cytis.

The Choler is conveyed into the Veica by many very mall roots,How the choler is brought into it. dipered in the Liver between the branches of the Porta and Cava; they are o very mall that they are carcely dicernible, but when they meet together, they make one pretty notable Trunk which is inerted into the Cytis near its Neck, with a Valve before its Mouth to hinder the regurgitation of the Choler. (For in the Jaundice the Choler does not return out of the Gall-bladder into the Bloud again, but either for want of a convenient ferment it is not eparated from the Bloud, or when the neck of the Veica is topt that none can pas out of it into the Guts, then the Gall-bladder is preently o fill'd that it cannot receive any more; and o the Choler being forc'd to tagnate in its roots, is received in by the branches of the Cava, and thereby contaminates the whole mas of Bloud.) But though it be evident that the Choler is brought into the Veica by this Pipe, yet if one open the Bladder to look for its Mouth in the Cavity, one hall hardly find where it is; which is no wonder,
eeing it is o difficult to find the inertions of the Ureters into the urinary Bladder, which are vatly larger than this. But Dr. Glion ays, that near its neck in the inide, there is a little pongy protuberance, into which this Trunk is pretty plainly inerted; and this protuberancy is the ame that we called before a Valve.

It has been taught by everal Anatomits,Its valves. that its Neck or Meatus has ometimes two, ometimes three Valves to hinder the recoure of the Choler: but Diemerbroeck profees he could never find any, but only that the egres of the Veica was very trait, and its Neck wrinkled. Dr. Glion declares alo that he could never dicover any in it, but on the contrary, he has often with a light compreion of his fingers found, that the Choler will fluctuate to and again, out of the Cytis into the Meatus, and on the contrary, as alo out of the Meatus into the Ductus communis and back again; o that he cannot believe there is any thing of a Valve in the whole paage. But one thing which he thinks has impos'd upon Anatomits, is a certain fibrous Ring (or Sphincten as it were) which is eated jut at the end of the Bladder and beginning of its Neck, which makes the paage betwixt them exceeding trait; but this cannot be a Valve, becaue as he oberves the Choler will go either way through it.
The Veica fellea hath two Veins called Cytica gemellae, Its veels. which pring from the Porta.
It hath prigs of Arteries proceeding from the right branch of the Coeliaca. And it hath a mall thread-like prig of a Nerve from the Meenterical branch of the Intercotal.
Many times tones are found in it,Of the tones in it. which being lighter and more pongy than thoe of the Bladder will wim above water.
The other paage which carrieth the thicker ort of Choler,Porus bilarius. is called Porus bilarius, or Meatus hepaticus, becaue it paeth directly from the Liver to the Ductus communis.

Within the Liver its Trunk and Branches are inveted with a double coat; its proper one, which it retains without the Liver alo, and another that is common to it with the Porta called Capula communis, which it has from the membrane of the Liver. In this common coat this Porus and the Porta are o cloely enwrapped that you would take them but for one Veel, till you either hold it up to the light, (which will dicover Veels of two colours in it) or very dextrouly rip up the Capula, and o lay them open. Its roots within the Liver are equally divided with thoe of the Porta every where, aving that little pace where the roots of the Veica are pread, in the imous and right ide of the Liver. So that having poken above of the diviions of the roots of the Porta, I hall refer the Reader thither for thee of the Porus. I hall only oberve that they are far larger and more numerous than thoe of the Veica, drawing Choler from all the parts of the Liver (aving whither the roots of the Bladder reach) and that more thick and vicous, yet les acrimonious.

This Porus eems to be a more neceary part than the Veica; for many Creatures, as Harts, Fallow-deer, the Sea-calf, &c. and thoe which have a whole Hoof, have no Gall-bladder, but there is none that is detitute of this.

Without the Liver it is as wide again as the Meatus cyticus, with which it is joyned at two inches ditance from the Liver, and both make the Ductus communis choledochus. It has no Valve in its whole progres; only the Ductus communis, where it enters the Intetin, having pierced the outer coat, paes betwixt that and the middlemot about the twelfth part of an inch, and then piercing that alo marches down further betwixt it and the innermot coat about half an inch, and at lat opens with a round mouth into the Intetin. So that this oblique inertion (as that of the Ureter into the urinary Bladder) erves intead of a Valve to hinder any thing from regurgitating out of the Gut into this Duct, epecially the inmot Tunicle of the Intetin hanging o flaggy before its mouth, that when any thing would enter in, it claps cloe upon it and tops it.

As to any anatomoes of the roots of either of thee Bilary veels with thoe of the Vena portae, uch indeed have been much talkt of, but without truth, for their extream Twigs or Capillaries terminate in the Parenchyma of the Liver, out of whoe grape-tone-like Glandules they imbibe the Choler there eparated from the Bloud; even as was aid before of the Capillaries of the Cava, that they received the Bloud it elf imported by the Porta, in like manner, without any inoculations.

The ue of both thee Veels may ufficiently be learned by what has already been aid of them.Their ue. As alo may the ue of the Bile it elf from what we quoted above out of Diemerbroeck, when we were treating of the action of the Liver, chap. 12. We will only further note two things.

Firt, that ometimes the Ductus communis is very irregularly inerted. For in ome it is knit to the bottom of the Stomach, and then the party vomiteth Choler, and is termed < in non-Latin alphabet > ; and ometimes it is inerted into the lower end of the Jejunum, and then bilious dejections follow: and uch a one is termed < in non-Latin alphabet > .

A econd thing is concerning the colour of the Bile; that though for the mot part, (in a healthfull tate) it be yellow, yet preternaturally and in a morbous tate it is often of everal other colours, as pale-coloured, eruginous, porraceous, vitelline, reddih and blackih. And when it thus degenerates and corrupts, it is the caue of mot violent and acute Dieaes; as the Cholera morbus, Dyentery, Colick, &c.

div.head: CHAP. XV.
Of the Pancreas.
div.p: THE Pancreas (as much as to ay All-fleh) or the Sweet-bread,Its ubtance. except its Membranes and Veels, is wholly Glandulous. It eems to be compacted out of many globules or knots included in a common Membrane, and joyn'd together by the Membranes and Veels. Every Globule by it elf is omewhat hard; but all together (becaue of their looe connexion) eem oftih. It is of a palih colour, very little tinctured with red. Its Membrane it has from the Peritonaeum.

It is eated under the bottom and hind-part of the Stomach,Situation. and reaches from the Cavity of the Liver (namely from that part where the Porta enters it) to the Spleen, cros the Abdom • n. It is knit alo to the Duodenum, (ometimes to the) Porus bilarius, the Rami plenici, the Caul, the upper part of the Meentery, and upper Nervous plexus of the Meentery. It is not joyned to the Spleen.
Its figure is long and flat,Figure. broader and thicker about the Duodenum, but towards the Spleen thinner and traiter.

It is leer than mot of the Bowels,Bignes. but by much the greatet Gland in the Body, commonly about five fingers breadth long; where it is broadet, it is about two fingers breadth; and about one fingers breadth thick.

Its Veels are of five kinds.Veels. Veins it has from the plenick branch; Arteries from the left branch of the Coeliaca, ometimes from the plenick; Nerves from the Intercotal pair, epecially from the upper plexus of the Abdomen; it has alo many Vaa lymphatica, which, as the ret, pas to the Receptaculum chyli. But beides thee Veels which are common to it with other parts, it has a proper membranous Duct of its own, which was firt found out by Wirtungus at Padua
• ight or nine and thirty years agoe. This Veel commonly has but one Trunk, whoe orifice opens into the lower end of the Duodenum or beginning of the Je • unum, and ometimes is joyned to the Ductus bilarius with which it makes but one mouth into the Intetin. Within the Pancreas (according to Dr. Wharton) it is divided into two Branches, which end forth abundance of
little Twigs into all the Globuli above poken of, by whoe means they receive the humours from all over the Pancreas, and by their Trunk tranmit them to the Guts. This pancreatick humour tho' is never found in this Duct, becaue it o quickly flows out into the Duodenum by a teep way; even jut as Urine, paing out of the Reins by the Ureters to the Bladder, is never found in them becaue of its rapid tranit.

Very many have been the differences of opinions concerning the ue of this Glandule.Office. Some have thought it to be only of ue to utain the diviions of the Veels, and to erve the Stomach for a Cuhion; others that it miniters a ferment to the Stomach; others that it receives the Chyle, and brings it to greater perfection; and others that it erves as a Gall-bladder to the Spleen, or ometimes erves in its tead. Which opinions being all very unlikely, I hall not pend time to examine them. There are two other opinions, for the former whereof let the credit of the learned Author (viz. Dr. Wharton) recommend it as it can, but to me it eems improbable, and it is this, That it receives the excrements or uperfluities of the uperiour plexus of the Nerves of the ixth pair (Dr. Willis's Intercotal) being united with ome branches from the pinal marrow, and by its proper Veel or Duct dicharges them into the Intetins. In anwer unto which I hall only ay this, That I cannot tell how thick Excrements hould be convey'd by the Nerves that carry uch pure animal pirits, and have no viible Cavity; nor econdly how thee Nerves in particular hould electivè (as he peak) end the Excrements hither, and all the
ret be dicharged from any uch Office. The lat opinion, and to me the mot probable, is defended by famous Phyicians and Anatomits, as Franc. Sylvius, Bern. Swalve, Regn. de Graef and Isbrand de Diemerbroeck, from which lat I hall trancribe it. I have found, aith he, in the diections of Brutes both alive, and newly trangled, a certain liquor ublimpid and as it were alivous, (omething autere and lightly ubacid, and having ometimes omething of altihnes mixed) to flow out of the Ductus pancreaticus into the Duodenum, ometimes in a pretty quantity. Whence I judged—that there is excocted in the Pancreas a peculiar humour from the erous and altih part of the arterial bloud brought into it, having ome few animal pirits convey'd thither by mall Nerves mixed with it, and that this liquor flowing into the Duodenum, and there preently mixed with the Bile, and the meat concocted in the Stomach gliding by the Pylorus into the Guts, does caue a peculiar effervecency in thoe aliments, whereby the profitable chylous particles are eparated from the unprofitable, are attenuated, and being brought to greater fuion (This operation of it, ays he, is hewn by the diverity of the ubtance of the aliments, concocted in the Stomach and till there contained, from that of thoe that have already flow'd into the Intetins: for the former are vicid and thick, and have the various colours of the food taken; but the latter on the contrary are more fluid, les vicid, and more white) are withall made apt to be impelled by the peritaltick motion of the Guts, through their inner mucous
coat into the Lacteal veels, the other thicker by little and little paing down to the thick Guts, to be there kept till the time of excretion. Now this effervecency is caued through the volatile alt and ulphureous oyl of the Bile meeting with the acidity of the pancreatick juice; as in Chymitry we oberve the like effervecencies to be caued by the concoure of uch things.] Thus he. So that he will not have this juice to be any thing excrementitious, nor to be o very little in quantity as ome have affirmed; to demontrate which he cites the experiment of de Graef, who in livediections could gather ometimes an ounce of it in even or eight hours time, which he has tated, and found it of the tat before-mentioned, viz. omething autere, ubacid and altih. Vide ejus Anatomen corporis humani, p. 73, &c. where you may ee what Dieaes it is the caue of when ditempered.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.
Of the Spleen.
div.p: THE Spleen or Milt in Englih, in Greek is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , and from thence Splen in Latin, and Lien.

The ubtance of it is flaggy,Its ubtance. looe and pongeous, commonly held to be a concrete anguineous body, erving to utain the veels that pas through it: but Malpighius with his Microcope
cope has dicover'd it to be a Congeries of Membranes form'd and ditinguih'd into cells like Honey-combs. And in thee cells there are very many Glands. He decribes them thus (lib. de Liene cap. 5.) In the Spleen, ays he, there may be oberved numerous bunches of Glands, or if you will, of Bladders or little Bags dipered all over it, which do exactly reemble a bunch of Grapes. Thee little Glands have an oval figure, and are about as big as thoe of the Kidneys: I never aw them of other colour than white; and though the Bloud-veels of the Spleen be fill'd with ink, and play about them, yet they always keep the ame colour. Their ubtance is membranous as it were, but oft and eaily crumbled; their Cavity is o mall that it cannot be een, but it may be gueed, in that when they are cut they eem to fall into themelves. They are almot innumerable, and are placed wonderfully in the aforeaid cells of the whole Spleen, where vulgarly its Parenchyma is aid to be; and they hang upon fibres ariing from their cae, and conequently on the utmot ends of the Veins and Arteries, yea the ends of the Arteries twit about them like the Tendrils of Vines, or clinging Ivy.—Each bunch conits of even or eight.] Thus he. It has abundance of nervous Fibres.

It is commonly but one in Men,Number. though ome have found two, yea Fallopius three. In Dogs there are ometimes two or three, unequal in bignes, out of each of which there paes a veel into the Ramus plenicus.

It is covered with a Membrane borrowed from the Peritonaeum, Membrane. which is thicker than that of the
Liver. Firt, becaue the Spleen hath a looer ubtance. Secondly, becaue it hath more Arteries, which require a trong Membrane to utain their beatings. Diemerbroeck ays, it has two Membranes; one from the Peritonaeum which is outer and common; the other inner and proper, ariing from the outer Membrane of the veels entring the Spleen, interwoven with a wonderfull texture of Fibres; and that betwixt thee two the Vaa lymphatica, of which afterwards.
In Infants new born it is of a red colour;Colour. in thoe of a ripe age it is omewhat blackih; and in old Men it is of a leaden or livid colour. Being boiled it looks like the dregs of Claret.

In Man it is bigger,Bignes. thicker and heavier than in Beats; for it is ix inches in length, three in breadth, and one in thicknes. Sometimes it is much larger, but the bigger the wore. Spigelius has oberved that it is larger in thoe that live in fenny places, than in thoe that live in dry; and in thoe that have large Veins, than in them that have mall.

In figure it is omewhat long,Figure. like an Oxe's Tongue. Towards the Stomach on its inner ide it is omewhat hollow; on its outer, gibbous, having ometimes ome impreion upon it from the Ribs. It is mooth and equal on either ide, ave where in its hollow ide it has a treight line or eam ( < in non-Latin alphabet > ) at which place the plenick Veels enter into it.

It is eated in the left Hypochondrium oppoite to the Liver:Situation. (o Hippocrat. 6. Epidem. calleth it the left Liver; and Aritot. 3. de hitor. animal. 7. the batard Liver) betwixt the Stomach and that
end of the Ribs next the Back; in ome higher, in others lower: but naturally it decends not below the lowet Rib. Yet ometimes its Ligaments are o relaxed, that it reaches down lower, yea ometimes quite break, o that it lips down into the Hypogatrium: o Riolanus tells the tory of a Woman that was troubled with a Tumour there, which was taken by her Phyicians for a Mole, but dying of it, and being opened, it was found to be occaioned by the Spleen fallen out of its place and lying upon the Womb. And as it very much endangers life when it falls out of its place, o can it not with afety be quite cut out of the Body, whatever ome have boated of. But none but obcure Men (of no credit) have bragg'd of uch feats; and how can one imagine that a part o difficult to come at, and that has uch large veels inerted into it, (not to mention its ue) could with afety be taken out of the Body? Wounds in it are commonly mortal; inflammation, or but obtructions in it do grievouly afflict the Patient and ometimes kill him: ure then the total ablation of it mut be very fatal. This experiment hath indeed been tried upon Dogs, and ome have liv'd after; but then they have grown penive and lazy, and not liv'd long neither.

It is tied to five parts;Connexion. its upper part to the Midriff, and its lower to the left Kidney by mall Membranes; by its hollow part which giveth way to the Stomach being ditended, to the upper membrane of the Omentum, and to the Stomach by vas breve. In its gibbous or arched part it is tied to the Back, for thither it inclines.

It hath Veels of all kinds;Veels. as 1. Veins from the Ramus plenicus of the Vena portae, 1. Veins. which are dipered throughout its Parenchyma, and come out of its hollow ide in three or more branches, which unite preently into the aboveaid Ramus. The aid branches at their coming out of the Spleen have each one a Valve which look from the Spleen outwards, permitting the humours to flow from the Spleen to the Ramus plenicus, but hindering them from returning back. And though one cannot dicover any anatomoes of the Veins with the Arteries in the ubtance of the Spleen (the Bloud paing out of one into the other in like manner as in the Liver, namely through and by help of the Glands) yet there is one notable one of the Splenick artery with this Ramus plenicus before it enter the Spleen. Whoe ue mut be, partly to further the motion of the humours contained in the Ramus towards the Liver, partly that the uperfluous plenty of Bloud, which perhaps cannot pas quick enough through the narrow paages of the Spleen, may return back again by help of this anatomois, through the Ramus to the Liver. There is alo another Vein called vas breve, which ariing out of the bottom of the Stomach is inerted into the Ramus jut as it comes out of the Spleen or a little after. The errour of the Ancients as to the ue of this Veel was detected before, chap. 12. and its true ue declared.

It hath two Arteries,2. Arteries. entring one at its upper, the other at its lower part. Thee commonly pring from the left Coeliack branch, which is called the Splenick artery; but ometimes (aith Diemerbroeck) from a certain branch ariing out
of the very trunk of the Aorta, and proceeding by a bending Duct along the ide of the Pancreas to the Spleen, where they are branched into a thouand Twigs. By thee Arteries the Bloud flows to it, where if it have not a free paage into the roots of the Veins and into the Ramus plenicus, it caueth a great pulation, o high that as Tulpius relateth (lib. 2. obervat. 28.) it has been heard by thoe that have tood 30 foot off.

Nerves it hath from one of the meenterical branches of the Intercotal pair,3. Nerves. which are not all pent on its inveting Membrane (as has been thought) but ome enter into its ubtance, which yet has a very dull ene; but that proceeds not from defect of Nerves (for it has a pretty many Twigs) but from that tupor or numbnes which that acid juice that is bred in the Spleen, mut be conceived to induce upon them.

Though Dr. Wharton in his Adenographia, 4. Vaa Lymphatica. cap. 4. going about to prove the Spleen to be no Gland, ues this as one argument, that there were never oberved any Lympheducts to be ditributed through this part; yet Olaus Rudbeck, Fr. Sylvius, Malpighius, Diemerbroeck, &c. affirm it to have many, which ariing from its conglobate Glands pas through the Omentum very plainly into the Receptaculum Chyli. See them expret in the following figure of a Calfs Spleen.

The Ancients knowing neither the true paage of the Chyle, e. nor the circulation of the Bloud, erred groly as to the ue of this part. They thought that it attracted a more feculent and melancholick part of the Chyle, by the Ramus plenicus, which having a little elaborated, it ent it out again partly by the vas breve, and
partly by the internal hemorrhoidal; but it is certain, both that no Chyle, nor indeed Bloud paeth by the Ramus plenicus to the Spleen, as neither any thing from the Spleen by the aboveaid Veels; but whatever they contain comes towards the Spleen, namely into the Ramus, and what is in it goes to the Liver. One need add no further reaon to evince the errour of their opinion; nor that of thoe that would make it a anguifying Bowel. Dr. Glion (in lib. de Hepate, cap. 45. p. 434.) thinks it to make an alimentary juice or at leat a vehicle for it, which being firt imbib'd by its nervous Fibres is from them received into the Nerves, by which it is firt carried to the Glandulae renales; where being refin'd it is received again by the Nerves, and is carried to the Brain and Spinal marrow, and from thence by the Nerves again into all the parts of the Body. We will not here enter into a dipute about the nutritious juice of the Nerves; but uppoing it, certainly this eems an odd way of conveying either it or its Vehicle thus to and again by the ame ort of Veels; not to ay that o acid a juice as is excocted in the Spleen, one hould think would be no very welcome guet to the Nerves, nor be uffer'd to march o quietly, epecially paing againt the current of the animal pirits that continually flow from the Brain and Spinal marrow. This opinion therefore we hall pas by as very improbable, having little ele to recommend it ave the credit of its learned Author. And its true ue we believe to be, to make a ubacid and altih juice of the Arterial bloud that flows plentifully into it, which paing by the Ramus plenicus to the Liver erves there to make
(and further the eparation of) the Bile. Now this juice is thus elaborated: There are a great many Glands in the ubtance of the Spleen (which being boil'd tats omething acid.) Into thee Glands is the Arterial bloud poured by the capillary Arteries, wherewith are mixed ome animal pirits depoited into the ame Glandules by the ends of the Nerves, which bridling the ulphureous pirit of the Bloud, induce on it a little acidity; and then being driven out of the Glandules by the beating of the Arteries and the preure of the adjacent parts, it is received by the roots of the Splenick vein, and o by the Ramus plenicus it flows to the Porta and the Liver. But before it enter into the roots of the Veins, it eems to tay a little in the abovementioned Cells, (whoe ubtance is acid) that it may acquire ome more acidity by that tay in them: as Wine tanding in a Vinegar-veel owrs more and more; and as the Bile by taying in the Gall-bladder gets a greater acrimony.

B The Trunk of the Ductus pancreaticus.
CCC Its Branches.
D The Ductus bilarius joyning to the pancreatick Duct.
E The Duodenum opened.
F The inertion of thee Veels.

list.item: A The Spleen of a Calf.
B The Sanguineous and Lymphatick veels tied.
C The Splenick vein.
D The Splenick artery.
E The Splenick nerves, whoe number is uncertain.
F The Lymphatick veels ariing out of the outer part of the Spleen.
ffff The Valves in the aid Veels.
G The Ligature

list.head: Fig. III. Repreents an Oxe's Spleen.
list.item: AA The ubtance of the Spleen cover'd with its proper Coat.
B A portion of the Vena portae.
C Its left or Splenick branch.
D This branch opened near the Spleen that the Valve b. may appear.
EE The Coat of the Spleen diected and turned back, that the progres and plexus of the Veels and Fibres may be hewn the better.
F A portion of the Splenick artery, which running through the whole ubtance of the Spleen, doth dipene into it the little Twigs aaa.
b The Valve in the Splenick branch looking outwards to the Porta.
ccc The holes which appear in the end of Ramus plenicus leading from the ubtance of the Spleen.
ddd Nerves running along the ides of the Splenick Artery.
eee The end of the Ramus plenicus.

div.head: CHAP. XVII.
Of the Kidneys, and the Glandulae renales.
div.p: THE Kidney is called in Latin Ren, Their denomination. from < in non-Latin alphabet > , to flow; becaue the eroity of the Bloud doth flow through the Kidneys to the Ureters, and through them to the Bladder. By the Greeks they are called < in non-Latin alphabet > , mingere, to make water.

They are in number two,Number. both becaue of the great quantity of the erous excrement that is to be dicharged by them; and alo that one being topped, the erum of the Bloud might be trancolated by the other.

They are eated in the Loins behind the Stomach and Intetins,Places. and under the Liver and Spleen, between the membranes of the Peritonaeum; their lower end rets on the head of the Mucle Poas (which is one of the movers of the Thigh) jut where the Nerve enters into it, which is the caue that a big tone being in the Kidney, and preing on the Nerve, a numbnes is felt in the Thigh of the ame ide. In Man the right Kidney is lowet, by reaon of the greatnes of the Liver, and commonly bigger alo than the left; yet it has not o much fat about it as the left, by reaon of the vicinity of the Liver, whoe heat hindereth the encreae of fat.

In figure they reemble the Aarum leaf or Kidney-bean:Figure. towards the Loin or outwards they are gibbous; and alo in their ends on the inide;
but in the midt where the Veels enter in and go out, they are hollow.

As for their connexion,Connexion. by the external fat Membrane they are tied to the Diaphragma, and the Loins; by the emulgent Veels, to the Vena cava, and the Aorta; and by the Ureters to the Bladder. The right hath the Intetinum caecum join'd to it, and ometimes the Liver; the left hath the Spleen and the Colon.

They are in length about five inches,Bignes. reaching as far as three and ometimes four vertebrae; three fingers breadth broad, and one inch thick. In alacious or lutfull Men they are commonly larger than in others.

Their Membranes are two.Membranes. The one is common and external,1. Common. borrowed from the Peritonaeum; within the reduplication of which the whole Kidney is lapped; and therefore it is called Renis facia. This Membrane is bemeared with copious fat; whence it is called Tunica adipoa; and into it entreth the Arteria adipoa from the Aorta; as alo the Vena adipoa, which on the right ide commonly arieth from the Emulgent, eldom from the Cava; but on the left, always from the Cava. By means of this Membrane 'tis that they are both joined to the Loins and Midriff; the right, to the Caecum and ometimes to the Liver; the left, to the Spleen and Colon, as was noted before. Although they be exceeding fat, yet ome part of the Kidney will remain uncovered about the middle.

Their inner and proper Membrane is made of the outer Coat of thoe Veels that enter into them,2. Proper. (for they enter the Kidney with only one Coat) and this adhereth very cloe to them,
having inerted into it mall Nerves from the Intercotal pair, and one from that branch of it which goes alo to the Stomach; whence that conent betwixt the Kidneys and it, that in the pain of the Stone in the Kidneys a vomiting is caued. But thee Nerves enter the ubtance of the Kidneys in very few but by mall lips, whence they have but a dull ene as to their Parenchyma.

The ubtance of the Kidneys,Subtance. as it appears to the bare eye, looks fibrous, compacted of the concoure and commixture of very mall Veels joined together by a flehy Parenchyma that has divers mall chanels; outwardly to feel upon, it is pretty hard, but within, it is indifferent pongie; its circumference is of a dull red colour, but towards the Pelvis it is more pale. Thus the Kidneys appear to the ight; but Malpighius with his Microcope hath made a far more accurate dicovery of their ubtance. He ays (lib. de Renibus) That though in grown Men their uperficies eems commonly plain, yet it is unequal in Infants new born; and that in adult perons the conjunction of Globules does till appear within from the diverity of colour, which in the everal Globules outwardly and towards the ides, to which they are joined, is red, but more pale on the inner ide. And as in Brutes thee Globules being round outwards, and extended inwards into an obtue narrownes become quadrangular, quinquangular or exangular and o are joined together; o alo in Men there may from the diverity of colour be manifetly oberved a like but more firm conjunction. —If one take off the Membrane from a
freh and as yet oft Kidney, there may by a good Microcope be dicovered certain round and hort Bodies roll'd about like little worms, not unlike thoe that are found in the ubtance of the Kidneys being cut through the middle; and under the outmot uperficies one may oberve wonderfull branches of Veels, with their Globules hanging at them, which run towards the Pelvis; as alo certain continued winding paces and inus's running through all the outer uperficies of the Kidneys, that become conpicuous by injecting ink through the emulgent Arteries: and moreover, innumerable mall pipes which look omething like fibrous or parenchymatous fleh, but are indeed membranous and hollow; thee make up a great part of the ubtance of the Kidneys, and are the excretory Veels of the Urine. Moreover he ays, that if (after the Membrane is removed) one make injection into the emulgent Artery with the pirit of Wine tinged black, he may dicern innumerable very mall Glandules hanging upon forked Arteries, which by the injection are alo coloured black; as alo many others in the intertices of the Urinary veels, which hang like Apples upon the Arteries, (now fill'd with the black liquor, and branched like a Tree.) He thinks that from thee Glands into which the extremities of the Arteries end, the roots of the Veins arie, and that the Nerves reach to them too; and that it is probable that the excretory Veels of the Ureter are extended o far alo, eeing this is contant in all Glands, that every little Globule has beides the Arteries and Veins, a proper excretory Veel, as
the Bilary in the Liver, &c. And he has oberved that thoe ame Pipes or Urinary fibres do many of them terminate in one of the Papillae, (twelve into one) through which the Urine is trancolated into the Pelvis, for into it they jet out; and that the ame iphons or urinary Veels are produced from the circumference to thee Papillae as to their c •• ntre.] By this curious and accurate decription of their ubtance he has greatly dipelled that mit of ignorance that Anatomits hitherto were in as to their frame and Parenchyma. But to proceed.

The Emulgent artery, Emulgents. pringing from the decending Trunk of the Aorta goes into the hollow ide of the Kidney,1. Arteries. being firt divided into two; but in the Kidney it is pread in divers branches through its whole ubtance, and ends in it in very mall and inviible Capillaries. By it much bloud is conveyed to the Reins (for it is a great Artery) partly to nourih them and the Urinary veels, partly that in their Glandules a good part of the Serum may be eparated from it, which being carried by the Urinary fibres to the Papillae ouzes through them into the Pelvis.

The Emulgent vein is a little larger than the Artery.2. Veins. Its roots pring from the Glandules in the Kidney, which being united into one Trunk comes out where the Artery goes in, and opens into the Cava, into which it dicharges the Bloud remaining from the nourihment of the Kidney, now freed from a good quantity of Serum in the Glands. For that there paes nothing by this Vein to the Kidney is plain, as from the general office of Veins, which always carry from the part where their Capillaries are pread (excepting
the Vena portae, which indeed has the office of an Artery) o from that notable Valve that is placed at its entrance into the Cava, looking towards it from the Kidney, o that the Bloud may freely pas out of the Emulgent into the Cava, but not back again. The Emulgent vein ometimes comes divided out of the Kidney, as the Artery goes in; but both the branches are preently united into one, and always open by one orifice into the Cava.
Of the Nerves we have poken before, dicouring of the proper Membrane of the Kidneys; and as to Lympheducts there has no certain dicovery been yet made of any in them.

Within the Kidney there is a membranous Cell or Sinus,
The Pelvis. called Pelvis or Infundibulum (i. e. the Baon or Tunnel) which is made of the Ureter expanded and dilated, and comes into the Cavity of the Kidney with eight or ten open and large Pipes. Into this Pelvis does the Serum iue from the Urinary iphons through the Caru • culae Papillares or Mammillares, for one of thee tands at the head of each of the aid eight or ten Pipes, (being of an equal number with them) and are like Glandules, of a fainter colour but harder than the ret of the Parenchyma; they are about as big as a Peae, flattih above, but round or bunching out on that ide next the Pelvis; their perforations are exceeding narrow, o that they will hardly admit the mallet hair.

The action of the Reins is to eparate and evacuate the erous humour from the Bloud,Their action. which, as was aid, is brought to them together with the Bloud by the Emulgent arteries; which is done in this order. After the two branches of the
Emulgent artery are enter'd the Kidneys, they are preently each of them divided into four or five, and thoe again into many more, till at lat they end in the mallet Capillaries which terminate in the Glandules towards the outer uperficies, whereinto they infue their liquor. Into the ame Glandules are inerted alo the Capillary veins, and the Uinary iphons, each of which imbibe thence their proper liquor. By the Veins the Bloud returns into the larger branches of the Emulgent veins, from thence into the ingle Trunk, and by it to the Cava, which conducts it to the Heart: But by the Urinary pipes does the Serum drill to the Papillae or Carunculae placed at the entrance into the Pelvis, through which it ditills into it. And this Pelvis being the head of the Ureter, the Serum glides readily out of it down by the Ureter into the Bladder.

But now it is very difficult to determine whether this eparation of the Serum in the Kidneys be procured by any kind of effervecency or fermentation; or whether they erve meerly as a trainer, through which it is queezed or trancolated. If it be eparated only this lat way, how admirable is the configuration of the Pores, that the Serum with all its contents hould pas by them without the leat drop or tain of bloud, when yet often purulent matter, brought out of the Thorax, and throughly mixed with the Bloud, and which is far thicker than the Bloud it elf, paes through them with the Serum, and not any thing of Bloud at the ame time! That uch purulent matter paes by Urine, is frequently oberved; but whether it be aborbed out of the Cavity of the Thorax by the mouths of the Veins
gaping into it, as the Ancients thought it might; or it be bred in the Parenchyma of the Lungs apotemating, as is more probable, 'tis not a fit place here to inquire. As neither would it ignifie much to give you the conjectures of ome learned Men, that becaue uch Pus, and much more becaue Pins, Needles, an Iron nail, &c. have paed by Urine; that therefore there mut be ome more direct and patent way for part of the Serum to be convey'd by to the Bladder; and therefore have imagined that ome Lacteals have been inerted into the Bladder, as others have uppoed other ways: for as far as could ever be dicover'd by Anatomits, there is no foottep of any uch paage, how plauible oever uch an Hypotheis may eem. And therefore we hall ay no further of it.

Some have thought the Kidneys to have other Actions beides the eparating of the Serum; as further to elaborate the Bloud, to prepare the Seed, &c. But thee opinions are grown obolete, and therefore rather to be neglected than examin'd.

Above each Kidney at about half an inch ditance there tands a Gland,Glandulae renales. by ome called Glandula renalis; by others Ren uccenturiatus; by Bartholin, Capula atrabilaria; by Dr. Wharton, Glandula ad plexum nerveum ita. Which everal names they have had given them, from the everal ues the Impoers have acribed to them.

They are commonly but two,Their Situation. and are placed over (but towards the inide of) the Kidneys, having the fat about the Kidney coming between. The left is nearer to the Diaphragm, tanding
higher than the right, but the right is nearer to the Vena cava.

They are eldom of the hape of the Kidneys,Figure and Subtance. but are of not much an unlike ubtance. Their figure is often three corner'd, having the hape of a Satchel with its bottom upward. Sometimes they are oval but flattih.

They are bigger in Children proportionably than in Men;Magnitude. for in the former they are near the bignes of the Kidneys; but they do not increae as other parts do, o that in adult perons they are not above two inches long and one broad. Commonly the right is bigger than the left.
They are covered with a thin Membrane which is knit very fat to the outer or adipoe Membrane of the Kidneys.Membrane.

They have a manifet Cavity in their larger end,Cavity. in which is contained a black and feculent humour, that tinges the ides of the Cavity. Into it there are a great many little holes gaping out of the ubtance of the Gland, according to Dr. Wharton; and it elf opens into a Vein, but has a Valve placed jut at the entrance, that permits the humour contained in the Cavity to flow out by the Vein, but hinders its return.

They have Veins and Arteries commonly from the Emulgents,Veels. ometimes from the Cava and Aorta, and ometimes from the Vaa adipoa. Their Nerves come from the tomachick branch of the Intercotals that runs to the proper Membrane of the Kidneys and to the Spleen alo. Lacteals they have none. Bartholin affirms they have Lymphaticks.

There have been divers conjectures of the ue of thee Glands, e. but none generally conented to
as true. Dr. Wharton's gues is, that ome humour is imbib'd from the Spleen by the Nerves that are common to the Spleen and thee Glandules (being both from one branch) and is depoited in their Cavity, which being not purely excrementitious (though perhaps unprofitable to the Nerves) is retored again to the Veins. Dr. Glion alo thinks they receive omething from the Spleen, which being refin'd here is imbib'd again by the Nerves, by which it acends to the Brain or Spinal marrow, and decends again by them, being either it elf a Succus nutritius, or ele a Vehicle for it. Riolanus thinks they are of no ue at all in Men, but only in the Foetus in the Womb. Velingius, Bartholin and many others think that they make a ferment or Coagulum for the ue of the Kidneys to help the eparation of the Serum from the Bloud. And this indeed were a probable ue if there could be found out any way whereby ought could conveniently pas from hence to the Kidneys. But the Veins that go out of them are inerted either into the Emulgent vein or the Cava, whoe Bloud is flowing from the Kidneys, o that it cannot pas this way, unles one would uppoe a contrary coure of humours in the ame Veel, which eems aburd. And there are no other Veels to erve this turn. Diemerbroeck conjectures that their black juice is made of the Arterial bloud, and acquires a certain fermentative power neceary for the Venous bloud, into which it is received by the Cava from the Veins that go out of thee Glandules. But this, ays he, is but a conjecture. And in truth all the other opinions are no more, nor very probable ones neither; o that we mut
till acknowledge our ignorance of their true ue.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.
Of the reters.
div.p: THE Ureters, in Latin Meatus urinarii, are called in Greek < in non-Latin alphabet > , either from < in non-Latin alphabet > , to pis, or < in non-Latin alphabet > , becaue they keep the Urine.
They arie out of the inner Sinus of the Kidneys,Their origine. whoe various Pipes (nine or ten) uniting into one make the Ureter.
There is one in each ide.Number.
They are white Veels,Subtance. like to Veins; yet they are whiter, thicker and more nervous. They reach from the Kidneys to the Bladder, not in a direct line, but omething crooked like an Italick .

They have been thought to have two Coats,Coats and Veels. the one common from the Peritonaeum; the other proper: but indeed it is but one, and that proper. It is trong, nervous, trengthned with oblique and treight Fibres, having mall Veins and Arteries from the neighbouring parts. As to their Nerves Dr. Willis aith, that after the Intercotals have ent forth all the Meenterick nerves, each Trunk decending ends forth three or four everal lips that are carried into the Ureters, which makes the pain o very exquiite when ome vicid matter or tone ticks in them.

As they go out of the Kidney they pas over the Mucles Poae (which bend the Thigh) between the two Membranes of the Peritonaeum, and decending as aboveaid, they are inerted in the Back and lower part of the Bladder, (not far from the Sphincter) running between the two proper Coats of it, about the length of an inch, and continued with its inner ubtance.
This inertion is oblique to hinder the regurgitation of the Urine,Why the inertion is oblique. when the Bladder is either compreed or ditended with Urine; for here is no Valve, as ome have affirmed.
Although the Ureter doth not ordinarily exceed in compas a Barly-corn, yet when tones do pas, it becometh ometimes as large as a mall Gut.
Their ue is to receive the Urine eparated from the Bloud in the Kidneys, e. and to convey it into the Bladder, thence at dicretion at certain times to be emptied out of the Body.

list.head: The Explanation of the Figure.
list.item: AAA The imous or hollow part of the Liver.
B The Gall-bladder.
C The Ductus bilarius turn'd upwards.
D The Vena cytica.
E The Artery ditributed both into the Liver and Gall-bladder.
F The mbilical vein turn'd upwards.
GG The decending Trunk of Vena cava.
HH The decending Trunk of the great Artery.
II The Emulgent veins.
KK The Kidneys in their natural ituation.
LL The Emulgent arteries.
MM The Renes uccenturiati with the propagines ent to them from the Emulgents.
NN The reters decending from the Kidneys to the Bladder.
O The bottom of the Bladder.
PP The inertion of the reters into its ides.
QQ A portion of the Urachus.
R A portion of the treight Gut cut off.
SS The Venae praeparantes, the right whereof prings out of the trunk of the Cava, the left out of the Emulgent vein.
T The Corpus pyramidale expret on the left ide.
V The rie of the Arteriae praeparantes out of the trunk of the Aorta.
XX The Teticles, the left whereof is diveted of its common Coat.
YY The Vaa deferentia, acending from the Tetes to the Abdomen.
Z The Yard.
aa The Cod, that cover'd the left Tetis, eparated from it.
bb The Oa ilia.
cc The Oa pubis.
dd The Loins.

div.head: CHAP. XIX.
Of the Bladder.
