div.p: THE Bladder is called in Latin Veica urinaria, Its name. in Greek < in non-Latin alphabet > from its office. It is membranous.

It is eated in the Hypogatrium, Seat. betwixt the two Coats of the Peritonaeum, in that Cavity that is formed of the Os acrum, Hips, and Oa pubis, and is called Pelvis. In Men it lies upon the Intetinum rectum; in Women it adheres to the neck of the Womb, which is placed betwixt the Bladder and the treight Gut: in both it is tied before to the Oa pubis. Moreover it is knit to the Navel by the rachus.
The Membranes of it are three.Membranes.
The firt is from the Peritonaeum; for it is contained within the reduplication of it. This in Man is bemear'd with fat, but not in Beats.

The econd is thicker, and endued with carnous Fibres, which Aquapendens and Bartholin will have to be a Mucle erving for the compreion of the Bladder, to queeze out the Urine, as the Sphincter erveth for contriction, to retain it.
The third and innermot is white and bright, of exquiite ene, as they can witnes who are troubled with the Stone.
It hath all orts of Fibres.Fibres.
Within it is covered with a lippery mucous Crut,Crut. which is an Excrement of the third concoction of the Bladder. This doth defend it from the acrimony of the Urine.
It is perforated in three parts,Perforation. to wit, in the Sides, where the Ureters are inerted, to let in the Urine; and before, to let it out.
The Bladder hath two parts,Parts. to wit, the bottom and the neck.

The bottom comprehends the upper and larger part of the Bladder, to which the rachus being tied reaches to the Navel, which together with the bordering Umbilical arteries becomes a trong Ligament in the adult, hindering the Bladder to pres upon its neck. Of the rachus ee chap. 33.

The neck is lower than the bottom, and traiter. In Men it is longer and narrower, and being carried to the rie of the Yard opens into the rethra; in Women it is horter and wider, and is implanted into the upper ide of the neck of the Womb: In both it is carnous, woven of very many Fibres, epecially tranvere or orbicular, which lie hid within the treight Fibres that urround the whole body of the Bladder, and thee make the Sphincter mucle, which contringes the neck of the Bladder o, as no Urine can pas out againt ones will, unles when it is affected with the Palie or other malady, by which there ometimes happens an involuntary piing. As the neck opens into the rethra, there is hung before it a little Membrane like a Valve, which hinders the flowing of the Seed into the Bladder, when it is emitted into the rethra. This Membrane is broken by putting up a Catheter into the Bladder, and ometimes corroded by a Gonorrhoea.
The Bladder is oblong,Figure. globous and round, in hape like unto a Pear.

Its Cavity is but one ordinarily;Cavity. yet ometimes it has a membranous partition, that divides it into two; which yet has a hole in it for the communication of each Cavity. Such a partition was oberved in the Bladder of the Great Caaubon.

It hath Arteries and Veins from the Hypogatricae, Veels. which are inerted into the ides of its Neck, where they are immediately branched into two, whereof one is pent upon the neck, and the other on the bottom. Nerves it hath (according to Dr. Willis) from the lowet Plexus of the Intercotals in the Abdomen, and from the Marrow of Os acrum. For the aid Plexus ending two Nerves into the Pelvis, they have each of them a Vertebral nerve joined to them, and o make two new Plexus, from one of which there paes a Nerve that, being divided into many branches, is on each ide ditributed into the Bladder and its Sphincter.

The ue of the Bladder is to receive the Urine from the Ureters and to contain it, e. like a Chamber-pot, untill the time of excretion, when it is queezed out of it partly by the help of its own carnous Membrane, and partly of the Mucles of the Abdomen.

Bartholin quotes ome obervations of Borrichius concerning the Bladder,Obervations. worthy to be noted, viz. If it be boil'd in acids, it turns into a Mucilage; if in alt liquors, it is thickned; if in oleous, or in the liquor of the Alkali alts of Tartar or Herbs burnt to ahes, it is neither thickned nor turns into a Mucilage, but is burnt as if it were laid on burning Coals, and may almot be crumbled to powder. By which, ays he, it
appears, with what great danger to the Bladder Men inject into it either acid, alt, or oleous liquors, for breaking the Stone.

div.head: CHAP. XX.
Of the Vaa praeparantia in Man.
div.p: HItherto we have handled the parts appointed for nutrition, whereby the nutriments are prepared in the lower Belly for the utentation of an individual body: Now we come to the organs of generation, whereby through procreation is conerved a perennity of Mankind, which Nature hath denied to particulars. Thee parts being not alike in both Sexes, we mut necearily treat of each apart, and firt of thoe of Men.

In Man ome of thee parts afford matter for the Seed,The parts of the genitals in man. to wit, the Arteriae permaticae; others bring back again the Bloud that is uperflous to the making of the Seed and to the nourihment of the Teticles, and thee are the Venae permaticae; and both the Arteries and Veins were formerly called Vaa praeparantia: ome make the Seed, as the tones: ome carry the Seed back again, as thoe which are called Vaa deferentia: ome contain the Seed, and an oleaginous matter, as the Veiculae eminales the firt, and the Protates the latter: ome dicharge the Seed into the Matrix; this is done by the Penis.
Vaa praeparantia, Vaa praeparantia. which are aid to prepare matter for the Seed, are of two orts, Arteries, and Veins.

The Arteries are two,Arteries. and pring from the Trunk of the Aorta, commonly two fingers breadth under the Emulgents, not jut from its ide but out of its fore-part, the right whereof climbing over the trunk of the Vena cava, runs obliquely to the Vein of the ame ide; as alo the left, marches to the Vein of that ide.

The Veins are alo two.Veins. The right aries uually from the trunk of Vena cava, a little below the Emulgent; the left from the Emulgent it elf, for otherwie it mut have gone over the Aorta, whereby it might have been in danger of breaking; or rather by the continual pule of the Artery the recoure of the Venal bloud might have been retarded. Now both thee Veins and Arteries a little after their rie meet, and are inveted both in one Membrane made of the Peritonaeum, and then run treight through the region of the Loins above the Mucles Poae on each ide, and above the Ureters, as they go betowing little lips here and there upon the Peritonaeum, between whoe duplicature they decend, and o arrive at its procees. The Veins divide very often into many branches, and by and by inoculate and unite again; but the Arteries go along by one Pipe only, on each ide, untill within three or four fingers breadth of the Stones, where each is divided into two branches, the les whereof runs under the Epididymis, the larger to the Teticle. And as I aid they decended betwixt the Membranes of the Peritonaeum, o they pas into the Scrotum between them, not perforating them in the procees, as in Dogs and other Creatures, wherein the procees of the Peritonaeum are hollow like a Quill; but in Man the inner
Membrane of the Peritonaeum huts the hole let the Intetins fall by it into the Cod; of which there is great danger in him (and we ee it often happen) becaue of his going upright. But to return to the Vaa praeparantia. It has been generally taught that there are divers inoculations of the Arteries with the Veins in their paage, whereby the Venal and Arterial bloud are mixed; but this opinion is now exploded, for that, granting the circulation of the Bloud, it is impoible. For the Bloud in the Arteries decends towards the Teticles, and that in the Veins acends from them, o that if thee two Veels hould open one into the other, the Bloud in one of them mut needs be driven back, or ele, tagnating, ditend and break the Veels. But the truth is, the Bloud both for the nourihment of the Teticles and the making of Seed flows down by the Arteries only, and that in an even undivided coure, without any of thoe windings and twirlings like the Tendrels of Vines talkt o much of, (as the curious de Graef by his own frequent inpection tetifies:) But the Veins bring back from the Teticles what of the Bloud remains from their nourihment and making of Seed, and thee indeed come out of the Teticles by almot innumerable roots by which they imbibe the aid Bloud, and are mot admirably interwoven and inoculated one with another till about four or five fingers breadth above the Teticle, which pace is called Corpus pyramidale, Plexus pampiniformis, or Varicous; but thee Veins are o far from preparing the Seed, as that they only bring back what was uperfluous from the making of it. And indeed the Arteries in Men do no more merit
the name of Praeparantes in repect to the Seed, than the Gullet in repect of the Chyle, or the Ductus thoracicus chyliferus in regard to the Bloud. But however, we continue the old names, declaring only againt the reaon of them. And we will only note two things more. Firt, that thee Spermatick veins have from their rie to their end everal Valves which open upwards, and o uffer the Bloud to acend towards the Cava, but not to lide back again. Secondly, that though the Spermatick Arteries go uch a direct coure in Men, as has been aid; yet in Brutes they are more complicated and twited with the Veins, but without any anatomoes of one into the other.

div.head: CHAP. XXI.
Of the Stones, or Teticles, and the Epididymidae.
div.p: THE Stones in Latin are called Tetes, Their name either becaue they tetifie one to be a man, or becaue amongt the Romans none was admitted to bear witnes but he that had them. In Greek they are called < in non-Latin alphabet > , Twins, becaue according to nature they are always two.

They have a peculiar ubtance,Subtance. (uch as is not in all the Body beides) whitih and oft,
made up of innumerable little ropes of Seed-carrying veels: there is no Cavity in them; but thoe aid Veels are continued to one another, and carry the Seed in their undicernible hollownes. The way to make thee Veels viible, de Graef has taught us: viz. Tye fat the Vas deferens in a Live-dog or other Brute, and then thee internal Ropes of Veels, otherways inconpicuous, will preently be o filled and ditended with eminal matter, as that they may be eaily dicerned.

They are in number two,Number, Situation, Figure and magnitude. hanging without the Abdomen, at the root of the Yard, in the Cod. Their figure is oval, only a little flattih. Their bignes differs very much in everal perons; as big as a Dove's Egg is reckon'd a mean ize. Hippocrates held the right to be bigger and hotter than the left, and therefore called it < in non-Latin alphabet > , the Male-getter, as the left < in non-Latin alphabet > , the Female-begetter. But thee are fanies that are obolete, and indeed eem ridiculous, eeing there is no uch difference of their bignes, and that their Veels are common.

They have Arteries and Veins (as was aid before) from thoe called Vaa praeparantia. Veels. Which ome have thought to reach only to the inmot Coat called Tunica albuginea, becaue they are not conpicuous in the inner ubtance of the Teticles. But that comes to pas by reaon that the Arterial bloud preently loes its colour, and by the eminiick faculty of the Stones is turned into Seed, which being whitih, of the ame colour with the Veels, makes them undicernible. Yet in thoe Men that have died of languihing Dieaes, and whoe Tetes have their faculty impaired,
Diemerbroeck affirms that he has oft dicover'd Sanguiferous veels in the inmot parts of the Stones, and has hew'd them to many in the publick Anatomical Theatre. As for Nerves, Dr. Willis ays he could never oberve more to go to them than one from a Vertebral pair, and that that too was mot of it pent upon the Mucle Cremater. Diemerbroeck agrees to one Nerve, but thinks it proceeds from the ixth pair, (which is Dr. Willis's Intercotal, as ditinguiht from that commonly call'd the ixth, but his eighth.) Others will have branches from both thee Nerves to go to them. Concerning the ue of thee Nerves there is great controvery. Dr. Glion, Wharton, &c. will have them to convey a Succus genitalis, which makes the greatet part of the Seed. Dr. Willis, as he denies (in Cerebri anatome, cap. 27.) any Succus nutritius to be conveyed by the Nerves to other parts, o that any Succus genitalis is brought by them hither, but only animal pirit. And whereas to trengthen the former opinion 'tis uually objected, That the Seed mut needs conit of a nervous juice and plenty of pirits brought from the Brain, becaue of the great debility and enervation that is induced upon the Brain and Nerves by the too great expene of it: he thus anwers, That this comes to pas, becaue after great profuions of Seed, for the retauration of the ame humour (whereof Nature is more olicitous than for the benefit of the individual) a greater tribute of pirituous liquor is required from the Bloud to be betowed on the Teticles: wherefore the Brain being defrauded of a due income and afflux of the aid pirituous liquor, languihes; and o the animal
pirits failing in the fountain, the whole Nervous ytem becomes depauperated and flaggy. Whereto may be added, that alo the animal pirits themelves that actuate the Protates, being derived from the Spinal marrow, are much wated by venereal acts; o that for this reaon beides, the Loins are enervated.] In this anwer Bartholin acquieces. And de Graef, Diemerbroeck, &c. confes indeed that the pirituous Arterial bloud is impregnated with Animal pirits from the Nerves, but affirm that the matter out of which the Seed is elaborated is only the aid Bloud; and to thee we ubcribe. Lympheducts they have alo ariing from betwixt their Coats, and acending upwards into the Abdomen with the Vaa deferentia. Thee have many Valves looking upwards, which hinder any thing from decending by them to the Tetes, but permit the Lympha to acend, which they convey into the Chyliferous veels.
They have two orts of Coats, Coats. proper and common.

The common invet both the Tetes, and are two. The outermot conits of the Scarf-skin and True skin (here • thinner than in other places.) This is called Scrotum, hanging out of the Abdomen like a Pure. It is oft and wrinkled, and without fat. This on the outide has a Suture or Seam that runs according to the length of the Cod, and divides it into the right and left ide. The other common Coat is the Membrana carnoa, here alo thinner than other-where this is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , growing to the proper Coat next under it (called Vaginalis) by many membranous Fibres.

The proper Coats are alo two, and thee encloe each Stone apart. The outer is called Elythroides, or Vaginalis; becaue it contains the Stone as a heath. It is a thick and trong Membrane, having many Veins. In the outide it is uneven, by reaon of the Fibres by which it is tied to the Dartos; but in the inner ide it is mooth. This is nothing ele but the production of the Peritonaeum, even as the Scrotum is of the Skin of the Abdomen. Into this Coat is inerted the Mucle Cremater, of which preently. The inmot is < in non-Latin alphabet > , the Nervous membrane, called Albuginea, from its colour. It is white, thick and trong, framed of the external Tunicle of the Vaa praeparantia. It immediately enwraps the Stone, towards which it is rough, but on the outide next the Vaginalis it is mooth; and between thee two the water is contained in an Hernia aquoa.

Into the outer of the proper Membranes (as was aid) is inerted the Mucle Cremater. Mucles. Thee Mucles (to each Stone one) in Men have their rie from the Ligament of the Oa pubis; and almot encompaing round the procees of the Peritonaeum decend with them to the Teticles; where their carnous Fibres run through the whole length of this ame Tunica vaginalis, epecially in its lower part, and o keep the Stones upended, from whence they have their name (from < in non-Latin alphabet >
upendo.) Thee pull up the Stones in the act of generation, that the Veels being lackned, may the more readily void the Seed.
Thee Mucles in icknes and old age become laggy, and o the Scrotum relaxeth it elf, and the Stones hang low.

Upon the Stones,Epididymidae. as yet clad with the Tunica albuginea, are fixed the Epididymidae (called alo Paratatae) enwrapped in the ame Coat with the Spermatick veels. They adhere cloer to the Teticles at their ends than in the midt. De Graef defines them to be Veels making with their various windings that Body that is fixt on the back of the Teticles. To find out their ubtance he directs us thus. Firt take off the Membrane that encompaes them and knits them to the Stones, and then there will appear many windings, which with the edge of a knife may without hurting the Veels be o eaily eparated from one another, that they may be drawn out into a length like a thing folded: for they are only folded from one ide to the other, and are kept in that ite by the Membrane received from the Tunica albuginea, (or Spermatick veels.) But when you have unravel'd half of them you mut cut another very thin Membrane, and then you will ee the Veels lie jut like thee, and may be diolved like them. And the whole being unravel'd, the thicker they are by how much further from their origine, which is implanted into the upper part of the Teticle by ix or even ramifications: which having run o far as where they join into one duct, make it as thick as a mall thread; and this by degrees o thickens, that being increas'd like a cord it makes the Vas deferens, (of which in the next Chapter.)

p.q:
So that (aith he) it is clear from hence, firt, that the Tetes do not differ from the Epididymidae (or Paratatae) aving that thoe conit of divers ducts; but thee, after their
TAB. V.
ix or even roots that arie out of the Teticle are united, (which they are in a hort pace) but of one, only a little thicker. Secondly, that the Epididymidae differ not from the Vaa deferentia, aving that thoe go by a erpentine winding paage, and thee by a treight, and that thoe are a little ofter and narrower. And o (concludes he) following this Ariadne's thread we have happily made our way out of the Labyrinth of the Tetes and Epididymidae.

div.p: The ues of the Stones are two: e.

The firt is to elaborate the Seed by the eminifical faculty reident in them. For they turn the Bloud, which is brought by the Arteriae praeparantes, and impregnated with Animal pirit, into Seed, for the mot part; ome is pent on their own nutrition; and what remains from both is carried back by the Veins called Praeparantes.
The econd is, to add heat, trength and courage to the Body, as gelding doth manifet, by the which all thee are impaired.

list.head: The Explanation of the Table. Figure I.
list.item: A The Artery preparing Seed, running from the Trunk of the Aorta to the Teticle.
B Its diviion into two branches.
CC The leer branch thereof, which runs to the Epididymidae.

DD The greater, which is implanted into the upper part of the Teticle and decends along its back towards its lower part, to which the
maller end of the Epididymis is annexed; then it goes back again along the Belly of the Teticle, where it is divided into many branches.
E The greater end of the Epididymis knit cloe to the upper part of the Teticle.
F The middle part of the Epididymis turn'd up, that the ramifications of the Artery that run along its lower part, may be een.
G The maller end of the Epididymis ticking firmly to the lower part of the Teticle.
H The end of the Epididymis, or beginning of the Vas deferens.
I The Vas deferens cut off, before it come to behind the Bladder.
K The Teticle placed o as that its Veels may bet be een.

list.head: Figure II.
list.item: A The Vein aid to prepare Seed running from the Trunk of the Vena cava to the Teticle.
BB The branches of the Vena praeparans tending to the Caul and Peritonaeum.
C The firt diviion of it into two branches, which afterwards are wonderfully ubdivided and united again.
DDDDD The Valves of the Venae praeparantes, about which the Veins being blown up appear knotty.
EEEE Very many diviions and unions of the Venae praeparantes, that the Bloud uperfluous from the generation of Seed, being detained in one ramification, may return to the Heart by the other.
F The upper part of the Teticle into which the ramifications of the Vena praeparans are implanted.
G The ramifications of the Venae praeparantes creeping along the ides of the Teticles through their white Coat.
H The body of the Teticle.
I The bigger end, K the middle, and L the maller end of the Epididymis.
M The Vas deferens cut off almot in the middle.

list.head: Figure III.
list.item: A The Preparing veels cut off.
B The Preparing veels as they run to the Teticles.
C Their ramifications tending to the Epididymidae.
D The greatet branch of the Arteria praeparans running along the Belly of the Teticle.
EE The ramifications of the Venae praeparantes.
F A Dog's Teticle welled with Seed.
G The bigger end of the Epididymis turgid with Seed.
H The leer end likewie tu • gid with Seed
I The end of the Epididymis or the beginning of the Vas deferens.
K The Vas deferens of a Dog tied before the Coitus the Preparing veels being unhurt, that the Seminary veels being filled with Seed may be een more apparently.

div.head: CHAP. XXII.
Of the Vaa deferentia, Veiculae eminales, and Protatae.
div.p:
OUT of the Epididymidae at their maller end arie the two Vaa deferentia, Vaa deferentia. or Ejaculatoria, being but a continuation of them. They are white, hardih bodies, like a pretty large Nerve, with a Cavity not very dicernible, but which may be made o, if one open one of them ix or even fingers breadth above the Teticle, and then either blow into it with a mall pipe, or quirt ome colour'd liquor into it with a Syringe towards the Tetis, for then the Veel will be ditended, and the colour will run along its Cavity towards the Epididymidae: Or if you either blow, or quirt liquor by a Syringe the other way towards the Veiculae eminales, the aid Veiculae will be ditended. Now from the Epididymidae thee Vaa deferntia acend, and pas out of the Cod into the Abdomen the ame way by which the Vaa praeparantia came down, viz. by the proces of the Peritonaeum. When they are entred the Abdome • , they are carried preently over the Ureters, and turning back again they pas to the backide of the Bladder; between which and the Intetinum rectum they march till about the neck of the Bladder, being omewhat evered, where they grow wider and thicker; and then jut as they are going to meet, their ides open into the Veiculae eminales, in which they depoite the Seed; but not terminating
here, but coming cloe together and growing maller and maller, they go on and end at the rethra betwixt the Protatae.

Thee Veiculae are little Cells like thoe in a Pomegranate,Veiculae eminales. or omething like a bunch of Grapes; De Graef compares them to the Guts of a little Bird diverly contorted. They conit of one thin Membrane, through which ome mall twigs of both Veins, Arteries and Nerves run. They are about three fingers breadth long, and one broad; but in ome places broader and ome narrower, as they run in and out. They are two, (one for each Vas deferens) divided from one another by a little intertice; and they do everally by a peculiar paage emit the Seed contained in them into the rethra. They are very anfractuous and winding, and (as was aid) conit of many little Cells, that they hould not pour out all the Seed contained in them, in one act of copulation, but might retain it for everal. They have no communication one with another; not even in their very opening into the rethra; but the Seed that is brought to the Veiculae eminales on the right ide by the right Vas deferens, iues by its proper paage into the rethra; and that which is brought to the left, likewie. So that if by any accident the Veiculae on one ide be burt or cut (as in cutting for the Stone they mut needs be) yet thoe on the other being entire may till uffice for generation. Now when the Seed is emitted out of thee Veiculae in the act of generation, it paes out the ame way it came in; which in this cae may eaily be, (though it be unuual there hould be a contrary motion in the ame Veel) for as it comes in from the Vaa deferentia, it
drills along gently without any force; but in Coitu when the Mucles of the Yard and all the bordering parts are much tumified, it is expreed or quirted out of them with ome violence, and paing along their neck, (which is a continuation of the Vaa deferentia) ouzes through a Caruncle (like Quick-ilver through Leather) into the rethra, or the Duct of the Yard that is common both to the Seed and Urine. I ay it ouzes from the necks of the Veiculae through a Caruncle into the rethra, for there is one plac'd as a Valve before the orifice of each of them; partly to hinder the coming of the Urine into them, partly to hinder the involuntary effuion of the Seed.

Now though naturally the little holes through which the Seed paes out of the necks of the Veiculae into the rethra be almot imperceptible; yet if they be either eroded by the acrimony of the Seed (uch acrimony as is contracted by impure embraces, or in Claps as we call them) or if of themelves they be debilitated and o become more lax (as ometimes happens to old or impotent Men that meddle too much) then there happens a Gonorrhoea or continual efflux of Seed. And o Vealius and Spigelius have oberved them much dilated, in diecting uch as have died with a Gonorrhoea upon them.

The Protatae (in Englih tanders by or waiters) are placed near to the Veiculae eminariae;
• rotatae. de Graef calls them Corpus glandoum, uppoing them to be one body, and only divided by the common Ducts of the Veiculae eminales and Vaa deferentia coming through the midt of it. They are of a
• hite, pongy and glandulous ubtance, about as big as a mall Walnut, encompas'd with a
trong and fibrous Membrane from the Bladder, to the beginning of whoe neck they are joined at the root of the Yard. In hape they come nearet to an oval, ave that on their upper and lower part they are a little depret, and in that end by which the Vaa deferentia enter, they are omething hollow like a Tunnel. The Sphincter mucle of the Bladder encompaes them, o that for o far as they cover the neck of the Bladder, the Sphincter touches it not, they coming between. They have all orts of Veels, which run motly on their outer ide. In their inner part they have ten or more mall Ducts which all unload themelves into the rethra by the ides of the great Caruncle (through which the Seed paes from the Veiculae into the rethra) but themelves have each one a mall one to top its orifice let the liquor that is contained in the Protates hould continually flow out, or the Urine hould flow in. And thee mall Ducts I uppoe are continued from thoe mall Veiculae which appear in the Protates of thoe that die (any way) uddenly after having had to doe with a Female. For in uch, the pongy part of the Protatae is very turgid with a erous liquor, and in their inner part may be found thee ame Veiculae, like to Hydatides, which if you pres upon, they will dicharge themelves into the aboveaid Ducts.

What the liquor they contain hould be,Their ue. or what is their ue, there is great variety of opinions. Some think that the Seed that flows from the Teticles is further elaborated here. But that cannot be; for that the Vaa deferentia depoite nothing in them, but all into the Veiculae eminales. Others think that from the Bloud there is eparated
in them an acrimonious and erous humour, which erves for titillation or cauing the greater pleaure in venery. As to this, de Graef appeals to the tat of it, which has nothing of acrimony. Dr. Wharton thinks they make a particular kind of Seed, as the Teticles do another, and the Veiculae eminales a third. That thee lat make a Seed different from that made in the Teticles is grounded on a mitake in Anatomy, viz. that the Vaa deferentia have no communication with the Veiculae, whereas they apparently open into them, and depoite in them all the Seed they contain. That the Protatae make a peculiar ort, he endeavours to prove, becaue gelded Animals emit ome Seed. But that is but precarious; for though they emit omething, 'tis not neceary it hould be any true Seed. Or if it be, it may well be uppoed to proceed from the Veiculae eminales that have been full when the Animal was gelt. For, for this reaon it has been oberved that preently after gelding they have ometimes got the Female with young, but not afterwards when that tock was pent. Bartholin with many others thinks they make an oily, lippery and fat humour, which is preed out, as there is need, to bemear the rethra, whereby to defend it from the acrimony of the Seed and Urine, and let it hould dry up. Diemerbroeck confees that it is neceary the inide of the rethra hould be kept moit and lippery, but thinks that that is done here as in the Bladder, Intetins and many other places, namely from ome mucid part of the nourihment of the rethra it elf; and concludes that the Vaa deferentia depoite not all the Seed into the Veiculae eminales, but
carry a maller part to thee Protatae. De Graef denies that the Vaa deferentia convey any thing to them or have any communication with them; and therefore believes, that the humour that is eparated in the Corpus glandoum (as he calls the Protatae) erves for a Mentruum or Vehicle of the Seed, which flowing but in mall quantity through mall pores into the rethra, it was neceary that this humour hould be mixt with it that it might better reach the Womb. Whatever this humour be, it is queezed out partly by the intumecence and erection of the Penis, and partly by the compreion of the Sphincter of the Bladder that girds the Protatae about.

Thee Protates are often (at leat partly) the eat of the Gonorrhoea; and the humour that they contain, that which is hed: for, if it were true Seed, they could never endure a Gonorrhoea o long (ome, thirty years) without more notable weakning and emaciating, the flux being o large as ometimes it is.
I hall here omit all philoophical enquiries into the nature of the Seed, contenting my elf purely with the Anatomical part.

The ditance betwixt the root of the Cod and the Podex is called Perinaeum, Perinaeum. à
< in non-Latin alphabet > ,Why thee parts in men are hairy. circumfluo, becaue it is till moit with weat. The Pubes, Scroton, and Perinaeum in Men, are furnihed with Hair, becaue Glandules are placed there, which receive plenty of uperfluous moiture: a part whereof they end to the Skin for the generation of Hair.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII.
Of the Yard.
div.p: THE Seed being elaborated and treaured up in the aforeaid Organs, there was need of a peculiar Intrument whereby it might be conveyed into the Womb of the Female; and to this purpoe Nature has furnihed the Male with a Yard which we come now to anatomize.

It is called in Latin Penis, Its name. à pendendo, becaue it hangeth without the Belly. Alo Virga, Membrum virile, Veretrum, Mentula, and by many other names invented by lutfull perons and lacivious Poets.

It is an Organical part,Decription. long and round, yet omewhat flat in the upper part, eated about the lower part of Os pubis, appointed partly for making of water, but principally for conveying the Seed into the Matrix.

As to its thicknes or length,Magnitude. it differs much in divers Men. But it is generally oberved to be larger in hort Men, and uch as are not over much given to Venery; alo in thoe that have high and long Noes, and that are tupid and half-witted.
The parts of it are either common or proper. Parts.
The common are three, the Scarf-skin, the Skin, and the Membrana carnoa.

It hath no fat,Why it hath no fat. for that would have hindred its erection into that tiffnes that is neceary; and econdly would have occaion'd it to grow too bulky; and latly would have dull'd that great pleaure that in Venery the Male is affected with in this part.
The proper or internal parts are thee: the two Nervous bodies, the Septum, the rethra, the Glans, four Mucles and the Veels.

The Nervous bodies (o called) are encompaed with a thick,The nervous bodies. white, nervous and very firm Membrane (like an Artery) but their inner ubtance is pongious, being motly a contexture of Veins, Arteries and Nervous fibres, woven one with another like a Net; and when the Nerves are filled with Animal pirit, and the Arteries with hot and Spirituous blood, then the Penis is ditended and becomes erect: but when the Spirits ceae to flow in, then the Bloud and remaining Spirits are aborbed by the Veins, and o the Penis becomes limber and flaggy.

They pring from the lower ide of the Os pubis at ditinct originals, where they appear like two horns, or are of a figure reembling the Letter Y, that the rethra may have room to pas between them. When they leave the Os pubis they are each covered with a everal Membrane, and are afterwards joined together with only the Septum between, which the nearer it comes towards the Glans, is the thinner, o that before it come to the middle of the Penis its Fibres extend towards the back of the Yard from the rethra in order like a Weaver's Slay, and while it till goes further, its Fibres by degrees grow o very mall, that near the Glans the Septum is almot obliterated,
and the two Nervous bodies grow into one. Whence it is that the Penis is equally erected; for if the Septum had exactly ditinguiht one part from the other, it might ometimes have o happened by the compreion or obtruction of the Arteries of the one or the other ide, that one part of it would have been extended, and the other remained flaggy.

Dr. Wharton affirms, thee Nervous bodies have Glandulous fleh within them, which keeps the Yard omething plump even when it is not erect. But de Graef denies this, and demontrates that they have no other ubtance than beforeaid, thus. Let the Yard be prepared thus: Firt gently queez the bloud out of it, which it always has in greater or leer plenty, and then put a little Tube into the pongy ubtance, namely in at that end that is next to the Os pubis; and let the Cavity of the Penis be half fill'd with water by the help of a Syringe, and hake the Penis with the water in it: pour out that bloudy water, and fill it again with clear, and o three or four times till the water is no longer tain'd with bloud. Then betwixt two Linen cloths queez out what water is in the Nervous bodies, and at length blow up the Penis o long till it have its natural bignes; in which poture if you will keep it, you mut tie it hard. When the Penis is thus ditended and dried, you may examin it as you pleae, and will find no other ubtance than was mentioned. Diemerbroeck ays that their ubtance is not a meer texture of Veels, but is fibrous, fungous and cavernous (uch as is the ubtance of the Lungs) receiving in their hollow Intertices Bloud and Spirits out of the Veels that are dipered through their ubtance.

Below thee Nervous bodies lies the rethra,
The Urethra. being of a much like ubtance to them, aving that its pongy part, which is outer and lower, hath les pores becaue of its maller and more plentifull Fibres. This part does tumefy whenoever the Nervous bodies do. Its inner part is membranous, round and hollow, and exceeding enible. It is of an equal largenes from one end to the other, ave in its fore-part, where the Glans is joined to the Nervous bodies, for there it hath a mall Cavern, into which the acrimonious Urine lighting in the Stone of the Bladder, while it wheels about in it, caueth pain, and is a great ign of the Stone. Sometimes alo the acrimonious eroding liquor in a Gonorrhoea taying here, doth caue a mot tormenting ulceration.

It is continuous to the neck of the Bladder, but has not its rie from it, nor is of the ame kind of ubtance. If you boil the Bladder and it, it will eaily eparate, and appears of a clear other ubtance and colour. It begins at the neck of the Bladder and reaches to the end of the Glans, which it eems to betow a Membrane upon from its own inner one, for it is plainly continued from it.

Its ue is to convey along the Seed and Urine. And to that end there open into it mall pores that tranmit the Seed into it from the necks of the Veiculae eminales (of which in the foregoing Chapter;) and alo the neck of the Veica rinaria which pours out the Urine into it, at which place it has a membranous Valve, of which likewie before in Chap. 19.

The Mucles are two in each ide,Mucles. and o four
in all. Of thee one pair are called Collateral mucles, by others Erectores. Thee are horter and thicker, and pring from the appendix or knob of the Coxendix, under the beginning of the Nervous bodies, and are inerted into the ame, a little from their beginning. Thee erve for erection of the Penis.
The econd pair is longer and maller, proceeding from the phincter of the Anus.

Thee pas treight by the ides of the rethra, and are inerted about the middle of it, which they erve to dilate for miction and ejaculation of the Seed, and are called Dilatantes, wideners, and Acceleratores or hatners.

Thee have been generally held to be the ues of thee Mucles, but de Graef (as alo Swammerdam, not. in prodr. p. 35.) aigns a clear contrary to them, and that with great hew of reaon. For eeing the action of a Mucle is contraction, how hould the former pair extend the Penis, and not rather draw it back towards their original? Or how hould the latter erve to dilate the rethra, and not rather traiten it, eeing in the action or contraction of a Mucle its Belly or Middle wells? Therefore he ays that the Mucles only contribute thus far or in this repect to the extenion or erection of the Penis, in as much as by their welling (partly by bloud and pirit flowing into them, partly by their proper action) they erve to traiten and compres the roots of the Nervous bodies and the pongy part of the
rethra, and o drive the Bloud that flows in by the Arteries towards the Glans, and hinder its returning back again by the Veins: even as we daily ee in a piece of a Gut, which if we fill with
wind or water, and then compres one end, we hall ee the other trut out and be more ditended.

The end or head of the Penis is called Glans, Glans. and Balanus. Into this the Nervous bodies terminate, and being a little thicker (on that ide next them) than they, it encompaes them with a circle like a Crown. On its fore-part it is maller and harper. It has a peculiar ubtance (Dr. Wharton ays glandulous) oft and pongy, and being covered with a very thin Membrane produced from the internal one of the rethra (which coming out of its hollow, dilates it elf o as to cover all the Glans) it thereby and from its proper ubtance, much interwoven with Nerves, becomes mot exquiitely enible, and is the principal eat of pleaure in copulation. Which if it had not been very great, who would have taken delight in o brutih a thing as Venery? To this purpoe Andreas Laurentius elegantly, (Anat. lib. 7. cap. 1. q. 7.) Who (mot trange!) would have olicited or accepted of o vile and filthy a thing as lying with a Woman? with what face would Man, that divine Animal, full of reaon and counel, have handled the obcene parts of Women polluted with o much filth, which is dicharged into this low place as into the common ink of the Body? On the other ide, what Woman would have accepted of the embraces of a Man, conidering the toil and tediounes of going 9 months with Child, the mot painfull and often fatal bearing of it, and its education full of care and anxiety, unles the Genitals had been affected in the act with tranporting pleaure?
The Glans is covered with the Praeputium, Praeputium. or Fore-skin, which is framed of the reduplication of the Skin.

It is called Praeputium, becaue it is placed prae pudendo before the Yard: or rather à praeputando, from being cut off, for this is that which the Jews cut off in Circumciion, from whence they are called Apellae and Recutiti. And it is reported by divers perons from their own inpection, that in Jewih Children it is ix times as large as in Chritians, and hangs a great way over the Glans, before it be cut off.
The Ligament by which the Fore-skin is tied to the Glans in the lower part of it,Fraenum. is called Fraenum, the Bridle.
Of the Veels,The Veels. ome are cutaneous, ome pas to the inner parts of the Penis.

The cutaneous veins and arteries pring from the Pudendae; Veins and Arteries. thee entring at the root of the Yard, pas by the ides towards the back of it, and are conpicuous enough. The Veels which are betowed upon the inner parts of it, come from the Venae and Arteriae hypogatricae, and enter jut at the meeting of the two Nervous bodies, through whoe length they run, and are motly dipered in them, and in the fungous part of the rethra, ending forth little twigs at the ides.

It has two Nerves from the lowet Vertebral.Nerves. The greater of them, that is very large and long, is ditributed into the Nervous bodies, rethra and Glans; the leer upon its Mucles. Concerning which Dr. Willis thus dicoures. This Member (ays he) having only Nerves from the Spinal marrow, hould only have a pontaneous motion according to our Hypotheis
(viz. that the Nerves from the Brain erve for natural, and the Vertebral for voluntary motion.) And yet through the turgecency of the Genital humour, it is often erected and filled with Spirit againt ones mind; which is from hence, becaue from this Vertebral pair, whence the Nerves of the Penis pring, a prig is reached forth to the Vertebral pair next above it, viz. in which is radicated the Plexus that is placed in the Pelvis and betows Nerves on the Protatae, into which Plexus alo a notable Nerve is implanted from the Intercotal pair. Seeing therefore there is a communication between the Protatae, (which depend much on the Intercotal Nerves) and the Penis it elf (by reaon of the inertion of the aforeaid prig into the Plexus from whence the Protatae have their Nerves) hence it comes to pas that it acts accordingly as they are affected. But they, (viz. the Protates) are not only apt to be moved by the turgecency of the Seed; but, by the communication of the Intercotal nerve, according to the impreions made on the Senes or Brain, are wont to be irritated by too importune an action; into conent wherewith the Penis is preently excited.

Its principal ue is to convey the Seed into the
terus of the Female; e. and its ue to pis withall, is but econdary, for many Creatures (as Fowls in general) make no water by it, yet have a Penis for the ue aboveaid.

That part that is next above it towards the Belly is called the Pubes, and its lateral parts are called the Groins; both which places in the Mature are covered with hair, whereby Nature
would in ome meaure veil the Privities, eeing natural modety requires it.

list.head: The Explanation of the Table. Figure I.
list.item: AA Parts of the Vaa deferentia, which appear thick, but have only a mall Cavity.
BB The parts of the Vaa deferentia of a thin ubtance and large Cavity, being widened.
CC The extremities of the Vaa deferentia narrowed again, and gaping each with a little hole into the neck of the Seed-bladders.
DD The neck of the Seed-bladders parted from each other by a Membrane going between, o that the Seed of one ide cannot be mixed with that of the other, before it come to the Urethra.
EE The Veiculae eminales or Seed-bladders blown up, that their wonderfull widenings and narrowings may be een.
FF Veels tending to the Seed-bladders.
GGG The Membranes whereby the Seed-bladders and Vaa deferentia are kept in their places.
HH The Sanguinary veels running by the ides of the Vaa deferentia.
I A Caruncle-reembling a Snipe's head, through whoe eyes as it were the Seed iues out into the Urethra.
KK The Ducts of the Corpus glandoum or Protatae opening into the Urethra by the ides of the Caruncle.
LL The Corpus glandoum divided.
MM The Urethra opened.

figure.p:
TAB. VI.
Figure II.
A The upper or fore-part of the Bladder.
B The neck of the Bladder.
CC Portions of the reters.
DD Portions of the Vaa deferentia.
EE The Veels running to the Seed-bladders.
FF The Veiculae eminales or Seed-bladders.
GG The fore-part of the Protatae or Corpus glandoum.
H The Urethra adjoining to its pongy part.
KK The Mucles called the Erectors or Extenders of the Penis.
LL The beginnings of the Nervous bodies eparated from the Oa pubis, which puff up like Bellows when the Yard is erected.
MM The Skin of the Penis drawn aide.
NN The duplicature of the Skin making the Praeputium.
OO The Skin that was faten'd behind the Glans.
PP The back of the Penis.
R The urinary paage whereby the Glans is perforated in its fore-part.
SS The Nerves running along the back of the Penis.
TT The Arteries running along the back of the Penis.
U The Nervous bodies meeting together.
WW Two Veins which unite together, and run along the back of the Penis in a remarkable branch.
X The Vein opened, that the valves in it may be een.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV.
Of the Vaa praeparantia.
div.p: THough it has been the method of divers Anatomits to begin with the decription of the outer parts of the Privity; yet becaue we would oberve, as much as may be, the ame order in Women as we have in Men, we hall firt begin with the Spermatick veels, which are of two orts, Arteries and Veins.

The Arteries are two,Spermatick arteries. as in Men. They pring from the great Artery a little below the Emulgents (very rarely either of them from the Emulgent it elf) and pas down towards the Tetes not by uch a direct coure as in Men, but with much twirling and winding amongt the Veins, with which tho' they have no inoculation, as has been generally taught. But for all their winding, when they are tretcht out to their full length, they are not o long as thoe of Men; becaue in them they decend out of the Abdomen into the Scrotum, but in Women they have a far horter paage, reaching only to the Tetes and Womb within the Abdomen.

The Veins are alo two,Veins. ariing, as in Men, the right from the trunk of the Cava a little below the Emulgent, the left from the Emulgent it elf. In their decent they have no more bendings than in Men, and therefore are coniderably horter.

Both the Arteries and Veins as they pas down are cover'd with one common Coat from the Peritonaeum; and near the Tetes they are divided into two branches, the upper whereof is implanted into the Teticle by a triple root; and the other is ubdivided below the Tetes into three twigs, one of which goes to the bottom of the Womb, another to the Tuba and round Ligament, the third creeping by the ides of the Womb under its common Membrane, ends in its neck, where it is woven with the Hypogatrick veels like a Net. By this way it is that the Mentrua ometimes flow in Women with Child for the firt months, and not out of the inner Cavity of the terus: but yet that Bloud does not flow at that time o much by the Spermatick Arteries as by the Hypogatrick.

The ue of thee Spermatick veels is to miniter to the (generation of Seed,Their ue. according to the ancient doctrine; but) nutrition of the Eggs in the Ovaria or Tetes (according to the new) the nourihment of the Foetus, and of the olid parts, and the expurgation of the Menes; inamuch as Bloud is conveyed by the Arteries to all thoe parts to which their ramifications come, in which parts they leave what is to be eparated according to the law of Nature, the remaining bloud returning by the Veins.

div.head: CHAP. XXV.
Of Womens Teticles or Ovaria.
div.p: WOmens Teticles differ much from Mens both in their ituation, figure, greatnes, covers, ubtance, and alo ue.

Firt,Their Situation. their ituation is not without the Body, as in Men, but in the inner Cavity of the Abdomen, on each ide two fingers breadth from the bottom of the Womb, to whoe ides they are knit by a trong Ligament, that has us'd to be called and accounted the Vas deferens; as if the Seed were carried by it from the Tetes to the Womb. Of which afterwards.

They are flat on the ides;Figure. in their lower part oval, but in their upper (where the Bloud-veels enter them) more plane. Their uperficies is more rugged and unequal than in thoe of Men. They have no Epididymides, nor Cremater Mucles.

They differ in bignes according to age.Greatnes. In thoe newly come to maturity they are about half as big as thoe of Men; but in thoe in years they are les and harder. Preternaturally they ometimes grow to a vat bignes from Hydropical tumours, in which everal quarts of erous liquor have been found to be contain'd.

They have but one Membrane that encompaes them round;Tunicle. but on their upper ide, where the Vaa praeparantia enter them, they are about half way involved in another Membrane that accompanies thoe Veels, and prings from the Peritonaeum.

When this cover is removed,Subtance. their ubtance appears whitih, but is wholly different from the ubtance of Mens Teticles. For Mens (as was aid above) are compoed of Seminary veels, which being continued to one another are twenty or thirty Ells long if one could draw them out at length without breaking: But Womens do principally conit of a great many Membranes and mall Fibres looely united to one another; amongt which (in the outer uperficies of the Tetes) there are everal little Bladders (like to Hydatides) full of a clear liquor, through whoe Membranes the Nerves and Vaa praeparantia run, and are obliterated in them. The liquor contained in thee Bladders had always been uppoed by the followers of Hippocrates and Galen to be Seed tored up in them, as if they upplied the place of the Veiculae eminales in Men. But from Dr. Harvey downwards many learned Phyicians and Anatomits (according to Aritotle) have denied all Seed to Women. Of which the aid Dr. Harvey thus dicoures, De ovi materia, Exercit. 34. Some Women end forth no uch humour as is called Seed, and yet is not conception thereby necearily frutrated; for I have known everal Women (ays he) that have been fruitfull enough without uch emiion; yea, ome that after they begun to emit uch humour, though indeed they took greater pleaure in copulation, yet grew les fruitfull than before. There are alo infinite intances of Women, who though they have pleaure in coitu, yet end forth nothing, and notwithtanding conceive. I greatly wonder that they that think this emiion neceary to generation,
have not oberved, that the humour is cat out, and iues mot commonly from about the Clitoris and orifice of the Privity; very eldom from any depth within the neck of the Womb, but never within the Womb it elf, o as that it hould there be mixed with the Man's Seed; and that it is not ropy and oyly like Seed, but erous like Urine. Now to what purpoe hould that be cat out, whoe ue is necearily required within? Ought that humour to be ent to the mouth of the Privity, (bidding farewell as it were to the Womb) that it might be drawn back again with the greater kindnes and welcome?] And indeed whatever that humour be that the more alacious Women emit in copulation, (of which afterwards) it cannot be that which is contained in thee Veiculae, both becaue it is ent forth in greater quantity than that it can be upplied from them, and alo the Veiculae are detitute of any uch pore or paage whereby the liquor contained in them might iue out; for if you pres them never o hard, unles you burt them, there will nothing pas out of them. We mut therefore ubcribe to that new but neceary opinion that uppoes thee little Bladders to contain nothing of Seed, but that they are truly Eggs, analogous to thoe of Fowl and other Creatures; and that the Teticles (o called) are not truly o, nor have any uch office as thoe of Men, but are indeed an Ovarium wherein thee Eggs are nourihed by the Sanguinary Veels dipered through them, and from whence one or more (as they are fecundated by the Man's Seed) eparate, and are conveyed into the Womb by the
Tubae Fallopianae, of which by and by.

That thee Veiculae are analogous to the little Eggs in the Ovarium of Fowl, de Graef evinces by this Experiment, That if you boil them, their liquor will have the ame colour, tate and conitency with the white of Birds Eggs. And their difference in wanting hells is of no moment; for Birds Eggs had need of a hell, becaue they are hatched without the Body, and therefore are expoed to external injuries; but thee of Women being fotered within their Body, have no need of other fence than the Womb, by which they are ufficiently defended.

Having compared thee Veiculae to the Eggs of Fowls, I might here follow the method of Doctor Harvey and de Graef, and decribe the Ovarium, &c. in Hens, &c. that from thence thee in Women might the better be conceived of and apprehended; but to the curious and learned Reader I hall recommend the aid Authors for atifaction, and avoiding all unneceary and (to this Epitome) unuitable excurion, I hall only further note two things: Firt, that thee Eggs in Women are commonly towards the number of twenty in each Teticle or Ovarium, of which ome are far les than others. And econdly, that the objection of the Galenits againt the Aritotelians, (viz. that the Tetes of Females mut needs make Seed, becaue when they were cut out, barrennes always follow'd) will be ufficiently obviated by this new Hypotheis, that agrees to the neceity of the Teticles o far as to affirm that the Veiculae contained in them become (when they are impregnated by the Maculine Seed) the very conceptions themelves, which
therefore it would be in vain to expect if the Female were catrated.
Beides the Vaa praeparantia, and Nerves, (of which in the 27th Chapter) they have alo Lympheducts, according to Dr. Wharton.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI.
Of the Vaa deferentia in Women, or their Oviducts.
div.p: GAlen with mot of the Ancients reckoned thoe hort procees that go treight from the Tetes to the bottom of the Womb, to be Vaa deferentia; and that the Seed was emitted from the Stones through them into the Fundus uteri. And Fernelius, Riolanus, &c. thought they found a mall Pipe paing on each ide out of thee procees by the ides of the Womb to its neck, into which they were inerted and opened near its orifice. By the former it was uppoed Women not with Child did emit their Seed into the bottom of the Womb; and by thee latter uch as were already impregnated: for that, if it hould have iued into the Fundus where the conception was, it would there have corrupted to the great prejudice of the Foetus.

But as to thee latter ducts, Velingius, Diemerbroeck, de Graef and many other accurate Anatomits, have not been able to find the leat foottep of them. And as for the former, eeing they are not pervious, nor have any Cavity, (and
therefore can have nothing of Seed in them) we mut conclude with de Graef that they are only Ligaments of the Teticles to keep them in their place; which he evinces further by oberving, that they come not to the inner Cavity of the
terus, but are knit only to its outer Coat: for he ays, there are only two holes in the Fundus uteri that admit a Probe, and thoe lead to the Tubae Fallopianae and not to thee Ligaments.

Seeing therefore that thoe which have been accounted Vaa deferentia either are not to be found at all,Tubae Fallopianae. or are found uncapable of uch an office; and having withall rejected the opinion of Womens having Seed, and affirmed that that which makes the conception is one of thoe Veiculae in the Tetes, dropping from thence and conveyed into the Womb, we mut inquire by what way they can pas. For if the aboveaid Ligaments (reputed Vaa deferentia) have no paage whereby even the Semen, if there were any, might pas; much les could one of thee Veiculae be conveyed that way. And therefore for Vaa deferentia we aign thoe ducts that Fallopius in his Anatomical obervations calls Tubae, and decribes thus: They are very lender and narrow ducts, nervous and white, ariing from the horns (or ides) of the Womb, and at a little ditance from it they become larger, and twit like the tendrel of a Vine, till near their end, where ceaing their winding they grow very large, and eem membranous and carnous. Which end is very much torn and jagged like the edge of rent Clothes: and has a large Foramen, which (ays he) always lies cloed, becaue thoe jags fall together; but yet being
opened they are like the utmot orifice of a Bras Trumpet.] But de Graef ays, though they grow very large towards their end, yet of a udden the very extreme part is narrowed before it is divided into the aforeaid jags, which he reembles unto leaves. Who alo appeals unto experiment for thee Tubae's being pervious, affirming that if one put a little Tube into the beginning of one of thee ame Trumpets and blow it, the wind will preently break through it, which he aith he has oberved in all the kinds of Animals that he has diected.

Thee Tubae (according to Dr. Harvey) are the ame in Women that the Cornua or Horns of the Womb are in other Creatures. For they anwer to thoe both in ituation, connexion, amplitude, perforation, likenes and alo office: for as other Animals always conceive in the Cornua, o it has been ometimes oberved (as by Riolanus from others; and by himelf) that a conception has in a Woman been contained in one of the Tubae.] Which mut have happened, when the Ovum being received out of the Tetis into it, has been topt in its paage to the Womb, either from its own bignes, or ome obtruction in the Tubae.

Their ubtance is not nervous (as Fallopius in the above-recited decription affirms) but membranous.Their ubtance. For they conit of two Membranes, the outer and inner. The inner prings from (or at leat is common with) that which covers the inner ubtance of the Womb; but whereas it is mooth in the Womb, it is very wrinkled in the Tubae. The outer is common with the outmot of the Womb; and this is mooth.

The capacity of thee ducts varies very much:Width. for in the beginning as it goes out of the Womb, it only admits a britle, but in its progres where it is larget it will receive ones little finger. But in the utmot extremity where 'tis divided into jags, it is but about a quarter o wide.
They are very uncertain alo in their length;Length. for from four or five, they ometimes encreae to eight or nine fingers breadth long.

Their ue is, e. In a fruitfull copulation to grant a paage to a more ubtile part of the Maculine eed (or to a eminal air) towards the Tetes, to bedew the Eggs contained in them; which Eggs (one or more) being by that means fecundated (or ripened as it were) and dropping off from the Tetis (in the manner as hall be decribed Chap. 30.) are received by the extremity of the Tubae, and carried along their inner Cavity to the terus. For Dr. Harvey affirms that they have a worm-like or peritaltick motion like that of the Guts (de Cervarum & Damarum tero, Exercit. 65.) And the ame is affirmed by Swammerdam, Not. in Prodr.

Againt this ue two objections may be made; Firt, that the end of the Tuba not adhering cloe to the Tetis, when one of the Veiculae, (or Ova, as we think they are) hall drop off from the Tetis, it would more probably fall into the Cavity of the Abdomen, than light jut pat in the mouth of the Tuba. Secondly, That when it is received by it, its duct is o narrow, that 'tis hard to conceive how it can pas by it.

As to the firt; the ame objection may lie againt the ue of the Oviduct or Infundibulum in Hens, for neither in them does it join quite cloe
to the Ovarium, (as Swammerdam, &c. truly oberves) and yet it is certain that the Vitelli or little Yelks (or rudiments of the Eggs) do all pas by them to the terus. The ame, Swammerdam oberves alo in Frogs, in one of whom there are many hundreds of Eggs, which all pas one after another from the Ovarium by the Oviduct or Infundibulum, and yet the mouth of the Oviduct is almot two fingers breadth from the Ovarium, and beides is immovable, whereas the Tubae in Women are at liberty (and are more than long enough) to embrace the Ovarium with their orifice: and we mut believe that they do o when a conception is made; for it is not improbable that when all the other parts of the Genital are turgid in the act of Copulation, thee Tubae alo may be in ome meaure erected, and extend their opened mouth to the Teticle, to impregnate the Ova with the Seminal air teaming through their duct, and if any one be fecundated and eparate, to receive it afterwards by its orifice.

As to the econd objection, which urges the narrownes of thee Tubae; He that coniders the traitnes of the inner orifice of the Womb, both in Maids and in Women with Child, and yet oberves it to dilate o much upon occaion as to permit an egres to the Child out of the Womb, cannot wonder that to erve a neceary end of Nature the mall duct of the Tubae hould be o far widen'd as to give paage to an Ovum, eeing its proportion to their duct is many times les than of the Child to the uual largenes of the aid orifice.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII.
Of the Uterus or Womb, and its Neck.
div.p: HAving treated of the Vaa praeparantia (o called) that bring nourihment to the Tetes or Ovaria, as alo of thee and their Ova, and latly of the Tubae through which the Ova pas to the terus; we now come to the terus it elf which receives the Ova, and in which the conception is formed, and the Foetus nourihed till it acquire its due maturity and be fit for the birth.

The terus or Womb is uually divided into four parts, the Furdus or bottom, Os internum or Cervix, the Vagina, and the Sinus pudoris or outward Privity. Of each of thee in order. And firt of the Fundus.

This in a pecial manner is called the Womb,Its name
becaue all the ret eem to be made for its ake. It is alo called the Matrix, from its being as a Mother to conerve and nourih the Foetus; and likewie triculus from tris a Bottle.

It is eated in the Hypogatrium or lowet part of the Abdomen, Situation in that large hollow that is called Pelvis, and is formed out of the Oa Ilii, the Hip, the Oa pubis, and the Os acrum. In this Cavity it is placed between the Bladder and the treight Gut; o that Man being bred betwixt pis and dung, if he would but conider his origine, might hence draw an argument of humility.
Its hindmot part is looe,Connexion. that it might be extended as the Foetus encreaeth. But its ides are tied fat by two pairs of Ligaments.

The firt pair are further from the Os internum, Ligaments. and are broad, ariing from the Peritonaeum. They have a membranous, looe and oft ubtance, and for their hape are reembled to Bats wings. They tie the ides of the Fundus, the Tetes and a good part of the Tubae together, and are faten'd to the Oa Ilii, whereby the Womb is kept from falling down. But if they be either immoderately relaxed, or by any violence broken, then the Womb decends and ometimes falls out (turning inide outwards) if the ubtance of the Womb happen to be relaxed alo.

The econd pair arie nearer to the inner orifice of the Vagina, about where the Tubae do, and are called the round Ligaments, or worm-like. From their origine which is broad, they acend on each ide between the duplicature of the Peritonaeum towards the Groins, and running out of the Cavity of the Abdomen become round, and then pas obliquely above the Os pubis towards the fat that is plentifull there (and makes the Mons Veneris) in which they terminate near the Clitoris, being divided into many parts. They conit of a double Membrane, the inner whereof has all orts of Veels, Nerves Arteries, Veins and Vaa lymphatica; and are about a pan long. Vetingius, Diemerbroeck, &c. ay that they receive a mall Seminal veel from the Tetes and Tubae, which they conduct to the Clitoris into which they are inerted, and ought rather to be accounted Vaa deferentia than Ligaments. So that what Women emit from about the Clitoris in copulation, they think to be true Semen conducted hither by thoe eminal ducts. But de Graef denies any uch ducts, and affirms that thee Ligaments reach
not the Clitoris, but are terminated in the aforeaid fat. And that humour which Women emit (ometimes) he thinks doth iue out of the Lacunae in the orifices of the Vagina and urinary paage, or alo from the Meatus's in the neck of the Womb. Which humour is upplied to the former parts from the thick and membranous body that is about the urinary paage; and to the latter from the nervoe-membranous ubtance of the neck of the Womb. And indeed who can think Nature o prodigal of o pirituous and noble a liquor as Seed, as to ordain it to be hed at the orifice of the Pudendum, and o to be quite lot, and never mixed with the Mans, which is ejected into the bottom of the Womb? But we have above denied all Seed to Women; and therefore believe that the liquor they emit is only for the lubricating of the Vagina to caue the greater pleaure in coitu. But to this purpoe more before.

It hath two Membranes. Membranes. The outer is trong and double, ariing from the Peritonaeum: the inner, being proper, is fibrous and more porous. Betwixt thee Membranes there is a certain carnous and fibrous contexture, which in Women with Child, together with the aid Membranes, does imbibe o much of the nutritious humours that then low thither, that the more the Foetus encreaeth, the more flehy, fibrous and thick doth the Womb grow; o that in the lat months it becomes an inch thick, and ometimes two fingers breadth, though it be extended to o much greater compas than it has when a Woman is
not with Child. And yet (which is trange) within ixteen or twenty days after a Woman is brought to Bed, it becomes as thin as before (viz. about half a fingers breadth) and the whole contracts into o little a compas as to be held in ones hand.
In Virgins it is about two fingers breadth broad,Bignes. and three long. In thoe that have lain with a Man it is a little bigger, and omething larger yet in thoe that have born Children.
In hape it is omething like a Pear,Figure. only a little • lattih above and below. But in Women with Child it becomes more round.

In Maids its Cavity is o mall that it will hardly hold a large hazel nut.Cavity. In thoe that have had Children it will hold a mall walnut. It is divided into no Cells as it is in mot viviparous Brutes, but only into the right and left ide by a Suture or line that goes lengthways, much like that in a Man's Cod. Its Cavity is not quite round, but jets out a little towards each ide; which jetting ome call its Horns, but improperly: for though Galen (and many after him) having never diected any Woman, preuming that their Womb was like that of other viviparous Creatures, attributed Cornua thereto, yet in truth they have none, but the Tubae Fallopianae (as was noted before) anwer to them and do their office. Only in Brutes (viz. uch as have Cornua) the conception is always formed in the Cornua, as being the greatet part of the terus (which from the very orifice of its Fundus is preently divided into them, as when one parts the forefrom the middle finger as wide as one can) but very rarely in the Tubae in Women, but mot
an end in the Fundus it elf. Of which more in Chap. 30.

Its Arteries pring partly from the Spermatick or Praeparantes, Arteries. and partly from the Hypogatrick. Thee two Arteries do on each ide by a notable branch inoculate one with the other. And both their branches that run on one ide the Womb, do inoculate with thoe of their own tock on the other. Which may plainly be een by blowing into the trunk of either of them on which ide you will, for then the branches on the other ide will be puffed up, as well as thoe on that ide you blow.

They run along the Womb not with a treight or direct coure but bending and winding, that they may be extended without danger of breaking when the Womb is enlarged to o great a bulk by the Foetus. By thee Arteries it is that the monthly Coures flow, in greatet quantity out of thoe that open into the terus it elf, but in leer out of thoe branches that reach and open into the Cervix or neck of the Womb, and in leat (if at all) out of the Vagina. Now whether the Bloud be ent forth this way at uch times only from the two great quantity of it; or whether at uch tated eaons there is alo a fermentation of the Bloud whereby the orifices of the Arteries are unlocked, is a controverie of two large conideration for this place. We will only ay that the latter is more probable, becaue when a Woman feeds high, and o breeds much Bloud, they flow never the ooner (though it may be in greater quantity) and when he ues the greatet abtinence and parenes of diet (if he be healthfull) they will be never the longer of coming. So
that when through uch effervecency the Bloud flows plentifully into the Uterine veels, and the Veins of the Womb being too few (for they are fewer than the Arteries) to return it all back again by the circulation, it burts forth of the extremities of the Arteries o long, till the too great quantity of the Bloud be leen'd and the fermentation ceaes, which it does after three or four days, and o the flux tops till the next period. In Women with Child they eldom flow, becaue then the redundant Bloud is betowed on the nourihment of the Foetus: and it is the wanting of the Menes at the uual eaon, that commonly gives Women the firt Item of their having conceived. But of this alo more in Chap. 30.

The Veins do likewie pring from the Praeparantes and from the Hypogatrick.Veins. There are many anatomoes of thee Veins one with another, (as there was noted of the Arteries) but epecially in the ides of the terus, which do more readily appear by blowing of them up, than thoe of the Arteries above poken of. The Bloud brought hither by the Arteries, that is not pent on the ordinary nutrition of the Womb, or is not cat out when the Menes flow, returns by thee Veins back to the Heart.

It has Nerves from the Plexus meenterii maximus of the Intercotal pair,Nerves. and from the lowet Plexus of the ame. As alo from the Nerves of Os acrum. And the ame run alo to the Tetes or Ovaria. Now it is thee Plexus of Nerves that are chiefly affected in the Hyterical paion, or Fits of the Mother. For thee Fits are meerly Convulive, and often happen without any fault of the Womb at all. And that ymptom that in
uch Fits is uual, namely when omething like a Ball eems to rie from the bottom of the Belly and to beat trongly about the Navel (which is uually taken by Women for the riing of the Womb or Mother) is nothing but the convulion of thee Plexus of Nerves: which one will the rather believe, when he coniders that ome Men are afflicted with the ame ymptom. Of which ee more in Dr. Willis (in Cerebr. anat. p. 201.) who derives the pain of the Colick alo from the ame caue.

p.U:
ays there are many Lympheducts that creep through the outer ubtance of the
terus, Lympheducts. which one after another meeting into one empty themelves into the common Receptacle: And thee he ays, Bartholin mitakes for Venae lacteae.

div.p:
The ue of the Womb is to receive into its capacity the principles of the formation of the Foetus,
e. to afford it nourihment, to preerve it from injuries, and at length when it is grown to maturity and requires the light and a freer air, to expell it forth.

The Cervix or Os internum of the Womb being contiguous to it and coming betwixt it and the Vagina, The neck of the Womb. we will treat of it in this Chapter. It eems to be a part of the Fundus or of the Womb properly o called, only it is much narrower, for its Cavity is no wider in Virgins than a mall Quill, and in Women with Child its inner orifice doth either quite cloe its ides together, or is daub'd up with a limy yellowih humour, o that nothing can then enter into the Womb, unles in very lutfull Women it be ometimes open'd
in uperfoetation. It is an inch or more in length. Its Cavity as it opens to the Vagina is compared to the mouth of a Tench; Galen likens it to the Glans of a Man's Penis; for its Cavity is not round, but long and tranvere. It is wrinkled, and has many mall ducts opening into it, out of which one may pres a pituitous erous matter. It has the ame Membranes and the ame Veels with the terus it elf. De Graef ays that amongt its wrinkles he has often oberved Hydatides or little watry Bladders; and thinks that aboveaid erous matter erves only to moiten the Vagina, &c. and to excite to Venery.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII.
Of the Vagina, and its Contents, viz. the Hymen and Carunculae myrtiformes.
div.p: IT has its name Vagina or Sheath,I • s nam • . becaue it receives the Penis like a Sheath. It is called alo the door of the Womb, and its greater Neck, to ditinguih it from the leer, jut now decribed in the foregoing Chapter.

It is a oft and looe Pipe,Decription. uneven with orbicular wrinkles, of a nervous but omewhat pongy ubtance (which lut caues to puff up a little, that it may embrace the Yard more cloely) about even fingers breadth long, and as wide as the treight Gut: all which yet, both length, width and looenes differ in repect of age, &c. and as a Woman is inflam'd more or les with lut.
So alo the aforeaid wrinkles are much more numerous and cloe et in Virgins, and in Women that eldom accompany with a Man, and that have never born Children, than in thoe that have born many Children, and in Whores that ue frequent copulation, or thoe that have long laboured under the fluor albus, for in all thee three orts they are almot obliterated.

It has very many Arteries and Veins, ome of which inoculate one with another, and others not: By the Arteries that open into it do the Menes ometimes flow in Women with Child that are plethorick: for they cannot come from the Womb it elf, unles abortion follow, as ometimes it does. Thee Veels bring plenty of Bloud hither in the venereal congres, which heating and puffing up the Vagina encreaeth the pleaure, and hinders the Man's Seed from cooling before it reach the terus. They pring not only from the Hypogatrick but alo from the Hemorrhoidal, but thee latter run only through the lower part of the Vagina. Its Nerves pring from thoe that are inerted into the terus, but mot from thoe of Os acrum. De Graef ays that all along the Vagina there are abundance of pores, out of which a erous pituitous humour always flows to moiten it, but epecially in coitu, when it is ometimes offenive to the Man through its quantity, but encreaes the pleaure of the Woman, and is that which is taken for her Seed, as has been noted already.

Near its outer end, under the Nymphae (of which in the next Chapter) in its fore and upper part it receives the neck of the Urinary bladder encompaed with its Sphincter; oppoite
whereto in its hinder or lower part it is trongly knit to the Sphincter of the treight Gut.

In Virgins its duct is o trait, that at their firt congres with a Man they have commonly more pain than pleaure through the extenion of it by the Penis, whereby ome mall Veels break, out of which Bloud iues as out of a lain Victim (to peak with Diemerbro • ck:) unles we hould rather think that the Bloud proceeds from the rupture of the Hymen, which we now come to decribe.

The Hymen is a thin Nervous membrane interwoven with carnous Fibres,Hymen. and endowed with many little Arteries and Veins, pread acros the duct of the Vagina, behind the inertion of the neck of the Bladder, with a hole in the midt that will admit the top of ones little finger, by which the Menes flow. It is otherwie called the Zone or Girdle of Chatity. Where it is found in this form decribed, it is a certain note of Virginity; but upon the firt admiion of a Man's Yard it is necearily broke and bleeds, which Bloud is called the Flower of Virginity; and of this the holy Text makes mention in Deuteron. 22. veres 13.— 21. And when once it is broke, it never cloes again.

But though a Bridegroom when he finds thee igns of Virginity may certainly conclude he has married a Maid; yet it will not follow on the contrary, that where they are wanting, Virginity is alo wanting. For the Hymen may be corroded by acrimonious fretting humours flowing through it with the Menes, or from the falling out or inverion of the terus or the Vagina at
leat, which ometimes happens even to Maids. Or if a Maid be o indicreet as to become a Bride while her Coures flow or within a day after, then both the Hymen and the inner wrinkled Membrane of the Vagina are o flaggy and relaxed, that the Penis may enter glibly without any lett, and o give upicion of Unchatity, when indeed he's unblameable aving for her imprudence to marry at that eaon.

Sometimes in elderly Maids the Hymen grows o trong that a Man is glad to make many eays before he can penetrate it. Yea in ome naturally it is quite cloed up, and thee by this means having their Menes topt, are in great peril of their life if they be not relieved by Surgery, viz. opening it with ome harp Intrument.

Cloe to the Hymen lie the four Carunculae myrtiformes, Carunculae myrtiformes. o called from their reembling Myrtleberries. The larget of them is uppermot, tanding jut at the mouth of the urinary paage which it huts after water is made. Oppoite to this in the bottom of the Vagina there is another, and on each ide one, o that they tand in a quare. But of thee there is only the firt in Maids; the other three are not indeed Caruncles, but little knobs made of the angular parts of the broken Hymen roll'd into a heap by the wrinkling of the Vagina, according to Riolanus and Diemerbroeck. Thee three when the Vagina is extended in a Womans labour, loe their aperity and become mooth, o that they diappear, untill it be again contracted to its natural traitnes.

De Graef affirms, that the Vagina near its outer orifice has a Sphincter mucle almot
three fingers broad, that upon occaion contringes or contracts it. So that he ays Men and Women need not be olicitous concerning the Genitals being proportionable one to the other; for the Vagina is made o artificially (affabrè is his word) that it can accommodate it elf to any Penis, o that it will give way to a long one, meet a hort one, widen to a thick one, contringe to a mall one: o that every Man might well enough lie with any Woman, and every Woman with any Man.] Thus he.

Having thus decribed the parts of the Vagina, its ue is eaily declared to be, to receive the Man's Yard being erect, to direct and convey the Seed into the Womb, to erve for a Conduit by which the Menes may flow out, and to afford a paage to the Foetus in its birth, and to the Afterbirth.

div.head: CHAP. XXIX.
Of the Pudendum muliebre, or Woman's Privity.
div.p: THE parts that offer themelves to view without any diduction are the Fiura magna or great chink, with its Labia or Lips, the Mons Veneris and the Hairs. Thee parts are called by the general name of Pudenda, becaue when they are bared they bring pudor or hame upon a Woman.

The great Chink is called Cunnus by Galen, Fiura. à
< in non-Latin alphabet > to conceive; by Hippocrates, Natura. It is alo called Vulva, Porcus, Concha, and by many other names that fancy has impoed upon it.

It reaches from the lower part of Os pubis to within an inch of the Anus: being by Nature made o large, becaue the outward Skin is not o apt to be extended in travail as the membranous Vagina and Collum minus are. It is les and cloer in Maids than in thoe that have born Children. It has two Lips, which towards the Pubes grow thicker and more full or protuberant, and meeting upon the middle of the Os pubis make that riing that is called Mons veneris, the Hill of Venus, which all thoe that will war in the Camp of Venus mut firt acend.

Its outward ubtance is Skin covered with Hair,Mons veneris. as the Labia are, which begins to grow here about the fourteenth year of age.
