The inner ubtance of this Hill, which makes it bunch o up, is mot of it fat, and erves for a oft Cuhion as it were in copulation to hinder the Oa pubis of the Man and Woman to hit one againt the other, for that would be painfull and diturb the venereal pleaures. Under this fat lies that Mucle that we poke of from de Graef in the lat Chapter, that contringes the orifice of the Vagina, and prings from the Sphincter ani.
By a little drawing aide the Labia there then appear the Nymphae and the Clitoris.

The Nymphs are o called becaue they tand next to the Urine as it pouts out from the Bladder,Nymphae. and keep it from wetting the Labia. They are called alo < in non-Latin alphabet > or Wings. They are placed
on each ide next within the Labia, and are two carnous and oft productions, beginning at the jointing of the Oa pubis or upper part of the Privity (where they are joined in an acute angle, and make that wrinkled membranous production that clothes the Clitoris like a Praeputium or Foreskin) and decending, cloe all the way to each other, reaching but about half the breadth of the orifice of the Vagina and ending each in an obtue angle. They are almot triangular, and therefore, as alo for their colour, are compared to the thrills that hang under a Cock's throat.

They have a red ubtance,Their ubtance. partly flehy, partly membranous; within oft and pongy, looly compoed of mall Membranes and Veels, o that they are very apt to be ditended by the influx of the Animal pirits and Arterial bloud. The Spirits they have from the ame Nerves that run through the Vagina, and Bloud from that branch of the inner Iliacal artery that is called Pudenda: Veins they have alo from the Venae pudendae which carry away the Arterial bloud from them when they become flaccid. They are larger in grown Maids than in younger, and larger yet in thoe that have ued Venery or born Children. They never according to nature reach above half way out from between the Labia.
Their ue is to defend the inner parts, e. to cover the urinary paage, and a good part of the orifice of the Vagina. And to the ame purpoes erve the Labia above decribed.

Above betwixt the Nymphae in the upper part of the Pudendum does a part jet out a little that is called Clitoris, Clitoris. from < in non-Latin alphabet > , that ignifies laciviouly
to grope the Pudendum. It is otherwie called Virga, for it anwers to a Man's Yard in hape, ituation, ubtance, repletion with pirits and erection, and differs from it only in length and bignes. In ome it grows to that length as to hang out from betwixt the Lips of the Privity: yea there are many tories of uch as have had it o long and big as to be able to accompany with other Women like unto Men, and uch are called Fricatrices, or otherwie Hermaphrodites; who it is not probable are truly of both Sexes, but only the Tetes fall down into the Labia, and this Clitoris is preternaturally extended. But in mot it jets out o little as that it does not appear but by drawing aide the Labia.

It is a little,Its ubtance. long and round body, coniting (like a Man's Penis) of two nervous and inwardly black and pongy parts, that arie on each ide from the bunching of the Os Ichium, and meet together at the jointing or conjunction of the Oa pubis. It lies under the fat of Mons Veneris, in the top of the great fiure. In Venery by means of the two nervous bodies it puffs up, and traitening the orifice of the Vagina contributes to the embracing of the Penis the more cloely.

Its outer end is like to the Glans of a Man's Yard,Glans. and has the ame name, as alo Tentigo. And as the Glans in Men is the eat of the greatet pleaure in copulation, o is this in Women: whence it is called Amoris dulcedo and oetrum Veneris. It has ome reemblance of a Foramen, but it is not pervious. It is mot of it covered with a thin Membrane from the conjunction of the Nymphae, which for its likenes to the Praeputium in Men is alo called o.

The Clitoris has two pair of Mucles belonging to it.Mucles. The upper are round and pring from the Bones of the Coxendix, and paing along the two nervous bodies above-decribed are inerted into them. Thee by traitning the roots of the aid bodies do detain the Bloud and Spirits in them, and o erect the Clitoris, even as thoe in Men do the Penis. The other arie from the Sphincter ani, and are thoe we mention'd above in the end of the foregoing Chapter: for though they have been thought to erve for the erection of the Clitoris, yet we think with de Graef that they rather contribute to the puring up or contringing the outer orifice of the Vagina.
It has Veins and Arteries from the Pudendae, Veels. and Nerves from the ame origine with the Vagina, which are pretty large.

Its ue may be known from what has already been dicoured. And we will note further, that in ome Eatern Countries it ues to be o large, that for its deformity and the hindrance it gives to copulation, they ue to cut it quite out, or hinder its growth by earing it, which they improperly call Circumciion.

list.head: The Explanation of the Table. Figure I. Repreenteth the Genital parts of a Woman taken out of the Body, and placed in their natural ituation.
list.item: AA The trunk of the great Artery.
BB The trunk of the Vena cava.
C The right Emulgent vein.
D The left Emulgent vein.
E The right Emulgent artery.
F The left Emulgent artery.
GG The Kidneys.
HHHH The reters cut off.
I The right Spermatick artery.
K The left Spermatick artery.
L The right Spermatick vein.
M The left Spermatick vein.
NN The Iliack arteries.
OO The Iliack veins.
PP The inner branches of the Iliack artery.
QQ The outer branches of the Iliack artery.
RR The inner branches of the Iliack vein.
SS The outer branches of the Iliack vein.
TT The Hypogatrick arteries carried to the Womb and Vagina.
UU The Hypogatrick veins accompanying the aid arteries.
XX The branches of the Hypogatrick artery tending to the urinary Bladder.
YY The branches of the Hypogatrick vein carried to the Bladder.
ZZ Portions of the mbilical arteries.
a The Fundus uteri cloathed with its common Coat.
bb The round Ligaments of the Womb as they are joyned to its Fundus.
cc The Tubae Fallopianae in their natural ituation.
ddd The Fimbriae or jags of the Tubae
ee The Foramina or hollows of the Tubae.
ff The Teticles in their natural ituation.
g A portion of the treight Gut.
h The neck of the Womb, diveted of its common Coat, that the Veels may be better een.
i The fore-part of the Vagina of the Womb, freed from the urinary Bladder
k The urinary Bladder contract ••
ll The Bloud-veels running through the Bladder.
m The Sphincter mucle contringing the neck of the Bladder.
n The Clitoris.
oo The Nymphae.
p The urinary paage.
qq The Lips of the Pudendum.
r The orifice of the Vagina.

list.head: Figure II.
list.item: Exhibiteth a Woman's Teticle or Ovarium with the end of the Tuba annexed to it.
A The Teticle opened lengthways in its lower part.
BB Eggs of divers bignes contained in the membranous ubtance of the Tetes.
CC The Bloud-veels in the middle of the Tetes, proceeding plentifully from its upper part, as they run to the Eggs.
DD The Ligament of the Teticles, whereby they are knit to the Womb, cut off.
EE A part of the Tuba Fallopiana cut off.
F The Cavity of the Tuba cut off.
GG The hole that is in the end of the Tubae.
H The leavy ornament of the Tubae.
I The leavy ornament of the Tubae knit to the Tetes.

div.head: CHAP. XXX.
Of a Conception.
div.p:
HAving decribed all the parts that erve for Generation both in Man and Woman; order would, that we hould peak of the efficient caues, matter or principles from whence that which is generated by and in them, doth proceed. And in the firt place there occurs the Man's Seed, which is the active principle or efficient caue of the Foetus; but when we dicoured of the Tetes, we hewed what the matter of it was, viz. Arterial bloud and Animal pirits; and as to the manner of its • ecundating the Ovum, we omit that as being too philoophical for this place. In the next place therefore we mut come to the matter or paive principle of the Foetus, and this is an Ovum impregnated by the Man's Seed. And here becaue in Women it cannot be oberved by what degrees and in what time an Ovum in the Ovarium or Tetis becomes a Conception in the
terus, we mut be forced to gues at that by the analogy in other Creatures. To this purpoe Dr. Harvey de generatione Animalium is worthy to be read of the curious; epecially concerning the manner and order of the generation of the parts of a Chicken in an Hens Egg, in his Exercit. 56. But when he comes to apply this to the Conceptions of viviparous Animals, being ignorant that there was any formal Ovum pre-exiting in them, and only then ecundated, he runs into great errours and odd notions about Conception: imagining
an analogy betwixt the Brain's forming its Phantams or Conceptions, (which he calls Animal) and the Wombs forming hers, which he calls Natural. He rightly indeed rejects the Hypotheis of the Womans having true Seed, as alo the notion that the Man's Seed is any part of the Conception: but then he gives an unatisfactory account of it when he ays it is formed of the primeval albugineous humours that tranude into the Cornua in Brutes or terus in Women, after they are impregnated or matur'd, as he peaks. I hall not therefore reheare the hitory of generation in Harts that he has given us, for an analogical explication of that in Women; but hall trancribe the obervations of the curious de Graef concerning the generation of Rabbets, as being more adapted to our purpoe.

p.q:
We made the firt trial, (ays he) on a female Rabbet that had not yet accompanied with the male. Diecting which we oberved a very wide Vagina and about eight fingers breadth long, which being opened lengthways, there tood out two narrow mouths in its upper part divided with a • milunar partition, namely the beginning of each Cornu: for the Womb in Conies is preently from the very Vagina divided into two parts, one of which bends towards the right hand, the other towards the left about three fingers breadth aunder, where they are preently contracted and continued with the Oviducts, which in thee Animals have a peculiar ituation (or make) becaue if you lightly blow up the Cornua thee will not well, nor the wind penetrate them becaue of ome looe Fimbriae or rags cloing like the valve
of the Gut Colon. Thee Oviducts being mall at their riing from the Cornua, for five fingers breadth run with a winding duct beyond the Teticles, widening more and more by degrees, and then they turn back towards them and end in the form of a Tunnel..... The Teticles are mall, but contain very many limpid Eggs, which being cut open there iued out a clammy liquor like the white of an Egg. This being premied,

We opened another half an hour after the coitus, the Cornua of whoe terus lookt a little redder, but the Ova in the Teticles were not yet chang'd, unles they had remitted a little of their clearnes: but neither in the Vagina nor in the Cornua could we perceive any Seed or any thing like it.

About ix hours after the coupling we diected another, in whoe Teticles the Folliculi (or Caes) of the Ova inclined to rednes, out of which being pricked with a needle a clammy and clear liquor iued firt, but bloud followed, flowing out of the Sanguinary veels dipered through the Folliculi: We could find no Seed neither in this Coney.

Four and twenty hours after the coitus we opened another, in one of whoe Teticles we found three, and in the other five Folliculi of the Ova very much changed; for being before limpid and colourles, they were now turn'd duskih and of a faint red, in the middle of whoe uperficies a little Papilla (or Teat) as it were dicover'd it elf: when the Folliculi were cut open, there appear'd a little limpid liquor in their middle, a • d in their
circumference a certain thicker and reddih matter.

Twenty even hours after the coitus we inpected another, the Cornua of whoe terus with the Oviducts looked more bloudy, alo the extremity of the Oviduct did on every ide embrace the Tetes like a Tunnel; in the middle uperficies of the Folliculi, as in thoe before, there tood out little Papillae, through which by preing the ubtance of the Teticles there iued a limpid liquor, which was followed by another redder and thicker. Opening the Cornua of the Womb we found no Eggs, but the inner wrinkled tunicle of the Cornua was a little more tumid.

Eight and forty hours after the coitus we examin'd another, in one of whoe Teticles we found even, in the other three Folliculi changed, in whoe middle the Papillae were omething more eminent, through which, by preing the ubtance of the Teticles, there iued a little liquor like the white of an Egg, but the remaining reddih ubtance of the Ova, being now become omething thicker, was not o eaily preed forth as in thoe before.

Two and fifty hours after the coitus we viewed another, in one of whoe Teticles we found one, in the other four Folliculi altered; cutting open which we found a glandulous-like matter, in the middle of which there was a little Cavity, wherein finding no notable liquor, we begun to upect whether or no their limpid ubtance, which is contained in proper Membranes, were burt forth or expelled: wherefore we earched carefully both the Oviducts and the Cornua, but
we could find nothing; only the inner tunicle of the Cornua being much pufft up hined.

Seventy two hours (or three days and nights) after the coitus we inpected another, which exhibited a far other and mot wonderfull change; for the Infundibulum did embrace the Teticles on every ide mot cloely, which being pull'd off we found in the Teticle of the right ide three Folliculi a little greater and harder, in the middle of whoe uperficies we aw a tubercle with a little hole in it like a Papilla; but diecting the aid Caes through the middle, their Cavity was quite empty; wherefore we earched the ways through which the Ova mut pas, again and again, and found in the middle of the right Oviduct one, and in the outer end of the Cornu of the ame ide two very mall Eggs, little bigger than mall pins heads, which notwithtanding their mallnes are cloathed with a double Coat; out of thee Eggs being pricked there iued a mot limpid liquor...... In the very beginning of the Cornu of the left ide we found only one Egg, jut like thoe mall ones of the other ide: whence it is clear that the Ova excluded out of the Tetes are ten times les than thoe that yet tick in the Tetes; which eems to us to come to pas inamuch as thoe that are till in the Tetes contain as yet another matter, namely that of which the glandulous ubtance of the Caes is made.

The fourth day from the coitus we opened another, in one of whoe Teticles we found four, in the other three Globules or Caes emptied; and in the Cornua of the repective ides
we found as many Eggs, greater than the former, which did not tick in the Oviducts or beginnings of the Cornua, but were now rolled on towards their middle: in their Cavity we beheld as it were another Egg wimming, far clearer than in the other before.....

The fifth day from the coitus we diected another, in whoe Ovaria or Teticles we told ix emptied Folliculi, that had each a notable Papilla, through whoe Foramen we eaily put an ordinary britle into their Cavity: we found alo the ame number of Eggs (bigger than thoe the day before) in divers parts of the Cornua, in which they lay o looely, that by blowing only, one might drive them this way or that way. The inner tunicle of thee (or the Egg within an Egg as it were) was become yet more conpicuous.

The ixth day after the coitus we examin'd another, in one of whoe Teticles we oberv'd ix Caes emptied, and in the Cornu of the ame ide we could light of but only five Eggs near the Vagina, brought as it were upon a heap: but in the Tetiole of the other ide we found four Folliculi emptied, and in the Cornu of that ide only one Egg: The caue of which difference we uppoe to be, either becaue ome Eggs by the wave-like motion of the Cornua (not unlike the peritaltick motion of the Guts) being carried downwards towards the Vagina were driven forth; or becaue being conumed in the Folliculi they came not to the
terus; or light on ome other michance. Thee Eggs were as big as mall Peae.

The eventh day from the coitus we examin'd
another, in whoe Ovaria we found ome Folliculi emptied that were greater, redder and harder than the foregoing, and aw as many tranparent Tumours or Cells in divers parts of the terus; out of which being opened we turned Ova as big as Pocket-pitol Bullets, in which we beheld nothing but the Inner tunicle very conpicuous and a mot limpid humour. It is to be wondred at, that in o hort a pace of time the Eggs hould imbibe o great plenty of liquor, that whereas before they might eaily be taken out of the Womb, now they could very difficultly.

The eighth day from the Coitus we opened another, in the right Cornu of whoe terus we aw one, in the left two Cells; one of thee was almot twice as big as the other: for Nature doth ometimes o vary, that there are Eggs of divers bignes found not only in divers Animals of the ame pecies diected at the ame ditance from the coitus, but alo in one and the ame Individual. In the horns of the Womb being opened we aw the Eggs a little bigger than the day before, but all of them, their tunicles breaking, poured out their clear liquor before we could take them quite out: for which reaon we tried another diected likewie the eighth day after the coitus; the right Cornu of whoe terus we aw welled up into two, and the left into four tranparent Tumours or Cells, out of which that we might take the Ova we ued the greatet diligence and attention; but as oon as we came to them, their tunicles were o very tender that they burt as the former: which when we aw, the Eggs that remained
we boiled with the terus, whereby their contents harden'd like the whites of Hens Eggs. The inner ubtance of the Cells, on that ide whereon it receives the Hypogatrick veels, was become more tumid and red.

The ninth day after the coitus we diected another that was old; the Teticles of this were almot as big again as thoe of younger: in the right we aw two, in the left • ive Folliculi lately emptied, and beides thee, others that lookt very pale, which we judged to be thoe that had been emptied the coitus before this, although for the mot part they leave only ome palih points or pecks, to which the increae of the Teticles is owing. The Folliculi of the lat coitus were each beet with a Papilla, but the others were mooth. In the right Cornu there were two, and in the left five Cells, whoe ubtance being more rare and pellucid than the other parts of the terus was interwoven with many twigs of Veins and Arteries. Opening ome of thee Cells, we could ee the Ova, but could not take them out whole; wherefore being compelled to examine the content of the Eggs in the very hollow of the Cells, we found it clear like Crytal; in the middle whereof a certain rare and thin cloud was een to wim, which in other Conies diected likewie on the ninth day after the coitus for its exceeding finenes ecaped our ight. The inner ubtance of the Cells, namely that which receives the Hypogatrick veels, being more tumid than the ret, exhibited the rudiments of the Placentae.

The tenth day after the coitus we inpected
another, in whoe right Teticle we found one only Folliculus emptied, which by reaon of the Sanguineous veels dipered plentifully through it was redder and had a les Papilla; in the middle of this pale ubtance there appear'd as yet a very mall Cavity: but in the left Teticle we found ix uch Folliculi. In the Cornua of the terus we found alo o many Cells, namely one in the right and ix in the left ditant a fingers breadth one from another, in the middle of which Cells lay a rude mucilaginous draught of the Embryo like a little Worm one might alo plainly dicern the Placenta to which the Egg by means of its Chorion was annexed. The matter of the Eggs boil'd with the Womb hardned like the white of an Egg, and tated like the boiled congealed ubtance of the Eggs in the Teticles.

The twelfth day after the coitus we opened another, in one of whoe Teticles we found even, in the other five Folliculi emptied, and as many Cells in the Cornua much bigger and rounder than the foregoing, in the middle of which the Embryo was o conpicuous, that one might in a ort dicern its Limbs, in the region of whoe Breat two anguineous pecks and as many white ones did offer themelves to view: in the Abdomen there grew a certain mucilaginous ubtance inclining here and there to red. We could not dicern more in this hapeles little Animal becaue of its tendernes.

div.p:
The fourteenth day after the coitus we die •
ted another, the Cells of whoe terus we beheld to be yet greater, and the Sanguineous veels more, and more turgid: we alo noted
that the Cells the larger they grew, came alo nearer to one another, and their Intertices were leened. The Membranes Amnios and Chorion were knit together, which though they appear thicker and tronger, are yet more hard to be eparated from one another than in the Ova taken intirely out of the Womb; tearing thee we aw an Embryo with a great and pellucid Head, with the Cerebellum copped; its gogle Eyes, gaping Mouth, and in ome ort its little Ears might be dicovered alo. Its Back-bone was drawn out, of a white colour, which bending in about the Sternum reembled a Ship; by whoe ides mot lender Veels run, whoe ramifications were extended to the Back and Feet. In the region of the Breat two anguineous pecks greater than the foregoing exhibited the rudiments of the ventricles of the Heart; at the ides whereof were een two whitih pecks for Lungs. In the Abdomen being opened, there firt hew'd it elf a reddih Liver; then a white Body, to which was knit a mucilaginous matter like a writhed thread, being the rudiments of the Stomach and Guts. All which in thoe that we diected afterwards had acquired only a greater bulk and perfection. And therefore to prevent tediounes by repeating the ame things, we will on purpoe pas by all the other diections we made in this kind of Creature, excepting only one which we made the day before the kindling; that thoe things that in the former were only confuedly dicerned, may appear plain in this.

p.q:
At length on the twenty ninth day after the coitus we inpected another, that had kindled
ix weeks before, and in the coitus by which he was impregnated had voided all the thicker part of the Seed of the Male, which in ome meaure did reemble the conitence of a mot limpid jelly. In her Ovaria we found eleven little whitih Folliculi; and beides thee, others far les, little or nothing differing from the ubtance of the Tetes. The Folliculi of the Ova in the Tetes eem not to vanih wholly, but to leave a certain peck in them; whence it certainly comes to pas, that Conies, the oftner or the more young ones they bring forth, have the greater and whiter Teticles; o that one may gues by only viewing the Tetes, whether they have had many young ones or often. Having view'd the Ovarium we pat to the terus, which we found no longer ditinguih'd into Cells, but all along ditended like a Pudding; which was o agitated with a wave-like motion like the peritaltick of the Guts, that the young ones nearet the Vagina as yet included in their Membranes were excluded, and that o hatily, that if we had not cut out the whole terus, they had all certainly gone the ame way. The Womb was no thicker than when they are not with young, otherwie than we have aid it to be in Women. In its Cavity we aw eleven Foetus prawling, which were all o cloely coupled together by the Membrane Chorion (wherein all are everally involved) as if they had all been included in one and the ame Chorion—

div.p:
Thus much I thought fit to tranlate of that accurate Anatomits obervations concerning the generation of this ort of Animal, becaue it
gives o very great light into the manner of the generation of a humane Foetus. For there is an exact analogy betwixt them, abating ome circumtances; as Firt that in Women the Conception is not formed in the Cornua, eeing her Womb has none, nor in the Tubae very eldom and according to Nature, for they are only the Infundibula or Oviducts to convey the Ova from the Tetes to the Fundus uteri, though they bear ome reemblance to the Cornua in Brutes; I ay the Conception is not formed in thee, but in the Fundus uteri or Womb properly o called, whereinto the Ovum being received preently begins to well and grow bigger, and there appears as it were an Egg within an Egg, by means of the two Membranes with which it is cloathed; which Membranes are originally in the Ovum while it is in the Teticle, and imbibe the moiture that is ent now plentifully into the Womb, even as the little Yelks in Hens, &c. gather the white about them in the Oviduct and terus, which they have none of in the Ovarium; or as Seeds in the Ground do imbibe the fertile moiture thereof to enable them to prout. Another coniderable circumtance wherein they differ is the low procedure of the formation of the Foetus in Women in comparion of that in Conies now decribed. For eeing thee go with young but 29 or 30 days, and Women nine months, we mut imagine that the Embryo is as perfectly formed in the former on the tenth day as in the latter in the tenth week, or longer. But I ay abating thee or if there be any other uch like circumtances, there is o great a likenes betwixt the one and other, that without initing more on the matter or manner of the
Conception, we hall pas on to the decription of the parts that encompas the Foetus, then hew how it is nourihed, and latly what parts there are in a Foetus that differ from thoe in a Child born.

div.head: CHAP. XXXI.
Of the Placenta Uterina or Womb-liver, and Acetabula.
div.p: IN diecting the Womb of a Woman with Child the firt thing that offers it elf is the Placenta uterina or Womb-cake, otherwie called Hepar uterinum or Womb-liver, from the likenes of ubtance, and alo ue according to thoe that impoed the name.

Its ubtance is very like that of the Spleen,Its ubtance. only that is more brittle and this more tenacious, o that it cannot o eaily be eparated from the Veels. It is oft and has innumerable Fibres and mall Veels. Its Parenchyma is partly glandulous, by means of which Glands the eparation of humour that is made in it, is performed.

It is of very different hapes in everal Creatures,Shape and ituation. but in Women it is circular, yet with ome inequalities in its circumference. It is two fingers breadth thick in its middle (but thinner near the edges) and a pan or a quarter of a yard over from one ide to the other when the Foetus is come to maturity ready for the birth. On that ide next the Foetus it is mooth and omething hollowih like Navel-wort, and is knit to the
Chorion; but on that next the Womb it is very unequal, having a great many tubercles or bunchings whereby it adheres fat and immediately to the Womb. But to what part of it, is not agreed among Anatomits, ome affirming it to grow to the fore-part, ome to the hinder-part; ome to the left ide, others to the right. Dr. Wharton (aenting to Fallopius) ays, it always adheres to one of the two corners of the Womb (that anwer in ome manner to the Cornua in Brutes) whereinto the Foramen of the Tuba opens; o that he ays the aid Foramen is as it were the centre to the Placenta. De Graef thinks it is mot commonly faten'd there, but not always, becaue the Ovum for a while being looe in the Cavity of the terus, may be tumbled to this or the other part, and wherever it fixes, there is it join'd to the Womb by the Placenta.

When there is but one Foetus in the Womb it is but one,Number. but if there be Twins, then according to Dr. Wharton, &c. are there two Placentae, either ditinct in hape, or if they appear in the hape of one, then are they eparated by a Membrane one from the other; and a particular rope of Umbilical veels, is inerted into each from each Foetus.

It grows not out of the Womb originally,Origine. but its firt rudiments appear like a woolly ubtance on the outide of the outer Membrane that invets the Embryo (called Chorion) about the eighth or ninth week, upon which in a hort while a red, carnous and oft ubtance grows, but unequally and in little knobs, and then it preently thereby ticks to the Womb, and is very conpicuous about the twelfth or thirteenth week. Till now
the Foetus is encreaed and nourihed wholly by the appoition of the crytalline or albugineous liquor wherein it wims looe in the inner Membrane (called Amnios) having no Vaa umbilicalia formed, by which to receive any thing from the Placenta. But when it waxes bigger and begins to need more nourihment, the extremities of the Umbilical veels begin to grow out of the Navel by little and little, and are extended towards this Placenta, that out of it, as Plants by their Roots out of the Earth, they may draw a more firm nutritive juice, and carry it to the Foetus. But of this more in the 33d Chapter.

It has Veels from a double origine,Veels. ome from the Womb, and ome from the Chorion. The former are of four kinds, Arteries, Veins, Nerves and Lympheducts: all which though they be very large and conpicuous in the Womb, and are o even in that very place where the Placenta is joined to it; yet they end but the mallet Capillaries into the Placenta it elf (namely that half that is next the Womb.) Thoe that come from the Chorion are Arteries and Veins, and Dr. Wharton uppoes alo Lympheducts. The Arteries and veins that come from the Womb pring from the Hypoga • tricks, and alo that branch of the Spermaticks that is inerted into the bottom of the Womb. Thoe that come from the Chorion are the Umbilical veels of the Foetus. Of the ue of both the one and other we hall peak in Chap. 33. when we come to dicoure how the Foetus is nourihed, as alo of the ue of the Placenta it elf, of which we hall only oberve this further here, That after it is joined to the Womb, it ticks mot firmly to it for the firt months as unripe
Fruit do to the Tree: But as the Foetus becomes bigger, and riper and nearer to the birth, by o much the more eaily will it part from the Womb, and at length, like to ripe Fruit, after the Child is born, it falls out of the Womb and makes part of the After-birth.

It was an old tradition continued for many hundred years,Acetabula. that the Placenta adheres to the Womb by certain parts called Cotyledones or Acetabula. That there are uch in ome Creatures it is certain; Dr. Needham ays they are only properly o called in Sheep and Goats, in whom being with young the Uterine glands are hollow like a Saucer or an Acorn-cup, and are adapted to the little Prominences (or Digituli) of the Placentulae that grow on the Chorion; (though Diemerbroeck ay, that on the contrary the Placentulae are hollow (and o are truly the Acetabula) and the Uterine glands protuberant) and doubts not but thee names were firt given by thoe that diected thee kind of Creatures, and were afterwards applied in following ages to other Animals. So that no wonder there have been o great contets even about the ignification of the word Cotyledon (which is the Greek word for the herb mbilicus Veneris or Navelwort) and what that was that was o called in the everal Creatures that were aid to have them. But becaue uch Controveries are now obolete, and that 'tis generally confeed that Women have them not, we hall not in this Epitome run out into needles Diputes; but only oberve one ingular opinion of Diemerbro • ck, who acribes Cotyledones to Women. He thinks that each Woman (unles he go with Twins) has but one
Cotyledon, and that the foreaid Placenta uterina is it. And indeed it mut be confet that it reembles much the hape of that from which the Cotyledones have their name; and therefore eeing he formed this opinion to defend our great Mater Hippocrates, who had acribed them to Women, (that is, as Diemerbroeck expounds it, one Cotyledon to one Woman) we hall not oppoe it, but confes it to be, if not true, yet both ingenious and ingenuous.

div.head: CHAP. XXXII.
Of the Membranes involving the Foetus, and of the humours contained in them.
div.p: NEXT to the Placenta follow the two Membranes that involve the whole Foetus, Chorion the outer, and Amnios the inner: betwixt which two, after the Foetus is perfectly formed, Dr. Needham, &c. affirms there is a third, viz. Allantois, which in Women likewie includes the whole Foetus. Of each of thee in their order, with the liquors they contain.

The outer Membrane is called Chorion, Chorion. it is pretty thick, mooth on the inide, but without omething unequal or rough, and in that part of it that adheres to the Placenta and by it to the Womb, has very many Veels which pring from the Placenta it elf and the Umbilical veels. It is but one even when the Mother goes with Twins: for as in a Nut that has two Kernels in it, they are both included within the ame Shell, but
are each inveted in their proper Membrane; o Twins are both incloed in one Chorion, but have each a particular Amnios. It invets the Ovum originally, which Ovum being brought into the Womb and becoming a Conception, this Membrane imbibes the moiture that bedews the Womb plentifully at that time. For whiles the Conception is looe in the Womb, and has no Veels that reach out of it elf, nor is faten'd to any part, it mut have its increae after the ame manner as the Egg has in Hens, which while it is in the racemus or knot, attains no other ubtance but Yelk; and when it drops off from thence and decends through the Infundibulum, it receives no alteration; but when it comes into the Cells of the proces of the terus, it begins to gather a White, although it tick to no part of the terus nor has any Umbilical Veel; but (ays my Author, the immortal De generat. Animal. Exercit. 9. de generat. Ovi. Harvey) as the Eggs of Fihes and Frogs do without, procure to themelves Whites out of the water; or as Beans, Peae and other pule, and Bread-corn being teep'd in moiture well, and thence acquire aliment for the bud that is pringing out of them: o in like manner out of the plicae or wrinkles of the Womb (as out of a Dug or Womb-cake) does there an albugineous moiture low, whence the Yelk (by that vegetative and innate heat, and faculty wherewith it is endued) gathers and concocts its White. And therefore in thoe Plicae and the hollow of the Womb does there plentifully abound a liquor reembling the tate of the White. And thus the Yelk decending by little and little is encompaed with a White, till at lat in the
outmot terus having aumed Membranes and a Shell, it is perfected] Thus I ay does the Chorion imbibe that albugineous liquor that from the firt Conception increaes daily in it (and tranudes through the Amnios wherein the Embryo wims) till the Umbilical veels and the Placenta are formed, from and through which the Foetus may receive nourihment.

This liquor that it imbibes I take to be nutritious juice that ouzes out of the capillary orifices of the Hypogatrick and Spermatick arteries,Its liquor. and is of the ame nature with that which afterwards is eparated in the Placenta and carried to the Foetus by the Umbilical vein, and with that alo which abounds in the Amnios even till the birth. For the platick or vegetative virtue is only in the Ovum it elf, and the augmentation that the firt lineaments of the Embryo receive, is only by appoition of this nutritious albugineous juice. But this Membrane Chorion by that time the Umbilical Veels and Placenta are formed, is grown o dene and compact, that it is not capable of imbibing more; but that which at this time is in it, does in mall time tranude into the Amnios, and o it elf becomes empty, and gives way to the encreae of the Allantois, (which thenceforward begins to appear) whoe liquor augments daily as the Foetus grows nearer and nearer to the birth. This is my conjecture, which I ubmit to the cenure of the learned.

The Amnios is the inmot Membrane that immediately contains the Foetus. Amnios. It is not knit to the Chorion in any place ave where the Umbilical veels pas through them both into the Placenta. It is very thin, oft, mooth and pellucid,
and encompaes the Foetus very looly. It has Veels from the ame origines as the Chorion. It is omething of an oval hape.

Before the Ovum be impregnated,Its liquor. this Membrane contains a limpid liquor, which after the impregnation is that out of which the Embryo is formed. In it reides the platick power and the matter alo out of which the firt lineaments of the Embryo are drawn. But becaue its liquor is o very little, there tranudes through this Membrane preently part of that nutritious albugineous humour that is contained in the Chorion, which it had imbibed out of the terus, as was but even now hewn, and this Dr. Harvey calls Colliquamentum. And by the juxta-appoition or addition of this humour to the undicernible rudiments of the Embryo, it receives its encreae. But though the Amnios have its additional nutritious liquor at firt only by tranudation; yet when the Umbilical veels and the Placenta are formed, it receives it after another manner. For then being eparated from the Mothers Arteries by the Placenta and imbibed by the Umbilical veins of the Foetus, it paes directly to its heart, from whence being driven, a great part of it, down the Aorta, it is ent forth again by the Umbilical arteries, out of whoe capillaries dipered plentifully through the Amnios it iues into its Cavity, even as far more gros and vicid juices in taking a purge (or ometimes critically) ouze out of the mall mouths of the Arteries that gape into the Intetins.

There are ome that think they have oberved Venae lacteae to come directly to the Placenta, and that out of it (as out of the Glands in the Meentery)
there arie others that convey the Chyle into the Amnios: and this indeed were a plauible opinion, if it were grounded on any certain or frequent obervation of uch Lacteals, and were not rather invented to avoid ome difficulties with which the former opinion eems to be preed.

A third Membrane which invets the whole Foetus (according to Dr. Needham, Allantoides. &c.) is that called Allantoides, though improperly as to Women. For it is o called from its likenes to a Pudding ( < in non-Latin alphabet > , Farcimen) which indeed it does reemble in Sheep, Does, Hogs, &c. but in Women, as alo in Mares, it has the ame figure as the Chorion and Amnios, betwixt which it is placed in their whole circumference. Now though it mut be uppoed that this as well as the other two, is originally in the Ovum, yet there is no appearance of it till after the Umbilical Veels and Placenta are formed, and the albugineous liquor (o often mentioned) ceaes to be imbibed by the Chorion out of the terus. But aoon as the Foetus begins to be nourihed by the Umbilical veels, and the rachus is permeable, then preently this Membrane begins to hew it elf, containing a very thin liquor, which is the Urine of the Foetus brought into it by the rachus from its Bladder, and with which it is filled daily more and more till the birth. It is very thin, mooth, oft and yet dene. It may be known from the Chorion and Amnios by this, that they have numerous Veels dipered through them, but this has not the leat viible Vein or Artery. It is very hard to eparate the Chorion from it, becaue when it appears, the Chorion becomes void
of all liquor, and o claps cloe to it. But towards the birth of the Foetus it becomes o turgid with Urine, that the Amnios (immediately containing the Foetus) wims in it, and o may mot eaily be ditinguiht and eparated from it.

The liquor that it contains is (as has been aid) the Urine of the Foetus brought hither by the rachus. Its liquor. For aoon as the Foetus is perfectly formed, its Kidneys mut needs perform their office of eparating the Serum from the Bloud, for otherwie it would be affected with an Anaarca. I ay the Serum is eparated in the Kidneys and glides down from thence into the Bladder, in which it is found pretty plentifull when the Foetus is five or ix months old. Now it flows not out of the Bladder by its orifice, becaue at that time the Sphincter is too contracted and narrow, and if it hould pas that way, it would mix with that nutritious juice in which the Foetus wims in the Amnios, and wherewith, by taking it in by its Mouth, it is partly nourihed, and o would defile and corrupt it, and make it unfit for nourihment. Nature therefore has provided it another exit by the rachus, inerted into the bottom of the Bladder; which though after the Child is born it grow olid like a Ligament, like as the Vena umbilicalis does, yet while the Foetus is in the Womb it is always pervious, and conveys the Urine into the Allantoides that is placed betwixt the Chorion and Amnios, where it is collected and preerved till the birth.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIII.
Of the mbilical veels, and of the nourihing of the Foetus.
div.p: HAving opened the Membranes that enwrap the Foetus, The navel-tring. there appears the Navel-tring or Rope, which is membranous, wreath'd and unequal, ariing out of the middle of the Abdomen, (viz. the Navel) and reaching to the Womb-liver or Placenta, of a notable length, being three pans or half an Ell long, and as thick as ones finger. It was convenient to be o long and lax, that when the Foetus in the Womb grows trong, it might not break it by its prawling and tumbling about; and after it is born, the Secundines or After-birth might be drawn out the better by it.

The way that it paes from the Navel to the Placenta is very uncontant;Its ituation. for ometimes it goes up on the right hand to the Neck, which having encompaed, it decends to the Placenta, and ometimes it goes on the left hand up to the Neck, &c. Sometimes it comes not to the Neck at all, but goes firt a little up towards its Breat, and then turns round its Back, and from thence paes to the Placenta.
The Veels contained in this tring (and which are enwrapped in a common Coat called Funiculus or Intetinulum) are four,Veels. one Vein, two Arteries and the rachus.

The Vein is larger than the Arteries,Vein. and aries
from the Liver of the Foetus, (viz. out of its fiure) at the trunk of the Vena porta (of which it eems to be but a branch) and from thence paing out of the Navel it runs along the Funiculus to the Placenta, into which it is implanted by innumerable roots; but before it reaches it, it ends ome little twigs into the Amnios.

The Ancients that thought the Foetus was nourihed by the Mothers Bloud only,Its ue. taught the ole ue of this Vein to be, to carry Bloud from the Placenta to it: and ince it has been found out and believed that it is nourihed alo (if not only) by Chyle or Succus nutritius, ome have continued the ame office to this Vein, and think that the Chyle is brought by Lacteal veels ariing out of the Placenta, as (they ay) it was brought thither by the Mothers Lacteals. And indeed if any certain dicovery had been made of thee ame Lacteae, we hould have embraced this opinion as the mot probable. But we are not to form hypothees out of rational notions only, but much rather from what appears to the Eyes of the Diector. We do affirm therefore that the Umbilical vein erves for conveying to the Foetus the nutritious juice eparated in the Placenta from the Mothers Arteries. How this eparation is made, and how it is firt of all turned into Bloud, we hall conider by and by.
But together with this juice there returns o much of the Arterial bloud (that comes from the Foetus) as is not pent upon the nourihment of the Placenta, or of the Chorion and Amnios.

Beides this Vein which is common to all Creatures, there have been oberved in Whelps (and may perhaps in others) two mall Veins more
that pas directly from the mbilicus to the Meentery, as the other great one does to the Liver; which may trengthen the opinion that the Chyle or Succus nutritius is brought to the Foetus by the Sanguinary vein (or Veins) from the Placenta.

In the Funiculus are included alo two Arteries,Arteries. which are not both of them together o big as the Vein. They pring out of the inner Iliacal branches of the great Artery, and paing by the ides of the Bladder they rie up to the Navel, out of which they are conducted to the Placenta in the ame common cover with the Vein and rachus, with which they are twined and wreathed not unlike a Rope. I ay they are inerted into the Placenta, and with the Vein make a mot admirable texture, and net-like Plexus. Dr. Harvey ays, the Vein is conpicuous a pretty while before thee Arteries appear.

Bloud and Vital pirit are not carried by them from the Mother to the Foetus, Their ue. as many, from Galen, have taught; but on the contrary, Spirituous bloud is driven from the Foetus, by the beating of its Heart, to the Placenta and the Membranes for their nourihment; from which what Bloud remains, circulates back again in the Umbilical vein together with the Succus nutritius afreh imbibed by its capillaries dipered in the Placenta. But beides Arterial bloud, there flows out of the Navel by them part of the Succus nutritius that was imported by the Umbilical vein, namely that of it which is more cras and terrene, which by one circulation through the Heart (or it may be many) could not be changed into Bloud: this part I ay flows out by thee Arteries,
which by their branches that are dipered through the Amnios diimbogue it by their little Mouths into it; for what ue, hall be declared preently.

And here I hall trancribe a material objection with the anwer to it,How the veels pas through the membranes. out of Diemerbroeck. Obj. How can thee Veels (Vein and Arteries) when they have grown from the belly of the Foetus to that length as to reach the Membranes, penetrate and pas through them to the Placenta? Anw. This is done in the ame manner as the roots of Herbs, Shurbs and Trees penetrate into the hard Ground, yea often into thick Planks, Walls and Stones, (which water cannot enter) and root themelves firmly in them. For jut o the firt harp-pointed and mot fine ends of the Umbilical veels ininuate themelves by little and little into the pores of the Membranes (for the figuration of thoe pores are fitted for their entrance) and pas through them, and yet the liquors contained in thee Membranes cannot flow out by them: and when thoe Veels inhering in the pores grow more out into length, by little and little the aid pores are more and more widened, (according to the increae of the Veels) and are ineparably united unto and grow in them.

The fourth Umbilical veel is the rachus or Urinary veel,Urachus. and it is a mall, membranous, round Pipe, endued with a very trait Cavity, ariing from the bottom of the Bladder up to the Navel, out of which it paes along within the common cover, and opens into the Allantoides. It is more apparently pervious in many of the larger Brutes than it is in Man, in whom ome
have denied it any Cavity: but that it is hollow in him, is confirmed by many Hitories of perons adult, who having the ordinary urinary paage along the Penis topt, the paage in this Veel has been unlocked, and they have made water by the Navel, which could not have been imagin'd to have happen'd, if it had been originally a Ligament without any Meatus. Bartholin and others have affirmed that the rachus in Men reaches no further than the Navel; How then comes that humour into the Allantois that has perfectly the ame tate with the Urine in the Bladder? But their errour prung from hence, that they thought an humane Foetus had no Allantois, and that humour that is found in it, they thought had been contained in the Chorion. But this is in hort refuted above, but more fully and accurately by Dr. Needham, lib. de formato Foetu, cap. 3. As to the perviounes of the rachus I hall add this further, that in abortions of five or ix months old, the Bladder of the Embryo is always full of Urine, out of which if in the following months it hould not be emptied by the rachus, the Bladder would oon burt, eeing there is daily ome Serum eparated from the Bloud in the Kidneys, and ent to the Bladder; and the more the Foetus increaes, the more mut needs be eparated.
Its ue has been ufficiently declared in the preceding Paragraph;Its ue. as alo above, when we delivered the ue of the Allantoides, which we hall not repeat.

Thee four Veels (as has been aid above) have one common cover,Funiculus. which alo keeps each
of them from touching other. It is called Intetinulum, and Funiculus (by which it with its Veels is ometimes undertood.) It is membranous, round and hollow, indifferent thick, coniting of a double coat, (the inner from the Peritonaeum, and the outer from the Panniculus carnous.) Sometimes it elf only is wreath'd about like a Rope, the Veels included in it running treight along its Cavity; and ometimes they are wreathed together with it.

It has everal knots upon it here and there,Its knots. which Dr. Wharton thinks to be Papillae or little Glands through which the lacteal (or nutritious juice) ditils out of the capacity of the Funiculus into the Cavity of the Amnios. I cannot tell whether this be o or no, but that ue that doting Midwives make of them, to gues by their number how many Children more the Mother hall have, and by their colour, whether thoe Children hall be Male or Female, is mot ridiculous and upertitious.

When the Infant is born,How to tie the navel-tring and cut it off. this Navel-rope is ued to be tied, about one or two fingers breadth from the Navel, with a trong thread cat about it everal times, and then about two or three fingers breadth beyond the Ligature to be cut off. What is not cut off, is uffered to remain till it drop off of its own accord. Which the longer or horter while it is a doing, the longer or horter-liv'd, Women prophecy the Children to be.

There have been great diputes among both Philoophers and Phyicians,Of the nutrition of the Foetus. with what and by what way the Foetus is nourihed. Some affirm by Bloud only, and that received by the Umbilical
vein; others by Chyle only, received in by the Mouth: each of which are in an extream. The truth is, according to the different degrees of perfection that an Ovum paes from a Conception to a Foetus ready for the birth, it is nourihed diverly.

For firt,Firt, by appoition. aoon as an Ovum impregnated is decended into the Womb, it preently imbibes through its outer Membrane ome of that albugineous liquor that at this time plentifully bedews the internal uperficies of the terus; o that aoon as the firt lineaments of an Embryo begin to be drawn out of that humour contained in the Amnios, they preently receive increae by the appoition of the aid liquor filtrated out of the Chorion through the Amnios into its Cavity. And this ame liquor that thus encreaeth the firt rudiments of the Embryo is called by Dr. Harvey Colliquamentum (as was noted above.) That this way of nutrition or augmentation of the Embryo is poible, need not be doubted by him that coniders, that the Foetus of a Sow have no other poible way of being nourihed till he is near gone half with Pig; for even till then, aith Dr. Needham, the Chorion cleaves not to the Womb, but look as many Foetus as there are, there are o many Eggs as it were without Shells, neither ticking to the Womb nor to one another; but when one opens the Matrix, they all tumble out of their own accord. There are no Glandules, no Placenta. But the Chorion which is oft and porous, does like a Spunge imbibe or uck up the erous liquor that weats out of the inmot Membrane of the terus, to be afterwards wallowed by the Veins, (I uppoe
he means the mouths of the Umbilical vein, after the aid Vein is o perfectly formed as to receive it.) But of this more in the beginning of the foregoing Chapter.

But when the parts of the Embryo begin to be a little more perfect,2. By the umbilical vein. and the Chorion becomes o dene that not any more of the aid liquor is imbibed by it, the Umbilical veels begin to be formed, and to extend to the ide of the Amnios, which they penetrate, and both the Vein and Arteries pas alo through the Allantois and Chorion, and are implanted into the Placenta, that at this time, firt gathering upon the Chorion, joins it to the terus. And now the Hypogatrick and Spermatick arteries, that before pued out the nutritious juice into the Cavity of the terus, open by their orifices into the Placenta, where (whether by meer percolation through it, or by ome ort of fermentation alo, I will not determine, but) they depoite the aid juice, which is aborbed by the Umbilical vein, and by it conveyed firt to the Liver, then to the Heart of the Foetus, where the thinner and more pirituous part of it is turned into Bloud. But the more gros and terrene part of it decending by the Aorta enters the Umbilical arteries, and by thoe branches of them that run through the Amnios, is dicharged into its Cavity. They that will laugh at this paage of the nutritious juice, becaue it is made by this doctrine to chooe its way as if it were ome animal or even rational Creature, let them avoid the like treatment if they can while they deliver, that the Chyle paes immediately either from the Meentery, the Receptaculum or Ductus communis to the Placenta, when a Foetus is
in the Womb. 'Pray how hould the Chyle know, or the Lacteals by which it paes, that there is any Foetus in the Womb, that the one hould offer to go that way, and the other give it way to go thither at that time, whereas the paage is hut at all other times? yet this my Opponents maintain. As alo how comes the Chyle preently to turn its coure after the Foetus is born, and intead of decending to the
terus, acend to the Breats? What mechanical caue can be aigned to thee and many other the like Phaenomena? We mut therefore be content to reolve ome things into the admirable and unintelligible dipoal of our wie Creatour.

But there lies another objection againt this opinion, Becaue it allows none of the Mothers Bloud to be received by the Foetus through the Umbilical vein, but only Succus nutritius; how hould Bloud be firt bred in the Foetus, eeing it has Bloud, before the Liver or Heart, or any other part that conduce to anguification, are in a capacity to perform their office?

I confes it is inexplicable by me how Bloud hould be made o oon; but that it may be and is made, out of the Succus nutritius or Colliquamentum, without the mixture of any from the Mother, is apparent from the mot accurate obervations of Dr. Harvey concerning the order of the generation of the parts in a Chicken, (which from firt to lat receives nothing from the Hen.) Says he,De generat. Animal. exercit. 51. there appears at the very firt a red leaping Punctum or Speck, a beating Bladder, and Fibres drawn from thence containing Bloud in them. And as much as
one can dicern by accurate inpection; bloud is made, before the leaping peck is formed; and the ame is endowed with vital heat, before it is tirred by the Pule: and as the pulation begins in the bloud and from it; o at length, at the point of death it ends in it.—And becaue the beating Bladder and the anguineous Fibres that are produced from it, appear firt of all; I hould think it conentaneous to reaon that the bloud be before its receptacles; namely the content before its container; and that this is made for the ake of the other. He confees it to be a paradox, that bloud hould be made and moved, and endued with vital pirit before any anguifying or motive organs are in being; and that the Body hould be nourihed and increaed, before the organs appointed for concoction (namely the Stomach and Bowels) are formed: but neither of thee are greater paradoxes than that there hould be ene and motion in the Foetus before the Brain is compoed; and yet, ays he,Exercit. 57. The Foetus moves, contracts and tretches out it elf, when there is nothing conpicuous for a Brain but clear water. I ay if all thee unlikely things do certainly come to pas in an Egg, that has nothing to et the vegetative, or vital principle thereof on work, but the warmth of the Hen that its upon it; why hould we think it trange that nutritious juice impregnated with the vital pirits of the Arterial bloud, with which it circulated through the Mothers Heart (it may be more than once) hould be turned into bloud in an humane Foetus (fotered with uch kindly warmth in the Womb) though it neither receive any humour under the form of
bloud from the Mother, nor have it elf as yet any organs of anguification o perfect as to perform their office? But to proceed.

The groer nutritious juice being depoited by the Umbilical arteries in the Amnios, 3. By the Mouth. aoon as the Mouth, Gullet and Stomach, &c. are formed o perfectly that the Foetus can wallow, it ucks in ome of the aid juice, which decending into the Stomach and Intetins is received by the Venae lacteae, as in adult perons.
That the Foetus is nourihed this way, Diemerbroeck evinces by thee reaons.

p.q: 1. Becaue the Stomach of the Foetus is never empty, but is found poet of a milky whitih liquor; and uch like is contained even in its Mouth.

2. Becaue there are Faeces contained in the Intetins, (which Philoophers call Meconium) which the Infant aoon as 'tis born voids by tool. Without doubt thee are the excrements of ome aliment taken in by the Mouth.
3. Becaue the Stomach could not preently after the birth perform the function of concoction, if it had not at all been accutomed to it in the Womb.

div.p: His fourth reaon, uppoing the Foetus to be nourihed in part by the Mothers bloud, I hall not recite, becaue I think that to be an erroneous opinion, as I think to make appear by and by.

p.q: 5. Becaue the Infant aoon as it is born knows how to uck the Breat, which it could not be uppoed to be o dextrous at, if while it remained in the Womb it had taken nothing by uction.

div.p:
6. Becaue many Infants aoon as they are
born, before they have ucked any Breat, or taken any thing by the Mouth, vomit up a milky aliment: which therefore mut needs be received into their Stomach in the Womb. This he gives an intance of in one of his own Children.

Thee Arguments I think ufficient to prove what they are alledged for; but when • he would afterwards prove that the Foetus is alo nourihed by the Mothers bloud conveyed by the Umbilical vein, I think his reaons are invalid. For he ays it mut be o, firt, becaue the aid Vein is implanted into the Placenta; (but this is but begging the quetion, for 'tis neceary it hould be implanted into it though it receive nothing from it but nutritious juice.) Secondly, becaue of the great quantity of bloud that will iue out of the Umbilical vein, if one tie the Navel-rope and then open the aid Vein betwixt the Ligature and Placenta: for he ays there will flow out four times as much bloud as could be uppoed to be contained in the mall Arteries on that ide the Ligature next the Placenta. I anwer, that firt one would be well atisfied that the Ligature was made o trait, that there could no bloud pas through it from the Foetus to the Placenta. And econdly it cannot exactly be gueed how much bloud may be contained in the Foetus's Arteries in the Placenta, o as that one hould be certain that there does four times more flow out by the Vein. But latly, uppoe there do four times as much more bloud iue out of the Vein as is contained in the Foetus's Arteries that are on that ide the Ligature next the Placenta, and this bloud come from the Dam's Hypogatrick and Spermatick
arteries; I ay there will not only four times, but forty times as much iue therefrom, for all the bloud of the Dam might then be drawn out this way. Wherefore I think this experiment makes much more againt his opinion than for it. His third reaon is the neceity of it; becaue as the Foetus increaes, it needs much aliment, and its weak Bowels can concoct but little, it mut therefore have ome purera liment, and which is already concocted (he means bloud) to nourih it, and by its commixture to help forward the changing the aliment received by the Mouth into bloud. Anw. This reaon himelf invalidates in the next Paragraph,Anat. corp. hum. p. 367. where he confees that the Foetus in the Womb is nourihed in the ame manner as the Chicken in an Egg, which receives increae firt by the inner White (as he ditinguihes) by way of appoition; econdly it receives nourihment in by the Mouth from the outer White, and at the ame time its Umbilical veels enter the Yelk (to draw nourihment from thence) which, he ays indeed, reembles the Mothers bloud, but eeing it has not the leat form of bloud, why would it not be more plauibly aid that it is intead of the Succus nutritius that the Foetus in viviparous Animals receives by the Navel-vein? And eeing thee everal liquors are turned, part of them, into bloud in a Chicken, without any of the Hens bloud to ferment them (as he peaks;) why hould not the ame power be granted to the vegetative or animal oul of the Foetus in the Womb, without any aitance from the Mothers bloud? To which I hall add another Argument (out of Dr. Harvey) taken from Caearean births, when living Infants
are cut out of the Mothers Womb, after he is dead. For if it had its life and heat from the Mothers bloud; urely it hould die aoon as he at leat, if not ooner: for when death approaches, the ubordinate parts do languih and grow cold before the principal; and therefore the Heart fails lat of all. Wherefore the bloud of the Foetus would firt loe its heat, and become unfit for its office if it were derived from the Mothers Womb; eeing her Womb is detitute of all vital heat, before her Heart. But enough of this.

But ome may object, If the Foetus be nourihed by none of the Mothers bloud, why hould her Menes be topt all or mot of the while he is with Child? To which I anwer, that 'tis for the ame reaon that Nures that give uck commonly want them alo; for as in Nures the chyle paes in a great proportion to the Breats, whereby the bloud being defrauded of its due and wonted hare does not encreae to that degree as to need to be leened by the flowing of the Menes; o in Women with Child, there is o great a quantity of the Succus nutritius (which is only chyle a little refined and impregnated with vital pirit) that paes to the Placenta by the Hypogatrick and Spermatick arteries for the nourihment of the Foetus, that unles the Mother be very anguine, her Menes intermit after the firt or econd month.

I hall conclude therefore, that the Foetus is nourihed three everal ways, but only by one humour: firt by appoition of it whiles it is yet an imperfect, Embryo and has not the Umbilical veels formed; but after thee are perfected, it
then receives the ame nutritious juice by the Umbilical vein, the more pirituous and thin part whereof it tranmutes into bloud, and ends forth the groer part by the Umbilical artery into the Amnios, which the Foetus ucks in at its Mouth, and undergoing a new concoction in its Stomach is received out of the Intetins by the Venae lacteae, as is done after the birth.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIV.
What parts of a Foetus in the Womb differ from thoe of an adult peron.
div.p: HAving delivered the hitory of the Foetus, we will only further hew in what parts a Foetus in the Womb differs from an adult peron. And this we cannot do more exactly than in the manner that Diemerbroeck has reckon'd them, whom therefore we hall here tranlate, with little alteration.
This diverity, he aith, conits in the difference of magnitude, figure, ituation, number ue, colour, cavity, hardnes, motion, excrements and trength of the parts.
Now this diverity is conpicuous either in the whole Body, or in the everal Ventricles, or in the Limbs.
There is coniderable in the whole Body,
1. The littlenes of all the parts.
2. The reddih colour of the whole.
3. The oftnes of the Bones; whereof many are as yet gritly and flexible, and that by o much the more, by how much the Foetus is further from maturity.
In the Head there are everal differences. As
1. The Head in repect to the proportion of the ret of the Body is bigger, and the hape of the Face les neat.
2. The bones of the Skull are ofter, and the Crown is not covered with bone, but onely with a Membrane.
3. The bone of the Forehead is divided, as alo of the under Jaw: and the Os cuneiforme is divided into four.
4. The bone of the Occiput or hinder part of the Head is ditinguiht into three, four or five bones.
5. The Brain is ofter and more fluid, and the Nerves very oft.
6. The bones that erve the ene of Hearing are wonderfully hard and big.
7. The Teeth lie hid in the little holes of the Jaw-bone.

There is no les diverity in the Thorax •
For,

1. The Dugs well, and out of them in Infants new born whether Male or Female, a erous Milk iues forth ometimes of its own accord, ometimes with a light preure: yet there are no Glandules very conpicuous, but there is ome fahion of a Nipple.

2. The Vert • brae of the Back want their pinous procees, and are each one made of three ditinct
Bones, whoe mutual concoure form that hole whereby the pinal marrow decends.
3. The Heart is remarkably big, and its Auriculae large.

4. There are two unions of the greater Veels, that are not conpicuous in adult perons: viz. 1. The Foramen ovale, by which there is a paage open out of the Cava into the Vena pulmonaris jut as each of them are opening the firt into the right Ventricle, and the latter into the left Ventricle of the Heart. And this Foramen jut as it opens into the Vena pulmonaris has a Valve that hinders any thing from returning out of the aid Vein into the Foramen. 2. The Canalis arterious, which two fingers breadth from the bais of the Heart joins the Arteria pulmonaris to the Aorta. It has a pretty large Cavity, and acends a little obliquely from the aid Artery to the Aorta, into which it conveys the bloud that was driven into the pulmonary Artery out of the right Ventricle of the Heart, o that it never comes in the left Ventricle; even as that bloud that is ent out of the left Ventricle into the Aorta never came in the right, (except a little that is returned from the nutrition of the Lungs) but paed immediately into it out of the Vena cava by the Foramen ovale. So that the bloud paes not through both the Ventricles as it does after the Foetus is born, for then it mut have had its coure through the Lungs, which it cannot have, becaue they are now very dene and lie idle and unmoved. Yea they are o dene and heavy that if one throw them into water they will ink, whereas if the Foetus be but born and take only half a dozen breaths, they become o pongy and light that
they will wim. Which (by the way) may be of good ue to dicover whether thoe Infants that are killed by Whores, and which they commonly affirm were till-born, were really o or no. For if they were till-born the Lungs will ink, but if alive, (o as to breath never o little a while) they will wim.
5. The Gland Thymus is notably large, and conits as it were of three Glands.
In the lower Belly there are thee differences.
1. The Umbilical veels go out of the Abdomen.
2. The Stomach is narrower, yet not empty, but pretty full of a whitih liquor.
3. The Caul is hardly dicernible, being almot like a Spiders web.
4. The Guts are even times longer (or more) than the Body.
5. In the mall Guts the excrements are pituitous and yellow, but in the thick omewhat hard and blackih, ometimes greenih: the Caecum is larger than uual, and often filled with Fae • es.

6. The Liver is very large, filling not only the right Hypochondre, but extends it elf into the left ide, and covers all the upper part of the Stomach. It has a paage now more than in the adult called Canalis venous, which ariing out of the Sinus of the Por • a carries the greatet part of what is brought by the Umbilical vein directly and in a full tream into the Cava above the Liver; but aoon as the Infant is born, and nothing comes any longer by the aid Vein, this Canalis preently cloes, as the Vein it elf turns to a Ligament; as alo do the rachus and the two Umbilical arteries.
7. The Spleen is mall.
8. The Gall-bladder is full of yellow or green choler.
9. The Sweet-bread is very large and white.
10. The Kidneys are bigger and unequal in their uperficies, and look as if they were compounded of a collection of very many Glandules.
11. The Renes uccenturiati are exceeding large; they do not only border upon the Kidneys, as in the adult, but lie upon them, and embrace their upper part with a large Sinus as it were.
12. The Ureters are wide, and the Bladder ditended with Urine.
13. In Females the terus is depreed, the Tubae long, and the Tetes very large.
The difference in the Limbs conits
1. In the tendernes and oftnes of the Bones.
2. The little bones of the Writ and Intep are gritly and not firmly joyned together.

div.head: XXXV.
Of the Birth.
div.p: THE Foetus wimming in the liquor of the Amnios, and the Navel-rope being o long, it mut needs have cope enough to change its ituation, and that is the reaon that Anatomits differ o much about it. But according to Doctor Harvey its uual poture is thus.

p.q: Its Knees are drawn up to the Belly,The poture of the Foetus in the Womb. its Legs bending backwards, its Feet acros, and its hands lifted up to its Head, one of which it holds to the Temple or Ear, the other to the Cheek; where there are white pots on the Skin as if it had been rubb'd upon. The Backbone turns round, the Head hanging down towards its Knees. Its Head is upwards and its Face commonly towards the Mothers Back.]

div.p:
But towards the birth (ometimes a week or two before) it alters its ituation,At its birth. and tumbles down with its Head to the neck of the Womb, with its Feet upwards. Then the Womb alo ettles downwards and its orifice relaxes and opens. And the Foetus being now ill at eae prawls and moves it elf this way and that way, whereby it tears the Membranes wherein it is included, o that the Waters (as they call them) flow into the Vagina, which they make lippery for the eaier egres of the Infant: though ometimes the Membranes burt not but come forth whole, (as
they do commonly in Brutes.) At the ame time the neighbouring parts are looened and become fit for ditenion: the joyntings of the Os acrum and Pecten with the Coxendix, as alo of the Oa pubis are o relaxed, that they yield very much to the paage of the Foetus. And its motion gives that diturbance to the terus, that preently the animal pirits are ent plentifully by the Nerves to its contrictory Fibres, and the Mucles of the Abdomen, which all contracting together, very trongly expell the Foetus, which (in the mot natural birth) goes with the Head foremot: and if the Feet or any other part (beides the Head) do offer it elf firt, the travail is always more painfull and dangerous.

The everal orts of Creatures have undry terms of going with young:The term of going with child. The tated and mot uual time of Women is nine months; though ome bring forth ome weeks ooner and others later. But when it is given out that perfect and prightly Infants are born at even months end; it is either to hide the faults of ome new-married Woman, or from the mitake of the ignorant Mother. As alo when ometimes the Mother has affirmed her elf to go eleven months or upwards, it is either through mitake, or to keep fat ome fair Etate, when the pretended Father's dead without an Heir, for which the cunning Widow plays an after-game.

Divers reaons are given why the Foetus at the tated time of birth is impatient of taying any longer in the Womb.The reaon of the birth. As the narrownes of the place, the corruption of its aliment or the defect of it, the too great redundance of excrements in the Foetus, and the neceity of ventilation or
breathing. All thee are plauibly defended by their everal Authors. But without blaming ingenious Men for exerciing their wits on uch a Subject, we chooe however rather to be content with reolving all into the wie dipoal of the great Creatour, whoe power and wiedom were not more eminent in creating Man at firt out of the Dut of the Earth, than out of thoe principles and in that method whereby he is produced in ordinary generation.

list.head: The Explanation of the Table. Figure I.
list.item: Repreenteth the uual ituation of the Foetus in the Womb.
A Its Head hanging down forwards, that its Noe may be hid betwixt its Knees.
BB Its Buttocks, to which its Heels cloe.
CC Its Arms.
D The mbilical rope paing by its Neck, and wound round over its Forehead.

list.head: Figure II.
list.item: Sheweth the Foetus taken out of the Womb and as yet tyed to the Placenta, the Umbilical veels being eparated at their rie.
AAA The Abdomen opened.
B The Liver of the Foetus.
C The rinary bladder.
DD The Intetins.
E The mbilical vein.
FF The mbilical arteries.
G The Urachus.
H The mbilical veels united and inveted in their common Coat.
I The Funiculus umbilicalis reaching to the Placenta.
KKKK The Veins and Arteries dipered through the Placenta.
LLL The Placenta of the Womb.

div.trailer: The end of the Firt Book.

div.head: CHAP. I.
Of the common containing parts of it.
div.p: HItherto of the Lower Belly or Abdomen, The Breat. and of the parts contained in it, whether appointed for Nutrition or Procreation: Now it followeth that we decribe the middle Cavity, called Thorax, which containeth the Organs of elaborating the Bloud and Vital pirits, and the rie of the Veels whereby they are ditributed into all the parts of the Body, for their intauration, and the preervation of their natural heat.

It is bounded above by the Claviculae or Chanel-bones,Its limitation. below by the Diaphragm or Midriff (whereby it is evered from the Abdomen;) in the fore-part by the Breat-bone and Cartilages;
in the Sides by the Ribs; behind by the vertebrae of the Back.
The figure of it is in a manner oval,Figure. omewhat flat before and behind, (whereas in Beats it is omewhat harp:) So that only Man lieth on his Back.
The parts whereof it is compoed,Parts. are either containing, or contained. The parts containing are either common or proper.

The common containing parts are in number four,The common containing parts. Cuticula, Cutis, Pinguedo, and Membrana carnoa. Of which having at large dicoured in Book I. Chap. 3. when we treated of the common containing parts of the Lower Belly, we hall not here repeat what is there delivered, but only hew ome mall matters wherein they differ. As
Firt,1. Cuticula. the Skin and Scarf-skin are hairy under the Arm-pits,2. Cutis. and above the pit of the Heart; the Skin of the Back is both cloer and thicker, and o is les hairy.

Secondly, the Skin of the back-parts is of a more exquiite feeling: firt, becaue many twigs of Sinews are betowed upon it from the Nerves proceeding from the Spinalis medulla; econdly, by reaon of the Mucles of the Thorax that lie under it, which being tendinous are very enible.

As for the fat,3. Pinguedo. it is not o plentifull here, as in the Belly: firt becaue the natural heat here is ufficiently preerved without it; econdly, becaue it would have hindred the motion of the Breat. Only here it is omewhat yellowih.

The Membrana carnoa hath nothing peculiar,4. The membrana carnoa. aving that in the fore-part of the Neck it is more flehy, and aumes the nature of a Mucle
where the Muculus quadratus is framed, which pulleth aide the Cheeks and Lips, (according to Spigelius.)

div.head: CHAP. II.
Of the proper containing parts; and firt, of the Dugs.
div.p: THE proper containing parts are either external or internal. The proper containing parts of the breat. The external are in number three, the Dugs, the Mucles, the Bones. The internal proper containing parts are three in like manner; the Pleura, the Mediatinum, and the Diaphragm.
Dugs are granted to both the Sexes,The paps. and are eated in the middle of the Thorax, on each ide one, upon the pectoral Mucle that draweth the Shoulder forwards.
In Men they are framed of the Cutis, 1. Of Men. the Membrana carnoa, Fat, and the Nipple, and erve only for beauty, and are called Mammillae.
In Women,2. Of Women. beides thee parts, they have remarkable Veels, Glandules, and Pipes to contain the Milk eparated by the Glandules, and are called Mammae.

They differ much as to their bignes in everal Women,Their bignes. and in the • ame Woman in regard of age and other circumtances: for before they have their Menes, and when they are very old, they bunch out but very little. And in the middle or flower of their age, when they give uck or are with Child, they are bigger than at other times.

They are made up of many glandulous bodies of a different bignes,Glands. and are not of one continued glandulous ubtance (as Dr. Wharton affirmeth, lib. de Gland. p. 236.) there is one in the middle jut under the Nipple that is bigger than the ret. The paces between the Glands are filled up with fat, and there are abundance of Veels that go from one to another. They are all incloed by the Membrana carnoa, and make up as it were an half globe. They are whiter of ubtance in Women than in Brutes. Through thee Glands the Milk is eparated from the Bloud, being nothing but the Chyle iuing out of the left Ventricle of the Heart with the Bloud (to which it is not as yet aimilated) and driven hither along the Thoracick arteries. Unles we will admit Venae lacteae to come hither, which opinion we hall examine afterwards.

Upon the middle great Gland tandeth the Papilla or Nipple,Papilla. which is round and of a pongy ubtance, covered with a very thin Skin, and has many little holes in it for the Milk to ditil out by when the Child ucketh it. It is of an exquiite ene, and reembles omething the Glans of a Man's Penis, in that by handling or ucking it becomes erect or tiff, being otherwie commonly
• laggy. It is red in Virgins, livid in thoe that give uck, and blackih in old Women. All the Tubuli lactiferi or Milk-conduits end in it.
It differs in bignes,Its bignes. being as big in ome as a Mulberry, in others as a Rapberry, in others les: when Women give uck, it is longer than at other times.

Its ue is, e. to be like a Pipe or Tunnel, which the Child taking in its Mouth may uck the Milk
through out of the Breat: And it is of o exquiite ene that the Milk paing through it may caue a kind of titillation, whereby Mothers and Nures may take the greater delight and pleaure to uckle their Infants.
There is a little circle that urrounds it called Areola, Areola. which in Virgins is pale and knotty; in thoe that are with Child or give uck, brown; and in old Women, black.

The Breats have all orts of Veels,Their veels. Veins, Arteries, Nerves, Lympheducts, which are common to them with other parts; and Tubuli lactiferi proper to themelves, and, according to ome, Venae lacteae. Of all thee in order.

The Veins are of two orts,Veins. for ome are external, ome internal. The external pring from the Axillar branch, and run only under the Skin which covereth the Dugs, and are called Thoracicae uperiores, or the uppermot Breat-veins. And thee are they that look o blue in the Breats of fine-skin'd Women. The internal, called Mammariae, pring from the Rami ubclavii: They are in number two, on each ide one. Thee enter in among the Glands of the Mammae, where they end forth a great many branches; but decending thence by the Mucronata cartilago, they pas out of the Breat, and go downward under the Muculi recti. When they are come to the umbilical region almot, they are aid to be joyned by undry inoculations with the Venae epigatricae, which meet them there; though mot late Anatomits deny any uch inoculation.

Thee Venae epigatricae pring from the external Ramus iliacus, and by a treight way pas upward under the aforeaid Mucles. And from the internal
