branch of the aid Ramus pring the Venae hypogatricae, which are inerted into the neck and bottom of the Matrix. Of which in Book I. when we treated of the Womb.

They have the ame number of Arteries as Veins,Arteries. and of the ame denomination, viz. Arteriae thoracicae uperiores which are ent forth from the Axillar, and Arteriae mammariae in like manner which pring from the Subclavian, and from the Breats decend to about the Navel. Whither when they are come, they are aid (but erroneouly) to be united by inoculation with the Arteriae Epigatricae acending. The ue of both Veins and Arteries hall be hewn by and by when we come to the ue of the Breats.

They have Nerves (according to Spigelius) from the fourth Intercotal nerve pringing out of the vertebral marrow of the Thorax, Nerves. which about the middle of the Rib, perforating the Intercotal Mucle, is divided into four branches, which are ent afterward to the pectoral Mucle, and o into the Breats, the thicket paing to the Nipple.

They have very many Lympheducts.Lympheducts. Doctor Wharton aith they are very conpicuous and numerous in the bera of Cows, but one can hardly trace them into the Parenchyma. Wherefore (aith he) 'tis likely that they carry back all the exhalations reolved into weat by help of the Membranes—which they rather miniter to than to the Par • nchyma.

Beides thee four orts of Veels that are common to them with mot other parts of the Body;
<…> . they have proper to themelves certain
• actiferons (or milk-carrying) Pipes, which are
the Store-houes wherein the Milk is reerved, and through which as by Conduits it flows to the Nipple when the Child ucks. Bartholin has oberved ten or more of them, full of Milk in Women giving uck, with their outer ends encompaing the Papilla circular-wie, each of which as they pas further into the Breats, are divided into undry branches, which end in the Mammary glands (above poken of) from whence they bring the Milk, and pour it into the common duct of the Papilla.

The everal branches of thee Tubuli amongt the Glands many do take for true Lacteals,Venae lacteae. and therefore do believe that there are ome Venae lacteae that conduct the Chyle directly to the Mammae. But from whence thoe Lacteals have their origine, is not agreed among the defenders of that opinion. Some affirm them to rie from the Stomach, ome from the Pancreas, and ome from the Ductus thoracicus. The truth is, it is no wonder they hould not agree concerning their rie, eeing the opinion is grounded more upon rational conjecture, than ocular dicovery. For as was aid in the former Book (Chap. 32.) dicouring of the Venae lacteae their being aid to convey the liquor into the Amnios, That that were a plauible opinion, if uch could be demontrated by Anatomy; o we may ay as to their conveying the Chyle to the Breats, where it comes to be called Milk. But with all due repect and deference to the Epouers of this Hypotheis (uch as the mot learned Sir George Ent, Capar Martianus, Diemerbroeck, &c.) we mut crave leave to dient therefrom (with Doctor Wharton, Doctor Needham, &c.) till there hall be oberved
more certain footteps of uch Veels.

The ue of the Breats in Women is to prepare or eparate Milk for the nourihment of the Child.The ue of the Mammae.
Which how it is done, we hall hew in as few words as may be.

It was an old opinion that Milk was made of Bloud ent from the Womb by the Epigatrick veels acending, and as was thought inoculating with thoe branches of the Mammariae that decend towards the Navel. But as later Anatomits have found thoe anatomoes only imaginary (invented to erve an Hypotheis;) o it is generally denied that either Bloud ent from the Womb, or from whereoever, is the true matter out of which Milk is made. For not to mention (which yet is very coniderable) that it is incredible that the Mother could every day endure the los of o much Bloud (uppoe a pound and half) as the Child ucks daily Milk from the Breats; I think the argument urged by Dr. Wharton may atisfie any Man. Viz. Nature does nothing in vain; he goes not forward and backward by the ame path. But if he make Bloud of Chyle (which is certain) and then make Chyle of Bloud again, he goes o. For Chyle is a ort of Milk, as appears by the opening of the Lacteal veins. If therefore that Chyle be firt excocted into Bloud, and then return again to the nature of Milk, Nature hould certainly frutrate her firt work.] We hall not therefore pend further time to refute o improbable (and now obolete) an opinion; but hall avow, that Chyle is the true matter out of which Milk is made, which is done after this manner.

The Chyle being received into the common receptacle from the Venae lacteae of the Meentery,How milk is made. acends up by the Ductus thoracicus, and by it is conveyed into the ubclavian Veins, where it is mixed with the Bloud, and from whence it is circulated with it through the ventricles of the Heart. And when it comes out of the left Ventricle by the Aorta, a good part of it (as yet not aimilated to the Bloud) is ent to the Breats by the Mammary and Thoracick arteries, whoe Capillaries are inerted into the Glands, through which it is trained or filtrated into the Tubuli lactiferi, even as the Serum of the Bloud is eparated from it by the Glands of the Kidneys into their Tubuli or Syphons. And as thoe Syphons of the Kidneys carry the Serum into the Pelvis, o do thee of the Mammae, the Milk into the common duct of the Nipple. As for the Bloud that came along with the Chyle to the Glands, that returns back again into the Subclavian and Axillar veins, and o to the Heart.

Beides this matter of the Milk (viz. Chyle) Dr. Wharton (uitable to his Hypotheis of the Succus nutritius of the Nerves) thinks that the Nerves contribute their hare, which he calls permatick, for the nourihment and encreae of the permatick parts of the Child. But if it hould be uppoed that the Nerves have uch Succus in them (which we do not believe) what weaknes mut it needs induce upon the Mother to have o much of it (with the animal pirits) daily drain'd out of them? whereas we ee that many Women are more chearfull and healthfull when they give uck, than at other times. We cannot therefore conent to that opinion.

And here a mot difficult quetion may arie, why the Chyle (whether it be brought by ome Venae lacteae, or by the Arteries) flows only to the Breats at ome certain times, and not always, eeing the Veels that carry it are not obliterated, nor it elf exhauted.

They that taught,Why it flows to the breats at ome times only. that the Milk was made of Bloud, and that that Bloud was ent from the Womb by the Hypogatrick veels inoculating with the Mammary; thee I ay deriving the Milk from the Mentrual bloud as its matter out of which it is made, thought that the topping of the Menes (as commonly happens to Nures, unles very plethorick) occaioned the regurgitation of the Bloud by the aid Veels up to the Breats, where o free a vent was found for it, after it was firt changed into Milk by their Glandules. They aigned the ame bloud for the nourihment of the Foetus in the Womb, and that after the birth it acended up to the Breats. But having in the former Book (Chap. 33.) hewn that the Foetus is not nourihed at all by the Mothers bloud, as alo in this Chapter that Milk is not made of it; we need not (though it were eaie to) hew how ill this Hypotheis would atisfy the quetion, if Bloud hould be uppoed the material caue of the Milk. And indeed it is far eaier to invalidate the reaons that have been urged for it, than to produce any new ones that are more atisfactory. For as above (in Book I.) dicouring of the manner and matter of the nourihing the Foetus in the Womb, we crupled not to expoe our elves to the miles of our o overagacious Virtuoi, in reolving all into the wie dipoal of the Creatour; o we hall not be
ahamed to profes our (I think invincible) ignorance in this alo, and acquiece in the wie providence of Nature. However we will not omit to give Diemerbroeck's opinion, which if it cannot atisfy, may for its ingeniounes delight.

The caue of it (ays he) is a trong imagination, or an intene and often thinking of Milk, Breats and their Suction, which worketh wonderfull things in our Bodies: not indeed imply of it elf, but by mediation of the appetitive power, or of the paions of the mind, which induce various motions on the pirits and humours. So the imagination and thinking of a great danger maketh a Man tremble, fall, be cold, fall into a woon, yea hath ometimes turn'd all the hairs grey in a hort time: The imagination of a joyfull matter caueth heat and animoity of the Body: thinking on a hamefull thing, or a view of it, caueth bluhing; thinking on a terrible thing, palenes; on a ad thing, cold. Lutfull thoughts make the Body hot, relax the trict Genitals of Women, erect the Penis, and do o open the eminary ways that are otherwie inviible, that Seed iueth out of its own accord in involuntary or nocturnal pollution. The ame intene imagination (adds he) and a deirous cogitation of uckling the Infant, is the Caue that the Chyliferous veels (by which he means Venae lacteae properly o called) are looened and opened towards the Breats, epecially if ome outward caues tending that way favour and further incite that trong imagination, as wanton handling of the Breats, the moving of the Foetus in the Womb, the ucking of
the Papilla, &c. For according to the different influx of the Animal pirits, the parts are ometimes traitned, ometimes relaxed, as every one knows; and according to that different contriction or relaxation the Bloud and other impelled humours, flow ometimes more, ometimes les into the parts; and ometimes beget heat, oftnes, rednes; ometimes contriction, cold and palenes. Amongt thee impelled humours is the Chyle, &c.—] To confirm this opinion he gives everal intances wherein nothing but imagination could move the Chyle to tend to the Breats. His firt is that known tory of Santorellus, That a poor Man's Wife dying, and not having Means enough to hire a Nure for the Infant he had left behind her, he ued, (to till it a little) often to lay it to his Paps (without doubt (ays Diemerbroeck) with a great deire to yield it ome Milk) and o at length by that intene and continual thought, and often repeated ucking of the Papillae, his Breats afforded Milk enough for the uckling the Infant. (Which by the way, eems to make much againt his opinion of the Chyle's being conveyed to the Mammae by the Venae lacteae; for eeing Men according to Nature give no uck, to what purpoe hould Venae lacteae be ditributed to their Mammillae? and yet here is an intance of a Man giving uck, and therefore the Chyle is more likely to be brought by the Arteries, which Men have as well as Women: unles we will grant that force to imagination, to make Venae lacteae as well as to end the Chyle by them, which would be an equal force of imagination to imagine. But to proceed.) He
tells another tory of an old Woman that came to give uck, and he delivers it with uch circumtances as may create a belief of the truth of it. At Vyanen a Town not far from us (viz. from
trecht, in which Province it is) about thirty years agoe there was an Hotes that kept the Bores-head Inne without the Gate, who was brought to bed a little after her Husbands death, and died in Child-bed or very oon after, leaving a healthfull Child behind her: and having left very little Etate, her Mother whoe name was Joan Vuyltuyt, being alo poor and not able to put it out to Nure, yet had uch pity on her Daughters Child, as to undertake to nourih it, and he was now threecore and ix years old. Now having ometimes ued, with the greatet commieration, to hold it to her Breats when it cried, and offered it the Nipple to uck; by that trong imagination, and deirous cogitation of nourihing the Infant, her Breats began to give Milk, and that in a few days o plentifully, as was abundantly ufficient to feed the Child, o that it had carce any need of other utenance: and o, to the admiration of all, the Infant was well nourihed with the Milk of this old Woman, whoe Breats for many years had been wither'd and flaggy, but now became plump and full like a young Woman's. There are many till alive in that City that remember the thing very well.] I confes the tory is very odd, but whether to be reolved into the force of imagination I leave the curious to meditate. However he very plauibly anwers everal objections that may be made againt it, which it will be worth the while for
the Latine Reader to perue, in his Anat. corp. human.. lib. 2. cap. 2. p. 409, 411, &c.
The two other proper containing parts of the Thorax are the Mucles and the Bones.
As for the Mucles, they are et down in the Treatie of Mucles, Book 5. cap. 15.
The Bones are et down in the Doctrine of Bones, Book 6. cap. 11, 12, 13.

div.head: CHAP. III.
Of the proper internal containing parts.
div.p: THee are in number three, the Pleura, the Mediatinum with the Thymus growing to it, and the Diaphragm.
The Pleura hath its denomination from the Ribs under which it is placed,Pleura. (for a Rib is in Greek called < in non-Latin alphabet > ) and o it may be termed in Englih, the Cotal membrane.
It is a Membrane,Its ubtance. white, thin, hard, reembling the Peritonaeum, and lining all the cavity of the Thorax.

Spigelius de human. corp. fabr. lib. 6. cap. 3. will have it to be thicker and tronger than the Peritonaeum, contrary to the opinion of Riolanus, who affirmeth the Peritonaeum to be thicker and tronger, becaue it is appointed for the utaining the weight of the Guts.

It is every where double:Parts. The inner part is thicket, moothet, and as it were bedewed with
a waterih humour, that it hould not offend the Lungs by its roughnes: This waterih humour doth pring from the vapours raied from the Bloud, condened by the repective coldnes of the Membrane. The outer part is thinner, yet is rougher; that it hould cleave the more firmly to the Ribs, and Mucles.

As for its figure,Figure. without it is arched, within hollow; above it is narrower, below broader, chiefly towards the Sides. From it ometimes pring ome inewy Fibres, by the which the Lungs are tied to it. If thee be too trait, the motion of the Lungs is hindred, and o an incurable difficulty of breathing procured.

Above,Holes. it is perforated in ix or even places, to give way to the Vena cava, and the Aorta acending, the Gula, the Wind-pipe, Lacteals, Lympheducts and Nerves. Below, where it covereth the Midriff, it is perforated in three places, to give way to the Vena cava, and the Aorta decending, as alo to the Gula.

It is aid to be framed of the Membranes covering the Spinalis medulla, Rie. from whence it comes forward on each hand by the ides to the Breatbone, under which the Membranes of each ide are joyned together, and o being doubled it goes back again treight from the middle of the Breat to the Back, dividing the cavity of the Thorax, and the Lungs alo, into two parts, like a partition-wall, and this is called Mediatinum, of which by and by.
Its Veins pring from the uperiour Intercotal branch,Veins. and from the Vena ine pari.

The Arteries in like manner proceed from the uperiour Intercotals,Arteries. (which arie from the
Subclavian) and thee decend to about the fourth Rib, below which it has its Arteries from the hinder part of the Aorta decending.

It hath twelve Nerves according to the number of the vertebrae of the Thorax; Nerves. from betwixt each of which there prings a pair of Nerves, and each pair is immediately divided into the fore- and hinder-branches: The fore-branches are they which erve the Intercotal mucles, external and internal, and alo the Pleura: as for the hinder, they are betowed upon the Mucles which are placed upon the Back.

The Veins and Arteries according to Spigelius run between the two Membranes of the Pleura, and therefore he thinks that when an inflammation of the Pleura (called a Pleuriie) impothumates, the matter is rather gathered betwixt its Membranes than betwixt the Intercotal mucles and it.
The econd proper internal containing part is the Mediatinum: Of the Mediatinum. o called becaue it tandeth in the middle of the Breat, and divideth the right ide from the left.

It pringeth from the Membranes of the Pleura meeting at the Sternum, Its rie. (as was aid before) o that at its rie it conits of four Membranes, becaue the Pleura, of the duplicature whereof it is made, conits of two. But as the Mediatinum tends from the Sternum through the middle of the Thorax towards the Back, its duplicated Membranes are o evered, that the Heart with its Pericardium are contained in its Cavity. Yet when they arrive near the Back, they join again as cloe as they did at the Breat, though they
preently part again, (aith Diemerbroeck) and make another narrower Cavity, but as long, for the Gullet, &c. to decend by. Some have formerly imagined a third Cavity at its origine under the Sternum, wherein they thought there were ometimes collected corrupt humours, that were the caue of many occult Ditempers. And indeed if the diection be begun at the Sternum, when one has pull'd it off from the Mediatinum, one would think at firt ight that there were as great a ditance betwixt the Membranes of the Mediatinum, as the Sternum is broad. But it is a great errour, for if one begin the Section at the Back and looe the Ribs there, and o come to the Sternum, he will ee the Pleura doubled knit cloe to the Sternum without any Cavity.

The ubtance of it is membranous;Subtance. where it is parted, it is thinner and ofter than the Pleura. The outer ide towards the Lungs is mooth, and hath fat about the Veels; but the interiour is rougher, by reaon of the Fibres whereby it adheres to the Pericardium in ome places, and its own two Membranes at their meeting are united.
It reacheth from the Throat to the Midriff.Length.
It hath moreover one pecial Vein called Mediatina, which pringeth from the lower part of the Ramus ubclavius.
The Nerves called Phrenici, Nerves. and Stomachici, pringing from the ixth pair, (Dr. Willis's eighth) decend betwixt its Membranes, and end forth mall twigs into it.

p.U: ays it has Lympheducts,Lympheducts. which riing here and there in many Rivulets, enter the Ductus thoracicus at lat in one channel. Thee imbibe the water that is condened betwixt its duplicature, and convey it into the aid duct.

div.p: It hath three ues: ue. Firt, it divideth the Breat and Lungs into two parts, that one being wounded or any way hurt, the other might perform the task of repiration.

Secondly, it holdeth up the Heart incloed in the Pericardium o, that it may not ret upon the Back-bone, when we lie upon our Back; or fall upon the Breat-bone, when we bend our elves towards the ground; or touch the Ribs, when we lie upon our Sides.

Thirdly, it giveth a afe paage to the Veels which pas by it, and holdeth up the Diaphragm o that it is not pulled too much down by the weight of the Bowels that hang by it, viz. the Liver and the Stomach.

To the upper part of the Mediatinum at the Throat there groweth a Kernel called Thymus, Thymus. eated between the diviions of the Subclavian veins and arteries. It is a whitih, oft, pongy, glandulous body, (in hape reembling a Tyme-leaf, from which it has its name.) It is larger in Children and Women than in Men. In Infants it conits of three Glands, and is in ubtance omething like the Sweet-bread; but in adult perons it dries up and contracts into one continued ubtance.

The Jugular Veins and Arteries pas through it as they go up to the Neck,Its veels. but if they end forth any twigs into it, they are o mall as not to be dicovered in diecting it. Dr. Wharton ays it
has Nerves from the ixth pair and from the ubclavian Plexus, which depoite their Succus nutritius in it, whoe uperfluous or impurer parts are eparated from it in this Gland and conveyed away by the Lympheducts, and the refined liquor is reumed by the Nerves dipered in it, for the ue of the nervous parts of the whole Body. And becaue he foreaw how open this opinion (which himelf calls crupoa ententia) lay to the objection, that it is very improbable that the Nerves hould bring the Succus nutritius to this part, and after depuration hould reorb it; he anwers that either the Nerves mut do it, or it cannot be done at all, eeing there are no other Veels fit for the reuming of it. But he had better have upected his uppoed office of the Thymus, when he aw himelf o hard et to maintain it. For it is more probable that when there is found any whitih liquor in it, (as there is in Infants, and in Calves, &c.) that liquor is Chyle which is brought thither by Lacteals, and decends from thence into the Subclavian veins; eeing if one kill a Calf about two hours after it has been plentifully uckled, the Thymus abounds with this juice, as Diemerbro • ck affirms; who alo denies that there are any perceptible Nerves inerted into it, but grants Lympheducts.

Its ues are, e. firt, to prop and trengthen the diviions of the Veels, namely of the Vena cava and great Artery; and econdly, to defend them from compreion by the Claviculae, in tooping forward. In adult perons it eems to be of little other ue; but in Infants, in whom it is larger and has liquor like Chyle in it, it eems to contribute omething towards the re • ining or depuration of it.

The third and lat internal proper containing part is the Midriff or Diaphragm (derived < in non-Latin alphabet > ,The Diaphragm. to ditinguih, becaue it divides the trunk of the Body into two Ventricles, the Abdomen and Thorax.) It is alo called < in non-Latin alphabet > , or
< in non-Latin alphabet > , the mind, becaue when it is inflam'd or otherwie much ditempered, the mind and enes are diturbed, through the great conent it has with the Brain, as being a very nervous part. The Latines call it Septum tranverum for the ame reaon as the Greeks call it Diaphragma.

Now this part being truly a Mucle aiting repiration, we might on that account have deferred to treat of it till we come to decribe the Mucles of the Thorax: but becaue it is wholly an internal part, and erves to make up the cavity of the Breat, we rather chue to dicoure of it here, and omit it in the treatie of Mucles.

It is almot round,Its figure and ituation. (excepting its two appendages whereby it is fatened to the Mucles or vertebrae of the Loins) and is eated tranverly or acros the Body, only loping a little backwards. It is as broad as the width of the Thorax, for its edges are fatened to the lower part of the Sternum, to the ends of the lowet Ribs, and to the lowet vertebra of the Thorax.

Its circumference is carnous,Subtance. but in its middle or centre (as it were) it is nervous and membranous, for thither do all the carnous Fibres run from the edges. Wounds in the nervous part of it are mortal, becaue the party preently falls into Convulions, and repiration faileth; but if it be wounded in its flehy part, the patient oft ecapes. It is clad with two Membranes,
the upper from the Pleura, to which the Mediatinum and Pericardium are joined, and ometimes the lowet tips of the lobes of the Lungs; the under, from the Peritonaeum.

It is perforated on the right hand near the nervous centre by the trunk of Vena cava acending from the Liver,Holes. and on the left hand near the aid centre by the Gullet and two Stomachick nerves pringing from the par vagum. Behind at the Vertebrae there decend betwixt its two appendages or productions the Aorta, a branch of the Vena azygos, and the Intercotal nerve (ditinguiht from the par vagum by Dr. Willis) for the ue of the parts of the Abdomen.

It has two Arteries, Veels. called Phrenicae, from the Aorta decending, and as many Veins from the trunk of Vena cava acending through it. Nerves it hath firt from the econd pair of the vertebrae of the Neck which (according to Dr. Willis) communicate with the Intercotal pair. By this communication of the Intercotal nerve with that from whence this Nerve of the Diaphragm pringeth, yea with this Nerve it elf, (for the aid Author ays that two or three Nerves are ent from the cervical Plexus of the Intercotal into the trunk it elf of the Nerve of the Diaphragm) he very ingeniouly gives a reaon of the great conent of the Midriff with the Heart, Brain and Face, when a Man laughs. For, ays he, as often as the imagination is affected with ome pleaant or wonderfull conceit, the Heart would preently fain triumph (ovare) and be lighten'd by throwing off its burthen as it were: wherefore that the Bloud may the quicklier be emptied out of its right Ventricle
into the Lungs, and conequently out of the left into the Aorta, the Diaphragm being intigated by the Nerves that goe to it from the aboveaid Plexus, is drawn upwards with a more rapid Sytole, and often repeating its jumps as it were, it bears up the Lungs, and caues them the quicker and frequenter to dicharge the Air and Bloud: and then inamuch as the ame Intercotal nerve, that communicates below with the Nerve of the Diaphragm, is alo continued above with the Maxillar nerves, when a cackling is begun in the Breat, the getures of the Mouth and Face pathetically anwer thereto.] And when the Diaphragm is wounded in its nervous part, then the Mucles of the Face uffer Convulions, and the laughter called Rius Sardonius (which is involuntary) is caued. Beides the aboveaid Nerves it has econdly mall twigs from the Stomachick nerves and Intercotal as they decend through it.

Its ue is firt to divide the Thorax from the Abdomen,
e. that noiom and impure vapours may not acend from the more ignoble parts as the Guts, to offend the more noble as the Heart, &c. Secondly, to help the Mucles of the Abdomen in compreing and excluding the excrements, and (in Women) the Foetus. But thirdly, its chief ue is to ait repiration, in which it is the principal Mucle. In inpiration it is tretched out plain; in expiration it grows laggy. Its motion eems to be a kind of mixt motion, but rather animal than natural; for though we move it in our leep, and o it may eem natural, yet eeing when awake we can top, lacken or haten its motion
as we pleae, it eems to be voluntary or animal.
And thus much of the parts containing, now to the parts contained.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
Of the Pericardium, and the Humour contained in it.
div.p: THE parts contained are either Vicera or Vaa, Bowels or Veels.
The Bowels are the Heart and Lungs. But the Heart being incloed in a membranous cover called Pericardium, we will firt treat of it, in this Chapter.

It is called Pericardium becaue it is placed < in non-Latin alphabet >
about the Heart.Its denomination. It is called alo Capula cordis, the Heart-cae, and Involucrum, the Cover, &c. It is membranous and encompaeth the whole Heart, whoe hape it therefore reembles, but is larger, both to grant a free motion to the Heart, and to contain its proper liquor.

It prings at the Bais of the Heart from the outer common Coats (that are borrowed of the Pleura) of thoe Veels that enter into the Heart.Origine. Whence it has five holes according to the number of Veels that go in or out of the Heart.Holes. As firt one made by the acending trunk of the Cava, another by the Vena ubclavia, both which enter the right Ventricle of the Heart, from whence there goes out Vena arterioa into
the Lungs, which makes a third hole. A fourth is made by the Arteria venoa entring the left Ventricle of the Heart, and a fifth by the Arteria magna going out of the ame.

Its outide adheres to the Mediatinum by many Fibres,Connexion. and is continued to it at the bais of the Heart, where the Veels perforate it. Its lower end is knit firmly to the centre or nervous part of the Diaphragm, which (Bartholin ays) is peculiar to men, for in all other Creatures it hangs looe.

It has Veins below from the Phrenicae, Veels. above from the Axillares. Its Arteries are o mall that they can hardly be dicover'd. It receives Nerves from the pair commonly called the ixth. Bartholin affirms it to have Lymphaticks alo; which is very probable, that they may aborb part of the liquor contained in it, let it abound too much, eeing it receives continual upply: for I am not of opinion that this liquor is pued out of the Lympheducts, as Steno thinks, but that they rather imbibe it and convey it to the Ductus thoracicus.

It contains in it a erous liquor,Its liquor. that in healthfull Bodies is a little reddih, much like water wherein fleh has been waht. It is bred of vapours exhaling out of the Heart, which are topt by this dene Membrane, and condened into humour. Dr. Lower oppoing this opinion brings for argument, that if it were collected this way, becaue it would be continually a gathering, it would oon encreae o much that this Capula could not hold it. But the aboveaid Lympheducts aborbing what is uperfluous, wah away this objection; which if they did not, his own opinion,
that it drops out of the Glands eated at the bais of the Heart, would be liable to the ame inconvenience. For uch detillation would be as continual as this condenation is uppoed to be. Naturally it is not in quantity above two poonfulls. This is that liquor that is uppoed to have lown from the Side of our Saviour when the Souldier pierced it with a Spear, for aith the Text (John 19. 34.) There came forth bloud and water.

The Pericardium is ome ort of fence to the Heart,Their ues. but it eems to be chiefly made for the ake of the liquor it contains, which erves for the moitening of the Heart and making it lippery, that it may move more glibly.

div.head: CHAP. V.
Of the Heart, in general, and of its Motion.
div.p:
THE Heart (in Latine Cor, in Greek < in non-Latin alphabet > or
< in non-Latin alphabet > , to burn, becaue it is the ource of vital heat) is the principal Bowel of the whole Body, which no perfect Animal does want, nor can long urvive its wounds. Vital pirit and natural heat are communicated from it to all the parts of the Body, though perhaps not o much owing to its ubtance as to the fermentation of the humours in it; as hall be dicoured hereafter.

It is eated in the middle of the Breat,Its ituation. encompaed with the Pericardium and Mediatinum, its
lower tip or Mucro bending a little to the left ide. Neither its Mucro nor ides are knit to any place, but it hangs looe in its cae, only upended by the Veels that go in and out of its upper part or bais. Its ituation in Beats that feed upon Gras is near the middle of the whole Body, reckoning from the Head to the Tail; but in Man (and mot carnivorous Animals) it is nearer the Head; whereof the learned Dr. Lower gives an ingenious reaon. Seeing, ays he, the trajection and ditribution of the Bloud depends wholly on the Sytole of the Heart, and that its liquor is not driven of its own nature o readily into the upper parts as into veels even with it, or downwards into thoe under it: if the ituation of the Heart had been further from the Head, it mut needs either have been made tronger to cat out its liquor with greater force; or ele the Head would want its due proportion of Bloud. But in Animals that have a longer Neck, and which is extended towards their food as it were, the Heart is eated as far from the Head as from the other parts; and they find no inconvenience from it, becaue they feed with their Head for the mot part hanging down, and o the Bloud, as it has farther to go to their Head than in others, o it goes a plainer and often a teep way.

It has a firm,Subtance. thick, dene ubtance, thinner and ofter in the right ide, thicker and more dene in the left, but mot compact and hard at its tip; only on the left ide of the tip it is thin, as coniting motly of the concoure of the inner and outer Membrane. Its Parenchyma is for the greatet part made up of muculary Fibres o
that it elf may truly be reputed a Mucle.

Its Fibres are a few of them treight,Fibres. but far more oblique. Both are inerted into a Tendon that is pread over its bais under the Auricles. Part of which Tendon at the egres of the Aorta in ome Creatures becomes bony, as in a Stag, &c. On the outer uperficies of the right Ventricle there run a few lender Fibres treight upwards and are terminated in its bais. In which alo terminate the oblique ones next under thee, acending from the left ide towards the right, piral-wie. The Fibres that lie under thee, go clean contrary. For they arie every where from the right ide of the Heart, whence being carried obliquely towards the left, and having embraced each Ventricle of the Heart, they rie to the bais of the left ide piral-wie as the other. But they run not all of them the whole length from the bais to the cone; for then would the Heart be as broad or thick at the lower end as the upper: but ome reach not above half way, others a little further, &c. and ome to the very Apex. The Fibres of the left Ventricle differ not from thoe of the right as to kind, only they are coniderably tronger. Which they are for this reaon, that whereas the right Ventricle only promotes the circulation of the bloud through the Lungs, the left mut cat it forth with that force as that it may circulate through the whole Body.

The curious Reader may find a mot accurate decription of thee Fibres in Dr. Lower's treatie de Corde, whither I refer him; for, to init too long on uch minute imilar parts, would not be uitable to this Epitome of Anatomy. Though
by a view of thoe Figures that I have borrowed of him, their tructure may be pretty plainly apprehended.

Its hape is like a Boy's Top (ave that it is flattih behind) or a Pyramid turn'd topy turvy;Figure. whence it is divided into its bais, which is its broader part and upper; and into its cone or apex, or narrower and lower part, which ends in a tip or mucro.

It is bigger in Men than in other Creatures,Bignes. conidering the proportion of their Bodies. It is leer but more dene in hot and bold Men, than in the cold and cowardly. In adult perons it is commonly ix fingers breadth long, and four broad at the bais.

Outwardly it is cover'd with a proper Coat,Coat. which is thin, but trong and dene, and very hard to eparate from it; it is the ame with the outer Coat of the great Artery, as that which cloaths the Ventricles on the inide is continued and common with that thin skin that covers the inide of the Arteries like a Cuticula: and hence 'tis likely (ays Diemerbroeck) that the Arteries borrow thee Coats of the Heart, as the Nerves borrow their two Tunicles from the Pia and Dura mater of the Brain. Upon this Membrane that invets the Heart, there grows ome hard fat about the bais, which erves to moiten it.
It is not nourihed by the bloud or nutritious juice received into its Ventricles,Veels. but by Veels running through its Parenchyma.

Its Arteries are two,Arteries. pringing out of the Aorta before it pas out of the Pericardium, and are called Coronariae, becaue their trunks do not
preently ink into the Parenchyma of the Heart, but fetching a circuit on its urface the better to branch out themelves towards its cone, they encompas its bais. And though at their rie they turn one on one ide and t'other on the other of the Heart, yet at their ends they meet again and inoculate one with the other: o that if one inject any liquor into one, it will run into the other.

It has alo two Veins called Coronariae which encompas its bais in like manner,Veins. and communicate one with the other. Thee receive and carry back the Arterial bloud that remains from the nutrition of the Heart, and refund it into the Cava.

Nerves it has from the ixth pair (Dr. Willis's eighth) which paing between the Arteria pulmonalis and the Aorta do end forth divers twigs on each ide into the Auriculae, Nerves. and then are branched out into the ubtance of the Heart. Dr. Lower ays they are manifetly apparent over all the outer uperficies of the Heart of a Calf or other Animal newly brought forth.

Great controverie hath been and till is about the motion of the Heart,The motion of the Heart. whether it depend on the influx of the animal pirits, or on the dilatation, ebullition, or accenion of the bloud in its Ventricles, or partly on one, partly on the other. Plauible Arguments are produced on every ide, but uch as rather tend to hew the hortnes and inufficiency of the contrary opinions to olve this Phaenomenon, than pretend to demontrate any certain reaon of it. That the immediate intruments of its motion are its Fibres,
none can doubt; but what ets thee Fibres on work is all the quetion. That it cannot be the Animal pirits conveyed by the Nerves (only) is apparent, firt, becaue the Heart moves in the Embryo before either Brain or Nerve are o perfectly formed, that the Animal pirits can be elaborated out of the Bloud by the former, or tranmitted to the Heart by the latter: yea eeing they are made of Arterial bloud, that mut be ent to the Brain by the pulation of the Heart before they can be generated. And econdly, becaue thoe mucular motions that depend on the influx of the Animal pirits, are voluntary, which this of the Heart is not, for we can neither top it nor haten it at our pleaure. Latly, becaue the Heart of living Foetus's (as of young Puppies) and of Eels, being cut out of the Body and from all the Nerves by which any Animal pirits hould flow into it, will continue beating as long as 'tis warm: yea when it has ceas'd beating, if one throw warm bloud or but warm water upon it, it will recover ome kind of pulation again. Which may erve alo to convict the econd opinion of errour; for if its motion depended only on the dilatation of the bloud, it would ceae aoon as the bloud flows no longer into its Ventricles.

And as to ebullition or accenion, Dr. Lower's experiment, or his obervation, are a ufficient confutation of their being the reaon of this pulation. His experiment is this: He drew out of the Jugular vein of a Dog about half of his bloud away, injecting by turns into the Crural vein a like quantity of Beer mixt with a little Wine; and this he repeated alternatively o often, till
intead of bloud there flow'd out of the Vein only a paler tincture like water wherein Fleh had been wah'd, or Claret diluted with very much Water; and yet the Heart in the mean time remitted but a little of its former pulation..... His obervation, which he had from a Phyician worthy of credit, is this: A Youth about ixteen years old, continuing bleeding for two days together, his friends and thoe that waited on him gave him good tore of Broth to keep up and recruit his Spirits; which wallowing down greedily, his bleeding was now and then encreas'd thereby, o that at length having poured forth almot the whole mas of his bloud, that which now run out was dilute and pale, neither of the nature nor colour of bloud, but liker the Broth he had drunk o much of: And this kind of flux continued a day or two, (the Heart the mean while retaining its pulation) till at length being topt, the Youth was retored by degrees to entire health, and grew to a robut and luty Fellow.] This experiment and obervation I ay do make it apparent, the motion of the Heart depends not on the ebullition or accenion of the bloud, for then when in the firt the Beer and Wine, in the econd the Broth flow'd into its Ventricles intead of Bloud, its motion mut either have been more notably alter'd, or rather have quite ceas'd, thee liquors being o far ditant from the nature of bloud, epecially the Broth.

And latly, that this motion is not caued partly by the influx of the animal pirits, and partly by the ebullition or accenion of the bloud, may be evinced by the Arguments produced
againt each opinion apart: and yet if a reaon could be given, this eems the mot probable. Namely, that the bloud detilling into the Ventricles of the Heart, is in them accended and rarefied, and wanting more room expands or bears againt their Sides: and then the Parenchyma of the Heart being moleted by that expanion, calls in the Animal pirits for help, which coming in in convenient plenty contract the mucular Fibres that make up the Parenchyma of the Heart, and o by traitning its Ventricles drive forth the bloud contained in them into the Arteries. But we had rather ingenuouly confes our ignorance of the reaon of o admirable an action, and profes with Dr. Lower that it is too hard for Man to conceive of, and that it is the prerogative of God only, who earcheth the ecrets of the Heart, to know the reaon of its motion alo.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
Of the Pule, and the circulation of the Bloud.
div.p:
THE motion of the Heart is called in Greek
< in non-Latin alphabet > ,The Pule. in Latine Pulus, pule or beating. And this is performed by Diatole, or Dilatation, in which it receives Bloud into its Ventricles; and Sytole, or Contraction, by which it expells it.

Contraction being the proper motion of a Mucle,Sytole and Diatole. the Sytole is the proper motion of the Heart, and the Diatole is but a ceaing or retitution from that motion. For in the Diatole the Fibres of the Heart are relaxed, o that the Bloud detills down into its Ventricles out of the Veins, whereby when they are filled and in ome meaure ditended, the Fibres both treight and oblique begin to contract themelves, and compres or traiten the Cavities of the Ventricles, and alo draw up the cone nearer its bais, whereby the Heart becomes rounder and harder, and the Bloud is expelled with force out of the Ventricles into the Arteries; which motion is called the Sytole. But why the Heart hould keep uch tated turns of Sytole and Diatole, and continue them for (may be) fourcore years together, that (as we aid above) we cannot conceive the reaon of, but admire the wiedom and power of the Creatour, in beginning and continuing uch a motion.The circulation of the bloud.

Now eeing by this continual reciprocation of
the Pule there is a contant expulion of Bloud from the Heart; there mut needs be a continual influx of Bloud into the Heart out of the Cava. And eeing the Cava from whence the upply is, is never drawn dry, and on the other hand eeing the Arteries that receive the Bloud continually from the Heart, are not unduly well'd with it, it necearily follows that this motion proceeds circularly, viz. that the Bloud is continually driven out of the Heart into the Arteries, out of thee into the Veins and parts to be nourihed, then from the leer Veins returns to the Cava, and o at length to the Heart again. The invention of which circulation is owing to our Countreyman Dr. Harvey, and may be prov'd invincibly by thee reaons.

1. The great quantity of Bloud that is driven out of the Heart into the Arteries at every Pule. For though the Ancients who knew not this circulation, imagin'd that only a drop or two were expelled by every Sytole, which they were neceitated to uppoe, to avoid the great ditenion that the Arteries mut be liable to, if any coniderable quantity iued into them; yet it is certain and demontrable that there mut needs an ounce or more be driven into them each time. For (taking it for granted that there is no other way for any liquor to pas from the Stomach to the Kidneys but through the Heart, along with the Bloud) eeing if ome Men at ome times drink three pints of Drink, they hall pis it out again in half an hour, yea more of Tunbridge Waters in that pace; and eeing econdly, that there is commonly as much Bloud as Serum that flows to the Kidneys (the Bloud returning back
by the Emulgent veins) it is clear that by the two Emulgents (which are none of the larget Arteries) there mut pas in half an hours time ix pounds of liquor, all which mut come from the Heart; and how much more then may we conceive to be driven through all the other Arteries that run through the whole Body? This is more accurately evinced by Dr. Lower's experiment, which is this: I cut aunder (ays he) both Cervical arteries in a large Dog, and at the ame time through an hole made in the left ide of his Breat over againt the Heart, I compret the trunk of the Aorta below the Heart with my finger, to hinder any Bloud from decending by it; and latly I took care alo to traiten the Brachial arteries under the Axillae, by which means almot all the Bloud was driven out of the Heart through the Cervicals (beides that which was ent into the Vertebrals) and which is wonderfull to be related, within the twentieth part of an hour the whole mas iued out; o that it is not to be denied but that it all pat through the Heart in that pace.] And though it may be granted that amidt uch wounds and tortures the Heart does beat omewhat quicker in uch a cae than at other times; yet the ame thing is partly evident from wounds in the Limbs when ome notable Artery is cut aunder, for 'tis trange in how mall a time a Man will bleed to death even at that one Artery. Yea we may give a great gues how much Bloud is ent out at every Pule, even from the ordinary opening of one Vein in the Arm, from whence a notable quantity of Bloud will iue in a hort time; how much then may we uppoe would flow out of
all the Veins, if they were opened at one time? Seeing then 'tis evident that o great a quantity of Bloud is expelled out of the Heart at every Sytole, and that for all that the Arteries are not unduly ditended nor any part well'd by it, neither yet the Cava and other Veins emptied, 'tis certain that the Bloud that is driven into the Arteries flows back to the Heart by the Veins, in a contant circulation.

2. A econd Argument to prove it, may be taken from the Valves in the Veins, which are o framed that Bloud may freely flow through them out of the leer Veins into the greater, (and o into the Cava) but not on the contrary out of the greater into the les. Yea if one blow into the Cava through a Pipe, there will no wind pas into the maller Veins; but on the contrary, if you blow up the leer Veins, the wind will readily pas to the larger and o to the Cava.

3. And latly, The ame thing is mot clear by the Ligature in bloud-letting. For whether you let bloud in the Arm or Foot, you always tie the Fillet above where you intend to make the Orifice, and then the Vein below the Ligature will preently fill and grow tumid, but above it will fall and almot diappear. Which mut needs be from hence, for that the Bloud being driven along the Arteries towards the extreme parts, returns by the Veins and acends upwards, which coming to the Ligature and being topt there, wells the Vein below the Ligature, and purts out aoon as the Orifice is made: but when the Fillet is looed again, the Bloud flows no longer out thereat, but holds on its wonted channel, the Vein, and the Orifice cloes up again.

Having ufficiently demontrated the circulation of the Bloud we will hew two things further, firt, how the Bloud paes out of the Arteries into the Veins, and econdly in how long a time the whole mas of Bloud may be uppoed to pas through the Heart in its ordinary circulation.

As to the firt, it was the opinion of Riolanus that the Bloud circulated only through the larger Veels, by anatomoes or inoculation of the Veins with the Arteries, and that that which run into the maller, was all pent on the nutrition of the parts. But it is clear that there mut be a circulation even in the mallet, from the great quantity of Bloud that will flow out of the leat Artery in the Hand or Foot, when it is cut; which it were very aburd to imagine to be all pent on the nourihment of the repective part. Now there are but two ways whereby the Bloud can be uppoed to pas out of the Arteries into the Veins, viz. either by the former opening into the latter by inoculation, or ele by the Capillary arteries letting out their Bloud into the pores of the ubtance of the parts, on whoe nutrition part is pent, and the remainder imbibed by the gaping mouths of the Capillary veins. And it eems neceary to admit both thee ways; this latter, becaue if part of the Arterial bloud did not iue into the ubtance of the parts, they could not be nourihed by it, for while it is in the veels it may add warmth indeed to the parts through which it flows, but cannot nourih them, eeing even the veels themelves are not nourihed by that tream of Bloud that glides along their Cavity, but by Capillaries running through their Coats; and if the Bloud be driven into the
ubtance of the parts, and that in a greater quantity than uffices for their nourihment (as was jut now hewn) what is uperfluous mut needs enter the mouths of the Capillary veins, from which it goes forward to the larger and o to the Heart: But eeing this way of transfuing the Blood through the ubtance of the parts anwers not to that haty circulation of the Bloud we above demontrated; it is neceary alo to admit of the former way, namely anatomoes, in which the Veins are continued to the Arteries, and that not only in their larger branches (as that notable one of the Splenick artery with the Splenick vein) but alo in their maller twigs in the extreme parts.

And econdly as to the pace of time in which the whole mas of Bloud may ordinarily circulate through the Heart, it is probably much horter than many have imagined. For uppoing that the Heart makes two thouand pules an hour (which is the leat number any peak of, and ome have told twice as many) and that at every pule there is expelled an ounce of Bloud (which we may well uppoe, eeing the Ventricles are wide enough to contain two ounces, and that it is probable both that they are filled near full in the Diatole, and that they are near if not quite emptied by the trong contriction of the Heart in the Sytole) eeing the whole mas uually exceeds not four and twenty pound, it will be circulated ix or even times over through the Heart in the pace of an hour. And by o much the oftener, by how much the Bloud comes hort of the uppoed quantity, or the pule either naturally, or by a Fever or violent motion is rendred more frequent.
By which quick motion the Bloud it elf is kept from coagulation and putrefaction, and the parts are cherihed with vital heat, which heat of the parts is much according to the lownes or rapidnes of the circulation; o when we it till and the pule is low or rare, we grow cold, but when upon running or any violent exercie the pule becomes more frequent and quick, we become hot.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
How Bloud is made of Chyle, of its Colour, and whether the Body be nourihed by it.
div.p:
ACcording to Dr. Harvey's obervations there appears in an Embryo a punctum aliens, or red beating peck, which is Bloud, before any the leat lineament of the Heart. So that whatever intrument of anguification the Heart may appear to be afterwards, it contributes nothing to the elaborating of the firt Bloud; but it eems rather to be made for the Bloud's ake to tranmit it to all the parts of the Embryo or Foetus, than the Bloud to be made by it. But it mut be confet that things proceed in the grown Foetus far otherwie than they do in the firt formation. For the parts of an Embryo are nourihed and encreaed before it have a tomach to concoct any thing, and yet in a perfect Foetus none can deny that the Stomach does concoct and prepare nourihment for it: o it moves before the Brain is formed o perfectly
as to be able to elaborate Animal pirits; and yet after it is perfected, every one knows that the Brain does elaborate uch pirits, as being ent into all the parts of the Body by the Nerves enable them to move. In like manner though there be Bloud in the Embryo before the Heart be formed, yet after it is perfected, nothing will hinder but it may at leat contribute omething to anguification.

We will uppoe then, that as all the other parts are formed by the Vis platica or generative faculty of the (firt) vegetative and (then) animal Soul, eated in the Ovum, but aoon as they are perfected and the Foetus excluded, are nourihed by the Bloud; o the Bloud it elf being at firt made in like manner, aoon as the Veins, Heart and Arteries are compleated o as it can circulate by them, may, not improperly, be aid to be nourihed by the Chyle, the Heart aiting the aimilation of the one into the other. And this is done in this manner.How chyle is turned into bloud. The Chyle acending by the Ductus thoracicus (as was decribed Book 1. Chap. 10.) and flowing into the Subclavian vein, together with the returning venal Bloud is poured into the right ventricle of the Heart in its Diatole or Relaxation, then by its Sytole or Contraction it is driven out from thence into the Lungs, from whence it acends again into the left ventricle of the Heart, out of which it is expelled through the Aorta, and paing along with the Bloud through the Arteries of the whole Body, returns again with it by the Veins to the Heart. For it undergoes many circulations before it can be aimilated to the Bloud. Which is evident, both becaue it is the Chyle (but little
alter'd) that is eparated in the Placenta uteri for the nourihment of the Foetus, and in the Breats for the Infant to uck, in the form of Milk; and alo from hence, that if one be let bloud four or five hours (or later) after a full meal, there will a great quantity of the milky Chyle it elf wim a top the coagulated Bloud. But every time the new infued Chyle paes through the Heart with the Bloud, the particles of the one are more intimately mixed with thoe of the other in its Ventricles, and the vital pirit and other active principles of the bloud work upon the Chyle; which being full of alt, ulphur and pirit, aoon as its Compages is looened by its fermentation with the Bloud in the ventricles of the Heart (epecially, but alo in the Arteries) thee principles having obtained the liberty of motion do readily aociate themelves, and are aimilated with uch parts of the Bloud as are of a like and uitable nature. Now whether this alteration that happens to the Chyle, epecially in the Heart, hould be aid to be by fermentation, or accenion, or by what other action, is a thing not yet (nor likely to be) agreed upon, it is o full of difficulty. But it eems to be by fermentation, from the coniderable heat obervable in the Arterial bloud; and if there be any thing of accenion, that eems to proceed, not from any part inherent either in the Bloud or Chyle, nor to be effected o much in the Heart and Arteries, as in the Lungs, whiles the Bloud paes through their Parenchyma out of the Vena arterioa into the Arteria venoa, and is inpirited or impregnated with nitrous air drawn into them by inpiration. Which will be more evident by what follows.

Why the Bloud hould be of a red colour rather than any other,The colour of the bloud. no reaon can be given but the will of the Creatour, though ome attribute it to the Heart, others to the mixture of alt and ubacid juices with ulphureous; even as the Oyl of Vitriol being poured upon Conerve of Roes, or other thing that is of a palih red (if it contain any thing of ulphur) makes it of a mot deep red. We will not pend time to hew in how many repects this imilitude falls hort of explaining the reaon of the Phaenomenon, but hall content our elves with inquiring from whence the difference of colour aries between the Venal and Arterial bloud. Every one knows that Bloud let out of a Vein into a Porringer, is indeed of a florid carlet colour in its urface, but all that coagulates is of a dark red colour from the uperficies to the bottom, and of uch a colour it appears as it treams out of the Orifice of the Vein. But if an Artery be cut, the tream then looks of a far brighter colour, like the uperficies of the Venal bloud when it is congealed in a Porringer. Now the Arterial bloud receives not this florid colour in the Heart but in the Lungs. For if it receiv'd it in the Heart, then might the right Ventricle be uppoed to give it as well as the left: but that it does not do o, is clear by this experiment of Dr. Lower's. If you open the Vena arterioa which receives the Bloud out of the right Ventricle, the Bloud differs nothing in colour from the Venal, but its curdled part looks every whit as black. But if one open the Arteria venoa as it is entring into the left Ventricle, it has the perfect colour of Arterial bloud; which
hews, that as it ows not that colour to the left Ventricle any more than to the right, (being not yet arriv'd at it) o it mut receive that alteration of colour in the Lungs, in which the nitrous air being diffued through all the particles of the Bloud is intimately mixed with it, and (if you will) accends it. For if there be any uch thing as a Flamma vitalis (properly o called) in Animals, though the Bloud be to it intead of the Oyl or other matter whereon it feeds, yet it oweth the continuance of its burning to the Air, without the continued inpiration of which the Animal cannot live, but intantly dies, even as a Candle is preently extinguihed if you put it in a cloe place where the air cannot come to it, or by ome Engine be uckt from it. But this by the bye. For I mut confes that (notwithtanding the plauiblenes of the opinion) this alteration of the colour of the Bloud by the Air in the Lungs, is no ufficient argument to prove any uch vital flame, eeing the Arterial bloud being extravaated, retains its florid colour, when no doubt if there ever was any accenion, the flame is extinguihed. But this carlet colour is meerly from the mixture of the particles of the Air with the Bloud, from which it tranpires, in a great meaure, through the pores of the Skin, while the Bloud circulates in the habit of the Body out of the Arteries into the Veins, whence the Venous bloud becomes o much darker in colour than the Arterial. And yet the Venous bloud it elf when extravaated appears of a carlet dye in its urface, which is meerly from its being expoed to the Air; for if one turn the congealed Bloud in a Porringer upide down, the bottom which
at the turning is blackih, will in a little while turn red.

Though we have confeed that the Chyle does circulate through the Body everal times before it be perfectly aimilated to the Bloud;Whether the body be nourih'd by bloud. yet we do not think that it paes into the nourihment of the parts in the form of Chyle. And therefore when peaking of the nutrition of the Foetus in the Womb (Book 1. Chap. 33.) we often mentioned a nutritious juice (which was Chyle a little alter'd) we did not call it o with repect to the olid parts of the Foetus, but to the Bloud it elf whoe Pabulum or nourihment it is, aoon as the Umbilical vein is formed, as the Bloud is of the Body. For as to the increae of the firt delineated parts of an imperfect Embryo, that is far different from ordinary nutrition.

The Bloud then coniting of particles of a different nature, each particle paes into the nourihment of that part which is of the ame nature. So the alt and ulphureous particles being equally mixt, are agglutinated and aimilated to the flehy or muculous parts; the oily and ulphureous to the Fat; the alt and tartareous to the Bones, &c. Now this is not done by any election or attraction of the parts, as if they pick'd and choos'd (with a kind of dicretion) uch particles of the Bloud as are uitable to their own nature: For the mas of Bloud is equally and indifferently carried to all the parts: But there is that diverity of figure both in the everal particles of the Bloud and in the pores of each part, that in the circulation through the habit of the Body ome tick in thee, and others in thoe,
where they are faten'd aud united to the ubtance of the repective parts; and thoe which through their peculiar figure are unapt to adhere to one or other, return again to the Veins and o to the Heart, where they receive ome new alteration. So that as the Life of the Fleh is in the Bloud (according to Levit. 17. 11.) o has it its vital heat and nourihment from it alo.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
Of the parts of the Heart, viz. the Auriculae, the Ventricles and the Septum that divideth them.
div.p: HAving treated of the Heart in general, and of its Action, &c. we now come to dicoure in pecie of the parts which it is compounded of, viz. its two Auriculae, two Ventricles and the Septum.

The Auriculae or Ears of the Heart are o called from ome imilitude of hape they have with thoe of the Head;Auriculae. for they rie from a long bais, upon the bais of the Heart, and end in an obtue point, making an obtue triangle. They are as it were two appendages of the Heart, eated at its bais over the Ventricles. They are of the ame fabrick and ue, being both Mucles, and made up of the ame order of Fibres, which are carried into oppoite Tendons, whereof that at the bais of the Heart is common to it and thee Auriculae, and the other runs along their upper
part. The right is larger and ofter, the left is les, but more firm. Their uperficies is mooth when they are filled; but when empty, it is wrinkled, and the left more than the right. When they are cut open, there appear in their Cavity many flehy columns running from the upper to the lower Tendon, and betwixt them there are pretty deep Ditches or long Cavities, but fewer in the right than the left.

They are dilated and contracted in like manner as the Heart,Their motion. but at different times: for the Sytole of the Ventricles is at the ame time with the Diatole of the Auriculae; and on the contrary, the Sytole of the Auriculae with the Diatole of the Ventricles. So that the Auriculae are a receiving their Bloud from the Veins, while the Ventricles are expelling theirs into the Arteries; and when the Ventricles are relaxed and empty in their Diatole, the Auricles force their Bloud into them by their Sytole.

They erve to receive the Venal bloud immediately out of the Vena cava,
e. and Pulmonalis, and to meaure it as it were into the Ventricles. Whither that they may expell it with the greater force, the internal Fibres or Columns of their cavity ariing from their root where they are joined to the bais of the Heart, reach directly outwards towards the Vena cava, and Pulmonaris, and in the Sytole of the Auriculae grap the Bloud contained in their cavity like o many fingers, and queez it into the Ventricles whilt they are relaxed in their Diatole.

The Heart hath two Cavities,The ventricles. called Ventricles, whereinto it receives the Bloud from its two Auricles, and out of which it expels it into the
Arteria pulmonaris and Aorta. The right is wider and not exactly round but almot emicircular, nor reacheth down to the Mucro or tip of the Heart; the left is narrower but rounder and longer, reaching down to the very tip. Now though the outide of the Heart be mooth, yet thee Ventricles are very unequal, having their ides hollowed into divers intertices or furrows, and interwoven with carnous Fibres reaching this way and that way. They are more numerous in Men's Hearts, than in thoe of any other Animal; though uch as are big, as Hores and the like, have them larger. Thee Fibres or flehy Columns erve to traiten or contringe the Ventricles, and the clefts or furrows betwixt them help their ides to cloe more exactly in their Sytole than they could have done, had they been mooth. The Fibres are more and tronger and the furrows deeper in the left Ventricle than in the right, yea they are alo in that ide of the Septum that makes part of the left, though that ide that looks to the right be well nigh mooth. For there was need of greater and tronger contriction in the left than in the right; eeing the right expels the Bloud to no greater circuit than through the Lungs, but the left to the extreamet parts of the Body.

They are divided from one another by the Septum, Septum. or a partition that tands like a Wall betwixt them. It is hollow towards the left Ventricle, and (as was jut now aid) has uch like Fibres and Clefts as the ret of the Cavity; but towards the right it is convex or bunching out, and has but very little inequality. Many have been of opinion that it has ome wider pores
through which part of the Bloud does pas immediately out of the right into the left Ventricle; but he that earches for them diligently will find none, unles he firt make them with his Probe. And indeed if there were any in grown perons, we may much more uppoe them to be in Foetus's in the Womb, in whom are everal paages that after the birth are obliterated. But if thee were in the Foetus, then hould Nature have made thoe two other paages in vain, namely the Foramen ovale, whereby the Bloud paes out of the Cava into the Vena pulmonaris as it is entring the left Ventricle; and the Canalis arterious, which carries the Bloud out of the Arteria pulmonaris into the Aorta. I ay if the Bloud could have paed out of one Ventricle into the other (without going through the Lungs) by any pores that perforate the Septum, thee other paages had been uperfluous. And therefore we may uppoe, that as in grown perons they cannot be found by any Probe or Britle, o they were not there even while the Foetus was in the Womb, eeing there was no occaion for them.

As to the ue of the Ventricles, it may be learned partly by what has been dicoured in the three former Chapters, and partly by what hall be aid further in the following, wherein we are to decribe the Veels opening into and out of them. Whither alo we transfer the treating of their Valves that are placed at their Orifices.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
Of the Acending trunk of Vena Cava.
div.p: BEcaue the Veels contained in the Thorax either open into the Heart or run out of it, having finihed the decription of It, we hall dicoure next of them as appendages to it. But we hall not need to repeat here what we aid Book 1. Chap. 10. of the Ductus chyliferus thoracicus, that runs up the Thorax by the Spine, and opens into the Subclavian vein, but hall deire the Reader to look back thither for the decription of it. And now hall only meddle with the Sanguiferous veels that are four in number, viz. Vena cava, Arteria pulmonaris (or Vena arterioa) Vena pulmonaria (or Arteria venoa) and the Aorta or Arteria magna; and in this Chapter of the firt, viz. Vena cava.

In the former Book Chap 12.Vena cava. and 13. where we dicoured of the Veels contained in the Abdomen, we uppoed (with the Galenits) that both the Vena portae and Cava had their rie from the Liver, not dogmatically aerting it, but uppoing it for methods ake. And in Chap. 13. decribing the branches of the Cava in the Abdomen, we found it preently dividing it elf (after its rie out of the upper part of the Liver) into the Acending and Decending trunk; the decription of the branches of the latter (in the lower Belly) we there finihed; but traced the Acending trunk no further than its penetrating through the Midriff up into the Thorax, deferring the further
proecution of it till this place that we come to treat of the Veels contained in the Thorax.

As it acends through the Midriff it ends forth a mall prig on each ide,Venae phrenicae. called Venae phrenicae; thee run through the Midriff, the Mediatinum and Pericardium. If at any time matter gathered in the cavity of the Thorax be afterwards dicharged by Urine, (which many Phyicians have affirmed) it is probable that it is aborbed by the mouths of thee Veins gaping in the upper ide of the Diaphragm, (upon which uch matter mut be uppoed to fluctuate) whereby it is brought into the Cava, and o in the circulation is eparated by the Kidneys out of the Emulgent arteries, and decends by the Ureters to the Bladder.

From the Diaphragm it paes undivided to the right ventricle of the Heart,Venae coronariae. but before it enter it, having pierced the Pericardium it ends forth ometimes one, ometimes two twigs called Venae coronariae, which compaing the bais of the Heart bring back into the Cava the Bloud that is uperfluous from its nutrition. As thee open into the Cava there is a Valve placed, which permits the Bloud to return by them into the Cava, but hinders any to pas out of the Cava into them.

Before this trunk of Vena cava open into the Ventricle it is joined to that other trunk that decends from the Claviculae, (though for method's ake we mut conider that as a continuation of this, by and by) and both of them dicharge the Bloud contained in them by one mouth into the aid Ventricle. As they are going to join, there comes a Tubercle or Protuberance betwixt them, that hinders the one from opening into the other
in a direct line, but makes them both go obliquely towards the left hand as they enter the Auricula; without which proviion, that Bloud that is a decending from the Claviculae would have faln o full on that which is acending by this trunk of the Cava, we have been a decribing, as mut have made it either to tagnate (if not regurgitate) or however would have retarded its motion.

Now immediately below this protuberance, out of the united trunk there goeth a paage along the bais of the Heart to the Vena pulmonaria in Foetus's in the Womb, which aoon as they are born cloes up and becomes obliterate. The reaon of this paage of the Bloud in them is, becaue their Lungs having either none or but a very obcure and imperfect motion, the Bloud does but little of it pas through them, but a good part of it through this Foramen out of the Cava into the Vena pulmonaria jut as it is entring into the left Ventricle, into which this Bloud is dicharged together with that little that is returning by the aid Vena pulmonaria from the nutrition of the Lungs. For though there be expelled out of the right Ventricle a pretty quantity of Bloud at every pule into the Arteria pulmonalis, yet there is but a little of it that goes to the Lungs (though all do in adult perons, that it may be there impregnated with Air) but the greatet part by a Pipe called Canalis arterious runs into the Aorta, which Pipe does degenerate into a Ligament after the Foetus is born. So that the Foetus in the Womb liveth after the manner of Fih or other Creatures that have no Lungs and but one ventricle of the Heart; for there is but very little of its Bloud that paeth any more than
one of its Ventricles in one circulation, that which circulateth through one miing the other. But to return:

The united trunk of the Cava opens by one large Orifice into the right ventricle of the Heart, into which is poured all the Bloud that returns from all the parts of the Body (except the Lungs) in its circulation. And let in the Sytole or contriction of the Heart, the Bloud hould be expelled the ame way that it comes in by; at the Orifice of the Cava there grows a membranous circle, which is cleft into three membranous Valves, looking inwards, called Tricupides (or three-pointed) which permit the Bloud to come in, but not to go out. And this office thee Valves perform in this manner, (as is mot ingeniouly decribed by Dr. Lower.) Out of the ides of the right Ventricle there grow certain Papillae or round and long Caruncles (called before, flehy Columns) from whoe top there proceed certain tendinous Fibres that are knit to thee membranous Valves. Now thee Membranes encompas the orifice of the Cava round about, o that whereas the Mucro or tip of the Heart is in every Sytole drawn up towards the bais, the Papillae being alo moved upwards do lacken their Fibres (like Bridle-reins) whereby it comes to pas that the Membranes (or Valves) alo, to which they are tied, hanging looe are driven upwards (like ails filled with wind) by the Bloud that is queezed in every Sytole of the Heart, and thereby they hut this inlet into the Heart o cloely, that not a drop of liquor can flow back again into the Auricula or Cava, but is expelled all into the Arteria pulmonalis that is now open: But, as in
every Sytole of the Heart (its tip being brought nearer its bais) the Papillae do much relax their Fibres; o in the Diatole the tip receding from the bais again does alo draw down the Papillae and their Fibres with it: whence it comes to pas that the Membranes or Valves being alo drawn down do preently unhut this Orifice, and open the door as it were for more Bloud to come in, what came in before being expelled in the lat Sytole.

The united trunks of the Cava dicharging themelves thus into the right Ventricle, that which acends towards the Claviculae (for o we mut conider it for orders ake, though in truth it decends from thence) aoon as it is gone out of the Pericardium, endeth forth a notable branch called Vena ine pari, (or < in non-Latin alphabet > ) becaue it is but one, having no fellow.

It arieth out of the hinder part of the Cava, Vena ine pari. but more towards the right hand, and decends through the right ide of the cavity of the Thorax. After its beginning, which is betwixt the fourth and fifth vertebra of the Breat, it bends a little forward toward the right hand, till it be decended as far as the eighth or ninth vertebra, where it begins jut to keep the middle. It ends forth on each ide Intercotal branches to the Intertices of the eight lowet Ribs; and at the eighth Rib it is divided into two branches: One whereof, being the larger, decends toward the left hand betwixt the procees of the Diaphragm, and is inerted ometimes into the Cava above or below the Emulgent, but oftner into the Emulgent it elf: The other being the right is joined alo to the Cava, commonly a little above the Emulgent, but eldom into the Emulgent it elf.

It was formerly held, before the circulation of the Bloud was found out, that in an Empyema of the Thorax, the matter was aborbed by the mouths of this Vein, and carried directly to the Emulgent veins, where it was eparated with the Serum by the Kidneys. But eeing the Bloud does indeed acend from the Emulgents by this Vein, and that at its inertion into them there is commonly a Valve that hinders any thing from iuing out of the Vena ine pari into the Emulgent, but permits the contrary; it is certain that if this Vein be at any time an intrument to evacuate uch Pus, it mut firt acend to the Cava and pas through the Heart, and o be carried to the Kidneys by the Aorta and the Emulgent arteries ariing out of it. But though it is difficult to conceive how the mouths of this Vein hould open o wide into the cavity of the Thorax, as to imbibe limy roapy Pus, and yet not let forth the Bloud that is more fluid; o that one would hardly aign this office to it: yet when the Pus is collected betwixt the Pleura and Intercotal mucles and the Tumour does not burt, I ee not why it may not be uppoed that the Intercotal branches of the Vena ine pari do imbibe the matter out of the Tumour, and carry it that way which was jut now poken of. And if ever Pus be imbibed out of the cavity of the Thorax, becaue it floats upon the Diaphragm, the Venae phrenicae are liker to do it than this, as was noted before in this Chapter when we decribed thoe Veins. Of this Vena ine pari we hall ay no more, but that at its rie out of the Cava it has a Valve that opens towards the Cava, which having ent forth this Vein, acends on towards the Claviculae trengthned and utained
by the Mediatinum and Thymus, and before it is divided into the two Rami ubclavii (ometimes after) ends out yet two other mall Veins called

The uperiour Intercotals, Intercotales uperiores. on each ide one, each of which has a Valve where it joins to the Cava, permitting the influx of the Bloud into it, but hindring its relape. Thee run along the Intertices or intervals of the three or four uppermot Ribs. Yet ometimes the Vena ine pari ends twigs to thee four Intertices of the Ribs as well as to the eight lower, and then thee uperiour Intercotals are wanting.

Afterwards the trunk of the Cava is divided into two large Veins,Venae ubclaviae. one of which goes to the right hand, the other to the left. Thee while they are within the Breat are called Venae ubclaviae, running along the Channel-bones; but aoon as they are gone out of it, Axillares. They end forth everal branches both upwards and downwards. Sometimes the uperiour Intercotals jut now mentioned (though eldom) arie out of them. Next, the

Mammariae decend from them,Branches ariing from them. (though thee ometimes pring out of the trunk of the Cava; o uncertain is the origine of ome of thee Veins.)1. Mammariae. Thee end forth double branches, Internal and External. The Internal run to the gritly ends of the Ribs and their Intercotal paces, and ome of their twigs alo are terminated in the glands of the Mammae. The external pas down on the outide of the Breat, and end many twigs into the aid Glands, and marching further by the ides of the Cartilago eniformis decend out of the Thorax, continuing their coure down the
Abdomen, under the treight Mucles thereof, till about the Navel, where it hath been an old Tradition that they inoculate with the Venae epigatricae; but this was a mitake, as has been noted more than once already. Bartholin ays that ometimes there is but one Mammaria.

The econd Vein that arieth out of the Subclavian is the Mediatina; 2. Mediatina. this ends twigs to the Mediatinum (from which it has its name) to the Pericardium and to the Gland called Thymus. This alo ometimes pringeth out of the trunk of the Cava.

The third is Cervicalis or Vertebralis; 3. Cervicalis. this turns backwards towards the vertebrae of the Neck, into whoe lateral holes it enters by ome mall twigs, which dipere themelves through the Membrane that invets the marrow contained in thee Vertebrae; and other twigs it betows upon the Mucles that lie next upon the Vertebrae.
The fourth is Mucula inferior; 4. Mucula inferior. this is pent upon the lower Mucles of the Neck and the upper of the Thorax. It rieth ometimes from the external Jugular.
All thee pring from the lower ide of the Subclavian veins; but thee that follow from the upper. As
The Mucula uperior, 5. Mucula uperior. which is dipered through the Mucles of the Neck.

Then the Jugulars, 6. Jugulares. which are double, External and Internal. As they go out of the Subclavians there is placed ometimes one thin Valve, ometimes two, to hinder the return of the Bloud out of thee into them.

The External acend on the outide of the Neck, and thee are they which are opened when any one is let bloud in the Neck for any Ditemper
of the Head, or Quinzy, &c. They acend but jut under the Skin, and provide for the outward parts of the Neck, Chaps, Head and Face. They make the Temple-veins and the Forehead-vein, both which are wont ometimes to be opened. Yea they end mall Capillaries through the utures of the Skull into the Membranes that cover the Brain.

The Internal, in Men, are larger than the External. They acend from the Subclavian by the ides of the Wind-pipe, on which they betow mall twigs. Aoon as they are come to the bais of the Skull, they are each divided into two, the greater and les. The greater is carried backwards, and by that hole of the Os occipitis by which the ixth pair of Nerves (Dr. Willis's eighth) comes out of the Head, they enter in, and are dipered through the Dura mater, &c. The les enters in by the holes made for the third and fourth pair of Nerves, and is alo betowed on the Dura mater, &c.
When the Subclavian veins have ent forth all thee branches, they then pas out of the Thorax, and begin to be called Axillar, of which we hall treat in the fourth Book, Chap. 1.

Into the Vena ubclavia are inerted alo the Ductus chyliferus thoracicus (of which in the firt Book Chap. 10.) and Lymphaticus ramus, which returns the Lympha from the Arms, Neck, &c. but ometimes this opens into the Jugular.

div.head: CHAP. X.
Of Vena arterioa, and Arteria venoa.
div.p: THE econd veel in the Breat is called Arteria pulmonaris, Vena arterioa. otherwie Vena arterioa. It is an Artery from its office: for it carrieth Bloud out of the right Ventricle of the Heart to the Lungs. Its Coat is double alo like that of other Arteries.

As it rieth out of the right ventricle of the Heart,Its valves. there tand at its orifice three Membranous Valves looking outwards, called Semilunares, becaue they make as it were a half circle; as alo Sigmoides or Sigmoideae, from the hape of the Greek letter Sigma, which of old was of the ame figure with an Englih capital C.
