In the Sytole of the Heart they open, and permit the Bloud to iue out of the Ventricle into this Artery; but in the Diatole they hut, o that none can return back again.

Aoon as it is pat out of the Pericardium, Branchings in the Lungs. it bends towards the Apera arteria or Wind-pipe, and is divided into the right and left branch, which applying themelves to the like branches of the Apera arteria do every where accompany them on the under ide, and as they run along end out very many twigs on every ide, which preently aociate with thoe of the Wind-pipe, and of the Vena pulmonaris. And where the mall Pipes of the Apera arteria end into the little round Cells (which we hall decribe in the Chapter of the Lungs) the twigs of this Artery
being complicated with thoe of the Vein do embrace them like a Net. Whence one may gues that the reaon why the anguiferous veels do o exactly accompany all the branches of the Wind-pipe and its annexed little Bladders, is, that the whole mas of Bloud paing this way may be inpired or impregnated with the particles of the nitrous Air. For there is but a very little pent on the nutrition of the Lungs, but the greatet part of it is driven into the mall twigs of the Vena pulmonaria which inoculate with thoe of the Artery in all its ramifications.

The third veel is called Vena pulmonaria or Arteria venoa; Arteria venoa. this has but a ingle Coat as the other Veins have. After it has accompanied the Wind-pipe and Arteria pulmonaris in all their branchings in the Lungs, and by its mall twigs has received the Bloud by anatomoes out of the Artery, it unites firt into two trunks (viz. the right and left) afterwards into one, and opens into the left ventricle of the Heart.

At its orifice there are placed two membranous Valves called Mitrales, Its valve • . becaue when they are joined together they do in ome manner reemble a Bihop's Mitre. They are of a tronger contexture than thoe called Tricupides at the orifice of the Cava in the right Ventricle; and o are the Fibres that acend to them from the Papillae or flehy columns, tronger. For eeing the Bloud is expelled more impetuouly out of the left Ventricle than out of the right, (for the Bloud ent out of the one is to circulate only through the Lungs, but that out of the other, through the whole Body) it was convenient that the Valves and Fibres hould be tronger, to utain the violent
motion of the Bloud, and hindring it from returning into this Vein again, to direct its coure into the Aorta whoe orifice opens in the Sytole of the Ventricle.

Jut as this Vena pulmonaria is entring into the left Ventricle, there is, in a Foetus in the Womb, a Pipe called Foramen ovale that opens into it coming from the Cava, as was noted above. To which we hall here add, that at its orifice into this Vein there is a Valve placed, that hinders any Bloud from returning into the Foramen out of the Vein.

And here there is one thing worth noting concerning the pulmonary Artery and Vein, That whereas in all the other Arteries and Veins through the whole Body beides, the Bloud contained in the Arteries is of a bright carlet colour, and that in the Veins of a black purple; on the contrary, the Arteria pulmonaris containeth black purple Bloud, and the Vein carlet-coloured. The reaon whereof was hewn before, Chap. 7. viz. That the carlet colour of the Bloud is wholly owing to the mixture of Air with it in the Lungs. And therefore that Bloud which the pulmonary Artery brings into the Lungs out of the right ventricle of the Heart, being the Venal bloud that was brought thither from the circulation by the Cava, changes not its colour till it paes out of the mall twigs of the aid Artery into thoe of the pulmonary Vein, where the airy particles ininuate themelves into it, and o alter its colour.

The pulmonary Vein hath no Valve in it, except that at its opening into the left Ventricle. Of which Dr. Willis giveth this reaon, That the
Bloud within the Praecordia may always, becaue of the Impetus of the paions, freely fluctuate and regurgitate both ways, backwards and forwards. And let the left ventricle of the Heart hould at any time be uffocated by the Bloud ruhing too impetuouly into it, the flehy Fibres in the root of the Vein (for both this and the Cava have uch there) by the intinct of Nature contracting themelves invert its coure, and make it flow backward towards the Lungs.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
Of the great Artery, or Aorta.
div.p: THE fourth veel is the great Artery called Aorta (arcula, a little Chet) and by way of eminency Arteria magna, becaue it is the greatet Artery of the whole Body, from which all the others (except the pulmonary) are derived.

It pringeth out of the left ventricle of the Heart,Its valves. and at its rie hath three Valves looking outwards, called Semilunares, being altogether like thoe at the orifice of the Arteria pulmonaris in the right Ventricle. Thee hinder the Bloud from returning out of the great Artery into the Heart again. The orifice of the Aorta (or ele the Tendon of the Heart that adheres to it) in ome Creatures (epecially in Harts) does often grow bony; and ometimes in Men, according to the obervations of Bartholin and Riolanus.

Aoon as the Aorta is gone out of the Heart, it acends not in a direct coure towards the Head; for if it had, eeing it openeth treight upward out of the Ventricle, it would have poured the Bloud in too rapid a tream into the Brain, and the lower parts of the Body would have been defrauded of their due hare: but it firt bends arch-wie, o that its bowed corner utains the firt Impetus of the expelled Bloud, and directs the greatet torrent towards its decending trunk, and a leer quantity paes up by the acending, being to convey the Arterial bloud to fewer and maller parts.

In a Foetus in the Womb there comes a Pipe out of the Arteria pulmonalis into the Aorta, called Canalis arterious, which brings out of it the greatet part of the Bloud that was expelled out of the right Ventricle; little more paing into the Lungs than may erve for their nourihment: of which we gave the reaon before, Chap. 9. After the Foetus is born, this Canalis degenerates into an impervious Ligament.

Before the Aorta come out of the Pericardium, it endeth forth ometimes one, but oftener two mall twigs, from each ide one, which compas the bais of the Heart like a Garland, and end down according to the length of the Heart other twigs: Thee are called Coronariae. When thee two twigs have encompaed the bais and meet, they inoculate with one another, but not with the Veins. At their rie out of the Aorta there is a Valve placed, that permits the Bloud to flow out of the great Artery into them, but hinders its reflux.

When it hath pierced the Pericardium, The diviion of the Aorta. and bended a little arch-wie backwards, it is divided into two Trunks, whereof the one is called Truncus acendens, the acending Trunk; the other decendens, the decending.
Of thee two, the decending is larget, becaue it minitreth to more parts.

The acending Trunk running up under the Vena cava lies upon the Wind-pipe,The branches of the trunk acending. and is preently divided into two branches, whereof one paeth to the right,1. Subclavia. the other towards the left Arm: They are called Rami ubclavii, becaue they march under the Channel-bones; and aoon as they are gone out of the Breat are called Axillares. The right is the larger, and ariing higher goes a more direct way towards the Arm; the left is les, and ariing lower acends more obliquely towards the left Arm. They end out everal branches both from their lower and upper ide.

From the lower proceeds the uperiour Intercotal,2. Intercotalis uperior. which runs along the intertices or intervals of the four uppermot Ribs, and ends lips to the neighbouring Mucles and pinal marrow. Thee ometimes arie from the cervical Arteries, coming out through the holes of the Vertebrae.

From the upper ide of each ubclavian prings firt Mammaria, 3. Mammaria. which decends towards the Breats through the Mucles that fill up the intertices of the cartilages of the true Ribs; and a coniderable branch of each decending out of the Thorax by the ides of the Cartilago eniformis, run down the Abdomen under the Muculi recti, preading there into many twigs: which are aid
to inoculate with the extremities of the like twigs of the epigatrick Artery acending. But that opinion is o oppoite to the circulation of the Bloud, that it is impoible to be true. For no Bloud can acend by the Mammariae, nor decend by thee acending twigs of the Epigatricae.

The next is Cervicalis (otherwie called Vertebralis) which endeth lips to the Vertebrae and Mucles of the Neck,4. Cervicalis. at whoe eventh Vertebra it enters in by the holes of the tranvere procees and pierceth the Membrane that invets the pinal marrow, betowing twigs both on the Membrane and marrow, and runs up therewith in at the great hole of the Occiput, and being enter'd the Skull, both branches (the right and left) join under the marrow, and then are divided into innumerable mot mall twigs which make wonderfull net-like Plexus in the Pia mater about the Cerebellum, and run into the ubtance of the Cerebellum it elf; and ome of them being united with thoe of the Carotides make part of the very Rete mirabile.
The third Artery that ries out of the upper ide of the ubclavian is Mucula; 5. Mucula. this betows branches on the mucles of the Neck, and ometimes on ome of the Arm.
After the Subclavians have had all thee pairs of Arteries going out of them, they pas out of the Thorax, and begin to be called Axillar, of which in Book 4. Chap. 2.

At the ame place,Carotides. or very near, where the acending trunk of the Aorta ends out the Subclavians ide-ways, it acends directly upwards, divided into two, called Carotides, (though the right
ometimes aries from the right Subclavian.) Thee at their rie are utained by the Thymus, and having betowed twigs on the Larynx, Tongue, the Mucles of the Os hyoides and the neighbouring Glands, pas up on each ide by the ides of the Wind-pipe to the Jaws with the internal Jugular vein, and there are each ubdivided into the external and internal branches.
The external is maller, and is dipered into all the Mucles of the Cheeks, Fore-head, Temples, Lips; and in general, through all the outer parts of the Head and Face.

The internal, which is larger, ends firt ome more twigs to the Larynx, Tongue, &c. as alo to the Glands behind the Ears, and the pongy parts of the Palate and Noe. Then it entreth the upper Jaw, and betows a mall lip on the root of each Tooth (as the external did to the Teeth of the lower Jaw) whereby harp humours flowing in upon them ometimes caue a very painfull Tooth-ach. The remainder of it climbs upon the Skull, being about its bais divided into two branches. The les and hinder whereof having ent one lip to the inner Mucles of the Neck, and another through the hole of the uppermot Vertebra into the Membrane that invets the pinal marrow, acending further enters the Skull at the hole by which the ixth pair of Nerves (commonly o called) comes out, and creeping along the Dura mater ends near its Sinus, (which yet ome ay it enters.) The larger branch, tending upwards is carried through the bony channel in the wedgelike bone with a winding duct to the Sella equina; at whoe bais, after it has ent out a twig on each
ide into the Dura mater, it opens it elf into many mall lips, which being infolded with thoe of the cervical Artery (above-mentioned) make the Rete mirabile, which is more obervable in Beats than in Men. Yet it is not all pent on the aid lips, but perforating the Dura mater, it enters the Pia mater with two notable branches, which being divided into very mall twigs are mingled with thoe of the cervical Artery, with which they pas out of the Skull and accompany the pinal marrow even to the Loins. Afterwards it ends a mall branch through the econd hole of the wedge-like Bone with the optick Nerve, out of the Skull, to the Eye. And yet till upplying more twigs to the ubtance of the Brain and Pia mater, and being united with ome other twigs of the cervical Artery, it makes the Plexus choroides.

The decending trunk of the Aorta, The branches of the trunk decending. which is larger than the acending, goes down by the Gullet, to which it cleaveth. And hence is a Man that is hot, o much cooled with a draught of cold drink; for the Gullet being cooled thereby, the Bloud in the Aorta contiguous to it mut needs be cooled likewie.

Before it arrive at the Diaphragm it ends out of its hinder ide the inferiour Intercotals which run along the intertices of eight or nine of the lower Ribs,1. Intercotalis inferior. namely thoe which the uperiour Intercotals did not upply. They likewie end prigs by the holes of the Vertebrae made for the Nerves, to the marrow of the Back, and to the Mucles which ret upon the Vertebrae and alo to thoe of the Thorax. Sometimes above this and
ometimes below it, there aries alo out of the hinder part of the Aorta, an Artery called Bronchialis, firt found out and o named by Frederick Ruych, which accompanies all the Bronchia of the Wind-pipe.
When it comes to the Midriff,2. Phrenica. there pring out of it the Phrenicae, one on each ide: thee running through the Diaphragm, pas up into the Mediatinum, and ometimes into the Pericardium.

Then having penetrated the Midriff it decends in one trunk to the fifth vertebra of the Loins;3. Coeliaca. in which paage it firt endeth forth Coeliaca which arieth ingle, and is o called, becaue it endeth twigs to the Stomach. This pringeth from the fore-part of the Trunk, at the firt vertebra of the Loins, and decending under the hollow of the Liver, upon the trunk of the Vena portae it is divided into two branches, the right and left.

The right which is maller,Its branches. acending, produces in its upper part the Gatrica dextra, Gatrica dextra. that comes to the Pylorus, whence Spigelius calls it Pylorica. Cyticae gemellae. And beides, the Cyticae gemellae, which are very mall, and are dipered through the Gall-bladder. And out of its lower ide there pring out of it.
1. Epiplois dextra, Epiplois dextra. which runs through the right ide of the lower leaf of the Caul and the Colon that is annexed to it.
2. Intetinalis, Intetinalis. betowed on the Duodenum and beginning of Jejunum.
3. Gatroepiplois dextra, Gatroepiplois dextra. on the bottom and middle of the Stomach, and alo on the Caul that is knit to its bottom.

4. Hepaticae, Hepaticae which are two mall ones: thee are pent on the inveting membrane of the Liver (for its Parenchyma is nourihed by the Porta) the Capulá communis, the Gall-bladder and Porus bilarius.
The remainder of this right branch enters the Meentery with many twigs.

The left branch of the Coeliaca, Splenica. which is called Splenicus (ometime pringing immediately from the Aorta) is larger than the right, and as it goeth towards the Spleen it endeth forth of its upper ide Gatrica major, Gatrica major. which after it hath betowed a lip on the higher and middle part of the Stomach, is divided into two others; the firt whereof is called Coronaria tomachica, Coronaria tomachica. which encompaes the upper orifice of the Stomach like a Garland, and ends many twigs to the body of the Ventricle it elf.Gatrica initra. The other is called Gatrica initra, and this is carried towards the right hand into the upper part of the Stomach and the Pylorus. Epiplo's potica. Out of its lower ide pring, firt Epiplois potica, which runs to the lower leaf of the Omentum, Epiplois initra. and the Colon annexed to it; econdly Epiplois initra, which is betowed on the lower and left ide of the Omentum.

Jut as this plenick branch is entring into the Spleen,Vas breve arterioum. there arie out of its upper part Vas breve arterioum, which goeth treight to the left part of the bottom of the Stomach;Gatroepiplois initra. and the Gatroepiplois initra, which being utained by the upper leaf of the Omentum ends ome twigs thereto, and alo to the left part of the bottom of the Stomach, and to both its fore and hinder ides. Then it enters into the Spleen, whoe branchings therein we decribed in the former Book, Chap. 16. of the Spleen.
All thee Arteries pring from the Coeliaca, and accompany the Veins of the Porta of the like denomination.

The next that aries out of the trunk of the Aorta is the upper Meenterick,4. Meenterica uperior. which prings from the fore-part of it as the Coeliack did. It accompanies the Vena mearaica of the Porta, and runs through all the upper part of the Meentery, and betows many branches on the Guts Jejunum, Ileum and that part of Colon that lieth in the right Hypochondre.

Immediately below this,5. Emulgentes. about the econd vertebra of the Loins, there go out of each ide of the decending trunk of the Aorta an Emulgent artery, each of which being after its rie divided into two and ometimes three branches, enters the Kidney of its own ide. The right prings out of it a little lower than the left. Both are ubdivided into innumerable twigs in the Parenchyma of the Kidneys, and their Capillaries end in the Glands, wherein the Serum that thee Arteries bring with the Bloud is eparated therefrom, and carried from them by the urinary Siphons into the Pelvis, of which more in the former Book, Chap. 17. of the Kidneys.

Next to thee arie the Spermaticae (called Arteriae praeparantes.) 6. Spermaticae. Thee go out of the fore-part of the Trunk very near together (very eldom either of them out of the Emulgents, as the left Spermatick vein does) and the right paes over the trunk of the Vena cava. About two fingers breadth from the Emulgents they are each joined with the Vena praeparans of their own ide, and decend with them in Men through the proces of the Peritonaeum to the Stones, being divided
into two branches a little before they arrive at them, one of which runs under the Epididymis, and the other to the Tetis. In Women, when they come near the Tetes, they are divided alo into two branches, one whereof goes to the Tetis, and the other to the bottom of the Womb.

Next below the Spermaticks prings the lower Meenterick out of the Trunk a little before it is divided into the Rami iliaci. 7. Meenterica inferior. This entreth the lower region of the Meentery, and ditributes many branches to the left part of the Colon and to the treight Gut, and latly decending to the Anus, makes the internal hemorrhoidal Arteries.

Very near to this,8 Lumbares. out of the Trunk till, arie the Lumbares, reckoned four in number. Thee go out of the backide of the Aorta, and are ditributed not only to the neighbouring mucles of the Loins, and to the Peritonaeum, but enter in at the holes of the vertebrae of the Loins, and run along the Membrane that involves the pinal marrow, and penetrate into the marrow it elf.
Beides thee ome reckon other two, on each ide one, called Muculae uperiores, (which run to the Mucles of the Abdomen) unles thee be two of the four called Lumbares.

When the Trunk is decended as low as the lat or fifth vertebra of the Loins and the top of Os acrum, it begins to climb upon the Vena cava, under which it paed thus far. But as it begins to get upon it, it is divided into two equal branches called Rami iliaci, Rami iliaci. and at its very diviion there prings out of it Arteria acra, whoe mall twigs entring in at the holes of Os acrum
penetrate into the marrow contained in it.
The Trunk of the decending Aorta being divided into the Rami iliaci, Their branches. thee are ubdivided preently into the interiour and exteriour branches.
From the interiour, which is les, proceed three others.
Firt,1. Mucula inferior. the inferiour Mucula (called otherwie Glutea) which is betowed on the Mucles named Glutei that make the Buttocks, and alo on the lower end of the Iliack mucle and the Poas.

Secondly,2. Hypogatrica. the Hypogatrick, which is large, and at the lower end of Os acrum runs to the Bladder and its Neck, and the Mucles that cover the Oa pubis. In Men it goes alo along the two nervous bodies of the Penis as far as the Glans: and in Women it is ditributed in numerous branches into the bottom of the Womb and its Neck, out of which for the greatet part iue the Menes in their monthly purgation. It goes alo to the Podex, where it makes the external hemorrhoidal Arteries.

Thirdly,3. Umbilicalis. the Umbilical artery, which acending by the ides of the Bladder, and being inerted into the duplicature of the Peritonaeum, proceeds to the Navel, out of which it paes in a Foetus in the Womb, and runs into the Placenta uterina, of which before, Book 1. Chap. 33. But after the Infant is born, when there is no more ue of it, it cloes up, and hardens into a Ligament, utaining the Bladder, and hindring it from preing on its Neck.
From the exteriour branch of the Ramus iliacus two Arteries arie.

Firt,4. Epigatrica. the Epigatrick, which turning upwards on the outide of the Peritonaeum runs betwixt it and the Muculi recti of the Abdomen as high as the Navel, where the Mammary artery meets it, and according to tradition (though fale) inoculates there with it. Of which before, in this Chapter.

Secondly,5. Pudenda. Pudenda, which ends forth a notable Artery on each ide into the nervous body of the Penis in Men, and into the Clitoris in Women. Hence it is carried inwards by the jointing of the Oa pubis to the Pudenda and Groins, and their Glands, and is pent on the Skin of thoe parts, and of the Yard.

When all thee pairs of Arteries have arien out of the Rami iliaci, they run down out of the Peritonaeum to the Thighs, where they begin to be called Crurales, where we hall leave them till we come to peak of the Arteries of the Limbs, Book 4. Chap. 5.

Having now traced all the Arteries pringing out of the Aorta (whether out of its acending or decending Trunk) in the Thorax and Abdomen, taking occaion to doe o, becaue the great Artery out of which they all arie, has its origine in the Heart, to which we have conidered it as an appendage; we hall pas on to the decription of the remaining parts in the Breat, not yet poken to.
Pag 281. Tab. IX.

list.head: Figure I.
list.item: Repreenteth the Veels that go into and out of the Heart.
a The Bais of the Heart.
b The Mucro or Cone of the Heart.
c The trunk of the Cava acending from the Liver.
d The trunk of the Cava above the Heart decending from the Claviculae.
e The uniting of thee two Trunks as they enter into the right auricle of the Heart.
f The Arteria pulmonaris riing out of the right Ventricle, and paing towards the Lungs.
g The Canalis arterious from the Arteria pulmonaris to the Aorta, pervious in a Foetus in the Womb.
h The Vena pulmonaria coming from the Lungs, and entring into the left ventricle of the Heart.
i The Aorta acending out of the left ventricle of the Heart.
k The acending trunk of the Aorta.
j The decending trunk of the Aorta.

list.head: Figure II.
list.item: Repreenteth the oblique Fibres of the Heart (lying under the treight, which are outermot, but here removed) which acending from the left ide towards the right obliquely, terminate in the bais of the Heart, (from Doctor Lower.)
a The bais of the Heart.
b The Cone.
c The Fibres that encompas the left Ventricle.
d The Fibres encompaing the right Ventricle.
e A Sinus in the intertice of the Ventricles made for receiving the veels of the Heart.

list.head: Figure III.
list.item: Repreenteth a econd rank of oblique Fibres lying under the former, and running clean contrary, from the right ide of the Heart to the left, (alo from Dr. Lower.)
a The bais of the Heart.
b The Cone.
c The right ide of the Heart.
d The left.
e The Fibres of the right Ventricle.
f The Fibres of the left.

list.head: Figure IV, V, VI, VII.
list.item: Repreent the Valves of the Veels that go into and out of the Ventricles of the Heart.

list.head: Figure IV.
list.item: A The orifice of the Vena coronaria.
B A print of the Anatomois between the Vena cava and Pulmonaria, by means of the Foramen ovale.
CC The Valvulae tricupides with the Fibrillae by which they are tied.

list.head: Figure V.
list.item: A The right Ventricle of the Heart opened.
BBB The Valvulae igmoides of the Arteria pulmonaris.

list.head: Figure VI.
list.item: AA The Vena pulmonaria laid open.
B A print of the Foramen ovale opening into it.
CC The two Valvulae mitrales.
D The left Ventricle laid open.

list.head: Figure VII.
list.item: A The Aorta cut open near the Heart.
BBB The Valvulae emilunares in the orifice of the Aorta.

div.head: CHAP. XII.
Of the apera Arteria and Lungs.
div.p: AS in the firt Book, being to treat of the Stomach, we firt decribed the Gullet, which erves as a Tunnel to it; o the ame reaon induces to begin with the Windpipe, called Trachea or apera Arteria, thereby to uher in the decription of the Lungs, to which it performs the ame office as the Gullet to the Stomach, this receiving in Air, as that does Meat and Drink.

The Apera arteria then is a long Pipe,The wind-pipe. coniting of Cartilages and Membranes, which beginning at the Throat or lower part of the Jaws and lying upon the Gullet decends into the Lungs, through which it preads in many branchings.

It is commonly divided into two parts,Its parts. the upper which is called Larynx, 1. Larynx. and the lower, that is named Bronchus. Of the former we hall peak in Chap. 14. where we hall treat of the parts contained in the Neck; of the other here.

By the Bronchus we mean all the Trachea beides the Larynx, 2. Bronchus. as well before as after it arrive at the Lungs. It is joined immediately to the Larynx, to whoe lowet Cartilage all thoe of the Bronchus are aimilated. Thee Cartilages are like o many Ribs, Hopes or Rings, eated one below another at equal ditances, and kept in their places by the inner membrane of the Trachea, which fills up their intertices and ties them one to another like a Ligament. Yet thee Rings
have not their circle intire, but on the back-ide of the Bronchus next the Gullet, that they might give way to the Meat in wallowing, they pas into a Membrane, which is the ame with the inner Membrane that ties them together. So that they are in figure like the letter C.

Beides the inner there is alo an outer Membrane that helps to connect thee Cartilages the more firmly one to another, and the whole Trachea to the neighbouring parts, that it may more afely and firmly decend into the Thorax. This is much thinner than the other: for the inner (according to Dr. Willis) has two rows of mucular Fibres, the outer treight, the inner oblique; the firt by their contraction horten the Trachea, the latter traiten it: o that he thinks they ait expiration, epecially when it is violent, as in coughing, hawking or the like. It is alo of mot exquiite ene, as every one knows, being the leat thing offends it and caues a Cough, which is a ort of Convulive motion. And this it ows to the recurring Nerves of the ixth pair (Dr. Willis's eighth) creeping along it more than the outer. It is uually bemear'd with a fattih and mucous humour, to hinder its drying, and to make the voice moother: for when this humour is fretted off in Catarrhs, or it becomes unequal from any caue, the voice becomes hoare; and when it is dryed by too much heat, as in Fevers, it becomes queaking.

The apera Arteria has Veins from the external Jugulars.Its veels. Arteries from the Carotides, and from the Arteria bronchialis, (firt found out by Frederick Ruych) which prings from the backide of the decending trunk of the Aorta, a little above
the lower Intercotals. Nerves it receives from the recurring branches of the par vagum, as aboveaid.

When it is decended as low as the fourth vertebra of the Thorax, Diviion. it is divided into two Trunks, whereof one goes into the right lobe of the Lungs, the other into the left, and each is preently again divided into two, and thoe into others, till at lat they end in very mall branches, which are dipered among the roots of the pulmonary Artery and Vein, and end into and are continued with the little Bladders that make up the greatet part of the Parenchyma of the Lungs. For

Though the Lungs (called in Greek < in non-Latin alphabet > ,The Lungs. à
< in non-Latin alphabet > to breath) have been held to be of a carnous ubtance,Their ubtance. not much unlike the Liver or Spleen; yet Malpighius hath dicover'd them to have a far other Parenchyma, namely oft, pongie and rare, made up of mot thin and fine Membranes continued with the inner coat of the Trachea, which Membranes compoe an infinite number of little round and hollow Bladders, o placed that there is an open paage from the Trachea out of one into another, and all are terminated at the outer Membrane that incloeth the whole Lungs.

Thee Bladders though they are continued to the Bronchia, yet they have no Cartilages as thoe have; but though they are very fine, yet they have mucular Fibres, whereby they contract themelves in expiration, but not o cloe as to expell all the Air included in them; for if the Parenchyma of the Lungs had fallen flat and cloe in expiration, it would have given ome top to
the circulation of the Bloud through them out of the pulmonary Artery into the Vein; whereas now that there remains till o much Air in thee Veiculae as to keep the Lungs a little pufft up and rare, the Bloud can pas the more eaily and wiftly through them.

That there are uch Bladders annexed to the Bronchia, Diemerbroeck hews by two notable Stories: The one of a Stone-cutter's Man that died of an Athma, in whom he found thee Veiculae o tufft with the dut of the hewn Stone, that when he cut his Lungs open, his Knife eem'd as if it went through an heap of Sand: The other of one that being employed to pick and cleane Feathers, died of a long continued Athma, and had thee Bladders quite fill'd with the fine Dut or Down of the Feathers. From whence he concludes, That whereas in a natural tate the Air in inpiration is received as well into thee Bladders as the Bronchia, eeing they could not now admit any Air, being tufft with the aforeaid matters, the Patients were necearily Athmatical, and dyed o.

We aid before that all thee Veiculae were inveted with a common Membrane in the uperficies of the Lungs;Inveting membrane. and this Dr. Willis will have double: The outer tunicle is thin and mooth, which eems to be a fine texture of nervous filaments; the inner rough and thicke • , coniting almot wholly of the extremities of the Veels and Veiculae; and through the little pits that are all over made in it by them, its inner uperficies looks like an Honey-comb. This inveting Membrane coniting thus of two Tunicles has many large pores, but uch as admit not any thing to pas from
within outwards; for if one fill the Lungs newly taken out of a Sheep or the like (before they are cold) with a pair of Bellows never o full of wind, there will none pas out of the Membrane, not o much as to make the flame of a Candle to wave: but on the other ide they do admit even liquors to pas from without inwards; o when the Breat has been opened to let out matter in an Empyema, (which was too thick to be aborbed by the too narrow pores) and bitter cleaning injections have been quirted into the cavity of the Thorax, to clear it from the purulent matter tagnating in it, it has been oberved that a good part of uch injections have been hawkt and cough'd up. And though ome think that whenoever Pus is cough'd up, it is certainly bred in the Lungs themelves; yet I am of opinion that in an Empyema when it is thin, thee pores may be o large as to imbibe it even out of the cavity of the Thorax; otherwie I ee not how any labouring of an Empyema hould ever be cured without tapping: for of the two I think this a far more probable way to dicharge the matter by, than that it hould be imbib'd by the mouths of the Veins gaping (as is uppos'd) either in the uperficies of the Pleura or Diaphragm. But to proceed.

The Lungs are divided into the right and left part,Diviion. being parted by the Mediatinum, and each part is otherwie called a Lobe. And becaue they are two, that have no communication one with the other (ave in one Trachea, by which the Air comes into and goes out of them) hence in common peech we ay Lungs in the plural. Each of thee parts or Lobes is ubdivided into
two, ometimes three others, and thoe into many leer Lobules, as may be een in the following Figure taken from Dr. Willis.

The Lungs hang by the Apera arteria that runs through the middle of their ubtance,Connexion. and o by its means adhere to the Neck. Preternaturally (though pretty often) they cleave by their outer uperficies to the Pleura, and ometimes with their lower end to the Diaphragm.

They have all orts of Veels,Veels. that are common to them with other parts;1. Trachea. but peculiar to themelves they have Bronchia or the branches of the Wind-pipe, for bringing in and carrying forth of Air.

Their Arteries and Veins are the Arteria and Vena pulmonaris, 2. Arteries and Veins. that accompany all the diviions of the Apera arteria within their everal Lobes. Thee open one into the other by many anatomoes, and are interwoven one with another all through the coats of the Veiculae. But of thee we dicoured o largely before, Chap. 10. that we hall ay no more of them here. Beides thee, that were all the anguiferous veels Anatomits had oberved to reach to the Lungs, there has of late been found out an Artery by Frederick Ruych (which he calls Arteria bronchialis) that eems to convey Bloud for the nourihment of the Lungs and Bronchia. But of this likewie before (in this Chapter.)

They have abundance of Lympheducts that attend upon the Veins and Arteries.3. Lympheducts. Their mall twigs running upon the outer uperficies of the Lungs, towards their root unite into everal greater trunks; which being inerted into the common thoracick duct, dicharge thereinto the
Lympha imbibed by them in the Lungs. They may be made to appear very plain in the outward urface, if in diecting a Live-dog, one pres upon the top of the thoracick duct, o as nothing be poured from thence into the Subclavian vein: for then the Lympheducts of the Lungs, eeing they cannot unload themelves into the common duct that is now topt and full, will well very much and be very conpicuous. If thee Lympheducts at any time be obtructed or broken, Dr. Willis thinks there often proceeds from thence a Dropie of the Breat or Lungs, yea Coughs and Phthiical ditempers.

The lat ort of Veels dipered in the Lungs are the Nerves.4. Nerves. And thee proceed from the recurring Nerves of the Par vagum, uually called the ixth pair, but Dr. Willis's eighth, who ays they are ditributed all over the Lungs along with the anguiferous Veels and ducts of the Bronchia, to upply animal pirits to the mucular Fibres of their Coats.
Their Action is repiration, of which in the next Chapter.

AAA The inner uperficies of the Sternum and of the Cartilages knit to it.

Fig. 2.
Fig. 3.

C The glandulous body called Thymus.
DDDD The ides of the Mediatinum pull'd aunder from the Sternum.
EE The pace between the Membranes of the Mediatinum, ariing from the tearing of it from the Sternum.

A The left Nerve of the Diaphragm.
B The right.
C The upper membrane of the Diaphragm a little eparated.
D The carnous ubtance of the Diaphragm bared.

list.head: Figure III.
list.item: Repreenteth a piece of one Lobe of the Lungs, (according to the ramifications of the Apera arteria) divided into many leer Lobules, (from Dr. Willis)
A The mucular Villi or Fibres running treight lengthways in the inide of the Apera arteria, upon which other circular ones lie.
BBB A part of the trunk of the Trachea, as alo its branches that make the leer Lobules, uncut open, that their annular Cartilages may be een.

CCCC The econdary Lobules hung upon the tems of the Bronchia like Grapes (which might yet be divided into leer Lobules) all whoe inner ducts pas out of the Bronchia into the Air-bladders, or veiculary cells.
dddd The anguiferous veels creeping along the uperficies of the Lobules.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.
Of Repiration.
div.p: THE Action for which the Lungs are appointed by Nature is Repiration, which is an alternative Diatole and Sytole, or dilatation and contraction of the Breat, whereby the Air is received in, and driven forth of the Lungs.

Now the Lungs do not dilate themelves by any proper power or faculty of their own,How repiration is performed. being detitute of intruments to perform uch an action; nor do they attract the Air by any magnetick property, in inpiration: But the Mucles of the Thorax being o framed, that though contraction be the only and proper action of a Mucle, yet the Thorax is dilated by certain of them, as it is contracted by others; whilt it is dilated, there is greater pace given for expanding the Lungs, and then the Air by its proper elatick virtue does of its own accord iue in at the Trachea, and ininuates it elf into all its Bronchia and into the Veiculae, and puffs them all up; namely to the end that its nitrous particles may every where meet with the Bloud as it glides through all the parts of the Lungs: And when the Breat receding from that dilatation is contracted, the Lungs, being partly compreed thereby, and partly by the mucular Fibres of the Veiculae and of the inner coat of the Trachea and Bronchia, expell the Air out again.

The Mucles that ait the dilatation of the Breat,Mucles minitring to repiration. are thoe that lift up the Ribs and draw
them backwards; which hall be decribed Book 4. Chap. 15. And beides thee there is another internal Mucle, namely the Midriff, that contributes towards it, as was hewed Chap. 3. of this Book, where we treated of it. And as for the traitning or concidence of the Thorax, that it is not only a motion of retitution, or a ceation of the foreaid Mucles from their action, as evident, eeing ometimes expiration is performed more laboriouly and violently than inpiration, as in coughing, hollooing, or the like. And therefore Nature has provided peculiar and proper Mucles for that purpoe, decribed in the ame Chapter of the fourth Book; and thee are aited partly by ome Mucles of the Abdomen, and partly by the mucular Fibres of the Veiculae, Trachea and Bronchia, as aboveaid.

There hath been great controverie among Philoophers whether repiration be an Animal or Natural motion.What kind of motion repiration is. That it is natural, is thought to be proved, both in that it is performed as well when we are aleep, as awake; and alo that though it be continued through a Man's whole life, yet we are never wearied with it as we are with animal and voluntary motions. On the other ide ome prove it to be animal, firt becaue it is performed by uch Intruments as erve for animal motion, namely Mucles; and econdly becaue at our pleaure we can make it quicker or lower, tronger or weaker, or alter it how we pleae. Others thinking the arguments on either ide convincing, take both in, and uppoe it a kind of mixt action, partly natural, and partly pontaneous. But I think there is no neceity from the arguments alledged to grant this
motion to be natural, or any more than animal or pontaneous. For as to the firt argument, that the motion is as well performed when we leep as when we are awake, and therefore it cannot be voluntary; if this were allowed to be of force, we mut alo grant walking and talking to be natural motions, becaue many perform them both, when they are aleep. And as to the econd, from our not being wearied by it, in anwer to it we may ditinguih of animal actions, into uch as are done by intinct and are free, and into uch as erve the affections of the mind: the former proceed always and without impediment, even when we think not thereon, but may notwithtanding be directed and moderated when we do think of them, and uch is repiration; the latter is not performed continually, as to run, leap, write, &c. In the former there is a plentifull and continual influx of animal pirits into the Mucles, of cutom or coure; whence there follows no wearines, though they be continual: In the latter, eeing by the determination that is made in the Brain the pirits now flow in and anon ceae, ometimes in greater plenty and ometimes in les, from this mutation and unaccutomednes does the wearines proceed.

Repiration is o neceary to the continuance of life,The ue of it. that after once the Foetus comes into the open Air and begins to breath, it can hardly live two minutes without it. But upon what account it becomes o neceary is not agreed among learned Men, each party exhibiting uch reaons of it, as may bet uit with their hypothees. Hence ome (and thoe the mot) think that repiration erves for the cooling and ventilating of the
Bloud that acquires a great heat in the right Ventricle of the Heart, and alo for the carrying out fuliginous treams therefrom. Others, that it erves for the better mixture of the particles of the Bloud as it paes through the Lungs, as alo to further its circulation. Others, that the Air is inpired for the greater ubtilization of the Bloud, and inkindling of the vital pirits, or (to continue the metaphor) vital flame. More opinions there are, but this lat is (if not the truet) the mot ingenious, and is very learnedly maintained by Dr. Willis, Dr. Charleton, &c. whom the Reader may be pleas'd to conult for further atisfaction.
A econdary ue is to form the voice; for uch Creatures as breath not (as Fih, &c.) are mute.

div.head: CHAP. XIV.
Of the Neck and the parts contained in it, viz. the Larynx, Pharynx, Tonillae, &c.
div.p: HAving now dipatched all the parts of the middle Venter or Thorax, we hould next proceed to the highet, viz. the Head; but betwixt thee two is the Neck, like an Ithmus between them, which therefore we mut take in our way, and decribe the parts contained in it.

It is called Collum, Its name. either à Colendo, becaue it ued to be adorned with Chains, &c. or becaue it rieth out of the trunk of the body intar Collis like an Hill. Collum is a general
name for the whole Neck; yet the hinder part of it is particularly called Cervix.
The parts of it are either containing, Parts containing. or contained. The containing are the ame which are found in the ret of the Body, aving that the Membrana carnoa eemeth to be more flehy.
The parts contained are thee.Contained.
1. The Larynx, 1. Larynx. which is the upper part of the Wind-pipe, and the intrument of forming the voice.
It is almot round and circular in figure,Its figure. only jetting out a little before, and omething flattih behind, to give way to the Gullet in wallowing.

Its bignes differs according to age,Bignes. ex, and temperament, whence proceeds the great diverity of voices. Such in whom it is narrow, as in younger people, have hrill and mall voices; uch as have it wide and are come to maturity, have fuller and more hoare. The voice is altered alo in repect of the length or hortnes of the Larynx, and as the Air is more trongly or weakly expelled.
It has Arteries from the Carotides, Veels. Veins from the external Jugulars, and Nerves from the recurring branches of par vagum.
Beides the Membranes which are common to it with the ret of the Trachea (decribed before,Subtance. Chap. 12.) it is made up of five Cartilages and thirteen Mucles.

The firt Cartilage is called < in non-Latin alphabet >
cutiformis, Cartilages. or Buckler-like; for within it is hollow, but without emboed or convex: that part which ticketh out is called pomum Adami, from an idle fable, that part of the fatal Apple by God's judgment tuck in his Throat, and that this Cartilage
being thereby ditended was made to jet out, and the protuberance propagated to poterity. It is greater in Men than in Women. The econd Cartilage is called < in non-Latin alphabet >
annularis, becaue it is like a Turkih ring, and compaeth the whole Larynx; in the hinder part it is broad and thick. The third and fourth becaue of the Membrane that invets them, eem but one, but it being removed they appear to be two. However they have but one name which is < in non-Latin alphabet >
guttalis, becaue when their two procees are joined together, they are intar gutturnii like to that part of the neck of a Jug or Ewer at which we pour out the water. For by their juncture they frame a rimula or little chink for the modulating of the voice, called Glottis. The fifth is called Epiglottis, becaue it is placed above the Glottis or Chink, and covereth it. It is of the form of a Tongue, and is appointed to hinder the falling down of any thing which may prove offenive unto the Wind-pipe, when we eat or drink. It is preed down by the weight of the things which are wallowed, and turneth them down to the Gula.
The Mucles by which thee Cartilages are moved in forming the voice,Mucles. are thirteen in number; but as for their names and decription, the Reader may pleae to conult Book 5. Chap. 11.

The econd part contained in the Neck is the upper part of the Gullet,2. Pharynx. which is called Pharynx, from < in non-Latin alphabet > , becaue it conveyeth the Meat and Drink towards the Stomach. It is continued to the Fauces, ( • or indeed is the greatet part thereof) reaching up behind to the vula, on the ides to the Tonillae, and before to the Epiglottis.
It is membranous, but not purely o, for it is thick and in ome ort carnous. It has even Mucles, to ait it in wallowing, three pair to open it, and an odd one, which is called its Sphincter, to traiten it, of which Book 5. Chap. 12.

The next parts are the Tonillae, 3. Tonillae. commonly called Almonds, which are two Glands eated at the root of the Tongue, on each ide of the vula, and at the top of the Larynx, covered with the common Membrane that invets all the Mouth. They are of a yellowih colour, and Dr. Wharton compares their ubtance to concreated Honey, only they are of a more firm conitency, but they look andy like it: They have mall veels from the Jugular Veins and Arteries, and Nerves from the fifth and ixth pair.

They have each a large oval common Duct or Sinus that opens into the Mouth,Their duct. o wide in an Oxe that one may put the top of ones little finger into it. Into this many leer open, and by it dicharge into the Mouth, &c. the liquor that is eparated in the Gland.

The ue of thee Glands is to eparate a certain mucous or pituitous matter from the Bloud, e. for the moitening and lubricating of the Larynx, Tongue, Fauces, and Gullet. Dr. Wharton acribes a more noble ue to them, viz. to make a Ferment to further the concoction of the Stomach, yea thinks that they are the chief Intrument of tate.

There are everal other Glands that are near to thee, as 1. the Thyreoideae that are eated towards the lower part of the Larynx at the ides of
the Cartilages Thyreoides and Cricoides, &c. 2. The Jugular, placed by the Jugular veels; of which Dr. Wharton has told fourteen on each ide: 3. Parotides, ituated at the root of the Ear; which whoo would ee accurately decribed, may conult the aid Dr. Wharton, in his Adenographia, cap. 18, 19, 20. for they are too minute and inconiderable parts to fill up any large room in this Epitome. Neither hall we mention the Veins and Arteries that pas through the Neck to the Head, having decribed them before in Chap. 9. and 11.

As to other parts that make up the Neck, viz. the even Vertebrae, and eight Mucles, thoe will come to be treated of in their proper Books: And therefore we hall pas immediately to the highet Venter, the Head.
div.trailer: The end of the Second Book.

div.head: CHAP. I.
Of the Head in general, and its common containing parts.
div.p: NOW followeth the third and highet Venter of the Body, called Caput, the Head. This is the mot noble Cavity of the three, containing the Brain, wherein the rational Soul more epecially operates, and whereby all the animal motions of the whole Body are moderated and determined; as well as performed by means of the pirits elaborated in it, and ent into all the parts by the Nerves.
Of figure it is pherical;Figure. yet omewhat flattih, and longih.
It is bigger in Man than in other Creatures,Bignes. conidering the proportion of their Bodies; as his Brain alo is.
The parts are of three orts,Parts. for they are either 1. ditinctive, or 2. expreive of the regions, or 3. contitutive of the whole.
The parts ditinctive are two, the hairy calp called Calva, and that without hair called Facies.

The parts which expres the regions (of the firt,) are four: 1. Sinciput or the fore-part, reaching from the Forehead to the coronal future. 2. Occiput the Noddle, or hinder part, beginning at the future Lambdoides, and reaching to the firt vertebra of the Neck. 3. Vertex, the Crown, which is ituated on the top of the Head between the bounds of the Sinciput and Occiput. And 4. the lateral parts decending from this on each ide between the Ears and Eyes are called Tempora, or the Temples.

The parts contitutive are either containing, or contained. the containing are either common or proper. The common are thoe we treated of in Chap. 3. of the firt Book, viz. the Cuticula, Cutis, Pinguedo, and Membrana carnoa. The Cuticula is thinner and ofter; but the Skin thicker than in any other part of the Body, yet porous, to give way to the nourihment of the Hair. The Membrana carnoa in ome cleaveth o to the Skin, that they can move it at their pleaure.

We hall not need to ay more here of thee
common containing parts, but refer the Reader to the above-cited place; and now proceed to the proper, having firt dicoured a little of the Hair.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Of the Hair.
div.p: THE Hairs of the Head are called in Latine Capilli, Its name. quai Capitis pili, and differ not from the Hairs in any other part of the Body, ave in length.
Now an Hair may be defined to be a body cold and dry,Definition. mall, thread-like, hard and flexible, budding from the Skin.

The Hairs are eldom round,Figure. but generally four quare, as the talks of ome Plants; ometimes triangular, but always porous, the pores running lengthways. All thee things may be oberved in a good Microcope. They are ometimes curled, and ometimes hang lank.

Hairs are commonly divided into Congeniti, uch as we bring into the World with us, as thoe of the Head, Eyelids, and Eyebrows; and Potgeniti, uch as begin to grow at certain eaons in our life-time, as the Beard, the Hairs growing about the Pudenda, on the Breat, in the Armpits, and the like.

They are no parts of the Body,Life. and therefore have no Animal life; yet they have a Vegetative life, and that peculiar to themelves, and not owing to the life of the Body, eeing they continue
to grow after a Man is dead, as has been oberved in embalmed Bodies.

The matter out of which they are bred and nourihed is commonly reputed to be a moit,Matter. fuliginous, cras, earthy and omewhat vicid excrement of the third concoction. Spigelius thinks they are nourihed by Bloud: which opinion he grounds on an analogy he uppoes there is between Hair, and the Feathers of Fowl; and thee latter he ays are apparently nourihed by Bloud, for if one pull one from off a young Fowl, its end is bloudy. Diemerbroeck dients not much herefrom, but thinks the Bloud to be prepared and concocted in a pecifical manner into a cras, earthy and vicid juice. Whatever the matter be, it is attracted by the white roots of the Hairs, and is carried even to their very ends by the pores; jut as Plants receive nourihment out of the Earth by their Roots, and communicate it to their outmot parts.

The colour of them is anwerable to the Climate,Colour. or to the natural contitution of the party, or to the diverity of thoe humours that are mixed with the juice whereby they are nourihed. In thoe of cold flegmatick contitutions they ue to be of a light colour, in cholerick, reddih, &c. They are mot commonly treight in thoe which are born in cold Countries, but curled in thoe who inhabit hot Climates.

And as the reaon of the difference of the colour of the Hair in everal perons is from different temperaments,Why hair turns white. &c. o the reaon why Men in old age grow grey, whenas their Hair before was of another colour, eemeth to be the predominance of flegm in that juice that nouriheth
them: whence alo the Hairs of the Head and Face oonet turn white, becaue the Brain does more abound with pituitous humours than any other part of the Body. But it is not o eay to give a reaon of ome Men's turning grey in one nights time, when they have been under great fears; of which there are many intances credibly reported.
The Hairs have three ues: Their ue. for they erve 1. for defence, 2. for beauty, and 3. hew the temperature of the whole Body and Skin.

div.head: CHAP. III.
Of the proper containing parts.
div.p: THE proper containing parts are five; to wit, the Mucles, the Pericranium, the Perioteum, the Cranium, and the Meninges. Look for the Mucles in the fifth Book, and for the Cranium in the ixth. Of the other here. And Firt

The Pericranium is a Membrane thinnih,The Pericranium. dene and white, of exquiite ene, immediately eated under the Membrana carnoa. It covereth the whole Skull, except where the temporal Mucles lie upon the Cranium, for it is tretched over them, and eeing it is very enible and tender, it caueth horrible pain and inflammation, when the temporal Mucle is wounded.

It is tied to the Dura mater by ome nervous Fibres,Its connexion. which pas within the Skull by its Sutures, to tay firmly the Dura mater, and alo the Brain which it invets, from inordinate moving. And
although in Infants new born thee be trongly united, inomuch that the Pericranium is aid by ome to pring from the Dura mater; yet in proces of time they part, and become joined only by ome fibrous ties, by which, inflammations may be communicated from the Pericranium to the Brain.

Next under the Pericranium is pread the Perioteum, Perioteum. which immediately cleaveth to the Skull and gives it that ene which it hath. It elf is a very thin and nervous Membrane, and of very acute ene. All the Bones of the whole Body (except the Teeth) are inveted with uch alike Membrane, and owe their ene to it. Some deny it to be found here, affirming that the Pericranium upplieth its place: But that cannot be o, for the Pericranium (as was noted above) goeth above the temporal Mucles, whereas the Perioteum always cleaveth cloe and immediately to the Bone, as here it doth to the Skull under the aid Mucles.
Thee two Membranes outwardly inveting the Cranium have Arteries from a branch of the external Carotides, Their veels. and Veins from the external Jugulars.

The Meninges follow, The Meninges. called by the Arabians, Matres; as if all the Membranes of the Body were propagated from them. Thee are immediately within the Skull as the other were without; but adhere not cloe thereto, as thoe do. They are two in number: the Craa meninx or Dura mater, and the Tenuis meninx or Pia mater.

The Dura mater is the outer,Dura mater. that is, is next to the Skull, through whoe Sutures ending Fibres to the Pericranium, it is upended thereby; for in other places it is looe from the Cranium,
aving in its bais, to which it is o firmly knit, that it can hardly be pulled from it; or where it is upended by Veels entring into it from the perforations of the Skull. It is thicker and harder than the inner, whence it has the epithet of dura, hard. It conits of a double Membrane, the outer of which is more rough, towards the Cranium; and the inner is more mooth and lippery, and as it were bedewed with water. It is knit to the Pia mater by many veels that pas from it thereto.

It has many foramina or holes for the tranit of the Veels;Its holes. and beides, one very large one at the decent of the pinal marrow, and another toward the Glandula pituitaria: And where it adheres to the Os cribriforme, it is perforated like a Sieve.

It has Arteries from the larger branch of the Carotides, Veels. entring into it through the holes of the wedge-like Bone, and that of the Forehead. Thee in ome places run out of it into the Pia mater, by means whereof they are in ome meaure knit together. Veins it has from the internal Jugulars.

At the Crown of the Head it is doubled,Falx. from whence its duplicature decending inwards, divides the Brain into the right and left ide. This duplicature, becaue it is broader backwards, and grows narrower forwards, and o reembles in ome manner a Reaper's Sickle, is called Falx. Now this Falx reaches as far forwards as to the top of the Noe, where it grows to the Partition-bone that ditinguihes the Proceus mammillares, and is called Galli crita or Cock's comb. But its hinder and broader part towards the Occiput, being
evered, decends towards both the right and left ide, and ditinguihes the Cerebellum from the Cerebrum.

In the aid duplicature are formed four Sinus or Cavities,Sinus. three pretty large, and one little one. The firt which is the highet and longet, runs along the upper part of the Falx, from the top of the Noe lengthways of the Head towards the Occiput, where it is divided into two lateral Sinus decending by the ides of the Lambdoidal future to the bais of the Occiput. And at the aid diviion the fourth hort Sinus proceeds inwards to the Glandula pinealis. Into thee Cavities the Mouths both of Arteries and Veins are aid to open; by the former whereof Bloud is extravaated into them, and aborbed again out of them by the latter. Whence if one open the Skull of a live-Creature, one may oberve a beating in the long uppermot Sinus, from the Bloud dicharged into it by the Arteries. And ome are of opinion that the Veins alo convey ome Bloud into them, which being uperfluous to the nourihment of the Brain and Meninges is poured in hither by the Veins from the repective parts, and is imbibed again by other Veins opening into them, namely the inner branches of the Jugulars, to be returned to the Heart. The place where all thee Sinus meet together at the Occiput, is called torcular Herophili.

The econd (and inner) Membrane inveting the Brain is called Tenuis meninx or Pia mater. Pia mater. This is of mot exquiite ene, and endowed with very many Arteries and Veins. It immediately cloaths the Brain and hinders it from running about, and alo involves all its windings and circuits, and
tying their ummities together makes all the uperficies of the Brain plain as it were: which upper connexion being looed, the windings of the Brain, becaue they are inveted with this Membrane, may eaily be eparated and laid open. From this ame Meninx proceeds alo a mot thin Membrane inveting the inner Ventricles of the Brain.

This Membrane is interwoven with many admirable Plexus or Nets of mot mall Veels,The Plexus of its veels. pringing from the Carotides and cervical Arteries and Jugular Veins joined every where by mutual inoculations, that by o great a number of Veels there might on every hand be affued Bloud enough for the nourihment of the Brain, and making of Animal pirits. Dr. Willis writes that he has oberved very mall Glands intermixt among thee Plexus of Veels, which he aith may be eaily perceived in a moit or hydropick Brain, but not o well in others.

Both the pinal marrow extended to the bottom of Os acrum, and all the Nerves that arie out of it, and out of the Brain, have a double Coat from thee two Meninges, with which being cloathed they run to their deigned parts.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
Of the Brain in general.
div.p: THE Pia mater being taken away, the Brain offereth it elf, called by the Greeks < in non-Latin alphabet > . It is the general organ of ene, in which the Soul, the governour of the Body, perceives and judgeth of the enations of all entient parts, and out of which, as out of a fountain, it communicateth the beams of its benignity (namely the Animal pirits bred in the Brain) by the ducts or rivulets of the Nerves to all the entient parts of the Body, and thereby endows them with the faculty of performing Animal actions.

Its ubtance is thick,Its ubtance. vicous, oft, and white. It is not a Glandule, for it is the Work-houe and Seat of the Animal pirits; but Glandules are appointed to receive excrementitious humours, and it is more curiouly framed than any Glandule. Neither is it of a marrowy ubtance; for marrow wimmeth in water, but this inketh. Beides, marrow nouriheth the Bones; but the Brain nouriheth no part. And latly, Marrow being cat into the fire flameth, but o will not the Brain. It eemeth therefore to be a Vicus or Bowel, endowed with a peculiar ort of a Parenchyma, part of which Malpighius by the help of his Microcopes has oberved to be of this ubtance, viz. That all the white part of the Brain (called the Corpus calloum) is evidently divided into flattihly round little Fibres, which in the
Brains of Fih are o apparent, that if you hold them betwixt you and the light, they repreent the mall teeth of an Ivory comb. Thee Fibres he aith are inerted by their ends into the Cortex or the ah-coloured outer part of the Brain, through which abundance of anguiferous veels are dipered, and out of which therefore the aforeaid Fibres eem to draw their nourihment. Dr. Willis calls thee Fibres Canales or Striae, whence the Corpus calloum might as well be called Striatum.

For nutrition and confection of Animal pirits it receives Bloud by Arteries derived from the Carotides and Cervical,Veels. whoe Capillaries are dipered through its ubtance: and what is uperfluous to the aid ues is partly imbibed by the Veins of the Meninges, and partly depoited in the Sinus's by the Arteries themelves, to be carried to the internal branches of the Jugulars, and thereby to the Heart. The Arteries inoculate one with another (i. e. the right Carotides with the left) as well as with the Veins. And it is from the Pule of the Arteries altogether, that the beating (or Sytole and Diatole as it were) of the Brain proceedeth.
A Man of all other living Creatures hath the bigget Brain;Bignes. for it weigheth four or five pound in ome; and is as big again as an Oxe's Brain.

The outer urface is full of windings,Figure. like thoe of the Guts, which are everally inveted with the Pia mater, as alo tied together by it. The whole Brain is much of the ame hape with the Head, viz. roundih, but with bunchings out towards the Forehead.
Of its Action we hall peak in the 9th Chapter.

div.head: CHAP. V.

Of the parts of the Brain properly o called, viz. Cortex, Corpus calloum, Septum lucidum, Fornix, three Sinus, Infundibulum, Glandula pituitaria, Plexus choroides, Rete mirabile, Nates, Tetes, Anus, and Glandula pinealis.
div.p: THE Brain taken in a large ignification hath three parts, Cerebrum, that which properly is called the Brain: the Cerebellum, or little Brain: and that part of the Spinalis medulla, which is within the Skull.

Now there are everal methods of diecting the Brain, ome beginning behind, as Dr. Willis; ome on the right ide, as Sylvius; and ome at the Crown, which is the old way, and this we hall follow, beginning with the Cerebrum properly o called, which lieth uppermot.
The Brain differeth from the Cerebellum; Its difference from the Cerebellum. firt, in ubtance, for it is ofter; econdly, in colour, for it is whiter; thirdly, in bignes, for it is three times as big.

The upper part of the Brain is divided into two parts by the Falx above-decribed,The diviion of the Brain. to wit, into the right and left. But this partition decendeth no deeper into the Brain than the thicknes of the ah-coloured part of it, which is called its Cortex.
Its Cortex. For if this be removed, that which lieth under it,Corpus calloum. being of a whiter ubtance, is a continued body, commonly called Corpus calloum,
whoe ubtance we decribed above in the foregoing Chapter out of Malpighius. Dr. Willis ays, it is wholly medullar: whence ome divide the Brain (properly o called) into Cortex and Medulla.

The inferiour part of the Corpus calloum maketh a partition,Septum lucidum. which is called Septum lucidum. It is looe and wrinkled; but if it be pread out, and held to the light, it appeareth clear. It cleaveth above to the Corpus calloum, but below to the Fornix. Some will have it to be a reduplication of the Pia mater; others a portion of the Brain.

Under the Corpus calloum, Fornix. the Fornix or Vault is eated, of the like ubtance. In the upper part it is arched; but in the lower part convex: in figure it is triangular. It holdeth up the weight of this upper part of the Brain from bearing down on the ubjacent parts.

There are everal Sinus or Cavities in the Brain,Sinus. that are continued indeed to one another, yet becaue at the firt view they eem eparate, are conidered by Anatomits as ditinct, and they commonly reckon four of them: three of which are eated in the Cerebrum, of which in this Chapter; and the fourth is common to the Cerebellum and Medulla oblongata, of which in the next.

The Brain being taken away as far as the Corpus calloum, The two anteriour. there appear two of the aid Sinus, which are called the uperiour, lateral, or anteriour, and which are divided into the right and left by the Septum lucidum jut now decribed. They are omething of the hape of Half-moons, or Hore-hoes, and being inveted with a very thin Membrane, they decend forwards by a pretty
large duct to the Proceus mammillares. And backwards they decend to the bais of the Brain, in which place branches of the Carotides enter their Membrane,Plexus choroides. and make in it the Plexus choroides, together with ome twigs of Veins interwoven with them. The Membrane wherein this Plexus is formed, has very many mall Glandules, which eparate a pituitous matter or flegm from the Veels into the Sinus. Along which it has been uppoed to flow to the Proceus mammillares, and from them to detill through the Os cribriforme into the Noe. But Dr. Lower denies any uch office of the Os cribriforme, affirming that the holes in it are only for the tranit of the Nerves and Membranes going forth from the Proceus, and that thee fill them o cloe that nothing can flow through them. And ays, that flux of Rheum through the Noe, upon the vula, and into the Mouth, &c. in Catarrhs, falls not from the Head, but is eparated from the Arteries in the Glands of the repective parts, as into the Noe through the Glands of its inveting Membrane, &c. And as to the erous matter that is infued into thee Sinus in the Brain, he ays it is all aborbed again by the Veels opening into them, and returns by the Jugular veins to the Heart.

The third Ventricle is nothing ele,The one poterior. but the meeting of the former two, towards the hinder part. In it there are two paages: the firt in the fore-part, which marcheth treight-ways down to the Infundibulum. The econd paeth under the Tetes and Nates to the fourth Ventricle, and is called Foramen ani or Vulva.

The Infundibulum, Infundibulum. or Funnel, is a certain Cavity
under this third Ventricle, paing down from about the middle of it, ay ome, but Doctor Wharton ays out of the fourth. It is framed of the Pia mater, which being wide at its beginning, and becoming narrower towards its end, repreenteth a Funnel.Glandula pituitaria. It endeth in the Glandula pituitaria, which is placed in the cavity of the Sella equina, and upon the wedge-like Bone, through which it has been thought to detil upon the Palate, the flegm poured upon it by the Infundibulum. But Dr. Lower denies this, appealing to the tructure of the parts, and his often experiments upon Calves heads: In which, he ays, the wedgelike Bone lying under the Glandula pituitaria is ometimes perforated in divers places, at leat by one large duct, which being divided into two does on each ide open into the Jugular veins: o that if Milk or Ink be injected through thoe ducts by a Syringe, it preently paeth through on each ide into the aid Veins; and nothing of tincture will appear about the Palate, Notrils, Mouth, Fauces or Larynx. So that in a Calf the humour that proceeds from the Brain, returns all again into the Veins. And the ame thing he ays he has lately tried in a Man's Skull, wherein though the wedgelike Bone be never perforated, yet Nature has framed other ducts whereby all the Serum may be again derived out of the Ventricles of the Brain into the Bloud: for there are two Veels eated on each ide the Sella Turcica (to be decribed Book 6. Chap. 6.) which with gaping Mouths as it were receive all the water detilled out of the Glandula pituitaria, and depoite it on each ide into the Jugular veins without
the Skull; whoe ducts will eaily appear if water or milk be quirted forcibly out of a Syringe into either Jugular vein near the Skull, for the liquor will by and by break out near the Glandula pituitaria, which makes it evident, that whatever Serum is eparated into the ventricles of the Brain, and iues out of them through the Infundibulum, detils not upon the Palate, but is poured again into the Bloud and mixed with it.] So that according to this opinion, the Rheum that iues o plentifully ometimes into the Mouth and Fauces, &c. falls not from the Brain, but, as was noted above, is eparated from the Arteries immediately by the Glands of the repective parts.

About this Glandule, all over the ides of the aforeaid Cavity, there is a membranous Plexus framed of innumerable twigs of Arteries; which pring from the larget branch of the Carotides, that paeth by a proper hole in the bones of the Temples, into the capacity of the Cranium: it is called Rete intrabile, Rete mirabile. repreenting a Net pread abroad.

About the hindermot paage of the third Ventricle which leadeth to the fourth Ventricle, certain round bodies appear, being mall protuberances or portions of the Medulla oblongata. As firt, and uppermot, there are the two ends of the roots of the aid Medulla, which are called Corpora triata, being of uch a like ubtance as the Corpus calloum before decribed. The ret lying under thee have their denomination from thoe things which they reemble. The firt is Glandula pinealis, Penis. or Penis; becaue it repreenteth the Pine-nut, or a Man's Yard. It is eated
in the beginning of that Pipe, by which the third and fourth Ventricles are united. Its bais is downwards, and its apex or end looks upwards. It is of a ubtance harder than the Brain, of a pale colour, and covered with a thin Membrane. This Gland des Cartes thinks to be the primary eat of the Soul, and that all animal operations draw their origine from it. But Bartholin has ufficiently confuted that opinion; for it eems to be but of the ame ue as other Glands, and particularly the Glandula pituitaria placed near it, viz. to eparate the Lympha from the Arterial bloud; which Lympha is reorbed by the Veins (or it may be by Vaa lymphatica) as was hewn above from Dr. Lower. Near to this on both the ides of this third Ventricle four round bodies appear. The two upper are leer, and are called Tetes: Tetes. the two greater are lower, and are called Nates. Nates. The Chink betwixt the Nates is called Anus. Anus.

The ue of thee Ventricles is firt for the more eaie paage of the Bloud;The ue of the ventricles. for it were not convenient for the anguiferous veels to be carried through the oft ubtance of the Brain; let being compreed by the weight of it, the paage of the Bloud hould have been hindred. Whereas now it has no uch lett, eeing the Veels are interwoven in the Membranes that invet thee Sinus, and make the Plexus choroides and Rete mirabile abovementioned. Another ue is for the reception of the erous excrement of the Bloud eparated from it by the glandulous Membrane of the Plexus choroides, and Glandula pituitaria; which according to the old doctrine was dicharged out of them by the ieve-like Bone at the top
of the Notrils, and through the wedge-like Bone upon the vula, Fauces, &c. but according to the new, is aborbed again by the Veins and decends by the Jugulars to the Heart.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
Of the Cerebellum, and the fourth Ventricle.
div.p: THE econd part of the Brain is called Cerebellum, or the little Brain.
It is eated in the hinder and lower part of the Head or Skull,Its eat. and is eparated from the Cerebrum by the two Membranes wherewith it is wrapped, namely the Dura and Pia mater.

It differeth not much from the Brain properly o called,Subtance. aving that it is harder. It does not run in uch windings as the Brain, but its ubtance is made up of Lamellae or Plates that lie one upon another, and are each kept apart from other by the Pia mater, that invets each one ingly, and is much interwoven with Arteries. Within, it is very white, but outwardly more dusky or greyih.

It is framed of four parts,Parts. whereof two are lateral, the right and the left: thee are pherical. Two are in the middle; to wit, the foremot and hindermot: thee are round, and are framed of undry orbicular portions; which becaue they are like unto the Worms that are in rotten Timber,Proceus vermiformes. are called Proceus vermiformes, or worm-like procees.
The one is in the fore-part of the fourth Ventricle; the other in the hinder part.

The ue of the Cerebellum eems to be the ame as of the Brain. e. Only Dr. Willis not content with this general opinion, ditinguihes their ues: writing that in the Brain are elaborated thoe pirits that perform voluntary motion, and in the Cerebellum thoe that ait natural, as that of the Heart, &c. But againt this new hypotheis of his, lie many objections; as firt, that Fowl have no Cerebellum, and yet their Heart, &c. moves. Secondly, The motion of the Heart, &c. called natural, depends at leat partly on the Animal pirits brought by the par vagum, which arie out of the Medulla oblongata, and therefore one cannot eaily conceive how they hould receive pirits from the Cerebellum; or if they did, why thirdly, not only the natural motion of the Heart hould be performed by the aid pair of Nerves, but voluntary motions alo, as thoe of the Larynx, &c.

Between the lower part of the Cerebellum and the Crura or roots of the Medulla oblongata, The fourth ventricle. is the fourth Ventricle formed. This is commonly called the noble Ventricle, from an opinion that the Animal pirits are elaborated unto perfection herein, as they were prepared in the three other. But as we have aigned other ues to the other, in the foregoing Chapter; o we cannot grant any uch office to this, as hall be further hewed in the eighth Chapter. Its lower part that runs in betwixt the forked roots of the Medulla oblongata, from its hape, ending in a point, is called Calamus criptorius, or a Writing pen.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
Of the Medulla oblongata and Spinalis.
div.p: NOW followeth the third part of the Brain,Its name. called Medulla oblongata within the Brain, and aoon as it is decended out of it into the Spine, Spinalis, or Doralis medulla.
The ubtance of it is fibrous,Subtance. being compoed of many lender long Filaments, which whether they are hollow or no, cannot be dicovered through their finenes.

It hath two parts;Parts. viz. that which is contained within the Brain, and that which is included within the vertebrae of the Back-bone, or Spine. That which is within the Skull is about four inches in length. That which is without, and beginneth at the great hole of the Occiput, reacheth to the Coccyx, growing maller and maller in the Os acrum towards its end.

If one cut through its ubtance,Veels. there will innumerable little pecks or prinklings of Bloud appear, but the Veels are o mall, that they cannot be dicern'd. But there are plainly dicoverable very many twigs of Arteries and Veins running through the Membranes that invet it; from which Arteries the Bloud is infus'd into the pores of the Medulla, as it is imbib'd again from thence by the Veins.

It eems not to be a eparate part from the Brain,Rie. but rather a production of it and the Cerebellum together, out of both which it eems to rie by ix roots; the two uppermot and foremot
are the mot coniderable, and are called Corpora triata, being the ends of its two Crura, by which it is joined to the Brain; the four lower and backer are the protuberances of the Nates and Tetes, by which it adheres more to the Cerebellum.

It hath three Membranes.Membranes. The firt is that which immediately toucheth it. This pringeth from the Pia mater, and paeth between both the parts of it, alone without the outer. The twigs of Arteries and Veins run motly through this. The econd covereth the firt, and pringeth from the Dura mater. There is no ditance between them, as there is in the Brain, but one toucheth another being knit together by Fibres. The third proceeding from the Ligament which joineth together the Vertebrae, covereth both thee.

It is divided all along from the very firt meeting of its Crura within the Skull,Its diviion. to the end of Os acrum, by a membranous partition parting it into two; but this diviion is not apparent in the Spine, becaue of the Dura mater that covers it; but it may be dicovered if that be taken off, and the Medulla evered in the middle. The partition is made of the Pia mater, and by means of It it is that the ue or motion of one ide only is ometimes taken away in the Palie.
From this Medulla within and without the Brain proceed all the Nerves of the whole Body.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
Of the Proceus mammillares.
div.p: TReating above of the two lateral Sinus of the Brain, we aid they decended forwards to the two Proceus mammillares, which we hall now decribe.
They are called Mammillares or Papillares, Their name becaue in their end they are round like the Nipple of a Woman's Breat. But they are hollow within and pretty full of moiture.

Anatomits are not agreed from whence their rie is,Rie. ome affirming it to be from the Brain, others from the Crura of the Medulla oblongata, amongt whom Dr. Willis is a leading Man. From which oever it is, they proceed as far forwards as the ieve-like Bone, eated at the top of the Notrils.

Dr. Willis takes them to be truly the melling Nerves, e. and calls them the firt pair. He ays they are very marrowy and oft, till they come to the Os cribriforme, but then they borrow Coats of the Dura mater, with which being divided into many Fibres and Filaments, and paing through the holes of the aid Bone, they go out of the Skull: whence being carried into the Caverns of the Notrils, they are ditributed all through the Membrane that invets them. Yet beides this ue of melling, he thinks they may detil ome of their moiture into the Notrils through the holes of the Os cribriforme by the duct of the Fibres and Filaments. Diemerbro •• k thinks they
have only this latter ue; only that the Rheum or Lympha detils from them as well upon the Fauces and their Glands, as into the Notrils. Dr. Lower grants only the former ue; and ays, that It is incredible that the humour that is contained in the cavity of thee procees hould iue out by the Nerves into the Notrils, for if it did, the ene of Smelling mut needs be much prejudic'd thereby. And beides, if this water could detil by and out of the Nerves, much more might the pirits, that are thinner and more ubtil, fly away.
