And as to the humour contained in the cavity of the procees, he uppoes it to be of very great ue: namely, that when Effluvia or mot ubtil particles exhaling from an external object are delivered to the olfactory Nerves, that their pecies may reach the Brain the better, it was neceary that thoe Nerves or Procees hould be made hollow from their very rie, and be filled with a limpid humour: Not that I believe, ays he, that the pecies themelves are conveyed through their cavities into the ventricles of the Brain, or that the Animal pirits are lodged in thoe Ventricles, as the Ancients thought; but that they are therefore hollow and moiten'd within with water, that their marrowy bodies may erve the better both for retaining and conveying mells into the Brain: For as things melled are better perceived from moit bodies and in a moit <> in a dry eaon from the parched ground (as Huntmen know too well) o it is likely that in the ame manner as they are bet perceiv'd outwardly, they are alo bet conveyed • nwardly, &c.] And indeed if we
will allow them to be olfactory Nerves, it is very incongruous that they hould erve for an Emunctory to the Brain, to dicharge its uperfluous Serum. And therefore we think it fit to acquiece in this learned Phyicians opinion: and to believe that the Lympha gathered in the ventricles of the Brain is emptied by thoe ways we before oberved out of the ame Author, and not at all by the nervous Filaments that pas from thee procees through the Os cribriforme into the Notrils.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
Of the Action of the Brain, and the uppoed Succus nutritius of the Nerves.
div.p: IT is generally agreed that the proper Action of the Brain (in a large ene) is the elaborating of Animal pirits; and that they are ent from it by the Nerves into the everal parts of the Body, for performing both natural and animal actions. But what thee Animal pirits are, and in what particular part of the Brain they are generated, is not agreed upon by learned Men.

Some are of opinion that the Animal pirits differ in no other regard from the Vital,The animal pirits what, and of what made. but only as they are conveyed by proper Veels, and miniter to other purpoes, and are of a cooler temperament; but that there is no pecifical difference betwixt them. Others on the other ide think they differ in pecie, and agree in nothing, but only that the Vital pirits and Bloud are the
matter from whence the Animal pirits are formed. A third ort deny the Arterial bloud to be the matter of thee Spirits, and affirm that the Nerves aborb a part of the Chyle, of which they are made, and beides, a Nutritious juice, (of which by and by.) And ome there are that uppoe Air alo to be an Ingredient, which acends into the Brain through the Os cribriforme. We cannot tand upon the examination and refutation of everal of thee opinions here; but upon a due conideration of the Arguments urged for each, we think that the Animal pirits are pecifically ditinct from the Vital, but that the Vital, with the Arterial bloud, their Vehicle, are the true and only matter, out of which they are elaborated.

And there is no les difference in what part of the Brain the Animal pirits are made.Where elaborated. Some thinking in the Sinus of the Falx. others the four ventricles of the Brain, epecially the fourth, a third ort the Plexus choroides and Rete mirabile; des Cartes, that they are eparated out of the Arteries of Plexus choroides in the Glandula pinealis into the Ventricles; and others latly aign the whole ubtance of the Brain for the place of their confection. As to the Sinus of the Falx, the ue of that was hewn above Chap. 3. And as to the Ventricles, eeing they are often almot quite full of waterih humour, but always have ome, they eem very unfit for the making or receiving uch ubtil and volatile Spirits as the Animal are. As for the Plexus choroides and Rete mirabile, there is no Veel in either that contains any thing, but under the form of Bloud; o that eeing there are no Vaa deferentia (or call them what you will) to convey the Spirits to the origine of the Nerves,
thee alo eem improper for uch an action. We mut therefore ubcribe to the lat opinion that acribes this work to the very ubtance of the Brain, and is performed in this manner. The Heart is like the Primum mobile of the Body, to which the motion of all the humours, that have once pat it, is owing. This by its Sytole impells the Bloud, as into all other parts, o into the Brain by the everal branches of the Carotides, whoe innumerable twigs run partly through the outer Cortex or greyih part of the Brain, and partly into the inner medullar or white ubtance. Thee twigs of Arteries pring partly from the Plexus choroides and Rete mirabile, and partly from the Carotides themelves immediately. The uperfluous Serum of the Bloud is eparated by the Glands above decribed; and that which is not elaborated into Animal pirit, is returned again to the Heart, by the Veins. But thoe particles that are fit and proper to be converted into them, are extravaated into the very Parenchyma of the Brain, or at leat are ditributed through it by inviible Capillaries, in which being perfected into Spirits, thee by help of the Fibres or Filaments which the inner ubtance of the Brain chiefly conits of, are conveyed to the Corpora triata (or other procees of the Medulla oblongata that adhere to the Brain) which conit of the like Filaments, and by them to the Nerves, whoe inner ubtance is fibrous like the Medulla from whence they pring. And the reaon of this ucceive motion from one to another, is the Pule of the Heart, whereby that which comes behind, always drives forward what is before. Whence the true caue of an Apoplexy (wherein motion
and ene are almot quite aboliht) is from the obtruction or compreion, &c. of the Arteries in the Brain; whereby both little Bloud and Vital pirit can be conveyed thither to make Animal pirit of, and alo when it is made, it is not impelled out of the Brain along the Fibres into the Nerves, to enable them to perform their functions.

There is no les controverie about the Nutritious juice of the Nerves:The uccus nutritius of the Nerves. ome contending for it to that height, as to affirm that all the parts of the Body are only nourih'd by it, and not at all by the Bloud, which by its rapid motion they ay is liker to wear and carry away omething from the parts through which it paes, than to adhere to them for their retauration. Others are more moderate, and uppoe that nourihment is dipened only to the permatick parts by the Nerves, which the Nerves receive not from the Bloud, but imbibing the mot thin part of the Chyle out of the Stomach and Guts do carry it up to the Brain, from whence it is conveyed again by the ame Nerves to the parts to be nourih'd by it. Diemerbroeck is of opinion, that the juice of the Nerves (which is as a Vehicle to the Spirits) being omewhat acid, does contribute or yield aitance to the nourihment of the permatick parts, not as it is the matter of, but as it eparates from the Bloud uch particles as are fit for, their nourihment. Whence it is, he ays, that uch parts of the Body as are mot exercied, and by conequent into which mot Animal pirits flow, grow the tronget, having more of uch particles of the Bloud as are fit for their intauration, eparated in them. So they that are ued
to walk, will endure it better, than others that are not o ued, though otherwie much tronger. And hence the right Arm is uually tronger than the left, in thoe that are right-handed (as we ay.) But he thinks that the Nerves have no juice in them which they did not firt receive from the Bloud. Dr. Willis is much of his opinion, aving as to this lat particular; for he ays, it is without doubt that the nervous Fibres and Filaments which cloath the enory of the tate, and the Bowels that erve concoction, do immediately take ome tate of the Aliments for the upply of the Brain, epecially at uch times as the Spirits are much wated in too long fating or over much exercie. But then that juice that may be uppoed to be made thereof in the Brain, and to be dipened by the Nerves into all the parts of the Body, he believes not to be the matter of the nourihment of any part whether permatick or anguineous: but that it is as the form only, and the Bloud the matter, whoe everal particles being analyed or evered by the aid juice, are directed and adapted by its directive faculty or platick power as it were, to uch parts repectively as they are uitable for. And from hence he draws a reaon why paralytick parts do wate o much, though the Bloud flow plentifully enough into them, becaue the Nerves being obtructed and no Animal pirits (with their Vehicle) paing by them, the particles of the Bloud are not eparated for the upply of uch parts.] As for the nervous juice, it mut needs be very little in quantity, eeing if one make a Ligature upon the Nerve, it will not well betwixt the Head and Ligature, nor if one cut the Nerve in under will
any thing detil out of it. So that 'tis very aburd to think that it hould be ufficient for the nourihment of all the parts of the Body, according to the firt opinion. Nor does it eem reaonable to imagine that the Chyle hould acend from the Stomach, &c. to the Brain by the Nerves, whiles this nervous juice that is contended for, with the Animal pirits, is decending by the ame; for one cannot conceive how uch contrary motions of liquors in the ame Veel can be at the ame time. Though from the udden refection that perons ready to faint receive from pirituous liquors, &c. it be probable that certain Effluvia or ubtil and pirituous vapours do enter the nervous ilaments of the Mouth and Stomach, and recruit the Animal pirits immediately, without fetching that compas that I believe all the Chyle does. And as the Nerves imbibe no Chyle from the Stomach, &c. o receive they no more from the Arteries, than ome of its mot pirituous and volatile particles elaborated in the Brain into Animal pirits, which have indeed ome little moiture accompanying them as a Vehicle, but which is neither of a uitable nature nor of proportionable quantity for the nourihment even of the permatick parts only. For eeing the Nerves have no conpicuous Cavity, but only imperceptible Pores, by which any liquor can drill along them; uch liquor mut needs be mot thin and watery, and therefore unfit to be aimilated to any part. And latly, as to the opinion that it eparates the particles of the Bloud, and o ditributes thoe that are repectively proper for, unto, each part, as the ulphureous to the fat, &c. or is to the Bloud as the form is to the
matter; it is an ingenious hypotheis I confes, but whether true, I dare not affirm.

div.head: CHAP. X.
Of the Nerves ariing within the Skull, and firt of the firt and econd pair.
div.p:
SO much of the ubtance of the Brain and of the Animal pirits, &c. It follows that we hew the Nerves which proceed from it. Of them there have been reckoned even pair, comprehended in thee Veres:
Optica prima; oculos movet altera; tertia gutat:
Quarta, & quinta audit; vaga exta; at eptima linguae et.
But aenting to Dr. Willis, that mot accurate decriber of them, who holds the Proceus mammillares to be the olfactory Nerves, and the Par vagum and Intercotale to be two ditinct pairs, we reckon nine in all: of the two firt of which in this Chapter.

Of all the pairs of Nerves that rie within the Skull, Nervi olfactorii, the firt pair. the olfactory or melling pair are the firt, otherwie called Proceus mammillares. They pring from the Crura of the Medulla oblongata betwixt the Corpora triata and the little hillocks or eminences out of which the optick Nerves rie (called by Galen, their Thalami.) Though Diemerbroeck, that denies them to be Nerves, affirms
that they pring not from the aid Medulla, but from the globous marrow of the Brain (properly o called) and its fore Ventricles. But having dicoured of thee in a particular Chapter, (viz. Chap. 8.) we hall adde no more of them here.

The econd pair the Optici or Viorii nervi make; Nervi optici, the econd pair. thee betow upon the Eyes the faculty of eeing. They pring from the Crura or Trunks of the Oblongata medulla behind the Corpora triata, as was noted in the foregoing Paragraph. They march on from thence drawing nearer one to another, untill they meet at the ella of Os phenoides; where they are united by the cloet conjunction, but not confuion of their Fibres, which run lengthways in thee Nerves as they do in all other. Thee of all the ret are bigget and thicket, but oftet. In their beginnings they are oftet, but in their progres become harder, that they may pas the more ecurely o long a way. Dr. Willis ays they have many Fibres from the third pair of Nerves, and many anguiferous veels running along them.

They are hollow untill they be united;The hollownes of the optick Nerves. but after, their hollownes cannot be dicerned. This hollownes may be hewed in a large Beat newly killed, and in a clear light.
After their unition they are eparated again,Their inertion. and each of them, paing through the firt hole of Os cuneiforme, are inerted obliquely into the centre of the Eye.

Thee Nerves have two Membranes,Their membranes and marrowy ubtance. and the inner oft marrowy ubtance, or Fibres. The Membranes pring from the two Meninges. The inner ubtance from the Medulla oblongata.

From the whole ubtance of thee Nerves are the Tunicles of the Eyes framed;Thee make the tunicles of the Eyes. for the Cornea or Sclerotica doth proceed from the thick Membrane or Dura mater, the vea from the thin Membrane or Pia mater, and the Retina from the marrowy ubtance.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
Of the third and fourth Pair.
div.p: THE third pair is termed Motorium oculorum, The third pair. becaue it moveth the Mucles of the Eyes.Its beginning. It hath its beginning at the innermot part or bais of the Medulla oblongata behind the Infundibulum.
This pair is united at its rie;Why both the Eyes are directed to the ame object. whence is commonly drawn a reaon why one Eye being moved towards any object, the other is directed alo to the ame.

It is maller and harder than the former,Its ubtance, and branches. and being preently divided paes along by the optick pair, and penetrating the econd hole of Os cuneiforme, is carried towards the globe of the Eye, where it is divided into four branches. The firt whereof mounting above the Optick, is betowed upon the attollent Mucle, and the Eyelid. The econd eaie to be een is betowed upon the adducent Mucles by undry mall twigs. The third by many Fibres is inerted into the depriment Mucle. The fourth is inerted into the middle of that Mucle that draws about the Eye
obliquely downwards to the inner corner. So that this pair only moveth four Mucles.

The fourth pair proceedeth from the top of the Medulla oblongata, The fourth pair. (contrary to all others, which arie either from its bais, Its beginning, marching, and inertion. or ides) behind the round protuberances called Nates and Tetes: whence bending forwards by the ides of the Medulla oblongata, it preently hides it elf under the Dura mater; under which proceeding a while, it paes out of the Skull at the ame hole with the others deigned for the Eyes, (communicating with no other Nerve in its whole progres) and is betowed wholly (as Dr. Willis affirms) on that Mucle of the Eye called Trochlearis.

div.head: CHAP. XII.
Of the fifth, ixth, and eventh Pair.
div.p:
THE Author lat mentioned ays,The fifth pair. the fifth pair aries out of the ides of the annular proces jetting out from the Cerebellum: Its rie. but I think it is more probably affirmed by others, that this pair aries alo from the Medulla oblongata a little below the former Nerves. Its trunk is very large, coniting of very many Fibres, ome oft and ome hard: o that it eems to be not one ingle Nerve, but a collection or bundle of many mall ones, ome of which are deigned for one part, ome for another; ome erving for motion and others for ene. And the reaon why
they are all united together in their rie, Dr. Willis thinks to be, that there may be a ympathy and conent of actions in the everal parts to which they are ditributed. Hence it is that eeing or melling what is pleaing to the appetite makes ones Mouth water, &c.

Its Trunk is divided into two notable branches,Diviion and progres. ometimes before but oftner after it has penetrated the Dura mater. The firt whereof tending treight downwards, and paing out of the Skull by its proper hole, in its decent towards the lower Jaw (for whoe parts 'tis chiefly deign'd) is divided into many leer branches, which provide for the temporal Mucle, as alo for the Mucles of the Face and Cheeks. From thee alo there go twigs to the Lips, Gums, roots of the Teeth, Fauces, Tonils, Palate and Tongue. The econd branch of this fifth pair, being the larger, goes a little treight forward by the ides of the ella Turcica, and over againt the Glandula pituitaria ends little twigs to the trunk of the Carotides; then inoculates with the Nerve of the ixth pair, and afterward ends back a lip or two, which being united with another lip returned from the Nerve of the ixth pair contitute the trunk of the Intercotal pair, which we hall reckon for the ninth, and peak of it by and by. After this it is divided into two notable branches; The les and upper whereof tends towards the globe of the Eye, and being again divided ends forth two other, the firt of which is parted into two more, that go one to the Noe and the other to the Eye-lids; and the econd into four or five lips, that are motly pent on the Eye-lids, but partly on the vea tunica and the Glands of the
Eye. The greater branch (of its econd diviion) being carried towards the orbit of the Eye is divided into two new branches. The lower whereof bending downwards is betowed on the Palate and upper region of the Fauces; and the upper being carried beyond the orbit of the Eye paes through an hole of the upper Jaw with the Vein and Artery which it twits about, and ends many lips to the Mucles of the Cheeks, Lips, Noe, and roots of the upper Teeth. From its twiting about the anguiferous veels deigned for the Cheeks and other parts of the Face, may a reaon be drawn why one bluhes when he's ahamed: for the Animal pirits being diturbed by the imagination of ome uncomely thing, as if they took care to hide the Face, enter this Nerve diorderly; o that its twigs embracing thee anguiferous veels, by compreing and pulling of them, caue the Bloud to flow too impetuouly into the Cheeks and Face by the Arteries, and detain it there ome time by contringing the Veins.

The ixth pair ries jut by the fifth,The ixth pair. and preently inking under the Dura mater goes out of the Skull by the ame hole with the Nerves of the third and fourth pair,Its rie and inertion. and is carried by a ingle trunk towards the orbit of the Eye; but o, as by the ide of the ella Turcica it inoculates with the econd or greater branch of the fifth pair, (as was noted in the former paragraph:) whence ending back ometimes one, ometimes two twigs, thee being united with the recurring twigs of the fifth pair (above-mentioned) make the beginning of the Intercotal nerve. Afterwards going forwards, near the orbit of the Eye it is divided into two branches; of which one is inerted
into the abducent Mucle of the Eye placed in its outer corner; and the other being cleft into many Fibres is betowed on the eventh Mucle proper to Brutes, whereby they defend the Eye from external injuries without cloing the Eye-lids, when they are aid nictitare, which I think we have no word to expres in Englih.

The eventh pair,The eventh pair. by the Ancients commonly reckon'd for the fifth,Its rie and inertion. miniters to the ene of Hearing. It has two Procees, one oft, and the other harder, which might eem to be two ditinct pairs, but are uually accounted one. They have been held to pring from the ides of the Medulla oblongata, but Dr. Willis ays (I cannot tell how truly) from the annular protuberance of the Cerebellum that lies by the ides of the aid Medulla. The oft part or proces that is properly the auditory Nerve, is carryed through an hole of Os petroum into the caverns of the Ear, which it cloaths with a mot thin Membrane. By this are ounds conveyed to the common enory. The harder proces erves rather for motion than ene; which paing out alo through its proper hole, preently admits a twig from the par vagum or eighth pair, after which it is immediately divided into two branches; one whereof tending downwards, is betowed on the Mucles of the Tongue and Os hyoides; and the other winding about the auditory paage, and bending upwards, is divided into three twigs; of which the firt correponding to the Nerve of the firt diviion betows certain lips on the Mucles of the Lips, Mouth, Face and Noe, and o actuates ome outward organs of the Voice, as the former ome of the inner; the econd is ditributed to the Mucles
of the Eye-lids and Forehead, and the third on the Mucles of the Ears. Whence upon ome unuual and atonihing ound, by a certain natural intinct the Ears prick up and the Eyes open.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.
Of the eighth and ninth Pairs.
div.p: THE next pair in order is the eighth, which has ued to be called the ixth, and par vagum, or wandring pair, from its being ditributed to undry parts.

It prings below the auditory Nerves,The eighth pair. out of the ides of the Medulla oblongata, its root coniting of twelve Fibres at leat (in Man) to which a notable Fibre,Its rie. or rather Nerve (much greater than any of thee twelve) coming from the pinal marrow about the ixth or eventh vertebra of the Neck, is joined, and inveted with the ame Coat from the Dura mater as if they grew into one Nerve; but if their common Coat be removed, this acceory Nerve, and many of the other Fibres remain till ditinct, and after they are gone out of the Skull together, are dipened to everal parts; the acceory Nerve to the Mucles of the Neck and Shoulder; and one notable Fibre of the eighth pair to the harder proces of the Auditory or eventh pair, as alo two others to the Mucles of the Gullet and Neck. But the other Fibres of this par vagum continue united, and intead of thoe companions they
have parted with, they entertain a new one, namely a branch from the Intercotal or ninth pair, whereby is made a notable Plexus (which in a Nerve is like the jointing of a Cane, or the knot upon the trunk of the Tree where a Bough goes out) and out of the ame Plexus there prings a coniderable branch, which being carried toward the Larynx is divided into three twigs, of which one goes to the phincter of the Gullet, a econd to the upper Mucles of the Larynx, and the third going under the Cartilago cutiformis, meets the top of the recurring Nerve and is united to it. Below the aforeaid Plexus of this par vagum, Progres. its trunk goes treight down by the ide of the acending Carotides, on which it betows ome lips. And at the bottom of the Neck it receives a econd branch from the Intercotal, (viz. from its firt Plexus) and near thereto ends out another twig into the recurrent Nerve, but only on the left ide. From hence the trunk of this eighth pair decends without any notable ramification, till it be come over againt the firt or econd Rib; where out of a econd Plexus (or knot) many twigs and Fibres go towards the Heart and its appendage, but not altogether in the ame manner on both ides. There is one notable difference (which we cannot but note) of the two recurring Nerves that pring out of the trunk of this eighth pair, viz. that that on the right ide aries out of it higher and windes about the axillar Artery; whereas that on the left prings much lower therefrom, and twiting about the decending trunk of the Aorta returns back from thence. Dr. Willis ays that the recurring Nerve is really a ditinct Nerve from the par vagum from the very
original, and was only included in the ame cae or cover for the more convenient and afe paage. The branches of the par vagum do frequently unite with others of the Intercotal pair about the Praecordia. And many twigs go out of the eighth pair into the Lungs, &c. Whence each of its trunks decending by the ides of the Gullet are divided into two branches, outer and inner: The outer unite with the outer, and the inner with the inner, and both decend to the Stomach, in which they terminate. As for their more particular ditribution, we have poke thereof while we treated of the parts themelves on which they are betowed.

We are now come to the ninth or lat pair (commonly not ditinguihed from that going before) which is called the Intercotal, The ninth pair. becaue as it marches down by the roots of the Ribs, betwixt every Rib it receives a branch from the pinal marrow.Its rie. It has no proper root of its own, but its trunk is compounded of two or three recurring branches of the fifth and ixth pair, (near their origine) as was noted when we treated of thoe pairs. Being thus formed it paes out of the Skull by its proper hole, and preently has a Plexus near that of the par vagum, into which two nervous procees out of the firt vertebral pair are inerted, and out of which there goes a twig into the phincter of the Gullet, and into the Plexus (aforeaid) of the par vagum. Whence decending by the vertebrae of the Neck, by that time it arrives at its middle, it has another greater Plexus, into which a large Nerve from a neighbouring vertebral pair is inerted; and
from which proceed many twigs that uniting with others of the par vagum are ditributed all about the Praecordia, as alo one ingle one a little lower. This Plexus cervicalis out of which o many branches pring is proper to Man, being not found in Brutes. From the Neck it decends by the Claviculae into the Thorax, where having arrived at the econd Rib it receives three or four branches from the vertebral Nerves next above, whereby is made another notable Plexus (commonly called the Intercotal.) From whence as its trunk paes down by the roots of the Ribs, in every one of their Intertices and even as low as Os acrum, from every jointing of the vertebrae it receives a vertebral pair. Aoon as it is decended out of the cavity of the Breat, and is come over againt the Stomach, it ends forth on each ide a notable branch, which tending towards the Meentery, make its chief Plexus, which are in number even, five large ones which are upper, and two les that are lower. For each branch is preently divided into two other, and every one forms one Plexus, which make four; and the fifth is in the middle of thee, being the larget, and like the Sun amongt the Planets (as Dr. Willis compares it.) And thee are the five upper. The two lower are framed of branches that pring from the trunk decended as far as the lower part of the Loins, and are ditinguihed by the names of Plexus Infimus, and Minimus. As to the parts that all the twigs which pring from thee even Plexus are ditributed to, it may be learned from the decription of the parts themelves in the firt Book, in which we contantly mentioned from whence each part had its Nerves. Latly when this Intercotal
Tab. XI. p. 341.
Fig. 1.
Fig. 2.
pair is come to the Os acrum, its two trunks bend towards each other, and eem to be knit together by two or three procees, and at length each of them ends in mall Fibres that are ditributed into the phincter of the Anus.
And thus we have done with all the Nerves that proceed from the Medulla within the Brain, in decribing of which we have followed Dr. Willis for the mot part, that mot accurate tracer of them.

list.head: Figure I.
list.item: Repreenteth the outer or upper uperficies of the Brain taken out of the Skull; where the Limbus of the Brain being looed from its coherence with other parts by Membranes, is lifted up and bent forwards, that the Crura of the Medulla oblongata, the Fornix, Nates and Tetes with the Glandula pinealis, and other procees may be clearly and ditinctly een, (from Dr. Willis.)
AA The Limbus of the Brain, which in its natural ituation was contiguous to the Cerebellum.
B The border or margent of the Corpus calloum pread over both hemipheres of the Brain, which in its natural ituation lay upon the Glandula pinealis.
C The Fornix.
DD Its Arms embracing the Crura of the Medulla oblongata.

EE The Crura of the Medulla oblongata, (out of
which the optick Nerves proceed) whoe ends (being placed further, out of ight) are called Corpora triata.
F The Glandula pinealis, betwixt which and the root of the Fornix is the chink that leads to the Infundibulum.
GG The orbicular protuberances called Nates.
HH The leer protuberances called Tetes, which are procees of the former.
II The Medullary procees, which acend obliquely from the Tetes to the Cerebellum, and make a part of each of its Meditullia.
K The joining of thoe procees by another tranvere proces.
L The rie of the pathetick Nerves (or fourth pair) out of the joining of the foreaid procees.
MM A portion of the Medulla oblongata lying under the foreaid procees and protuberances.
N The Foramen of the Ventricle of Cavity that lies under the orbicular protuberances.
OO A portion of the annular protuberance let down from the Cerebellum and embracing the Medulla oblongata.
PP The outer and upper uperficies of the Cerebellum.

list.head: Figure II.
list.item: Repreenteth the Eye cleft in two (from behind forwards) that the divers ituations of the humours may appear, (from Dr. Briggs.)
bab The Tunica cornea, or fore and more convex arch of the Eye.

ee The Tunica uvea (whoe Foramen o is called
Tab. XII. p. 343
the Pupilla) wimming in the watry humour cccc.
d The crytalline humour in itu.
ff The Tunica choroides, which in this Figure (as being too much eparated from the Sclerotica mm) cannot be duly repreented.
g A portion of the Optick Nerve.
h Some of its mall Fibres cut off near the exit of the Nerve.
I The centre of the Humor Vitreus, and of the Retina.
1, 2, 3, 4, 5, &c. The Capillamenta of the optick Nerve, whoe ends on each ide being cut off did adhere to the Ligamentum ciliare (namely by the region of the crytalline humour.)
Repreenteth the bais of an humane Brain taken out of the Skull, with the roots of the Veels cut off hort, (from Dr. Willis.)
AAAA The fore and hinder Lobes of the Brain.
BB The Cerebellum.
CC The Medulla oblongata.
DD The olfactory Nerves, or firt pair.
EE The optick Nerves, or econd pair.
FF The motory Nerves of the Eyes, or third pair.
GG The pathetick Nerves of the Eyes, or fourth pair.
HH The fifth pair.
II The ixth pair.
KK kk The auditory Nerves, and their two Procees on each ide, the eventh pair.
LL III, &c. The Par vagum or eighth pair, coniting of everal Fibres.
MM The pinal Nerve coming from a far to the origine of the Par vagum.
NN The ninth or Intercotal pair, coniting alo of many Fibres (that tending downwards, unite into one trunk) which emerges a little above the proces of the Occiput.
OO The tenth pair tending downwards.
PP The trunk of the Carotid Artery cut off, where it is divided into the fore and hinder branch.
QQ Its branch paing betwixt the two lobes of the Brain.
R The fore branches of the Carotides, being united, part again and proceed to the fiure of the Brain.
S The hinder branches of the Carotides united, and meeting the vertebral trunk.
TTT The vertebral Arteries, and their three acending branches.
U The branches of the vertebral Arteries uniting into the ame trunk.
WW The place where the vertebral and Carotid Arteries are united, and a branch on either ide acends to the Plexus choroides.
X The Infundibulum.
YY Two Glands placed behind the Infundibulum.
aaaa The annular protuberance which proceeding from the Cerebellum embraces the root of the Medulla oblongata.

div.head: CHAP. XIV.
Of the Nerves of the Spinalis medulla; and firt of the Nerves of the Neck.
div.p: WE oberved above, Chap. 7. that the Medulla oblongata eemed not to be any eparate part, but only a production from the Cerebrum and Cerebellum: and that when it is decended out of the Skull into the Spine, it loes its name of oblongata, and acquires that of Spinalis, which name it borrows from the Spine through which it paes, but is of the ame fibrous or filamentous ubtance as it was within the Brain. And now we come to decribe the Nerves that pring out of it, which ait the motion of all thoe parts, which thoe nine pair already decribed that arie within the Skull, reach not to.

In its whole progres from the Skull to the Coccyx, Nerves pringing from the Spinalis medulla. there pring out of it thirty pair of Nerves: even of which are of the Neck, twelve of the Breat, five of the Loins, and ix from the holes of Os acrum.
The firt and econd pair of the Neck come not out of the ides of the Vertebrae, as all the ret do; but becaue of their peculiar articulation pring out before and behind.

The fore Nerve of the firt pair cometh out between the bone of the Occiput and the firt vertebra of the Neck,Seven of the Neck. and is betowed upon the Mucles which bend the Neck,The firt pair. and lie under the Oeophagus. The hinder Nerve cometh out of the hole
which is common to the Os occipitis and the firt vertebra of the Neck. This hath two twigs: The maller is betowed upon thoe Mucles which tretch out the Neck; The bigger is inerted into the beginning of the Mucle which lifteth up the Shoulder-blade.

The fore Nerve of the econd pair (which is maller) cometh out between the firt and econd Vertebrae, The econd. and is betowed upon the Skin of the Face. The hinder cometh out at the ides of the hinder proces of the econd Vertebra, but preently is parted into two twigs. The thicker of which is betowed upon the whole Skin of the Head even to the Crown; The maller upon the greater treight, and the lower oblique Mucles which tretch out the Head. Dr. Willis ays, that the firt and greatet root of the Nerve of the Diaphragm arieth from this econd pair of the Neck: of which Nerve we hall peak more by and by.

The third pair cometh out of the lateral holes,The third. which are between the econd and third Vertebrae, and each is immediately divided into two branches; the formore whereof hath four twigs: The firt cometh to the long Mucle or the firt of the benders of the Neck; The econd decending is betowed upon the Mucles which lie under the Oeophagus, being firt united to a twig of the fourth pair; The third acending goeth to the Skin of the back-part of the Head, having firt joined with the thicker twig of the hinder Nerve of the econd pair; The fourth is betowed upon the tranvere Mucles of the Neck, and the Mucle which lifteth up the Shoulder-blade. The hinder branch is betowed upon the econd pair of
Mucles which heaveth up or wideneth the Breat.

The fourth pair cometh out of the holes common to the third and fourth Vertebrae, The fourth. and each hath two branches, like the third pair. The formore hath three twigs: The firt of which uniting with a twig of the third pair is betowed on the firt of thoe Mucles which bend the Neck, called Longus; The econd upon the tranvere Mucle of the Neck, and the Cucullaris of the Shoulder-blade: The third being lenderer than the other two, is joined with a twig of the fifth pair, and both with one of the ixth, and latly all three (according to Dr. Willis) with that of the econd pair above-mentioned: and the Trunk made up of all thee decendeth by the ides of the Gullet down the Neck and Thorax without any branchings till it come to the Diaphragm, where it is divided again into three or four twigs, on each ide, and is inerted into its flehy or muculous part, being known by the name of Nervus diaphragmatis, or Phrenicus. The hinder branch goeth back to the Spine under the Mucles of that part, upon which it betoweth twigs, and going down between the Mucles of each ide of the Neck it is carried to the Muculus quadratus that draweth the Cheek down.

The fifth pair marcheth out between the fourth and fifth Vertebrae, The fifth. and hath likewie two branches on each ide. The formore of which hath four twigs: The firt goeth to thoe Mucles that bend the Neck: The econd is that which joineth with the twigs of the econd, fourth and ixth pairs, and makes up the Nervus phrenicus: The third goeth to the Deltoides: The fourth goeth to the ame Deltoides, and to the Coracohyoideus, or the
third pair of the Mucles of Os hyoides. The hinder branch bendeth back to the Spine, and is betowed upon the Mucles there, as the like branch of the fourth pair was.

The ixth pair cometh out under the fifth Vertebra, The ixth. and hath, as the ret, two branches. The formore endeth firt one twig to make the trunk of the Nervus phrenicus; then proceeding further it is united with the three following, namely the lat of the Neck and two firt of the Thorax, making one Plexus with them, out of which thoe Nerves proceed that are carried to the Arm. The hinder branch goeth to the Mucles behind, which tretch out the Neck and Head.

The eventh pair cometh out of the hole common to the ixth and eventh Vertebrae. The eventh. The formore and larger branch is joined with the ixth of the Neck and two firt of the Thorax, as aforeaid, and is carried to the Arm. The hinder and maller is betowed upon the Mucles of the Neck, and quadrat Mucle which pulleth down the Cheek.

About where this ixth or eventh pair of Nerves rie,Nervus ad par vagum acceorius. there pringeth another, decribed by Dr. Willis, and by him called Nervus pinalis ad par vagum acceorius. It ries mall out of the ide of the pinal marrow, and acends up by the ide of it, growing thicker as it goes, (but without being inerted any where into the marrow) till having enter'd the Skull it is joined to the Fibres of the par vagum or eighth pair. Its progres from thence we oberved in Chap. 13. when we decribed the eighth pair.

div.head: CHAP. XV.
Of the Nerves of the Vertebrae of the Breat.
div.p: FROM the marrow of the vertebrae of the Thorax twelve pair pring.Twelve of the Thorax. In all of which the formore branch is bigger; and the hinder, which is betowed upon the Mucles eated in the Back, maller.

The firt pringeth out of the hole which is common to the eventh vertebra of the Neck,The firt pair. and the firt of the Breat, and therefore 'tis indifferent whether it be eteemed to belong to the Neck or Thorax, ome reckoning it to be the eighth of the Neck, and others (as we do here) the firt of the Breat. Each Nerve is preently divided (as all the ret are) into two branches; the formore of which is united to the ixth and eventh of the Neck as was noted in the foregoing Chapter, and o is all pent on the Arms, except one little twig that pringing out of its beginning marcheth forward towards the Sternum, and betoweth twigs on the Muculus ubclavius, and thoe Mucles which arie from the top of the Sternum; and another that goes to that Mucle which fills up the hollownes of the Shoulder-blade. The hinder branch creeping under the Mucles which cleave to the Vertebrae, is betowed upon the Mucles of the Neck, Head and Shoulder-blade.

The econd iueth out of the pace between the firt and econd vertebrae of the Breat;The econd. and its fore branch is united with the firt of the Thorax,
and together with it is joined to the ixth and eventh of the Neck, which all together make one Plexus that endeth forth all the Nerves to the Arms that they have, (as hall be further explained Book 4. Chap. 3.) But beides that branch by which it unites with thee, it ends a twig alo to the Intercotal nerve (or ninth pair) decending down the Thorax, (as alo does every one of the remaining ten pair) and from that twig before it join with the Intercotal there proceed mall lips to the Mucles that lie upon the Breat. The hinder branch hath the ame ditribution with the hinder of the foregoing pair.

The ret of the ten pair come out of the lateral holes of the Vertebrae, The ret of the pairs. and are all immediately divided into two branches; whereof the formore being larger, always endeth one twig to the Intercotal nerve, and the remainder of it is betowed on the Intercotal Mucles internal and external, and on thoe that lie on the Thorax; as alo on the obliquely decending Mucles of the Abdomen, &c. The hinder bend backward to the Spine, and are pent upon the Mucles and Skin of the Back.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.
Of the Nerves of the Vertebrae of the Loins.
div.p:
ALthough there be but four lateral holes in the vertebrae of the Loins;Five of the Loins. yet there are five pair of Nerves. The fore branches being
greater go to the Mucles of the Belly: The hinder to thoe which ret upon the Vertebrae. The formore are joined together, the firt with the econd, the econd with the third, the third with the fourth, and the fourth with the fifth, as the two lat of the Neck and two firt of the Breat were.

The firt cometh out of the lateral hole between the lat vertebra of the Breat,The firt pair. and the firt of the Loins. The fore branch is betowed upon the flehy part of the Midriff, epecially its two procees, and on the Mucle Poas. This Nerve being compreed by a Stone in the Kidney, there is caued a numbnes in the Thigh of the ame ide. It endeth alo a twig along with the Arteria praeparans to the Stone, according to Spigelius. From whence it is partly, that too immoderate Venery caueth a weaknes in the Loins. The hinder is betowed upon the Muculus longiimus of the Back, Sacrolumbus, &c.

The econd cometh out between the firt and econd vertebrae of the Loins,The econd. under the Mucle Poas, which is the firt of thoe that bend the Thigh. The formore branch is betowed upon the econd Mucle of the benders of the Thigh that fills up the cavity of Os Ileum, and on the Muculus facialis and the Skin of the Thigh. The hinder is betowed upon the Muculi glutaei, and the membranous Mucle which tretcheth out the Leg. That twig which from this pair joineth with the Intercotal, goeth to the Tetis of its own ide (according to Vealius, &c.

The third marcheth out between the econd and third Vertebrae, The third. under the Poas alo. The formore endeth one twig to the Knee and Skin
thereof, and another which doth accompany the Saphoena. The hinder turneth back, and is betowed upon the Mucles which ret upon the Loins.
The fourth being the larget of the Mucles of the Loins,The fourth. marching under the Poas and Os pubis, doth accompany the Vein and Artery which pas to the Leg.

The fifth cometh out between the fourth and fifth Vertebrae. The fifth. Its fore branch paeth through the hole that is between the bones of the Coxendix, Pubes and Ileum, and is betowed upon the Obturatores muculi of the Thigh, the Mucles of the Penis, and on the neck of the Bladder, and of the Womb. The hinder is betowed upon the Mucles and Skin which are above the Vertebrae.

div.head: CHAP. XVII.
Of the Nerves which come from the marrow of O • acrum.
div.p: FROM the marrow of Os acrum ix pair of Sinews pring. Six of Os acrum.

The firt iueth out between the lat vertebra of the Loins,The firt pair. and the firt of Os acrum, in the ame manner as thoe that pring out of the vertebrae of the Loins, and like them is divided into two branches. The fore branch is a great part of it mixed with thoe other of the Loins that go towards the Legs, yet it ends one twig to the Mucles of the Belly, and the econd which bendeth
the Thigh. The hinder is betowed upon the Skin of the Buttocks, and the greatet Glutaeus.

The other five pair pring after a different manner from the foregoing.Of the other five pair. For before they come out of the Os acrum, they are every of them double on each ide; and o from each on either ide there arie two Nerves, one of which is carried into the fore or inner, and the other into the hinder or outer ide. The three uppermot formore Nerves go towards the Leg, as the greatet part of the firt pair did: The two lower to the Mucles of the Anus and Bladder; in Men to the Penis, in Women to the neck of the Womb, and in both to the external Privity. All the five hinder Nerves are ditributed to the Mucles of Os Ilium and Sacrum, towards the back part, which are Longiimus, Sacrolumbus, Sacer, and the Glutaei.

And thus we have done with all the thirty pair of Nerves that arie out of the Spinal marrow, having hewn which way they pas and to what parts they are ditributed: which hould be diligently noted and well remembred, that we may the better know to what place to apply remedies, when from any outward caue, as from a fall, bruie or the like, any part has lot either ene or motion or both. For the Medicine is to be applied always to the beginning or rie of that Nerve that paes to that part, and not to the place in which the ymptom appears. And the ame thing is to be oberved in Palies, when the ue of ome particular Limb is taken away from an inward caue.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.
Of the Face and its parts.
div.p: IN the former Chapters we have dicoured of that part of the Head that is decked with Hair, of the Brain, &c. contained within it, of the Medulla oblongata ariing out of it and prolonged into the Medulla pinalis, with the Nerves that pring out of the ame both within the Skull and in the Spine of the Back, all which we have conidered as appendages to the Brain, eeing both the marrow out of which they arie, prings out of it, and alo all the Nerves have their Animal pirits from it. And now we come to peak of that part which is not altogether garnihed with Hair. In Latin it is called Facies, the Face, and Vultus, the Countenance.

Now though all the parts of the Body ufficiently hew the wiedom of the Creator; yet both the beauty of the Face, and its admirable conent with the mind doth epitomie as it were the comelines and dignity of all the other parts, and exhibits their affections as in a Glas. For from it are not only taken igns of health, dieaes, and imminent death; but alo mot clear tokens of the very dipoition, manners and affections of the mind. For as hame and frightednes betray themelves in the Cheeks, o do anger, joy, adnes, hatred, and epecially love, in the Eyes. So from the Forehead are known ones gravity and humility; from the Eyebrows (or Supercilia) pride; from the Noe, agacity or blockihnes;
&c. from the motion of the Face, wiedom or foolihnes, honety or wickednes, civility or incivility, good-will or hatred; from its colour, the temperament of the whole Body. Beides, the ex, the age, the tock, and one Man from another may be ditinguihed by the Face.
The parts of the Face are either containing, The parts of the Face. or contained.
The containing are proper or common.

The common are the Cuticula, Skin and Fat. The Membrana carnoa from the Eyes to the Chin is o thin that ome have affirmed there is none: but in the Brows it is thicker and cleaves very cloe to the Skin. Of thee common parts we have dicoured Book 1. Chap. 3.
The proper are the Mucles, Bones and Cartilages, which hall each be decribed in their proper places.
The parts contained are the organs of the four Senes, viz. the Eyes, Ears, Mouth and Noe.

The Face is divided into its upper and lower part. The upper is from the Hair to the Eyebrows, and is called Frons the Forehead. This while the Body is entire belongs to the Face, but in a Skeleton to the Skull. The lower is extended from the Eyebrows to the Chin, and includes all the parts betwixt them.

div.head: CHAP. XIX.
Of the Eye in general, and its outward or containing parts.
div.p: THE Eyes (in Latin Oculi, from occludo to hut, or occulto to hide, becaue they lie hid under the Eyelids) are the organs of ight, coniting of many imilar parts; and are as the two Luminaries of the Microcom, to afford us light; or like two Watchmen placed in the upper part of the Body as in a Watch-tower, to give notice of any approaching danger. To loe them is the greatet miery can befall a Man: for 'tis the ame as to be thrown into a Dungeon, when thee windows of the Body are hut up.
They are in number two,Their number. partly to make the ight tronger, and partly that one being hurt, the other might perform the office in ome meaure, though more imperfectly.
The Eye alone,Figure. deveted of its Mucles, is of a round or phaerical hape, both that it might move the better, and alo that it might more conveniently receive the viible rays.

The colour of the Eyes in Men is ometimes grey,Colour. ometimes brownih, ometimes black: which variety is mot conpicuous about the Pupilla in the Iris, and proceeds from the colour of the vea. Brutes of the ame pecies have not that diverity of colours.
Some have much larger Eyes than others;Bignes. but thoe which are larget and tand much out, have not o acute and piercing a ight as thoe that are les and tand further in.

They are each placed in a large Cavity,Situation. called Orbita (or the Socket) on each ide the Noe, which is hollowed out of the bones of the Skull. And thee orbits are inveted on their inide with the Pericranium, to which the fat and origins of the Mucles cleave firmly. Thee may be reckoned the firt containing parts of the Eye; as may alo in the econd place

The Palpebrae or Eyelids,The Eyelids. which erve as Curtains to the Eyes, by which dut and troubleome mokes and vapours, too much light and the injuries of the air are kept out, and the outward membrane of the Eye called Cornea is moiten'd, wip'd and clean'd. They conit outwardly of a very thin Skin which has no fat under it; inwardly they are lined with the Pericranium, that is here mot thin and mooth. Betwixt thee parts comes the Membrana carnoa, which is alo very thin. Each Eye has two. In Man the lower is les, and is but very obcurely moved in comparion with the upper: but in Birds the lower is the larger, and in mot eems only to be moved, the upper remaining unmoveable. As for their Mucles to which they owe their motion, thoe may be een in the fifth Book. At their edges they have little oft Cartilages, (called Cilia in Latin) to trengthen them, and that they may meet the more exactly. Upon thee Cartilages there grow Hairs, which having grown to a certain length, will naturally grow no longer, o that they never need to be cut. Thoe on the upper Eyelid turn omething upwards, and thoe on the lower downwards. Above the upper Eyelid grow alo a et of Hairs, betwixt it and the Forehead, out of the Supercilia or Eyebrows;
thee lie pretty flat bending from within outwards, and hinder weat, dut or other things from falling into the Eyes.

The Eyelids have two corners called Canthi. Canthi. The outer of thee is les, and in its upper part it has a Gland placed (uually called Innominata, or nameles, but might be named Lachrymalis, as affording the mot of that Lympha that makes the Tears.) This Gland is conglomerate, being made up of many leer, and has mall twigs of Arteries that creep to it and depoite Serum or Lympha in it to upply matter for Tears upon occaion. But the ordinary ue of this Lympha is to moiten the inner ide of the Eyelids and th • uperficies of the Eyes, that they may move more glibly. Diemerbroeck having reckoned eight opinions concerning the caue, origine and matter of tears rejects them all, and this we have mention'd with the ret: and thinks that their matter is the more erous and thin particles of the pituitous humour gathered in the Brain, and flowing to the Eyes, upon its contraction, through the Foramen lachrymale. Which the learned Reader may ee defended in his Anat. lib. 3. cap. 15. There is another Gland in the inner canthus or corner, which helps the former in its office. Dr. Briggs ays, there are two or three lymphatick veels, that receive Lympha from it, and end in the inner part of the Eyelid; and that eight arie out of the former Gland and end in the Tunica adnata, where they continually depoite omething of Lympha, to keep the Eye moit. Nerves come to them from the fifth pair, which communicating with the Intercotal, are much irritated in the paions of udden joy or of adnes,
and o twitch and compres thee Glands that the Lympha is queezed or milked as it were out of them, as Dr. Willis ingeniouly uppoes.
As for the Mucles of the Eye, they hall be decribed in the fifth Book.

div.head: CHAP. XX.
Of the Tunicles of the Eye.
div.p: HAving done with the outward or containing parts of the Eye, we come now to the Eye it elf, and firt of its Tunicles.

The outmot Tunicle of the Eye is common, The tunicles of the Eye, one common and is called Adnata. It prings from the Pericranium and is pread over all the White of the Eye above the Sclerotica, reaching as far as the Iris. By this the Eye is kept firmly within its orbit, from whence it is alo called conjunctiva. It is of very exquiite ene, and has many capillary Veins and Arteries creeping through it, which are mot conpicuous in an Ophthalmy or inflammation of the Eyes. Under this Tunicle are the Tendons of the Mucles extended and expanded to the circumference of the Iris, which encreae its whitenes; and ome take them for a econd Tunicle, calling it Innominata.

The proper Tunicles of the Eye are three,Three proper. according to the threefold ubtance of the optick Nerve.1. Sclerotica. For this Nerve (as all the other) conits of two Tunicles pringing from the Dura and Pia mater, and an inner marrowy ubtance.
From the Dura mater pringeth the outmot coat of the Nerve, and from this the Tunicle that is pread next under the Adnata, called Sclerotioa from its hardnes; but in its fore-part where it covereth the Iris and Pupilla, it is named Cornea, from its tranparency; though ometimes this latter name includes the whole Tunicle, as well behind as before.

That which lieth next under the Cornea is much thinner than it,2. Choroides. and is called Choroides, from its reembling the Membrane Chorion wherein the Foetus is included in the Womb. Its fore-part is otherwie called vea, becaue it is omewhat of the colour of a Grape. This prings from the Pia mater, and is pread from the bottom or centre of the Eye, behind all over the Eye to the Pupilla; to whoe circumference when it is come, it becomes double, making with one part the Iris, with the other the Ligamentum ciliare. On the inide it is of a duskih colour, (in Man) but blacker on the outide. But where it makes the Iris, it is of divers colours reembling the Rainbow, from whence it borrows its name: yet in ome it is more blue, in others black, in others grey. This Tunicle is perforated before as wide as the Pupilla (or ight of the Eye) to permit the rayes of viible pecies to pas in to the crytalline humour. Next unto which crytalline humour lies the Ligamentum ciliare, the econd part of the duplicated vea. This conits of lender Filaments or Fibres, (like the Hairs of the Eyelids) running like o many black lines from the circumference of the vea to the ides of the crytalline humour, which they encompas and widen or contringe as there is occaion, by contracting
or opening the Foramen of the vea.

The third Tunicle is made of the medullar ubtance of the optick Nerve,3. Retiformis. and is called Retina or Retiformis (Net-like:) This eemeth to be the principal organ of ight. For as Dr. Briggs well argues, neither the crytalline humour, through which the rayes pas much refracted; nor the Tunicle Choroides, are at all fit for this ue. For this latter part (as riing from the Pia mater) cannot communicate the impreions of the rayes to the medullar part of the Brain, which it does not at all touch. Whereas the medullary Fibres of the Retina have communication therewith, and therefore can well perform that office. The Fibres of this Tunicle are extended from the bottom or inner centre of the Eye, where the optick Nerve enters it, as far as the Ligamentum ciliare, (to which it affords Animal pirits for the continuance of its motion.) If one take this Tunica Retina and put it into warm water, haking it a little, to wah off the mucous ubtance that cleaves to it, and then hold it up to the light, thee Filaments will appear very numerous like the threads of the finet Lawn.

div.head: CHAP. XXI.
Of the Humours and Veels of the Eye.
div.p:
NEXT to the Tunicles of the Eyes are the Humours contained in them to be conidered.The ••
mours of the Eye three. And thee are in number three, viz. Aqueus,
Crytallinus, and Vitreus. The econd weighs as much again as the firt, and yet not o much as the third by a ixth part. The Crytalline is the mot d • ne of conitence by much; and the glay more dene than the watry.

The Aqueous humour is outermot,1. Aqueus. being pellucid and of no colour (as neither are the other two.) It fills up that pace that is betwixt the Cornea and the Crytalline humour before. If any thickih particles wim in it, then Gnats, Flies, Spiders webs and the like will eem to be
• lying before the Eyes. But if thoe particles grow till thicker, and cloe together o as to make a film, and this be pread before the hole of the Pupilla, then is the ight quite taken away, which dieae is called a Cataract.

The Crytalline humour (o called from its being as clearly tranparent as Crytal) is placed betwixt the aqueous and the vitreous,2. Crytallinus. but not exactly in the middle or centre of the Eye, but rather towards its fore-part. It is incloed in the boom as it were of the vitreous humour, and is flattih on the foreide, but rounder behind. It is more bright and olid than either of the other two. It has been the common opinion that it is incloed in its proper Membrane, which is called either Crytallina from its tranparency, or Aranea from its mot fine contexture. But Dr. Briggs, a very accurate Anatomizer of the Eye, denies any uch Tunicle, affirming that it is meerly adventitious when the humour is expoed for ome while to the Air, or is gently boiled. As to the collection or reception of the rayes of things viible, this humour is the primary intrument of ight: though as was aid before, the Tunica retina
is the principal as to perception, becaue through it the rayes are communicated to the common enory.

The third and lat humour of the Eye is the Vitreous, 3. Vitreus. o called becaue it is like to molten glas. This is thicker than the Aqueous, but thinner than the Crytalline; and much exceeds them both in quantity, for it fills up all the inner or hinder he • iphere of the globe of the Eye, and a pretty deal (toward the uperficies) of the formore. It is round behind, but hollowed in the middle forwards, to receive the Crytalline into its boom. This humour is alo aid to be eparated from the other two by a proper Tunicle, called Vitrea, which the aforeaid ingenious Author likewie denies.
See the ituation of thee Humours repreented in Fig. 2. of the Table inerted p. 341.

The Eyes have Arteries from the Carotides, The veels of the Eye. which betow twigs on their Mucles, and on their Tunicles. And thee are accompanied with Veins pringing from the branches of the Jugulars. As for their Nerves, they either ait the ene of eeing, and are called the optick Nerves, which we have reckoned for the econd pair and decribed before Chap. 10. or erve for the moving of them, being inerted into their Mucles, and to this purpoe erve the third and fourth pair, and ome twigs of the fifth. As to their Lympheducts, we have poken of them above Chap. 19. when we dicoured of the Glands placed at each canthus or corner of the Eye-lids.

div.head: CHAP. XXII.
Of the Auricula.
div.p: AS the Eyes are placed in the upper part of the Body like two Watchmen to decry approaching danger; o are the Ears there eated alo, that they might give information of what the Eyes cannot dicover either in the night for want of light, or through ome thick and opaque Body which the ight cannot penetrate. And as the Eyes contemplate the wonderfull works of God, whereby the mind may conceive of his Infinity; o the Ears are the Inlets or Receivers of verbal intruction in all wiedom and cience. For they are the organs of hearing, and are in number two, that the one failing, yet we might hear with the other. They are placed in the Head, becaue ounds acend.

The parts of the Ear are either outward or inward. The outward is called Auricula, which is only an adjuvant intrument of hearing, being pread like a Van to gather and receive the ounds. Its upper part is called Ala or Pinna the Wing;The names of its parts. and its lower and oft Lobe, uually Infima auricula. It has everal protuberances or eminences, and cavities. Its outer protuberance that makes its circumference, from its winding is called Helix; and that which is oppoite to it, Anthelix: but that next the Temple, becaue in ome it is hairy, is called Hircus or Tragus; and that which is oppoite to it, to which the oft lobe of the Ear is annexed, Antitragus, which likewie
in ome is hairy. Its Cavities are three. The inmot, becaue of the yellow Ear-wax (as we call it) that is gathered in it, is named Alvearium; as alo Meatus auditorius: the next to this outwards which is bigger, from its tortuoity or winding is called Concha. The third is that betwixt the Helix and Anthelix, which has had no name impoed on it.

The contituent parts of the Auricula are either common or proper. Its contituent parts. The common are Cuticula, Cutis, Membrana nervea, and fat in the Lobe. The proper are the Mucles, Veins, Arteries, Nerves and the Cartilage. As concerning the Mucles, they are et down in their proper treatie. The Veins come from the external Jugulars; the Arteries from the Carotides; the Nerves from the econd pair of the Neck, being joined with the harder proces of the eventh pair. As for the Cartilage, it is a ubtance that is fittet for this place. • or if a Bone had been here, it had been troubleome, and might by many accidents have been broken off: if Fleh, it had been ubject to con • uion. It erves to keep this outer part of the Ear expanded and open, and is tied to Os petroum by a trong Ligament which rieth from the Pericranium.

The ues of the outward Ear are thee: es. Firt, it erveth for beauty. Secondly, to help the receiving of the ounds. For firt, it gathereth them being dipered in the Air. Secondly, it doth moderate their Impetus, o that they come gently to the Tympanum. Such as have it cut off upon any occaion, are very much prejudic'd in their hearing, which becomes confued with a certain murmur or wooing like the fall of waters.

Both behind and below the Ears there are everal Glands outwardly under the Skin, that are called Parotides. But there are two more notable than the ret, near one another; of which one is leer, and is conglobate; but the other bigger, coniting as it were of many leer, and is conglomerate. Thee erve to utain the veels that acend this way, and are uually reckoned as Emunctories of the Brain. In the conglomerate Gland the Saliva is eparated.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII.
Of the inward part of the Ear.
div.p: THE inward part of the Ear is that which we properly call Auris, and begins at the Meatus auditorius, or that inmot cavity in which the Ear-wax is collected. This cavity acends omething with a winding duct, partly that if any thing fall into it it may more eaily be got out again; and partly that the vehement Impetus of the ound may be a little in • ringed. The Wax that is gathered in it is an excrement of the Brain, and by it Inects are hindred from creeping in, entangling them as Bird-lime.

Before its inner end is pread the Tympanum or Drum, The Tympanum. which is a nervous, round and pellucid Membrane, of mot exquiite ene. Some will have it to pring from the Pericranium, others from the Pia mater, a third ort from the Dura mater, a fourth from the ofter proces of the Auditory nerve expanded. And latly, ome
think that it has a proper ubtance, pringing from no other Membrane, but made in the firt conformation of the parts. It is very dry, that it might give the better ound. It is trong, that it hould the better endure external harms. It hath a cord behind it for trength and tretching of it, even as the military Drum hath, which ome take to be a Nerve, others a Ligament. It hath two Mucles to move it, which hall be decribed in the fifth Book.

When it is taken away,Four little bones. in the firt cavity on the inide of it (which alo by ome is called Tympanum) there appear four mall Bones. Thee have no marrow in them, nor are covered with any Membrane or Perioteum, yet at their extremities where they are joined, they are bound with a mall Ligament that proceeds from the Cord or Ligament of the Tympanum above-mentioned. And •• ey have this alo peculiar to themelves, that they are as big in Infants as in grown perons.

The firt is called Malleolus, 1. Malleolus. the little Hammer. It hath a round Head, which is inarticulated into the cavity of the Anvil by a looe Ligament. This Head is continued into a mall Neck, which reaching beyond the • iddle of the Tympanum, adhereth to it. About the middle it hath two procees: The one of which, b • ing horter, has the Tendon of the internal Mucle inerted into it; and the other, being longer, the Tendon of the external, the Tympanum coming between.

The econds is called Incus, 2. Incus. the Anvil, having one Head, and two Feet, being omewhat like one of the grinding or double Teeth that has two roots. The Head is omewhat thick, having in
the top of it a little mooth cavity, which receiveth the knob or head of the Hammer. The mallet and longet Foot is tied to the top of the Stirrop by a looe but • irm Ligament; but the thicket, broadet and hortet reteth upon the Os quamoum.

The third is Stapes, 3. Stapes. or the Stirrop. In figure it is triangular, in the middle hollow, to give way to the paing of the Air to the Labyrinthus. In the upper part of it is a very mall and round knob, upon which the longet foot of the Anvil reteth. Its hape is much adapted to the Fenetra ovalis (which opens into the Labyrinth) about which it is tied round omewhat looely, o that it may be driven to within its Sinus, but cannot without violence be pulled outwards.

The fourth Bone was found out by Franc. 4. Os orbiculare. Sylvius, and from its round hape is called Orbiculare. It is tied by a lender Ligament to the ide of the Stapes, where the Stapes is joined to the Incus.

From the lower ide of this firt inner cavity, wherein thee Bones are contained, there is a round Meatus to the Palate of the Mouth near the root of the vula, and another that runs to the cavity of the Notril, by which pituitous matter collected in it is dicharged. And by the help of that which opens into the Mouth it is, that deafih people are aited in hearing, for we commonly oberve uch to open their Mouth when they liten attentively.

In the middle alo of this cavity there are two holes, the greater and higher of which is hut by the bais of the Stapes (when no ounds penetrate the Ear) and is of an oval figure,Fenetra ovalis. whence it is called Fenetra ovalis, and opens inwards or backwards
pretty wide into the Labyrinth. The other is les and lower, and is of a round hape, whence it is called Rotunda. Rotunda. And this is always open, having no covering, and is divided into two pipes divided by the Os quamoum, one of which tends to the Cochlea, the other to the Labyrinth.

This Labyrinth is the econd inner cavity,Labyrinthus. being far les than the former, and was firt o called by Fallopius, from the hollowed bony emicircles (cloathed with a thin membrane) returning circularly into the ame cavity. The Fenetra ovalis opens into it out of the firt cavity: and beides this hole it has five others, one of which opens into the end of the larger Gyrus or winding of the Cochlea: The other four are o mall that they hardly admit an hair, through which the mot lender Fibres of the auditory Nerve proceed to the inner membrane that encompaes this cavity.

The third and lat inner Cavity is called Cochlea, Cochlea. becaue in its piral winding it reembles a Snail's Shell. It is les than the Labyrinth, and has two, ometimes three or four uch windings, which are cloathed inwardly with a mot thin Membrane, into which, as into the Labyrinth, the lender Fibres of the auditory Nerve enter, through three or four very mall holes.

Thee three inner Cavities are all formed within the inner Proceus petrous of the Temple-bone. And in them is contained a mot pure and ubtile Air, which ome think to be included in them in the very firt formation of the parts, and therefore call it Aer Initus and Congenitus. Some uppoe it to be Animal pirit, effued into them by the auditory Nerve.

This inner part of the Ear has Veins, Arteries and Nerves from the ame origines as the outer: only the harder proces of the auditory Nerve goes to the outer, and the ofter to this inner, which coming by the hinder Meatus of the Os petroum is inerted into and dipered through the circles of the Cochlea and Labyrinth.

All the parts of the Auricula and Auris concur to the perfecting the hearing, Hearing what. which is a Sene whereby ound is perceived from the various trembling motion of the external Air, beating upon the Tympanum, and thereby moving the internal Air with the Fibres of the auditory Nerve, and communicated to the common Senory. Now ound that is the object of it is nothing ele but a quality ariing from the Air or Water beat upon and broken by the udden and vehement concuion of olid bodies. And the diverity or greatnes of uch ound is ditinguihed by the four Bones that tand on the inide the Tympanum: For as from the greater or les, gentle or harh impule of the external onorous Air (fluctuating like Waves caued by a Stone thrown into the Water) the membrane of the Tympanum is accordingly driven or hak't againt the Malleus, the Malleus againt the Incus, and the Incus againt the Stapes; o, as the ame Stapes and Os orbiculare open the Fenetra ovalis more or les, is there a freer or traiter paage granted to the internal Air into the Labyrinth and Cochlea, in whoe tortuous and unequal windings it is variouly infringed and modulated, from whence the pecies of ound that is made thereby, (according to the diverity of the external impellent) is ometimes more acute, ometimes more full, ometimes more harh, ometimes more
gentle, ometimes bigger, ometimes les: the idea of which pecies is carried to the common Senory (and o repreented to the mind) by the Auditory nerve that expands it elf through the Membrane that invets the aid Labyrinth and Cochlea.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV.
Of the Noe.
div.p: THE organs of Seeing and Hearing being decribed in the foregoing Chapters, we come now to the intrument of the third Sene, viz. Smelling, which is the Noe.

The parts of the Noe are either external or internal. Its external parts. The external parts are thee, the Skin, Mucles, Veins, Arteries, Nerves, Bones and Cartilages. Firt, the Skin cleaveth o fat to the Mucles and Cartilages, that it cannot be evered without renting. Secondly, as for the Mucles,
they are et down in the decription of the Mucles Book 5. Thirdly, the Veins come from the external Jugulars, as the Arteries from the Carotides. Fourthly, the Nerves come from the third pair, on each ide one. Fifthly, the Bones of the Noe are et down in Book 6. Chap. 6. Sixthly, the Cartilages are in number five; the two upper are broader, and adhere to the lower ide of the Bones of the Noe where they are broader and rough, and being joined to one another pas from thence to the tip of the Noe, making up one
half of the Alae; the two under make up the other half; the fifth divideth the Notrils. Thee Cartilages are moved by the Mucles.

The inner parts of the Noe are thee:Its inner parts. Firt the Membrane which covereth the inide of the Noe, which proceedeth from the Dura mater, and paeth through the holes of the Os cribriforme. This Membrane on its backide hath abundance of little Papillae or Glands; in which the Serum or Rheum is eparated that runs out by the Noe. Secondly, the Muculous membrane, which draweth together the Notrils. Thirdly, the hairs which dipere the air, and hinder the creeping in of Inects. Fourthly, the red flehy pongious ubtance, with which the holes of the Os pongioum are filled up; from which the Polypus pringeth.
The length of a comely Noe is the third part of the length of the Face.

The upper part of the Noe which is bony, is called Droum nai, The denomination of its parts. or the ridge. The lower lateral parts, where the Cartilages are, Alae, or Pinnae. The tip of the Noe, Globulus, and Orbiculus. The flehy part, that at the bottom of the Septum reaches from the tip of the Noe to the upper Lip, is called Columna. And the two holes that are caued by the partition, Nares the Notrils. And thee about their middle are each divided into two, one of which goes up to the Os cribriforme, to convey cents thither; the other decends down upon the Palate to the Fauces, by which Rheum falls down either of its own accord if it be very thin, or by nuffing the air up trongly in at ones Noe, if it be thick, which we may hawk and pit out at pleaure.

The Noe is an external adjuvant organ of Smelling,Its ues. as the Auricula is of Hearing. For when mells exhale out of odoriferous bodies into the air, by taking our breath in at the Noe, the cents accompanying the air acend up the Notrils to the top of their Cavity, viz. to the Os cribriforme, through whoe holes the olfactory Nerves (otherwie called Proceus mammillares) iue out by their Fibres, and are the inward immediate and adequate organ of Smelling. Other inferiour ues the Noe has alo; as firt, ometimes to take in our breath by, that we may not keep our Mouth always open for that purpoe. Secondly, to help the Speech, which is very much impaired by the los of it. Thirdly, it erves for the eparation and dicharge of the uperfluous humours in the Bloud. And the like.

div.head: CHAP. XXV.
Of the Lips.
div.p:
AS to the Cheeks, their ubtance being Mucular, this is no proper place for the decription of their parts (but Book 5.) only we hall note that their upper part next under the Eyes, that jets out a little and is commonly highet of colour, is called Malum or Pomum faciei, in Englih commonly the Ball of the Cheek; and their lower part that is tretched out in blowing of a Trumpet or the like, is called Bucca. Therefore we hall pas on to the Mouth, wherein is
contained the Tongue the intrument of Tating, &c. The ue of it is fourfold; for it erveth for breathing, taking of food, peaking, and dicharging of the excrements of the Brain, Lungs, &c.

The parts of the Mouth are either external or internal. The external parts of the Mouth, viz. the Lips. The external are the Lips: thee are framed of a carnous oft fungous ubtance, and of the Mucles, covered with a thin Skin. They are in number two, the upper and the lower. (Of their Mucles ee Book 5.) The upper Lip has a little dimple in its middle which is called Philtrum; and its ides are named < in non-Latin alphabet > , whence the hair that grows thereon is called Mutaches. The inide of the Lips is covered with a Membrane common to the Mouth and Stomach; and from hence cometh the trembling of the lower Lip before vomiting.

The ues of the Lips are thee:The ues of the Lips. Firt, they help to retain the meat in the Mouth while it is chewing. Secondly, they erve for beautifying of the Face, if they be well fahioned. Thirdly, for the containing of the Spittle in the Mouth, that it hould not run out at uneaonable times. Fourthly, to keep the Gums and Teeth from external injuries. Fifthly, for framing of the Speech.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII.
Of the inner parts of the Mouth.
div.p: THE inner parts of the Mouth are thee: The Gums, the Teeth, the Palate or Roof of the Mouth, the Almonds, the vula, the Tongue, and Ductus alivales.

The Gums (Gingivae) are two,1. Gums. made up of a hard flehy ubtance, detitute of motion, et like a Rampire about the Teeth for the keeping of them in their Sockets.2. Teeth. As for the Teeth, look for them in Book 6. Chap. 8.3. Palate. The Roof of the Mouth is its upper part, omething concave like a Vault, formed in the Os phenoides, and erves partly for perfecting of the voice by repercuing the air, and partly aits the ene of Tating. It conits of Bones (of which, Book 6. Chap. 6.) of a peculiar glandulous Fleh and a thick Tunicle, with little holes for the Saliva that is eparated in the Glands to detil through into the Mouth. Of the Tonillae or Almonds we have poken before in Book 2.4. Almonds Chap. ult. 5. Uvula. The vula is a red, pongie and longih Caruncle, that being omewhat broad at its bais hangs down from the middle of the Palate (where the Notrils open into the Mouth) with a mall but bluntih end. It is covered with a very lax and oft Skin, and is often welled with defluxions of Rheum, hanging down flaggy, which is called the falling of the vula, and by ignorant people, the falling of the Roof of the Mouth.6. Tongue. The Tongue (Lingua, à Lingendo, from licking) is the intrument of Tate
and Speech. It is long and broad, thicker at the root than towards the tip. It is cloathed with two Membranes; The outer covers only the upper part of the Tongue, and is very porous, being pretty mooth in Men, but in Brutes it is rough with abundance of copped bodies ariing out of it, (and bonding towards its root) like the Teeth of Wool-cards, of omething a cartilaginous ubtance. This Membrane has a line that runs lengthways of it in its middle, dividing the Tongue into two parts. The inner covers the whole Tongue, the lower ide as well as the upper. This is thin and oft, and has many Papillae protuberating out of it, which are inerted into the pores of the outer. As to the ubtance of the Tongue there is great diverity of opinions. Some think it to be a Gland; others, that it has a peculiar ubtance; Spigelius, that it is truly a Mucle; and o does Dr. Wharton call it verus Muculus, though towards its root (he aith) it hath omething of a glandulous ubtance. Malpighius (exercit. Epitol. de lingua, p. 9.) ays it is rather muculous than glandulous; and decribes its ubtance thus. Immediately under the aforeaid Membranes there lie treight flehy Fibres, whereby the Tongue is drawn inwards and hortned. But the centre of the Tongue conits of a manifold kind of Fibres, long, tranvere and oblique, which riding one upon another are interwoven like a Mat.] But though this be its ubtance, yet it cannot properly be called a Mucle, both becaue no Mucle erves to move it elf, but ome other part; and alo becaue one Mucle is not moved by another, as the Tongue is by everal pair, decribed Book 5. It is connected
to the Os hyoides, Larynx, and Fauces, and by a membranous Ligament to the parts under it. The extremity of which Ligament is called Fraenum, which being too hort, or extended to the top of the Tongue, hindreth ucking in Children, when they are aid to be Tonguetyed.

Its Veins proceed from the external Jugulars,Its veels. and are very apparent under the Tongue, where they are called Ranulares. The Arteries come from the Carotides. Nerves it hath from the fifth and eighth pair.

The actions and ues of the Tongue are thee:Its actions and ues. Firt, it is the intrument of Tating; epecially the Papillae in its inner Membrane, which have the extremities of the Nerves inerted into them. Secondly, it formeth or modulateth the Speech. Thirdly, it helpeth the chewing of meat, by toing of it to and fro, and turns it down to the Stomach.

Beides the everal Glands in the Membrane that invets the inide of the Mouth,Ductus alivales. there is a very notable one that lies deep under the Tongue, from whence two Pipes, called Ductus alivales, acend obliquely to the ides of the Fraenum of the Tongue, where each is inerted into another mall Gland, through which they pour that Saliva into the Mouth which they firt received from the foreaid notable Gland. Thee were not unknown to the Ancients, but are more particularly decribed by Dr. Wharton. Beides thee, Steno about twenty years ago found out two more, which ariing out of the greatet (conglomerate) Gland at the root of the Ear run on the outide of the Jaw-bone to the center of the Muculus buccinator;
