and there end into the cavity of the Mouth, into which they dicharge the Saliva they had imbibed out of the Glands. Now this Saliva or Spittle is firt eparated from the Arteries by the Glands, and is not a meer excrement, but erves for the furthering of the fermentation of Meats in the Stomach, if it be not the main ferment of it. That it has a fermentative quality Diemerbroeck proves by this experiment, That if a piece of white Bread be chewed and moiten'd with much Spittle, and then be mixed with Wheatpate kneaded with warm Water, it will make it ferment.
div.trailer: The end of the Third Book.

div.head: CONTAINING A Decription of the VEINS, ARTERIES and NERVES OF THE LIMBS.
CHAP. I.
Of the Veins of the Arms.
div.p:
IN Book 2. Chap. 9. treating of the Acending trunk of the Vena cava we hewed that when it arrived at the top of the Thorax it was divided into two branches called Rami ubclavii; which running obliquely under the Claviculae, aoon as they were pat them and come to the Arm-pit, were called Axillares; and each of thee parteth it elf into two Veins, the Cephalica,
and Bailica. But before their diviion they end forth two mall Veins, viz. Scapularis interna and externa; whereof the firt paeth to the Mucles that lie in the cavity or inide of the Scapula, the latter to thoe on the outide.

The Cephalica paeth through the upper and outward part of the Arm, to the bending of the Elbow, where it is divided into two branches; of the which one, joining with the Bailica, makes the Mediana, which is very frequently opened when one is let bloud in the Arm: The other, marching according to the length of the Radius, reacheth to the Hand, through which it is pread; but chiefly in that part which is between the Ringfinger and the little Finger, where it is called Salvatella.
The Bailica paeth through the inner and lower part of the Arm, accompanied with the Artery and Nerves.

About its beginning there pring out of it the Thoracica uperior and inferior, (though ometimes thee arie from the Axillar before its diviion) of which the former runs to the inide of the pectoral Mucle, &c. the latter to the Muculus latiimus of the Back, and all over the ide of the Thorax, where 'tis aid to inoculate with the twigs of Vena ine pari.
Bailica about the bending of the Elbow is divided into that which is called Subcutanea, and that which is called Profunda.

Profunda, the deeper, is annexed to the Artery about the bending of the Elbow, not under. Then paing between the lna and Radius it is carried to the Hand by the outer part of the
lna.
The Subcutanea, or the hallowet branch, near to the bending of the Arm being turned up to the outer part of the lna, is carried along it to the Hand.

Note, that ince the circulation of the Bloud has been generally believed, it is held indifferent which of thee three Veins (the Cephalica, Bailica or Mediana) are open'd in bloud-letting; for they all receive their Bloud from one common Artery, viz. the Axillar, which returns by them all indifferently towards the Heart: only it is bet to open that which is fairet.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Of the Arteries of the Arm.
div.p: ASoon as the ubclavian branches of the acending trunk of the Aorta are pat out of the Thorax, they are called Axillar, (like the Veins) as we hewed in Book 2. Chap. 11.

This Artery before it arrive at the Arm endeth out of its upper part the Humeraria, which is betowed on the Mucles of the Shoulder: and out of its lower, Thoracica uperior, inferior, and Scapularis, which run to the ame parts with the Veins of the like denomination in the foregoing Chapter. Then having communicated mall twigs to the Glands in the Arm-pit, it accompanieth
the Bailica along the Arm, (for there is no cephalick Artery.) When it is come to the bending of the Elbow, it is parted into two branches, which pas almot wholly to the inner ide of the hand; for the backide hath no Artery but from a mall twig that runs betwixt it and the bone of the Thumb.
The one of thee reting upon the Radius, is that which beats about the Writ, and is commonly felt by Phyicians.
The other marcheth by the lna, and with the former is pread through the Hand.

div.head: CHAP. III.
Of the Nerves of the Arm.
div.p: THE Nerves that pring from betwixt the three lowet vertebrae of the Neck, and the firt three of the Back do every one end a branch towards the Arm; all which for their greater trength uniting with one another, and again eparating are carried under the Claviculae to the Armpit, where they are interwoven together like a Net; but they pas out of it again eparate one from another. The firt of them that prings from the fifth pair goes to the Mucle Deltoides, to the econd Mucle of Os hyoides, and to the Skin of the Arm. All the other five are betowed wholly on the Mucles and Skin of the Arm and Hand.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
Of the Veins of the Thigh, Leg and Foot.
div.p: THE Iliacal branches of the Vena cava after they are decended as far as the Thigh (where we left them B. 1. Ch. 13.) are called Crurales, which being pat the Groins are each divided into ix more notable Veins, viz. Saphoena, Ichias major and minor, Mucula, Poplitea and Suralis. The firt called Saphoena decends down on the inide of the Thigh and Leg betwixt the Skin and Membrana carnoa, and appears pretty large on the inide of the Ankle, where it is frequently opened in Dieaes of the Womb, and may with great afety, having neither Artery nor Nerve accompanying of it. The Ichias major is that which runs down on the outide of the Ankle; but the minor goes no further than the Mucles of the Hip. The other three are pent on the Mucles, Skin, &c. of the Thigh, Leg and Foot.

div.head: CHAP. V.
Of the Arteries of the Thigh, Leg and Foot.
div.p:
IN B. 2. Ch. 11. decribing the decending branches of the Aorta, we traced them to the Thighs, where the Rami iliaci begin to be called Crurales, as was aid of the Veins. The Crural artery is les than the Vein, and before it arrive at the Ham endeth forth three branches, viz. Mucula cruralis exterior, interior, and Poplitaea. The firt enters the fore
Mucles, the econd the inner Mucles of the Thigh; and the third runs down the hinder Mucles as low as the Ham, whence it has its name. When the trunk of the Crural artery is pat the Ham, it ends out three more called Tibiaea exterior, poterior elatior and poterior humilior, which are betowed on the Mucles, Skin, &c. of the Leg and Foot; and what remains of it decends to the Foot, upon which it is pent.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
Of the Nerves of the Thigh, Leg and Foot.
div.p: THE three lower pair of Nerves of the vertebrae of the Loins, and the four uppermot of Os acrum contitute the Crural nerves. For all thee very near their rie joining together, and proceeding united for a while, make four Nerves. The firt and third enter the Mu • cles that lie upon the Thighbone whether for its motion, or of the Leg. The econd accompanies the Crural Vein and Artery down by the Groins and the inide of the Thigh, on whoe formore Mucles it is mot of it pent, but ends one notable branch down the Leg, as far as to the great Toe. The fourth is the thicket, hardet and tronget of all the Nerves in the Body. This ditributeth twigs to the Skin of the Buttocks and Thigh, to the Mucles of the Thigh and Leg, and being decended to the Ham is divided into the outer and inner branches, which betow twigs on all the Mucles and Skin of the Leg and Foot, to which there comes no other Nerve, but the foreaid branch of the econd.
div.trailer: The end of the Fourth Book.

div.head: CONTAINING A Treatie of all the MUSCLES Of the BODY.
CHAP. I.
The decription of a Mucle.
div.p: A Mucle in Greek is called < in non-Latin alphabet > a moue,The decription of a Mucle. of which Muculus in Latin is but a diminutive; as if it reembled a fley'd moue: or ele from < in non-Latin alphabet > to contract. It is a diimilar or organical part, (framed of its proper membrane, a fibrous fleh, a Tendon, Veins, Arteries, and Nerves) appointed by nature to be the intrument of free motion.

The parts then are either common or proper. The parts contitutive. The common are three: The Vein, the Artery, and the
Nerve. The proper as many, viz. the fibrous fleh, the Membrane, and the Tendon.

The Arteries betow on the Mucles,Arteries. (as on all the other parts of the Body) Vital heat and nourihment;Veins. the Veins carry back from them what bloud is not aimilated to them;Nerves. and the Nerves bring Animal pirit whereby their action is performed. And thee Nerves pring either from the medulla oblongata within the brain; or from the pinalis, o called after it is decended out of the skull into the pine. The Nerve is implanted either into one end, or about the middle of the Mucle; but at what part oever it is inerted, that is the head or beginning of the Mucle. As oon as it hath entred into the ubtance of the Mucle, it is dipered into a number of twigs, which end in it, and are continued or elonged into Fibres.

A fibre is thus defined by Dr. Glion in cap. 4. de Ventric.Fibrous fleh. A body in figure like a thread, lender, tenacious, tenile, and irritable, made of permatical matter, for the ake of ome motion and trength. Which he thus explains: In figure like a thread] i. e. oblong and round; lender] like a piders web; tenacious] whoe parts firmly cohere and are not eaily broken; tenile] viz. that may be extended as to longitude, its latitude being leen'd, and in like manner that may be thicken'd as to latitude, its longitude being hortn'd; irritable] i. e. which by irritation may be excited to contract it elf, and the irritation ceaing, to be remitted of its own accord; made of permatick matter] namely if it be a bare Fibre; but if it be tuft with a parenchyma, perhaps it is not always made of only permatick matter; (for the tuft Fibres may be divided into anguineous
and permatick; of the former kind are thoe of the Mucles; of the latter, thoe of the tomach and guts:) for the ake of motion and trength] for in that it is tenacious it adds trength to the part, and that which is apt to be extended and contracted is detin'd for ome motion.] Thee Fibres being tuft in their intertices with a anguineous parenchyma, are that which we properly call fleh (without fat.) For (aith Dr. Croone) all the fleh of a Mucle (which makes the greatet part of it, and of which the bulk of the whole body chiefly conits) eems to be nothing ele but that portion of the bloud that flows through the intervals of the Fibres, which thickning by their coldnes is taid amongt them, and makes the muculous fleh. The Fibres are commonly treight; wherefore the Mucles of the belly (called oblique and tranvere) have not their denomination from their Fibres, for they are all treight; but from their own poition and ituation: o the Mucle called Maeter, is accounted double, becaue it hath two orts or ranks of Fibres, one lying upon another.
Every Mucle hath a proper membrane that invets it,Membrane. and ditinguihes it from others. It is continued unto the Tendon in uch Mucles as have one.

The lat proper part of the Mucle is the Tendon. Tendon. It is a imilar body, of a inewy-like ubtance, (yet it hath a peculiar ubtance differing from a inew) white with a kind of brightnes, dene, hard, and mooth, extended according to the length of the Mucle.Its beginning. Its beginning may be reckoned to be at the head of the Mucle, whence paing through the belly of it, it endeth in the tail.

All Mucles which are appointed for the moving of bones,Which mucles have tendons. have Tendons which are inerted into them; but commonly thoe which move other parts, as the Tongue, Lips, &c. as alo the Sphincter of the Bladder, and anus, have none, or however uch as are not eaily dicoverable; for indeed ome affirm (as Dr. Croone) that every Mucle has its Tendon.

It is not framed of the Nerve and Ligament mingled together,Of what a tendon is framed. as many have imagined: Firt, becaue a Nerve being lax and oft, will not admit commixtion with the Ligaments being hard. Secondly, becaue the Nerve is not carried in the form of a Nerve to the Tendon, but is either continued to or makes the Fibres of the Mucle. Thirdly, Ligaments are inenible, but Tendons are of exquiite ene; as appeareth by the great pain which enueth if they be pricked. But either it is framed by nature out of the firt matter of the Embryo, as other parts called Spermatick are, and o is an independent part: or ele it is a coalition of the Fibres of the Mucle, being emptied or freed of their parenchyma.
The Tendons are ometimes round,The figure of tendons. as in the muculus biceps; ometimes broad, as in the oblique and tranvere Mucles of the Belly.

Thee are the parts contitutive of a Mucle.The parts from the poition. It hath beides thee, parts derived from the Poition; and thoe are three: The Head, the Belly, and the Tail. The Head is the beginning, or that part unto which the Mucle is contracted: the Belly is the thicket part and the mot flehy: the Tail is the ending of it, and is inerted into the part which is moved. It is called in Greek
< in non-Latin alphabet > , and commonly Tendo.

The ue of a Mucle was et down in the lat part of the decription,The ue of a mucle. in that it was aid to be the intrument of free motion; which word we rather make ue of than of voluntary, becaue beats have Mucles and motion, unto whom will properly o called is denyed, becaue it preuppoeth reaon.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Of the differences and actions of the Mucl • s.
div.p: THE differences of Mucles are taken from undry things:The differences of mucles. Firt, from their ubtance: o ome are flehy, as undry of the Tongue and larynx: ome are membranous, as the contrictores or internal adducents of the noe: and ome are partly flehy, and partly nervous, as the temporal.

Secondly, from the quantity. Some are long, as the treight Mucle of the abdomen, the longet of the back, &c. others hort, as the pyramidal at the bottom of the abdomen: ome broad, others narrow; ome thick, others thin and lender, &c.
Thirdly, from the ituation: from hence ome are called external, ome internal; ome oblique, ome treight, ome tranvere.

Fourthly, from the figure: as deltoides, becaue it reembleth the Greek letter < in non-Latin alphabet >
delta. Some round, others quare, &c.
Fifthly, from their beginning: o ome proceed from bones, one or more; ome from cartilages or gritles, as thoe of the larynx.
Sixthly, from the variety of parts; o ome are called bicipites and tricipites, having two and three heads; others biventres, having two bellies.

Seventhly, from their compoition; o ome are ingle, ome double; becaue ome have more heads,The caues of the unity and plurality of mucles. ome more tails than one. The unity of the Belly and Membrane which enwrappeth the Mucle, caueth the unity of it; and the plurality of the Membranes and Bellies, the plurality of Mucles.

Eighthly, from their action. Four differences of Mucles are taken from hence: for firt, ome are hence called fraterni or congeneres, brotherly; ome antagonitae, adveraries. Secondly, ome onely move themelves, as the phincters; ome other parts, as the ret. Thirdly, ome have one onely action, as the greatet part of the Mucles; ome have divers actions, as the maeter and trapezius. The fourth difference is taken from the variety of the action; o ome are called flexores, others extenores; ome elevatores, others depreores; ome adductores, others abductores. Others upenores, rotatores, &c.
As for the proper action of a Mucle,The proper action of a mucle. it is nothing ele but the contraction of it towards its beginning.

The diverity of the action proceedeth from the diverity of the ituation of the Mucles:The caue of the diverity of the action. o a treight Mucle hath a treight motion; a tranvere, a tranvere motion; an oblique, an oblique motion; and that which compaeth a part hath an orbicular motion as the phincters. So all
internal Mucles erve for bending; all external for tretching out.

Now of the motion of the Mucles there are four differences;The difference of the motion of mucles. firt, the contraction: econdly, the pereverance of the contraction: thirdly, the relaxation of the contraction; and fourthly, the pereverance of the relaxation. This pereverance is called motus tonicus, Motus tonicus. whenas the member is till kept in the ame poture.

The efficient caue then of the action is the oul,The efficient caue of the motion. moved by its appetite. It ueth three Intruments, the Brain, the Nerve, the Mucle: the Brain receiveth the charge, the Nerve carrieth it to the Mucle with the animal pirits, and the Mucle doth perform the action. So that a Mucle from its action may thus be decribed:A decription of a mucle from its action. A Mucle is an organical part of the body, appointed for the free contraction of it elf towards the beginning, for the moving of the part into which it is inerted.

div.head: CHAP. III.
Of the Mucles of the Eye-lids.
div.p:
THE Lids of each Eye have three Mucles:Rectus. the firt is called rectus or aperiens, to lift it up. This is placed in the upper region of the orbit of the Eye, and pringeth from the ame origine with the elevator of the Eye, (above it) namely at the hole through which the optick Nerve paes into the orbit, and holds the ame coure with it, being of the ame figure and ubtance,
viz. flehy, till at lat parting from it with a pretty broad but thin Tendon, it is inerted into the cartilage of the upper Eyelid, which it erves to lift up, and o to open the Eye.

The two others are called Claudentes, Semicirculares. or hutters of the Eyelids, as alo emicirculares (others call them circulares taking them for one.) They are placed between the membrana carnoa and that Membrane that is extended from the pericranium. Each Eyelid has one, the upper a larger, the lower a les. That which draweth down or hutteth the upper, arieth from the inner corner of the Eye and that part of the upercilium that is next to the Noe, with a harp beginning: from whence it paes tranverly toward the outward corner, growing preently flehy and broader, o that it filleth up all the pace betwixt the Eyebrows and the lowet edge of the Eyelids on which the hairs grow, (which is called cilium or tarus) and at length is inerted into the outer corner. That which moveth the lower (though but obcurely) in order to hut it, is membranous and thin, ariing from the ide of the Noe with a harp beginning as the other; whence being carried tranverly it comes to the middle of the Eyelid, where becoming omething flehy it continues its coure to the outer corner which it turns about, and acending to the upper Eyelid is inerted into it with a broad end. Thee two Mucles being contracted hut the Eye, the greater drawing down the upper Eyelid, and the les pulling up the lower.

But it is to be noted that beides the Rectus aforeaid to open the Eye,Frontales. there ometimes concur, when we would open them very wide, the
muculi frontales, (on each ide one) which pringing from the Skull near the coronal future, and having one ide knit to the temporal mucles, do meet one another with the other ide upon the forehead, and decend with treight Fibres to the Eyebrows, where they terminate. By the help of thee we draw up and wrinkle the forehead, and by conequence pull up the upper Eylid a little. The skin grows very cloe to thee Mucles.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
Of the Mucles of the Eye.
div.p: THee are in number ix; four treight, and two oblique. The treight move the Eyes upwards and downwards, to the right hand and to the left: the oblique move them obliquely. The treight are more thick and flehy than the oblique. As to their beginning,The treight mucles. (viz. of the treight) they have all the ame origine; as to their progres, the ame tructure;Their rie and inertion. and as to their end, the ame inertion. Their origine is contiguous and acute, being at the hole through which the optick Nerve enters the orbit of the Eye, from whoe Membrane they pring. Their middle, or Belly, is flehy and almot round. Their end is a mot thin and membranous Tendon, whereby they are inerted into the tunica cornea, where it is pellucid, near the Iris, and o do encompas the whole Eye before as far as it is white.

The firt of the treight is called attollens, or uperbus; that which pulleth up the Eye. The econd is deprimens, or humilis, that which draweth down the Eye. The third is adducens, or bibitorius, that which pulleth the Eye to the Noe. The fourth is called abducens, or indignatorius, that which pulleth it from the Noe towards the outer corner.
The firt is placed in the upper region of the orbit, the econd in the lower, (oppoite to the upper) the third in the inner corner of the Eye, the fourth in the outer.

The oblique Mucles are called circumagentes, The oblique mucles. winders or rollers about, and amatorii, or amorous;Their rie and inertion. and are in number two. The firt is obliquus major, or uperior, the uppermot and larget. This beginneth within the orbit of the Eye, by the hole of the optick Nerve, and paing to the upper part of the inner corner of the Eye, endeth in a mall and round Tendon, which paeth through a tranvere cartilage there placed, (called by Fallopius trcchlea) as a cord through a pully, and is inerted into the upper ide of the cornea. The econd is obliquus minor, or inferior, the lowermot and mallet. This pringeth from the lower and almot outer part of the orbit; about the chink which doth unite the firt bone of the upper jaw to the fourth, with a carnous beginning. It is lender but not quite round, and paeth obliquely to the outer corner of the eye, which having turned about, it ends in a hort, roundih and nervous Tendon, which meeteth with the Tendon of the other oblique Mucle, and is inerted in an oblique line near the Iris betwixt the Tendons of the
attollens and abducens, with the other, o that both eem to have but one Tendon. This bringeth the apple of the Eye to the Noe, as the other draweth it from it.

Before you hew the Mucles of the eye,How thee mucles are to be hewed. cut off the fat with the ciers, then hew firt the obliquus major, then the obliquus minor, and lat of all the four treight Mucles. Nevertheles let the obliquus major remain lat, when all the ret are taken away, that you may hew how the Tendon of it paeth through the pulley the more plainly. And it will not be amis here to decribe this ame pulley or trochlea, Trochlea. which we hall do out of Spigelius: It is a little round cartilage, hollowed like a pipe or piece of a traw, that is upended by a Ligament in the inner corner of the eye, from which the aid greater oblique Mucle has the name of Trochlearis.

div.head: CHAP. V.
Of the Mucles of the Noe.
div.p: THE Noe is not all of it moveable, but only its lower gritly parts, which are called Alae or Pinnae. And thee are either drawn together to hut the Notrils, which is performed by the adducent Mucles; or drawn aunder to open the Notrils, which is done by the abducent. And there are two Pair to erve each Office. So that in all there are Eight Mucles that belong to the Noe.

The firt Pair of the abducent or opening Mucles is mall,The abducent mucles. rather Carnous than Membranous, ariing from the upper Jaw-bone, near the firt proper pair of the Lips; this is inerted partly into the lower part of the ala of the Noe, and partly into the upper part of the upper Lip, and is called Philtrum. The econd pair covering each ide of the Noe, begins at its top near the foramen lachrymale, with an acute and flehly Origine, and decending obliquely by the bones of the Noe it ends in a broad Bais, and till remaining flehy is implanted into the Alae. It is near of a threequare or triangular hape, like the Greek Letter delta, whence it is called by ome deltoides. Thee two pair by drawing the Alae upward widen and open the Notrils.

The abducent or cloing Mucles are very mall ones,The adducent mucles. o that they can hardly be dicovered or ditinguih'd exactly but in them that have large Noes. The firt pair of thee is external and flehy, riing about the root of the alae, which it acends creeping tranverly over them to the ridge or tip of the Noe, into which it is inerted. The econd is internal, and is hid in the cavity of the Notrils under the inner coat that covers them: it is membranous, and aries from the bones of the Noe, where they end about the gritles, and is inerted into the Alae. The former being contracted deprees the Alae; the latter draws them inwards, and o cloes or contringes the Notrils. And to the ame end or purpoe there is another that erves (which is common) namely the orbicularis of the upper Lip, which by drawing the Lip downwards, doth at the ame time contringe the Notrils.

Bartholin writes, that beides thee Mucles, he has ometimes found a mall carnous Mucle reaching treight down from the frontal Mucle with a broad Bais, but preently growing narrower, to end about the cartilage of the Noe.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
Of the Mucles of the Lips and Cheeks.
div.p:
THE Mucles of the Lips are either common to the Cheeks and Lips,The common mucles. or proper only to the Lips. The common are two on each ide. The firt is called detrahens quadratus: 1. Detrahens quadratus. this is a thin but broad Mucle, reembling a Membrane enterlaced with flehy Fibres. It hath its beginning from the vertebrae of the neck in the outer ide, the houlder-blade, the clavicula and the breat-bone, and mounting up by oblique Fibres to the face, is implanted in the Chin, Lips, and root of the Noe; which parts it draws obliquely downwards. Sometimes it proceeds alo to the root of the Ear, and is reckoned for one of its Mucles. It is called quadratus or four-quare from its hape. When a convulion happens in this Mucle, it caues the pamus cynicus, which we can imitate voluntarily by drawing down one ide of the Mouth. The econd is called Contrahens, 2. Contrahens. or Buccinator the Trumpeter. This lieth under the former, in the upper part of it. It doth make up all that part of the Cheek which is blown up when a Trumpet is ounded. It is round, and pringing from the brims
of the upper jaw-bone circularly, doth end in the brims of the lower jaw-bone. It is wholly membranous, and interlaced with divers Fibres, and is knit o cloe unto the Membrane which covereth the inide of the mouth, that it hardly can be evered from it. This Mucle is not only of ue to move the Cheeks with the Lips, but when it is contracted, it turneth in the meat upon the Teeth again, that had got to betwixt them and the Cheek, in chewing of it.

The Mucles proper to the Lips,The proper mucles. are five pair, and one odd one. Firt, par attollens. If both of thee act together,1. Attollens. they draw all the upper Lip directly upwards and outwards; but if only one, then is but one ide of the Lip drawn up obliquely. This pair pringeth from the firt bone of the upper-jaw, or os jugale, where the Ball of the Cheek is. At its rie it is broad and flehy: from thence marching obliquely to the fore-part, each is inerted into its own ide of the upper Lip near to the Noe.2. Abducens. The Second is called Abducens, and aiteth the motion of the former, or rather draweth the upper Lip more to one ide. It arieth out of the Cavity that is under the Ball of the Cheek with a flehy but lender and round beginning, and being covered with much Fat, it is implanted into the fraenum or little dimple in the middle of the upper Lib.3. Jugale. The third pair is called by Riolanus Zugomaticum or Jugale, ariing outwardly from the Jugal Proces. It is flehy and round, and decending obliquely through the Cheeks, is terminated near the corner of the Mouth on each ide; and erves to draw both Lips upwards ideways;4. Deprimens. for it is common to them both. The fourth pair is Deprimens, which pulleth down
the lower Lip. It pringeth from the ides of the Chin, where the two mall bunchings are: there it is flehy. From thence marching obliquely, it is inerted into the middle of the under Lip. It is every where broad.5. Obliquè detrahens. The fifth pair may be called oblique detrahens, for it draws the lower Lip obliquely downwards and outwards. It prings from the ides of the lower Jaw with a flehy and broad beginning, (being ometimes extended to the middle of the Chin) from hence it goes upwards, and growing narrower by degrees it is inerted obliquely into the lower Lip near its corner. Some make but one of this and the immediatly foregoing; as alo of the econd and third, but they are indeed ditinct. And thee are all of them pairs, one on each ide: but this which follows is ingle, namely the Orbicularis or Contringens, Contringens. and is common to both Lips. It is otherwie called Oculatorius, becaue it contracteth the Lips in kiing. This is that which makes the proper figure and oft ubtance of both the Lips, encompaing the whole Mouth like a Sphincter, which by its orbicular Fibres it contringes or pures up when one is aid to imper. It is cloely knit to the red skin of the Lips.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
Of the Mucles of the lower Jaw.
div.p: THE lower Jaw (for the upper is immoveable, and therefore has no Mucles) is moved upwards, downwards, towards the right ide, towards the left ide, and towards the back-part. To procure thee motions five pair of Mucles are appointed,The lower jaw hath five pair of mucles. of which there is only one pair that draweth the Jaw downwards, all the others in ome meaures upwards: whence one may be eaily made to hut his Mouth, there being only one pair of Mucles to oppoe; but it is difficult to open it againt ones will, through the great trength of the Mucles that hut it.

The firt pair of Mucles is called temporale, 1. Temporale. and is the tronget and larget: It pringeth from the bones of the frons, ynciput, temples and phenoides, with a flehy, large and emicircular beginning, and on its outer ide is covered with the pericranium, its inner lying next the perioteum. Its Fibres the further they are from its middle, the more obliquely are they carried towards its Tendon, for the further it decends, the narrower (but thicker and more carnous) it grows; and at length paing under the os jugale, it embraceth and is inerted into the acute proces of the lower Jaw (called < in non-Latin alphabet > ) with a hort but very trong Tendon. Spigelius ays, this Tendon is extended through the whole Mucle, in its middle flehy ubtance. Wherefore if this Mucle be wounded,
fearful ymptoms enue,Why the wounds of the temporal mucle are dangerous. partly becaue the Tendon paeth o; partly becaue it is covered with the pericranium. This Mucle forcibly pulleth up the lower Jaw, and o hutteth the Mouth. The Second pair is called deprimens, digatricum, or biventre, becaue it hath two bellies,2. Deprimens or biventre. between which a Tendon lyeth: this doth pull down the Jaw, and o openeth the Mouth. Wherein it is partly aited by the Quadratus decribed in the foregoing Chapter. It hath its beginning from the proces of the bone of the Temple, called Styloides, where it is nervous and broad; and afterward becoming flehy, mall, and round, it paeth downward, and in its middle, where it comes to the flexure of the lower jaw-bone, it loeth its flehy ubtance, and degenerates into a nervous and round Tendon; but by and by it becomes carnous again, and goes along the inner ide of the lower-jaw, to its forepart that is under the Chin, where it is inerted.3. Maeter or laterale. The third is called maeter, becaue it erveth for chewing by moving the Jaw to the right and the left ide: from its ituation it may be called laterale. This hath two beginnings: one is nervous, pringing from the uture where the firt bone of the Jaw is joyned to the fourth. This beginning is large and trong. The other beginning is flehy, proceeding from the os jugale, and o marcheth towards the Chin, and is implanted into the whole breadth of the lower Jaw trongly. The Fibres of this Mucle, by reaon of the two beginnings, cros one another; o that thee Mucles do not only move the Jaw laterally,4. Aliforme externum, or maxillam abducens. but backward and forwards alo.

The fourth pair is called pterygoideum externum, aliforme externum, or maxillam abducens. This hath
alo a double beginning, partly nervous and partly flehy; pringing partly from the upper external ides of the wing-like proces of the os phenoides, partly rom the rough and harp line of the ame bone. Whence marching down by treight Fibres, it becometh greater and thicker. And at length is inerted by a trong Tendon into the internal lateral part of the lower Jaw, which is under the Tendon of the temporal Mucle. This moveth the Jaw forward, which appeareth when the lower Teeth are tretched further out than the upper.

The fifth pair is termed maxillam adducens, or pterygoideum internum. 5. Alitorme internum, or maxillam adducens. This draweth the Jaw towards its head, or backward. This, in the beginning being nervous, doth pring from the inner cavity of the wing-like Proces of the os phenoides; then becoming flehy, large and thick, and marching down by a treight paage, it is inerted into the inner and hinder part of the lower Jaw by a nervous, broad and trong Tendon. Beides its more proper Action of drawing the Jaw backwards, it alo helps the temporal Mucle to draw it up.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
Of the Mucles of the Ear.
div.p: THE Ear conits of an outer and an inner part: and each has its proper Mucles.

The outer part is moved but very obcurely, becaue in Men the Mucles are exceeding mall; o that Galen calls them, only lineaments or reemblances of Mucles.The auricula hath four mucles. There are four of them, which by their ituation eem fit to move this outer part of the Ear (called auricula by Spigelius, to ditinguih it from the inner part called auris) four manner of ways.

The firt is called attollens. This is eated in the fore-part of the Face, and lies upon the temporal Mucle that draws up the lower Jaw. It aries at the outer end of the frontal Mucle (where it is contiguous to the temporal) with a thin and membranous beginning, but by degrees becoming narrower as it goeth down, it is inerted into the upper part of the Ear, which it moveth upwards and forwards. The econd is called detrahens.
This arieth broad and carnous from the mammillary Proces, and growing narrower is inerted into the root of the cartilage of the Ear ometimes by two, ometimes by three Tendons. It draweth the Ear upwards and backwards. The third is called adducens ad antericra, whereby the Ear is drawn forward and downward. This is but a particle of the muculus quadratus, that pulleth down the Cheeks, decribed before, which acending
with its Fibres, is implanted into the root of the Ear. The fourth is abducens ad poteriora, which draws the Ear backward. This hath its beginning in the back-part of the Head, from the Tunicles of the Mucles of the occiput, above the proceus mammillaris, where it is narrow, but waxing broader it is carryed downward tranverly, and is inerted into the Ear behind. All thee Mucles in Hores, Oxen and the like, are very large to what they are in Men (yea they have more than thee) whereby they can move their Ears more
• trongly and apparently, to hake off Flies or any thing that offends them.

In the inner part of the Ear (called Auris) there are two.The auris two. The firt is called externus. It is mall, pringing pretty broad from the upper part of the paage of the Ear; then becoming narrower it grows into a very fine and mall Tendon, which is carryed on the outide of the Membrane, called tympanum, till it arrive at its centre or middle, into which it is inerted, jut there where on the inide of the aid membrane the little Bone called malleus ticketh, which with the Membrane this Mucle draweth a little outward and upward. The econd is called internus. This is very mall, and is placed within the os petroum. It hath its beginning in the bais of the wedge-like Bone, there where it is joined with the proceus petrous, and at about its middle it is divided into two mall Tendons, whereof the one is inerted into the upper proces of the malleus, and the other into the neck of it. This draws the head of the malleus obliquely forward, and pulls it inward from the incus.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
Of the Mucles of the Tongue.
div.p:
THE Tongue being the chief Intrument of Speech, and a part which erves to roll the Meat in the Mouth this way and that way, has all manner of motions, being moved forward (when we put out the Tongue) and backward, upward and downward, to the right hand and to the left; it is alo tretched out broad, or contracted. Its Mucles are either proper to it elf, or common to it with the os hyoides (to be decribed in the next Chapter.)The tongue has five pair. It has five pair of proper Mucles. The firt is geniogloum, o called from its rie and inertion ( < in non-Latin alphabet > the Chin, and < in non-Latin alphabet > the Tongue) as mot of the ret are. This pulleth the Tongue without the Teeth and Lips. It pringeth from the ruggednes which is in the middle of the Chin, in the inner and lower part of it, and is inerted into the lower ide and towards the root of the Tongue. The econd is called Hypilogloum
(on the ame account.) It arieth from the middle and upper part of the os hyoides, and ends in the middle of the Tongue, which it draws treight backwards or inwards. The third is called Mylogloum. This pringeth from the inner part of the lower Jaw, where the farthet grinding Teeth are, and is inerted into the ligament by which the Tongue is tyed to the fauces. Authors differ about the ue of this pair; ome thinking that it draws the Tongue downward; others, that if both of
them act together, they draw the tip of the Tongue treight upward and backward to the Palate and upper Teeth; if but one, that it draws it obliquely upward toward its own ide. The fourth is called Ceratogloum, becaue it arieth from the two horns of the os hyoides. It is inerted into the ides of the Tongue. If both of thee be contracted at once, they draw the Tongue treight downward and inward; but if only one, then is the Tongue drawn obliquely to that ide. The fifth pair is called Stylogloum, becaue it arieth from the tyloides proceus; from which pringing flehy and mall, but afterwards becoming broader and thicker, it is inerted into the ides of the Tongue, at about the middle of its length. If both thee act together, they pull the Tongue upward and inward; but if one only, then to the right hand or to the left.

div.head: CHAP. X.
Of the Mucles of the Bone of the Tongue, called os Hyoides.
div.p: THis Bone is moved upwards, downwards, forward, backward, and toward the ides, as the Tongue is; for it is moved according as the Tongue is, eeing it is joined to it, and its Mucles are common to both.

To perform thee motions it hath four pair of Mucles. Os hyoides hath four pair. The firt is called Sternohyoideum. This pringing from the upper, but inner part of
the ternum with a broad and carnous beginning, and acending under the Skin of the Neck by the Wind-pipe, till keeping the ame largenes and ubtance, is inerted in the root or bais of the hyoides, which it moveth (and the Tongue with it) downward and backward. The econd is oppoite to this, and is called geniohyoideum. This pringing from the inner part of the Chin, (by the geniogloum) flehy and broad, is inerted into the upper part of the root of the Bone, where a cavity is made to receive it, and draweth it treight upwards and a little forwards. The third is Coracohyoideum.
It rieth from the upper ide of the capula near the Coracoides proceus, having a carnous beginning, and paing under the Levator of the houlder-blade, called muculus patientiae, it acends under the par matoides that bends the Head, where it loes its flehy ubtance, as giving way to one more worthy than it elf, and degenerates into a nervous and round Tendon. But as oon as it is pat this, it becomes carnous again, and o continues till it is inerted into the horns of the hyoides. Conidering its lendernes it is the longet Mucle of the Body, and has two Bellies like the par deprimens that pulls down the lower Jaw. It pulleth the Bone obliquely downwards. The fourth is tyloceratohyoideum. This rieth from the root of the proceus tyloides, and endeth in the horns of the hyoides, which it draweth obliquely upward.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
Of the Mucles of the Larynx.
div.p:
THE Mucles of the Larynx are either common
or proper. The common mucles are four. The common are four; two called par ternothyreoideum, and as many called par hyothyreoideum. The Hyothyreoideum pringeth from the whole bais almot of the Bone of the Tongue, having a broad and carnous beginning; from whence decending with treight Fibres, and covering all the outide of the cartilage thyreoides, it is inerted into its lowet part. When this is contracted, it draws the buckler-like (or thyreoides) cartilage upwards and inwards, and thereby traitens the Chink of the Larynx. The other pair called ternothyreoideum (vulgarly Bronchium) pringing from the upper and inner part of the ternum with a carnous and broad beginning, acends with treight Fibres up by the ides of the Wind-pipe (continuing the ame largenes and ubtance) and is at lat inerted into the lower ide of the buckler-like cartilage, by drawing down which it opens or widens the Chink. Diemerbroeck aigns clear contrary actions to thee Mucles, viz. that the former widens and this latter traitens the rima of the Larynx.

The proper Mucles are in number nine.The proper mucles nine. The firt pair is called Cricothyreoideum anticum. This pringeth from the fore-part of the cricoides or ring-like cartilage, and is inerted into the lateral parts of the Thyreoides. It extends the cartilage and o
widens the rimula, for the forming of a big Voice. Bartholin, from the inertion of the Nerve, ays it aries from the thyreoides, and is inerted into the cricoides. Alo if this pair be very broad, he ays, it may be divided into two pair (which Riolanus has done) and then the econd may be called Cricothyreoideum laterale. The econd pair is called Cricoarytaenoideum poticum, pringing carnous from the hinder and lower part of the Cricoides, whoe cavity it fills, and acending with treight Fibres it is inerted with a nervous end into the lower ide of the Arytaenoides, which it pulls upward and backward, and thereby opens and widens the Larynx. The third is Cricoarytaenoideum laterale,
which pringeth above from the ides of the Cricoides, with a lender beginning, but growing preently larger, it is implanted into the ides of the arytaenoides, in that part that the foregoing did not cover. This openeth the Larynx by drawing the cartilages obliquely aide. The fourth pair is called Thyreoarytaenoideum. This is internal, carnous and broad, ariing from the fore interior part of the Thyreoides, and is inerted into the ides of the guttalis or arytaenoides, which make the glottis. It draws thee Cartilages one to the other and o traitens the Larynx. The fifth and lat is reckoned to be but one Mucle, and is called Arytaenoides, becaue it has its rie from the Cartilage o called, namely from its hinder Line, from whence being extended with tranvere Fibres, it is alo inerted into its ides, and by contringing of it huts the Larynx.

div.head: CHAP. XII.
Of the Mucles of the Uvula and Throat.
div.p: THE Uvula is aid by Velingius, The Uvula aid to have two mucles. Riolanus, &c. to have two Mucles to hold it up; of which one is called Pterygotaphilinus externus, which pringeth from the upper Jaw, a little below the furthermot Grinder, and is inerted into the ide of the Uvula: The other Pterygotaphilinus internus, proceeding from the lower part of the internal wing of the pterygoides Proceus, and inerted into the Uvula in like manner. But thee Mucles are very hard to dicover: and indeed there eems no occaion for them, eeing the Uvula has no apparent motion, and its own frame eems ufficient to upend it.

The Throat, The throat hath even. or the beginning of the oeophagus, called pharynx, hath even Mucles, to wit, three pair and a phincter. Of the pairs, the firt is Sphenopharyngaeum. This pringeth from the harp point of the phenoides with a mall and nervous beginning, and paing downward, ends in a fine Tendon, which is inerted obliquely into the lateral parts of the Palate and Pharynx, which it widens in wallowing. The econd pair is called Cephalopharyngaeum, and pringeth from that part where the Head is joined to the firt vertebra of the Neck, and marching down it is pread about the Pharynx with a large plexus of Fibres, and eemeth to make its Membrane. This traitens the Throat in wallowing. The third is Stylopharyngaeum. This
pringing from the tyloides Proces, is inerted into the ides of the Pharynx to dilate it. That which hath no fellow is called oeophagiaeus, which pringing from one ide of the thyreoides, and circularly compaing the Pharynx with tranvere Fibres, is inerted into the other ide of the Thyreoides; and erves to contract the Mouth of the Gullet, as the phincters of the anus and Bladder do thoe parts.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.
Of the Mucles of the Head.
div.p:
THE Mucles of the Head are either common, or proper. The common. The common are thoe which together with the Neck move the Head. Thee are to be decribed in the next Chapter.The proper are eight pair. The proper are thoe which only move the Head when the Neck remaineth unmoved, and thee are in number ixteen, or eight pair. The firt pair called Matoideum bend the Head forward, if both act together; but on one ide obliquely, if but one. Thee have each a double beginning; one nervous from the top of the ternum, the other carnous from the upper ide of the clavicula; which origines joining, it becomes wholly carnous, and acending obliquely by the Neck, at lat is inerted with a carnous end at the hinder part of the Head into the Proces called Matoides, or mammillaris. This is the only pair that is placed in the fore-part and bows the Head forward; all the ret are eated behind, and bend it backward or to the ides. Of
which the firt pair is called plenium or triangulare. It ries with a nervous beginning from the five uppermot vertebrae of the Thorax, and five lowermot of the Neck; from whence acending and becoming thick and carnous, it is implanted into the occiput with a broad and flehy end. If both the Mucles of this pair act together, they draw the Head directly backward; if one ingly, then a little to one ide. The econd is called complexum or trigeminum, becaue it has o plainly a threefold beginning, that it eems to be compounded or made up of three Mucles. One beginning is from the tranvere Proces of the fourth and fifth vertebrae of the Breat, a econd from the firt and econd of the ame, and a third from the pine of the eventh vertebra of the Neck: All which in their acent being united into one, are inerted into the occiput ometimes by one and ometimes by a triple Tendon. This has the ame action with the foregoing, as have alo the three following. The third pair is called parvum & craum, becaue it is mall and thick. This lyeth under the econd pair. It aries nervous from the tranvere Procees of the ix uppermot vertebrae of the Neck, and is inerted into the hinder root of the mammillary Proces. The fourth pair is rectum majus. Thee pringing from the edge of the econd vertebra of the Neck, are inerted into the occiput. The fifth, rectum minus. Thee lye under the former, and proceeding from the back-part of the firt vertebra end into the occiput. The ixth is obliquum uperius. This pair lies under the two recta, anwering to them in ubtance and form. It prings from the Proces of the firt vertebra of the Neck, and is implanted into the occiput by the outer ide of
the recta. Some ay its rie is here, and its inertion into the vertebra. The eventh, obliquum inferius.
This is longih, flehy and round, riing from the pine of the econd vertebra of the Neck, and is inerted into the tranvere Proces of the firt vertebra of the ame. Thee oblique Mucles erve to turn the Head about.

div.head: CHAP. XIV.
Of the Mucles of the Neck.
div.p:
THE Head is not only moved by the proper Mucles aboveaid primarily,The neck hath four pair. but econdarily alo by thee of the Neck, which are eight in number, on each ide four. The firt and econd pair bend the Neck backward, or obliquely; the third and fourth forward, or to one ide, as both or one act. The firt is called Spinatum.
This proceeding from the pinae of the upper even vertebrae of the thorax, and of the five lowet of the Neck, is inerted trongly into the lower edge of the econd vertebra of the Neck. The econd, Tranverale. This riing from the tranvere Procees of the ix upper vertebrae of the Thorax, is inerted outwardly into all the Procees of the vertebrae of the Neck. The third, longum. This being placed under the oeophagus, doth pring from the fifth and ixth vertebrae of the back, and as it acends is knit to the ides of all the vertebrae, till it come to the firt or highet of the Neck, where each touching other, they are both inerted
into its Proces. The fourth, triangulare, or calenum. It proceeds carnous from the firt rib, and is inerted into the inide of all the tranvere Procees of the Neck, except ometime the firt and econd. It is perforated to make way for the Veins, Arteries and Nerves which pas to the Arms.

div.head: CHAP. XV.
Of the Mucles of the Breat.
div.p:
HAving done with the Mucles that belong to the Head, the highet Venter, we come now to thoe of the middle or Thorax, which ait repiration. Of thee ome dilate the Breat in inpiration,The dilaters. ome contract it in expiration. Of the Dilaters the firt is called par Subclavium. This arieth flehy from the inner part of the clavicula, and paing obliquely is inerted into the firt Rib, near to the Sternum. The econd is erratum majus. This doth arie from the inide of the Shoulder-blade, and the two upper Ribs, and is inerted into the lower five true Ribs, and two upper hort Ribs, before they end into cartilages. It is called erratum or Saw-like, becaue its unequal extremities being intermixed with the like unequal beginnings of the obliquely decending Mucle of the Abdomen, imitate the Teeth of a Saw. The third is erratum poticum uperius. This lying under the rhomboides, pringeth membranous from the pines of the three lower vertebrae of the Neck,
and of the firt vertebra of the Back, and is inerted into the three of four upper Ribs. The fourth is erratum poticum inferius. This arieth from the pines of the three lowet vertebrae of the Back, and of the firt of the Loyns, and is inerted into three or four of the lowet (hort) Ribs. Fifthly, The
eleven external intercotals, which perform the office but of one Mucle. Thee pring from the lower part of the upper Rib, and are inerted into the upper part of the lower Rib obliquely.
There is another Mucle beides thee, that aits the widening of the Breat, namely the Diaphragm: but of it we poke at large in Book 2. chap. 3. where the Reader may find its Decription and Ue.

Thee that follow contract the Breat.The contracters. Firt, the par triangulare. This ariing from the middle Line of the ternum, is inerted into the bony ends of the third, fourth, fifth and ixth true Ribs (where they are joined to the Cartilages.) The econd is acrolumbum. This aries from the os acrum,
and the Procees of the vertebrae of the Loins; and acending up to the Ribs, is implanted into each of them in their lower ide, about three Fingers breadth from the pine, by a particular Tendon. (Diemerbroeck decribes another pair oppoite to this (which he calls cervicale decendens) pringing from the third, fourth, fifth, ixth and eventh vertebrae of the Neck, and is inerted into the upper ide of each Rib as the acrolumbum is into the lower. And ays, that this pair by pulling the Ribs upwards in inpiration widens the Breat, as the other by drawing them down in expiration traitens it.) Thirdly, The eleven internal
intercotals, which are as one Mucle. Thee
pas obliquely from the lower to the upper Rib. Their Fibres run oppoite to thoe of the external, repreenting a St. Andrew's Cros, or the Letter X.
Thee Mucles are much aited in their action, econdarily, by the Mucles of the Abdomen, capulae and Arms.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.
Of the Mucles of the Back and Loins.
div.p:
THE Back, but epecially the Loins being moved diverly, viz. backward and forward and to the ides, into every vertebra there are Tendons of the Mucles inerted, as if there were a great many Mucles in all.The back and loins have four pair. But there are but four (proper) pair to ait the motion of both. The firt pair are two triangular Mucles, which being joined together make a kind of a quadrature, and are therefore called par quadratum. Thee arie broad and thick from the hinder upper cavity of os Ileum, and the inner ide of os acrum, and are inerted into the tranvere Procees of the vertebrae of the Loins even up to the lowet Rib. If both thee act together, they bow the vertebrae of the Loins treight forward, if one alone, obliquely forward. The econd and principal pair are the muculi longiimi, which pringing at the bottom of os acrum and Ileum, and acending up the pine, reach as far as to the proceus mammillares near the Temple-bones, betowing
Tendons on the Procees of all the vertebrae of the Loins and Back, (whence ome have divided this pair into as many as there are vertebrae) being almot confounded with the two following from their rie till the lowet vertebra of the Thorax, where this pair begins to be eparated from them. And hence becaue thee three Mucles are omething hard to eparate, ome account them for one. The third pair are the Mucles called acri,
which arie behind from the os acrum, with an acute and flehy beginning, and end in the pine of the lowet vertebra of the thorax, and for the mot part alo are inerted, by the way, into the pines and oblique Procees of the vertebrae of the Loins. This pair helpeth the action of the former. The fourth and lat pair are the emipinati, which pringing by a nervous beginning from all the pines of os acrum and the Loins, end in the tranvere Procees of the vertebrae of the Loins, and of the lowermot of the Thorax. This pair erects the Thorax.

Now there are none of thee Mucles but the firt pair, that bend the Loins and Back forward; but thee are much aited in that action by the recti of the Abdomen, which we hall decribe in the next Chapter.

div.head: CHAP. XVII.
Of the Mucles of the Abdomen.
div.p: IN the firt Book, Chap. 3. where we dicoured of the common containing parts of the Abdomen, or lowet Venter, we only barely mentioned its Mucles, deferring the further decription of them till this place, where it eems more proper.

The Abdomen then hath ten Mucles,The Abdomen hath five pair. five on each ide. The firt pair is oblique decendens. Its rie is parted into even or eight flehy Portions, like Comb-teeth, which being intermixed with the Tendons of the erratus major of the Breat divided in like manner imitate a Saw. It pringeth from the lower ide of the ixth, eventh, eighth, ninth, tenth, and eleventh Ribs, and the tranvere Procees of the vertebrae of the Loins, adhering alo to the edge of os Ilium; from all which places its Fibres decend obliquely, and it endeth by a broad Tendon in the middle of the Belly in the Linea alba; which Tendon cleaves o fat to that of the obliquely acending (lying next under this) that they cannot be eparated without tearing. (The Linea alba in which thee Tendons end, is a white part or Line running from the mucronata cartilago at the pit of the Stomach down the middle of the Belly by the Navel to the oa pubis, and is made of the concoure of the Tendons of the Mucles of the Abdomen; namely of this pair already mentioned, and of the oblique acendens,
the tranvere and pyramidal. The econd pair is the oblique acendens. Thee lye next under the former, and their Fibres acending obliquely cros thoe of the other like an X. They pring from the tranvere Procees of the vertebrae of the Loins and the pines of os acrum with a membranous beginning, and from the edge of os Illum with a flehy. Acending carnous from hence they are joined to the cartilages of the eighth, ninth, tenth and eleventh Ribs, and end in the linea alba with a broad and nervous Tendon. The third pair is the rectum or treight. Thee arie flehy from the lower part of the ternum, from both ides of the cartilago mucronata, and from the cartilaginous ending of four Ribs; and o marching treight down along the Belly, it is inerted by a trong Tendon into the oa pubis. Each hath ometimes three, ometimes four tranvere incriptions or interections, that appear tendinous: whence ome divide them into four or five Mucles, accordingly as they have three or four Interections. And indeed if Galen's Rule be true, that whereoever the Nerve is inerted into the Mucle, there is its head; we mut confes they are ditinct Mucles. For Nerves are inerted into both their upper and lower parts, and into each of thoe that lye betwixt the Interections. And by uppoing them thus ditinct, we may conceive how they may better perform their primary action, which is trongly to compres the Belly for the expulion of the faeces or foetus. Under thee Mucles do the Arteriae and Venae mammariae decend to about the Navel, as the Arteriae and Venae epigatricae acend under them to near the ame place; and thee were held to inoculate one with
another, (the decending with the acending) till of late that uch inoculation is dicovered to be meerly imaginary. The fourth pair is the pyramidal. Thee are placed above the lower part of the muculi recti. They pring from the oa pubis, mall and carnous, where they receive their Nerves. They are broader at their bais, and grow narrower as they acend, whence they have their name of pyramidal. They climb up upon the recti about four Fingers breadth (the left being horter and narrower) and inert their acute Tendon into the linea alba. They are aid to ait the recti in their action, and are for that reaon alo called uccenturiati. But they eem more particularly to erve to compres the Bladder in making Water. Sometimes one, and ometimes both of thee are wanting, and then the ending of the recti is broader and more carnous. The fifth pair is the tranvere, which is firmly knit to the peritonaeum, and whoe Fibres run cros or athwart the Belly. They pring from a Ligament that grows from the tranvere Procees of the vertebrae of the Loins, from os Ileum, and the cartilaginous ends of the lower Ribs, (having the ame Arteries, Veins and Nerves with the obliquely acending) and end in a broad and membranous Tendon in the linea alba. The ue of all thee Mucles hath been held to be, firt, while the Body is at ret, to trengthen the parts ubjacent, and to encreae their heat: and econdly, when they are in action, firt, to further the excretion of the Excrements; econdly, to help the delivery of the Infant in labour; thirdly, to ait the Breat in trong expiration and expectoration; and fourthly, to help to bend the pine in tooping, &c. Diemerbroeck
thinks that the treight, pyramidal and tranvere do erve for the compreion of the Belly, but that the oblique do elevate or dilate it; for in inpiration the Abdomen is elevated as well as the thorax: and an alternate elevation and depreion eems neceary for the furthering the motion of the Aliments and Humours through the Parts contained in the lower Belly.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.
Of the Mucles of the Genitals, both in Men and Women.
div.p: IN the firt Book, chap. 23. of the Yard, we decribed its Mucles and their action, whither the Reader may pleae to turn, and here we hall but jut name them.The penis hath two pair. They are two pair. The firt are the erectores or directores, which arie from the inner knob of the coxendix, and are inerted into the nervous Bodies of the Penis. The econd are the acceleratores, which arie from the phincter of the anus, and paing on the under ide of the Penis (by the ides of the urethra) end about its middle.

The Clitoris in Women,The clitoris hath alo two pair. (omething reembling the Penis in Men) hath alo two pair of Mucles, which having decribed Book 1. chap. 29. we hall not init on here, but remit the Reader thither.
As to the Cremater Mucles by which the Tetes are upended in Men, ee them decribed Book 1. chap. 31. As for Womens Tetes, they have no Crematers.

div.head: CHAP. XIX.
Of the Mucles of the Bladder and Anus.
div.p: THE Bladder hath but one Mucle,The bladder hath one mucle. called phincter, which doth compas round its Neck, and the protates. In Men it is about two Inches broad, and is nothing ele but the middle membrane here grown more carnous than in the ret of the Bladder. Its Fibres are orbicular, whereby it contringes or pures up the Neck of the Bladder, that the Urine cannot pas out without a voluntary relaxing of this Mucle. In Women it reacheth to the Hole by which the Urine paeth into the vagina uteri, and eemeth to form it.

The Anus hath three Mucles.The anus three. The firt is phincter: this is flehy, and encompaes the end of the treight Gut, being two Inches broad. Its Fibres are orbicular. It doth not pring from any adjacent Bone, but only adheres to the coc • yx. It erves to pure up the Fundament. The econd and third are called levatores. Thee pring from the Ligaments of the coxendix and os acrum, being broad and membranous, from whence paing by the ides of the treight Gut, they tick to it, and are inerted into the upper part of the phincter. Thee hinder the falling out of the Fundament, which ometimes happens when they are too much relaxed.

div.head: CHAP. XX.
Of the Mucles of the Scapula or Shoulder-blade.
div.p:
THus we have done with the Mucles of all the three Venters: now we come to thoe of the Limbs. And firt of the Scapula or Shoulder-blade. It is moved forward, backward, upward and downward.The capulae have four pair. Each Scapula hath four proper Mucles. The firt is called trapezius or cucullaris, becaue it with its fellow covering the Back reembles a Monk's Cowl. It hath its beginning from the lower part of the occiput towards the Ear, flehy; but from the poterior Procees of five vertebrae of the Neck, and the eight upper vertebrae of the Breat, it pringeth membranous and broad, and growing narrower in its progres, is inerted into the whole pine of the Scapula, the top of the Shoulder, and broader part of the clavicula. The econd is levator, or patientiae muculus. This hath its beginning from the tranvere Procees of the firt, econd, third and fourth vertebrae of the Neck; which beginnings being united about the middle of the length of the Mucle, it is inerted into the upper corner of the Shoulder-blade. The third is erratus minor anticus. This lies under the pectoral Mucle, and prings from the four uppermot Ribs (except the firt) before they become cartilaginous, by four flehy portions repreenting the Teeth of a Saw, and is inerted by a broad Tendon near to the Anchor-like Proces of the Scapula.
The fourth is rhomboides. This is placed immediately under the cucullaris. It pringeth flehy from the hinder Procees or pines of the three lowet vertebrae of the Neck and o many uppermot of the Breat; and is inerted by as broad a flehy ending, as the beginning was, into the bais of the Shoulder-blade.

Thee are the four proper pair of Mucles belonging to the Scapulae: Of which the firt pair, becaue of its everal Origines and everal Fibres, moves them diverly, upward, or downward, treight backward, or obliquely, according as thee or thoe Fibres are contracted. The econd draws them (with the Shoulders) upwards; the third forward toward the Breat; and the lat a little upward and backward.

It hath other Mucles that are common to it with other Parts, which in ome meaure ait its Motions, as the erratus major, decribed above, chap. 15. and the deltoides, which we hall decribe in the next Chapter.

div.head: CHAP. XXI.
Of the Mucles of the Arm.
div.p: THE Arm in common acceptation is meant of all the ditance betwixt the top of the Shoulder-blade and the Writ; but we take it more trictly here for that part only that reaches from the Shoulder to the Elbow, (which it elf is otherwie called humerus) and conits of one Bone, which we hall call the Shoulder-bone.Each Arm hath nine mucles. It hath five motions, for it moveth backward, forward, upward, downward and circularly.

It is moved upward by two Erectors,Erectors. deltoides and uprapinatus. Firt, deltoides (o called becaue in hape it reembleth the Greek Letter Delta ) pringeth nervous and broad from the middle of the clavicula, the top of the Shoulder, and the whole pine of the capula, and is extended as far as to the middle of this Shoulder-Bone, where it is inerted. This beides its raiing up the humerus, helps alo to draw up the Scapula. The econd is uprapinatus, or upercapularis uperior. This aries from the bais of the Scapula, and fills up all that cavity that is betwixt its pine and upper Edge, and paing over the jointing of the Scapula with the Shoulder-bone, by a broad and trong Tendon is inerted into the Neck of the latter. Some think this doth not only lift the Arm upward, but help to turn it round.

It is pulled down by latiimus, Depreors. and rotundus major. Latiimus is o called from its largenes; for
with its fellow it covereth almot the whole Back. It is called alo ani calptor, or teror; for without it thoe Offices could not be performed. It prings by a broad membranous beginning from the hinder Procees of all the vertebrae of the Back-bone, that are betwixt the ixth of the thorax, and the middle of os acrum, as alo from the upper part of os ilium: then paing upwards, when it is come to that part of the Back, where the Ribs begin to bend, it becometh flehy, and is carryed over the lower corner of the capula; where becoming narrower, it is inerted under the upper head of the Shoulder-bone, by a hort broad Tendon, between the muculus pectoralis, and this that follows, viz. Rotundus major, or more properly, teres major. (For rotundus means a thing phaerical, but teres long and round, like a Thread, as this is.) It pringeth carnous from the whole lower cota of the capula, and is inerted by a hort and trong Tendon into the Shoulder-bone, a little below the Neck of it.

It is drawn forward by pectoralis and coracoideus. Movers forward. Pectoralis hath a very large and for the greatet part membranous beginning, ariing from divers parts, yet is one and continuous. In its upper part it ries from the middle of the clavicula on that ide next the Breat; in its middle, from the whole length of the ternum and the cartilages of the Ribs annexed to it; in its lowet, from the cartilages of the ixth, eventh, and eighth Ribs. It preently becomes carnous and thick, but narrower, and running towards the Shoulder it is inerted into the Shoulder-bone, a little below its Head, between the deltoides and the biceps of the Cubit. Coracoideus beginneth at the coracoides Proces
of the Scapula, and endeth about the middle of the Shoulder-bone.

It is moved backward by three:Pullers backward. Infrapinatus, ubcapularis, or immerus, and Rotundus minor. Infrapinatus or upracapularis inferior pringeth from the lower bais of the Scapula, and filleth up all that pace that is betwixt its pine and lower edge, as the uprapinatus did that between the pine and upper edge. It is inerted by a broad and hort Tendon into the fourth Ligament of the Shoulder-bone. Subcapularis or immerus poeeth the whole inner cavity of the Scapula. It pringeth from the inner part of its bais, flehy, and o continuing, paeth forward (but becoming till narrower) to the Neck of the Scapula, and at the lat by a broad Tendon is inerted into one of the Ligaments of the Arm. Rotundus minor arieth from the lowet corner of the Scapula by a flehy beginning, and is implanted into the Neck of the Shoulder-bone. Some make but one Mucle of this and the Rotundus major.

As to the circular motion of the Arm, that is not performed by any particular Mucle, but everal of thee contribute towards it, namely the uprapinatus, infrapinatus and ubcapularis, and in ome meaure the others alo.

div.head: CHAP. XXII.
Of the Mucles of the Ulna.
div.p: THE lower part of the Arm from the Elbow to the Writ is called Cubitus, which coniteth of two Bones, called ulna and radius. The ulna erveth for flexion, and extenion; but the radius turneth it inward or outward, o as to make the back or palm of the Hand look upward or downward.

The ulna is bended by two,Benders of the ulna. to wit, biceps, and brachiaeus internus. Biceps hath two beginnings from the Shoulder-blade. The firt is that which is outward, tendinous and round, pringing from the upper brim of the hollownes of the capula; The econd is broader, and is framed partly of a Tendon, and partly of Fleh: it prings from the Anchor-like Proces of the Shoulder-blade; then decending by the inner head of the Shoulder-bone, it meeteth with the former, and becometh a trong flehy Mucle: which lying on the inide of the Arm, afterwards ends in a thick, round, and trong Tendon, which is inerted into the inner Prominence or knob of the Ulna. This is that Tendon which caueth great pain if it be pricked in Phlebotomy.
Brachiaeus internus lyeth under the biceps, being horter than it, and altogether flehy. It rieth where the deltoides endeth, viz. from the middle of the Shoulder-bone, unto which it cleaveth firmly, and is inerted between the ulna and they radius where meet, in their foreide.

The ulna is extended by four Mucles,Extenders. longus, brevis, brachiaeus, externus, and cubitalis. Longus
has two beginnings; the one is partly flehy and partly nervous, at the lower brim of the capula, near its Neck, (where it hath a peculiar hollownes to receive it:) this decends on the inide of the Shoulder-bone, and when it is come as far as the inertion of the ani calptor (decribed in the foregoing Chapter) there aries another carnous beginning towards the outer ide, that (according to Spigelius) joins with it and makes up one Mucle, which is inerted into the inner ide of the hinder Proces of the olecranus (or gibbous knob of the ulna.) Brevis riing from the hinder part of the Neck of the Shoulder-bone, endeth in the outer ide of the olecranus; namely, in that part of the Elbow that we lean upon. Brachiaeus externus
(o called by Riolanus to ditinguih it from, the internus) is placed on the outide of the Shoulder-Bone, and is confounded with the other two and endeth where they do. This eemeth to be Spigelius's econd beginning of the longus, which he ays grows into one Mucle with it. Cubitalis
or anconaeus arieth from the lower and hinder part of the Shoulder-bone, and paing by the jointing of the ulna, it endeth by a nervous Tendon in its lateral part about an Inch below the olecranus or ancon, whence it is called anconaeus. Some make one Mucle of this and the brevis.
Note that both thee benders and extenders of the ulna have only treight Fibres, and o only move the Cubit treightwie.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII.
Of the Mucles of the Radius.
div.p: THE Radius, the other Bone of the Cubitus, hath two orts of Mucles: for ome are called pronatores, uch as turn it inwards, and the Palm of the Hand downwards; and ome upinatores, which turn the Radius outwards, and the Palm of the Hand upwards.

The pronatores are two in number. The pronatores. The firt is, pronator uperior rotundus or teres. This pringeth from The Root of the inner knob of the Shoulder-bone, and from the inner ide of the ulna, where it is joined to the Shoulder-bone; and running obliquely on the inide of the Radius endeth about its middle by a membranous Tendon. The econd is pronator inferior quadratus, which is altogether flehy. It pringeth from the lower and inner part of the ulna two Inches broad; then marching tranverly above the Ligament which joyneth the radius to the ulna, it endeth in the inide of the radius. The ending is as broad as the beginning; wherefore it is called quadratus or four-quare.

The upinatores are in like manner two.Supinatores. The firt is upinator longus, o called, becaue of all the Mucles which march by the ulna, it hath the longet Belly. This pringeth flehy from the edge of the outer knob of the Shoulder-Bone; and marching obliquely under the radius, is implanted by a membranous Tendon into the upper part of the lower appendix of the radius, bending omewhat
to the inneride. The econd is upinator brevis.
This pringeth from the outward part of the ligament in the jointing of the lower end of the Arm-bone, and from the hinder Proces of the ulna; from whence it paeth on obliquely, being without membranous, and within flehy, and is inerted into the middle of the radius.

Note that though for orders ake we have decribed the Mucles of the radius next to thoe of the ulna; yet when one would hew them in Diection, the Mucles of the Fingers, Thumb and Writ are firt to be raied, and then thee of the radius after thoe are taken away.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV.
Of the Mucles of the Writ.
div.p: THE Carpus or Writ has three Motions: It is either bended, extended, or moved ideways. For its flexion and extenion it has proper Mucles: but as for its motion ideways, that is not performed by any proper Mucles, but as one, or two of the ame ide (of the benders and extenders) act; for then is it moved upward or downward accordingly.

It is bended by two Mucles in the inide.Benders. The firt is cubitaeus internus: this arieth by both a flehy and nervous beginning from the inner knob of the Shoulder-bone; then paing flehy the length of the ulna or cubitus, it doth end by a Tendon, partly nervous, and partly flehy, in the
fifth, ome ay the fourth Bone of the firt rank in the Writ. The econd is Radiaeus internus: this ariing from the ame place, and paing along the radius, is inerted into that Bone of the back of the Hand which utains the fore-Finger.

Two External Mucles tretch out the Carpus. Extenders. The firt is radiaeus externus, or bicornis: this arieth from the harp edge of the outer knob of the Shoulder-bone in the upper part of it, by a broad beginning: then becoming flehy, it paeth to the middle of the radius, where it becometh a trong Tendon, which preently is divided into two almot round Tendons. Both thee pas a little aunder by the radius under the Ligament, whereof one is inerted into that Bone of the back of the Hand which tayeth the fore-Finger, and the other into the Bone which tayeth the middle Finger. The econd is cubitaeus externus: this hath its beginning from the root of the external knob of the Shoulder-bone: it paes along the ulna, and when it is come to the Writ, it endeth in a trong round Tendon, which is inerted into the upper part of that Bone which tayeth the little Finger, not far from the Writ.

div.head: CHAP. XXV.
Of the Mucles of the Palm of the Hand.
div.p: THis is thought to have two Mucles.The Palm hath two mucles. The firt is palmaris, which ar • eth from the inner knob of the Shoulder-bone, round and nervous, but preently becoming flehy it continues its coure along the Cubit, under all the other Mucles, till at length it turns into a round Tendon, which paing over the ligamentum annulare of the Writ, is afterwards dilated into a broad nervous membrane, which cleaveth firmly to the skin of the Palm of the Hand, for firm apprehenion or griping, and quicknes in feeling, and endeth at the firt Joints of the Fingers.

The econd is caro quaedam quadrata, or a fourquare flehy ubtance: this pringeth from the membrana carnoa under mons luniae, where the eighth Bone of the Writ is placed. From thence it is carried under the muculus palmaris, to the middle of the Palm of the Hand, and is inerted into the outide of that Tendon which moveth the little Finger outwards. This repreenteth two or three Mucles, and erveth for the hollowing of the Palm of the Hand, to form Diogenes his Cup by, bringing the flehy eminence under the little Finger, unto the Tenar.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI.
Of the Mucles of the four Fingers.
div.p: THE Fingers are bended, extended, and moved laterally. But eeing the motion of the Thumb differs very much from that of the other four Fingers, we hall decribe its Mucles in the next Chapter, eeing they are altogether ditinct from thoe of the Fingers.

The Fingers are bended by three Mucles.Benders of the four fingers. The firt is called ublimis, or perforatus. This pringeth from the inide of the inner knob of the Shoulder-bone; and about the Writ it produceth four Tendons, which end in the econd joint of the Fingers. Near their end they are cleft, to give way to the Tendons of the profundus paing through. The econd is named profundus. This arieth from the upper parts of the ulna and radius, a little below the Joint of the Elbow, and being eparated at the Writ into four Tendons, thee run through the Clefts of the Tendons of the ublimis, and are implanted into the third Joynt of the Fingers. The third ort of Mucles are called Lumbricales. Thee are very mall, and arie from the Tendons of the muculus profundus, and end in a round Tendon in the firt Joint of the Fingers, being confounded with the Tendons of thoe Mucles that move the Fingers laterally; yea ometimes they proceed further along with them, by the ides of the Fingers, to the third Joynt, and ait their lateral Motion.

The Fingers are extended by three Mucles,Extenders. whereof one is common to all the four Fingers, and two proper to two particular.One common. The common is extenor magnus. This ariing from the outer knob of the Shoulder-bone, about the Writ is divided into four Tendons, which are inerted into the econd and third Joynts of the Fingers; ome make two of this.Two proper. The proper are two. The firt is called indicator, becaue it belongeth to the fore-Finger. It arieth from the outward and middle part of the ulna, and by a double Tendon it endeth in the econd Joynt of the fore-Fingers: but one of the Tendons becometh one with the Tendon of the extenor magnus. The econd is named auricularis, becaue it belongeth to the little Finger. It arieth from the upper part of the radius, and marching between the ulna and the radius, it is inerted by a double Tendon into the outide of the little Finger.

The Fingers are laterally moved two manner of ways: for either they are brought to the Thumb, or they are carried from it.Movers laterally, eight. Thee Motions are performed by eight Mucles, called interoei, becaue they are placed between the Bones of the metacarpium. They are flehy and round, and pring from the Bones of the metacarpium, to which they adhere, paing treight along them. When they are come to the Roots of the Fingers, they pas into Tendons which cleave to the ides of the Fingers, and end in the lat Joynt of the Fingers near the root of the Nails. When the Tendons of the Lumbricales joyn with thee, they may be reckon'd amongt the Movers of the Fingers laterally; and then there will be twelve in all, the Lumbricales being four, and thee interoe •
eight.

Beides thee Mucles,Abducing mucles, two. the fore-Finger and the little Finger have each one proper Mucle. That of the fore-Finger may either be called abducens in repect of the middle Finger from which it draws it; or adducens, in repect of the Thumb towards which it draws it. It prings from the inide of the firt Joint of the Thumb, and ends in the Bones of the fore-Finger, which it pulls towards the Thumb. That of the little Finger is called Abductor (by ome hypotenar) and prings from the third and fourth bone (of the econd rank) of the Writ; whence proceeding along the palm of the hand, It is implanted by a mall nervous tendon into the outide of the firt joint of the little Finger, which it draws outwards from the ret.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII.
Of the Mucles of the Thumb.
div.p:
THE Thumb is extended by two Mucles.Ex • enders. The firt is that which is called longior.
