This arieth flehy from the outer and upper ide of the ulna, near the membranous ligament which tyeth together the ulna and radius. From thence it is carried obliquely upon the radius, and before it come to its appendix, turneth into a round Tendon; which paing under the annular ligament of the Writ, marcheth along that ide of the Thumb, which is next to the fore-Finger, and is inerted into its third bone. The econd is named brevior. This arieth from the
ame origine with the other, and paeth obliquely above the radius. By one Tendon it is implanted into the root of the firt joint of the Thumb; the other becoming membranous, cleaveth fat to its econd and third bone.

It is bended alo by two Mucles;Benders. one of which pringing from the upper part of the radius, is implanted into the firt and econd joint of the Thumb; the other being les, proceeds from the bone of the carpus, lying under the other, and reacheth to the middle of the Thumb. Thee two Spigelius, de hum. corp. fabric. l. 4. c. 19. divides into five Mucles,Monticulus lunae. which together with the abducens of the Thumb, make the monticulus lunae.

It is moved laterally by two Mucles.Movers laterally. The firt is called thenar or abducens. This pringeth from the inner part of that bone of the Writ, which tayeth the Thumb, by a nervous beginning: then becoming flehy, it is inerted into the firt joynt of the Thumb by a membranous Tendon, and draweth it from the fore-finger. Some make three of it. The econd is antithenar, or adducens, which lyeth in the pace between the Thumb and fore-finger. This doth arie from the outide of that bone of the metacarpium which utaineth the firt finger; and being flehy is inerted into the whole inner ide of the firt joynt of the Thumb, and endeth a membranous Tendon to the econd. This draweth the Thumb to the fore-finger. Some decribe a econd ariing from the inner ide of the bone of the Writ that utaineth the Thumb, and ending in its econd joynt.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII.
Of the Mucles of the Thigh.
div.p:
THE Thigh has four manner of motions: It is either bended (and that forwards, or backwards) or drawn inward, or outward, or moved round.Be • ders forward. It is bended forward by three Mucles. The firt is called poas, or lumbaris: this lyeth in the inner part of the abdomen, upon the vertebrae of the loins, &c. It arieth flehy from the tranvere procees of the two lowermot pondyls of the thorax, and two or three uppermot of the Loins, from whence decending by the inide of os ilium, it is inerted by a round and trong Tendon into the leer rotator. The econd is iliacus
internus: This pringeth with a lender and flehy beginning from the inide of os ilium, and being joyned to the Poas by its Tendon, it endeth before between the greater and leer rotator. The third is pectineus: this ariing broad and carnous from the upper part of the os pubis, is implanted a little below the neck of the Thigh-bone, on the inide, and draweth the Thigh upward and inward, and o helps us to lay one Thigh over the other when we it cros-leg'd.

It is bended backward or extended by the three glutaei, Benders backward. which make up the Buttocks, and erve to go backward withal. The firt is the outermot and the greatet, called glutaeus major. It pringeth very carnous from the coccyx, from the pine of os acrum, and from all the circumference of
the pine of os ilium, and is inerted by a trong Tendon four inches below the great rotator. The econd is the middlemot, called glutaeus medius:
This pringeth from the foreide of the pine of os ilium a little lower than the former, and is inerted into the outer and upper ide of the great rotator. The third is the lowermot, called glutaeus
minor: This pringeth a little lower, from the outer or back part of os ilium, lying wholly under the econd, and is implanted into the upper and inner part of the great rotator.

It is drawn to the inide by the muculus triceps: Drawers to the inide. this is the thicket of all the Mucles of the Body, and might more jutly be called quadriceps, eeing it has four beginnings; but they that impoed the name of triceps, made a particular Mucle of the fourth Head, and called it pectineus, or lividus. The firt head doth proceed nervous from the upper part of the hare-bone, and is inerted into the rough line of the thigh-bone. The econd pringing from the lower ide of the ame bone, being leer, is inerted a little higher up into the aid line. The third ariing from the whole lower part of the coxendix, is inerted a little under the leer rotator. The fourth pringing from the apex or tip of the coxendix is implanted into the inner and lower tubercle of the Thigh by a round Tendon, which is joyned with the lender Tendon of the firt part of this Mucle.

It is turned towards the outide by four mall Mucles called quadrigemini. Turners towards the outide. They are placed above the articulation of the thigh one by another. The firt is called from its ituation Iliacus externus, and from its figure pyriformis; it is longer than the ret, and arieth from the lower and outer
part of the os acrum. The econd arieth from the knob of os ichium. The third arieth from the ame part. Thee three are inerted into the hollownes of the great rotator. The fourth is called
quadrigeminus quadratus, more flehy and broad than the ret: it lyeth two inches ditant from the third, and arieth from the inner part of the knob of the ichium, and is implanted into the outward part of the great rotator.

It is turned about obliquely by two Mucles called obturatores. Turners about obliquely. The firt is obturator internus, this turneth it outward. It arieth from the inner circumference of the hole that is between the ichium and os pubis, and is inerted into the cavity of the great rotator. The econd is obturator externus: this arieth from the external circumference of the aid hole, and turning about the neck of the thigh-bone, as about a pulley, it endeth in the cavity of the great rotator, under the fourth quadrigeminus, and turneth the Thigh inward.

Note, that though for orders ake we have decrib'd the Mucles of the Thigh before thoe of the Leg, yet the Diector cannot o eaily nor conveniently raie and hew them, till thoe of the Leg are firt raied and removed.

div.head: CHAP. XXIX.
Of the Mucles of the Tibia or Leg.
div.p:
THE Leg is either bended,Benders. extended, or moved obliquely. There are five that bend it. The firt is longiimus or facialis. This arieth from the inner knob of os Ilium, and decends outermot jut under the skin on the inide of the Thigh, being lender, and near the Knee it ends in a Tendon, which is inerted under the Knee, into the fore and inner ide of the tibia. The econd is called gracilis, and pringeth with a nervous and broad beginning at the joynting of the oa pubis; from whence it runs down the inide of the Thigh, and is implanted by a round Tendon into the inner ide of the tibia, near the inertion of the firt, but a little lower. The third is named eminervous: This beginneth nervous and lender at the knob of the ichium, and decending obliquely to the back and inner part of the Thigh endeth in the inner ide of the tibia, towards the backide, about the middle of its length. The fourth is emimembranous: it proceedeth from the ame knob, partly nervous, and partly membranous; and marcheth by a broader Tendon than the third to the hinder part of the tibia. The fifth is biceps: this arieth from the ame knob of the ichium; and being carried on the outide of the Thigh, about its middle it becometh flehy, as if it begun there with a econd head; from whence decending it is inerted by a notable
Tendon into the outer ide of the upper proces of the fibula.

The Leg is extended by five Mucles.Extenders. The firt is membranous: this proceeding flehy from the upper part of the pine of os ilium, on the outide near the great proces of the Thigh-bone it turns into a broad membrane, wherefore it is called facia lata, for it covereth almot all the Mucles of the Thigh and tibia, and at lat is inerted a little below the Knee, into the outer and foreide of the tibia and fibula. The econd is longus: this arieth from the upper and fore-part of the appendix of os ilium, and paing by the inide of the Thigh obliquely, it endeth in the inide of the Leg a little below the Knee. It extends the Leg, drawing it inwards; and becaue it helps to lay one Leg upon the other when we go to it cros-leg'd, ome call it utorius, the Shoomakers or Tailors Mucle. The third is rectus: this pringing from the lower brim of the os ilium, and paing with a carnous and round belly treight down the Thigh before, when it is come to the patella, it ends in a broad and trong Tendon, by which it adheres cloe to the patella, as if it would end in it; but it paes further, and is inerted into the foreide of the tibia a little below the Knee. The fourth is vatus externus: this pringeth from the root of the greater trochanter, and endeth a little below the patella, near the ame place with the former. The fifth is called vatus internus: this arieth from the root of the leer trochanter, and endeth a little below the patella with the other. The vatus externus decends on the outide of the rectus, and the internus on the inide thereof, whence they have their name.
To thee ome add a ixth Mucle called crureus,
which pringeth from the fore-part of the Thigh-bone, between the two trochanters, and endeth in the ame place with the former.

Note that thee four lat Mucles being joined together about the Knee, make one common broad and trong Tendon, by which they involve the patella or Knee-pan, and which being inerted into the Tibia, tyes it and the Thigh-bone together like a trong ligament. Note alo that the Mucles which extend the Leg are tronger than thoe which draw it in, that the weight of the Body may be the more firmly upholden when we tand.

There is alo a ingle Mucle called poplitaeus, Mover obliquely. or ubpoplitaeus, which moveth the Leg obliquely: this lyeth in the hollow of the ham, and pringeth from the lower and outer knob of the Thigh-bone, and is carried obliquely to the hinder and inner root of the upper appendix of the tibia.

div.head: CHAP. XXX.
Of the Mucles of the Tarus or Intep.
div.p: THE Foot is bended, extended and moved ideways,Benders. according to the motion of the Intep, which firt is bended when it is drawn upwards. To perform this motion it hath two Mucles. The firt is tibiaeus anticus: this arieth from the upper appendices of the tibia and fibula, and cleaving unto the whole os tibiae, about the middle of it, it becometh narrower, and turneth by degrees into a Tendon, which paing under the annular ligament of the Intep, that prings from the lower appendices of the tibia and fibula, is commonly divided into two; whereof the one is inerted into the firt of thoe bones which are called innominata, and the other into that bone of the metatarus that is et before the great Toe. If the Tendon continue one, then it is implanted into the inner ide of this lat Bone. The econd is peronaeus anticus: this arieth from the outer and upper part of the fibula, and being carried through the chink of the outer ankle, it is inerted into that bone of the Metatarus which utaineth the little Toe. It decends all along by the outide of the foregoing Mucle, and hath ometimes two Tendons.

The foot is extended when it is drawn backwards.Extenders. To perform this motion it hath three Mucles. The firt is gemellus externus,
or gatrocnemius externus: this Mucle hath two heads, the firt of which aries under the ham, from the inner part of the end of the thigh-bone, flehy and broad. It marcheth down by the back and inner part of the tibia, and when it is come to the middle of it, it becometh tendinous. The other head likewie arieth under the ham, but from the outer part of the end of the Thigh-bone, and paing down by the outward and back part of the Leg, becometh tendinous a little above the former, and joyning with it they both grow into one trong, broad, and inewy Tendon, which is inerted into the Heel. This is the Mucle that maketh up the greatet part of the Calf of the Leg. The econd is gemellus internus,
or gatrocnemius internus, or oleus. This lyeth under the former, and is of a livid colour. It pringeth from the hinder appendix of the fibula by a trong nervous beginning, and growing pretty bulky it continueth o till it hath paed the middle of the tibia, when it becometh narrower, and tendinous; and a little above the Heel it is o united to the Tendon of the former gemellus, that both eem to be but one, and is inerted with it into the Heel. The third is plantaris. This pringeth from the outer part of the end of the Thigh-bone in the ham, being very mall but carnous. It decends but a little way before it ends in a
very long and lender Tendon, which joyning very cloely with thoe of the two former is fatened to the Heel, but reaches as far as the middle of the oal of the Foot; Spigelius ays, as far as the Toes, and is inerted into each of them, imitating the palmaris of the hand. The three Tendons of thee three Mucles thus uniting make one mot trong and thick Tendon, uually called the great cord; and this being implanted into the Heel makes a wound there o very dangerous.

The Foot is moved ideways by two.Movers ideways. The firt is tibialis poticus, adducens pedem, or Nauticus, becaue Sailers ue it much when they go up by the Ropes. It pringeth both from the tibia and fibula, and from the Ligament which tyeth them together, whence decending among the hinder Mucles, near to the inner Ankle it becometh tendinous: then paing by it, it goeth to the oal of the Foot, and is inerted into the lower part of that Bone of the tarus which is next to the cubiforme. This moveth the Foot inwards. The econd is peronaeus or fibulaeus poticus: this arieth from the upper and hinder part of the fibula or perone, by a nervous and trong beginning; and cleaving to the outide of the fibula, it paeth down round and flehy: the outer part is of a livid colour, but the inner of a red. When it is come to the middle of the fibula it becometh tendinous, and decends with the pernoaeus anticus by the fiure of the outer Ankle, but joins not with it, for it goes under the oal of the Foot, and is inerted into the root of the
greater os cuneiforme that is eated before the great Toe. Sometimes, though eldom, there is another Mucle, called peronaeus tertius, which being very lender accompanies the poticus in its whole progres, and is inerted into the ame place, aiting its Action.

div.head: CHAP. XXXI.
Of the Mucles of the Toes.
div.p: THE great Toe is moved by its proper Mucles,Extenders. as the Thumb of the Hand was: but the other four, by common; which we will firt decribe. They are extended by two. The firt is tenor longus. This arieth by a nervous and harp beginning from the upper and fore appendix of the tibia, and preently becoming carnous, it goeth treight down, and being come to the Intep it is divided into four Tendons, which paing under the annular Ligament, go each to one of the leer Toes, and are inerted into their econd and third joint on the upper ide. The econd is tenor brevis. This lyeth under the former, having its beginning from the tranvere or annular Ligament, flehy and broad, and by its four Tendons is inerted into the firt joynts of the four Toes.

The benders of the Toes are in like manner two,Benders. and four Lumbricales. The firt is flexor longus, or perforans: it lyeth under the gemellus internus, and arieth from the upper and hinder part of the tibia by a long and flehy beginning; and paing down lengthways of the Tibia, (unto which it cleaveth) when it is pat the middle of it, it becometh tendinous: then running by the inner Ankle, under the Ligament of the tibia and Heel, to the oal of the Foot, it is there divided into four Tendons, which paing through the holes of the flexor brevis, are inerted into the third and lat joynt of the four Toes.

The econd is flexor brevis, or perforatus: this pringeth from the lower and inner part of the Heel-Bone, and when it hath paed the middle of the Foot, it is parted into four round Tendons, whcih are inerted into the econd joint of the four Toes, being perforated to give way to the Tendons of the former Mucle to pas to the third joint.

They are alo bended by four Lumbricales,
Four Lumbricales. which agree altogether with the Lumbricales of the hand both in their ue, figure and rie. Thee pring from the Tendons of the two former mall and round, and are inerted by a mall Tendon into the ide of the firt joint, which they help to bend. The flehy ubtance, which rieth with two harp beginnings from the fore part of the lower ide of the Heel-bone, and reacheth to the rie of thee Mucles, eemeth much to further their Action, and to afford them their carnous Subtance.

The Toes are moved obliquely by the Interoei, Movers obliquely. which are o called, becaue they are placed between the bones of the Metatarus. They are ten in number, whereas there are but eight in the Hand, becaue the Metatarus hath one bone more than the Metacarpus. Each of them doth pring from the under ide of that bone where it is placed; and all marching according to the length of the bone flehy, they are inerted the outer into the firt joint, the inner into the econd of the Toes, by hort and omewhat broad Tendons. If the inner be contracted, the Toe is moved inwards; but if the outer be moved, the Toe is carried from the ret outwards. But if they both act together, then are the Toes extended. In the four ditances between the bones, there are eight uch Mucles; at the outide of the great Toe one, and another at the outide of the little Toe. But beides it, the little Toe hath a proper Abductor to move it outwards, which ariing from the Heel paes on the outide of the fifth bone of the Metatarus, and is inerted into the outide of its firt joint.

The great Toe hath five peculiar Mucles.Extender of the great toe. The firt is Extenor: this pringeth by a flehy beginning from the outide of the Tibia, where it parteth from the Fibula. It cleaveth fat to the Ligament which ties the Tibia to the Fibula, and marching along the upper part of the Foot, it is inerted into the whole upper part of the great Toe.

The econd is Flexor: Bender. this pringeth from the upper and back part of the Fibula, and decending by the ide of the Flexor longus to the inner Ankle, it there becometh tendinous, and is inerted
into the third or lat bone of the great Toe, by one trong Tendon. But ometimes it is divided into two Tendons, whereof one is inerted as aboveaid, and the other into the econd Toe: and when this happens, the Flexor longus ends but three Tendons to the three lat Toes, and none to the econd.

The third is Abducens pollicem, Movers ide-ways. which draweth the great Toe from the ret, to the inner part of the Foot. It pringeth nervous from the Ligament which tieth together the Heel-bone and the Talus, (or according to ome from the inner ide of the Heel it elf) and running forwards on the inide of the Foot, it is inerted by a round Tendon into the outide of the firt joint of the great Toe.

The fourth is Adducens pollicem major. This pringeth from the Ligament of that bone of the Metatarus that utains the little Toe and the next to it, and proceeding obliquely over the other bones it is implanted into the inner ide of the firt joint of the great Toe.

The fifth and lat is Adducens pollicem minor (otherwie called Tranver alis.) This arieth from the Ligament of the little Toe that tieth its firt joint, and paing cros the firt bones of the Toes it ends in the inide of the firt bone of the great Toe. Some think this erves only to tie together the firt bones of the Toes (like a Ligament:) But Caerius (who firt found it out) ays it draws the great Toe to the little one, and o makes the Foot hollow, graping the ground as it were, when we go in tony and uneven places, to fix the Foot more firmly.
div.trailer: The end of the fifth Book.

div.head: CHAP. I.
Of the Nature of a Bone.
div.p:
A Bone is called in Greek < in non-Latin alphabet > ,Its name. from < in non-Latin alphabet > to tand; for according to Hippocrates,
< in non-Latin alphabet > , it affords tability, treightnes and form to the Body.
It may be defined to be a imilar part,Definition. mot dry and cold, inflexible, void of ene, affording tabiliment and form to the whole Body.

Bones have been commonly taught to be made of the more cras,Matter. tartareous or earthy part of the Seed, in the Womb, and that they are nourihed with the like particles of the Bloud, and moiten'd with their contained Marrow. And I ee no reaon to recede from this doctrine, unles one would commence litem de nomine, brangle
about a term: for though Women have no true Seed, and the Man's being only an active principle of generation affords nothing of matter to the parts of the Foetus, but only impregnates the Ovum, (as was hewn in Book 1.) yet if we will but grant the name of Seed to the humour in the Ovum, (which we may do without aburdity) we may continue the old manner of peaking. Now though they are continually nourihed, yet towards Manhood, by the encreaed heat of the Body, the primigeneal moiture is o leened, that the Bones through their hardnes are not apt to be any longer extended; and o Men ceae to grow any higher of tature.

Their nourihment is brought to them by the Arteries, Veels. and what is not fit for their ue returns back by the Veins. Several of them, as the Shoulder and Thigh-bones, have apparent holes for the entrance of the veels into their Marrow: and uch as have no Marrow and o want uch holes, they are commonly of a more pongie or fungous ubtance, into which no doubt ome nutritive particles of the Bloud pas from the Arteries, though their branchings therein are not o apparent. There are no Nerves that are inerted into them (except into the Teeth) but thee only run through the Membrane or Perioteum that invets them.

Their ubtance is whitih and hard,Subtance. (in ome Bones, and at ome ages, more, and in others les) not altogether dry in living perons, but bedewed with a fat and unctuous moiture, which the more it abounds, the Bones are the tougher and les apt to break; and when they are broken, they are the apter to grow together again with a Callus, which uch vicous juice contributes very much to. And it is only by a Callus that any Bone is joined after fracture; for a Bone being of the number of thoe parts that are called permatick, can never be generated anew.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Of the natural affections of Bones.
div.p: THE Affections of Bones are either common to all, or proper to ome only.

The common are even.Common affections. For firt, a Bone mut be hard, the more firmly to utain the Body. Secondly, of a whitih colour, becaue it is a permatick part. Thirdly, detitute of feeling, for avoiding of pain in motion. Fourthly, it mut be either hollow to contain Marrow in its Cavity for moitening of it; or pongious and porous, that ome nutritive particles of the Bloud may pas through its very ubtance. Fifthly, its ends
mut be covered with a Cartilage, and that bedewed with an unctuous humour, to procure an eaie motion. Sixthly, it mut be covered with a Membrane, to preerve it from carioity; except the four Bones of the Ear, and the parts of the Teeth above the Gums. Seventhly, it mut be equal. Wherefore the Callus wherewith a broken Bone is united, and nodes in the Pox, are not natural affections.

Thee tokens that follow, hew a Bone to be preternaturally affected: Firt, if it be oft; becaue that mut caue the Member to be too flexible. Secondly, if it be too dry; for then it is ditempered. Thirdly, if it be black; for then it is carious. Fourthly, if its figure be altered; for then it mut hinder the action of the part.

The proper affections are four:Proper. The firt is a Cavity; and it is twofold: for it is either deep, as in the Hip-bone, and is called Cotyle; or hallow, as in the Knee, and is called Glene. The econd is a Protuberance, of which there be two kinds: for it is either a continued part of the Bone jetting manifetly above its plain uperficies, for the more commodious inertion of the Mucles, &c. and is called Apophyis, a Proces; or ele it is like an additional Bone growing to another by imple and immediate contiguity, (and generally ofter and more porous than it) and is called Epiphyis, an Appendage. If the Protuberance of the Bone be round, it is called its Caput; under which is the Cervix, as in the upper end of the Thigh-bone: If it be flat, it is called Condylus: If pointed, Corone. Other Protuberances are named from the imilitude they have to other things; as Styloides, Coracoides, &c. The third
is Inequality: this is een in the outide of the Occiput for the inertion of the Mucles. The fourth is Smoothnes, as in the outide of the ret of the Skull.

div.head: CHAP. III.
Of the differences of the joining of Bones together.
div.p: THEY are coupled together either by Articulation or jointing; or ele by Symphyis or growing together.

Articulation is either for manifet, Articulation. or obcure motion. The jointings which erve for manifet motion are three. Firt, Enarthrois, which is when a large head of a Bone is received into a deep Cavity, as the Thigh-bone into the Hipbone. Secondly, Arthrodia, which is when the Cavity which receiveth is hallow, and the head of the Bone which is received, flattih: uch is the articulation of the lower Jaw with the Temple-bone. The third is Ginglymos; when the ame Bone receiveth, and is received. This falleth out three manner of ways. Firt, when the Bone is received by another, and receiveth the ame; this is een in the articulation of the Shoulder-bone with the lna. Secondly, when a Bone receiveth one Bone, and is received by another: this may be een in the Spondyls or Vertebrae of the Back, where the middle Bone receiveth the upper, and is received by the lower. The third
is, when the proces of the Bone being long and round, is inerted into another upper Bone, and o is turned in the Cavity like an Axle-tree in a Wheel; o is the econd vertebra of the Neck jointed with the firt.
Articulation for obcure motion is called Synarthrois; and uch is the jointing of the Ribs with the Vertebrae, of the Bones of the Carpus and Metacarpus, and of the Talus with the Heel-bone.

Bones grow together either without ome middle heterogeneous ubtance,Symphyis. or with it. Without ome middle ubtance they are joined three manner of ways. Firt, by a imple line, as the Bones of the upper Jaw and Noe: this is called Harmonia. Secondly, by a uture, as the Bones of the Skull. Thirdly, when one Bone is fatened in another, as a nail in wood; and o are the Teeth fatened in the Jaw-bone: this is called Gomphois. If Bones grow together by a middle ubtance, it is either by a Cartilage, as the Share-bones are joined; which unition is called Synchondrois: or by a Ligament, and o the Thigh is joined with the Hip-bone; this is called Syneurois, or more properly, according to Spigelius, Syndemois: or lat of all by Fleh, and o is the Bone of the Tongue by its Mucles to the adjacent parts; this is termed Syarcois.

Spigelius reckons two other heterogeneous middle ubtances by which Bones are united; one when they are joined by a Tendon, as the Kneepan to the Thigh-bone and Tibia, which unition he calls Syntenois; the other by a Membrane, as in Infants the Bones of the Synciput with the Os frontis; and this he calls Synymenis.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
Of the Sutures of the Head.
div.p: THE Bones of the whole Body belong to thee four parts of it; the Head (and Neck) the Breat, the lower Belly, and the Limbs.
The Head is that part which is above the vertebrae of the Neck: of it there are two parts, the Skull and the Face. The Skull is that bony ubtance which containeth the Brain, and is decked with hair.
In the decription of the Bones of the Head thee two things are to be noted; the Sutures, and the number of the Bones.Sutures proper or common. The Sutures are either proper, or common.
The proper are thoe which join the Bones of the Skull one with another;Proper utures true or counterfeit. and they are either true Sutures, or (mendoae) counterfeit.

The true are thoe which repreent two Saws joined together by their Teeth;Three true. and thee are three in number: the firt is Coronalis, which is eated in the fore part, and paeth from one Temple to the other tranverly, joining the Os frontis to the Synciput. The econd is Lambdoides, oppoite to this, reembling the Greek letter . This beginning at the bais of the Occiput acends obliquely to either Ear, and joins the Bone of the Occiput to the Bones of the Synciput and Temples. The third is Sagittalis, which beginning at the top of the Lambdoides comes treight forward by the Crown to the middle of the Coronalis,
and in Children for ome years (ometimes in the adult) it runs to the top of the Noe, dividing the bone of the Forehead into two.

The counterfeit or mendoae reemble a line only,Two counterfeit. and might more properly be called Harmoniae than Sutures. They are two in number. The firt paing from the root of the Proceus mammillaris upwards with a circular duct, circumcribes the Temple-bone on each ide of the Head, decending down again to the bais of the Ear: this joins the Bones of the Synciput, Occiput and Sphenoides with the Temple-bones, thee lying upon thoe like the Skales upon Fih, whence thee Sutures are called Squamoae. The econd runs from the top of this quamous conjunction obliquely downwards towards the orbit of the Eye, to the beginning of the firt common Suture, and joins this Bone above with the Bones of the Synciput, below with the Bone of the Forehead.

The common Sutures are thoe which belong to the Skull,Common utures. the wedge-like Bone, and the upper Jaw. The mot remarkable are thee: firt, Frontalis, by which the outer proces of the Os frontis is joined with the firt Bone of the upper Jaw. The econd is Cuneiformis, by which the wedge-like Bone is joined with the firt Bone of the upper Jaw. The third is Cribroa: this is common to the wedge-like Bone, and the Septum or partition of the Noe.

The Sutures have three ues.The ues of the utures. The firt is to help to tay the Brain from tottering, and its parts from being miplaced in violent motions, by permitting ome Fibres to pas through from the Dura mater to the Pericranium, by which the aid Mater and the Brain inveted in it are upended
as it were. The econd is to permit the teams and fumes in the Brain to evaporate. And the third, to hinder the fiures that happen in the Skull from knocks or falls, &c. from extending any farther than through one Bone, for they generally top at the next Suture.

div.head: CHAP. V.
Of the proper Bones of the Skull.
div.p: THee are in number ix, one of the Forehead, another of the Occiput, two of the Crown, and two of the Temples.

Firt,Os frontis. Os frontis, the Forehead-bone. It is bounded by the Coronal and firt common Suture, before; and in the ides by the temporal Bones. It is but one in thoe of ripe age, but double in Children, being divided by a Suture paing from the Coronal to the Noe.

Betwixt the Laminae of this Bone in the upper part of the Eye-brows at the top of the Noe,Its cavity. there is a large Cavity, (often two) from whence two holes pas to the Notrils. The outer Lamina that contitutes this Cavity, makes the upper plane part of the orbit of the Eye; but the inner, on each ide above the Eyes forms a bunchy protuberance uneven with many jettings out like little Hills. The Cavity is inveted with a very thin greenih Membrane, and contains a clammy humour. What its ue may be is hard to ay; ome think it gives an Echo to the Voice, making
it more onorous; others that it receiveth the odoriferous air drawn in by the Noe, to tay it awhile before it be ent to the Brain. It hath two holes in the middle part of the Eye-brow, which go to the orbit of the Eye, by which the firt branch of the Nerve of the fifth conjugation of the Brain goes to the Mucle of the Forehead, &c. It hath alo four procees; the greater two are eated at the greater corner of the Eye, but the leer two at the leer, making the upper part of the orbit.

The Bones of the Crown are in number two.The bones of the Synciput.
Before, they are joined with the Bone of the Forehead, by the Coronal uture; behind, with the Os occipitis by the Suture Lambdoides; and on each ide to the Temple-bones, by the Suturae quamoae. They are joined to one another in the middle of the Crown by the agittal Suture. On the outide they are mooth, but on the inide uneven, for they have a great many furrows running along them for the paage of the Veins of the Dura mater. Their ubtance is thinner and more rare even in the adult than that of the other Bones (for the better exhalation of vapours) but in Infants that abound with much humidity, they are membranous and oft, hardening by degrees.

Under thee on each ide are the Bones of the Temples.The Temple-bones. They are joined in their upper part to the outide of the Bones of the Crown by the Suturae quamoae; before, to the firt Bone of the upper Jaw, by its firt proces; behind, to the Os occipitis, by a counterfeit Suture. Thee Bones are even and thin in the upper part, like a Skale; but below thick, hard and unequal or eraggy; wherefore they are called Petroa.

They have each two Sinus;
Their Sinus. the outer greater, lined with a Cartilage, betwixt the Meatus auditorius and the proces of Os jugale, that receives the longer head of the lower Jaw; the inner les, common to the Bone of the Occiput, placed on the hinder ide of the aid proces.
By thee Sinus there tands a lender,Os tyloides. harp and longih Appendix, from its hape called Styliformis, which in Infants is cartilaginous, but in the adult becomes bony.
Beides this Appendix they have three other Procees, two external and one internal.
The firt external is blunt;Proceus mammillares. thick and hort, a little hollow within, and becaue it omewhat reembles a Cow's Pap is called Mammillaris.
The econd is carried forward from the Meatus of the Ear, and is joined with the Bone of the upper Jaw, both of them framing the Os jugale, of which in the next Chapter.

The third, that is internal, is pretty long, jetting out to the inner bais of the Skull, within which it has two holes, through one of which an Artery, and through the other the auditory Nerve pas to the inner Cavities of the Ear, that are excavated in this Bone, namely the Tympanum, Labyrinthus and Cochlea; and without the Skull it hath three holes; the firt of which is the Meatus auditorius; the econd is narrow, hort and oblique, near to the firt, by which the Jugular vein enters the inner Cavities; the third is eated betwixt the Proceus mammillaris and the Styloides appendix, and ends into that paage that goes from the Ear to the Mouth.

As to the four little Bones that are contained in its Cavities, viz. Incus, Malleus, Stapes, and
Os orbiculare, we have poken of them before in Book 3. Chap. 23.

The Os occipitis, Os occipitis. that makes the hinder and lower part of the Head, is five-corner'd, by two of which corners it is joined in its upper part to the Bones of the Synciput by the Lambdoides Suture, by two other in its foreides to the Temple-bones by a counterfeit Suture, and by its fifth corner to the Os cuneiforme, (according to Spigelius.) It is but one in the adult, but it conits of four or more in Infants. It is the thicket and mot compact of all the Bones of the Skull. It is aid to have nine Sinus, two external, and even internal. Of the internal the two larget are thoe that receive the protuberances of the Cerebellum. It has alo five Protubernances, and five Foramina, of which the lowet and larget is that by which the Medulla oblongata paes out of the Skull into the Cavity of the Vertebrae. The ret are les, and are for the tranit of the Veels.

Thee Bones of the Skull conit of two Tables or Laminae, all but the quamous part of the Temple-bones. The uppermot is hardet, thicket and moothet: The lower is unequal, and pitted, to give way to the Veels dipered through the Dura mater. Between thee two Tables there is a certain pongious ubtance, containing a marrowy and red juice, for the nutrition and humectation of the Bones, and is call'd Diploe. It is red, by reaon of the many mall Veins and Arteries paing that way. Many times in the Pox a virulent humour is gathered herein, which eats through and corrupts the Laminae, and caues mot tormenting pains in the Perioteum and Pericranium.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
Of the Bones common to the Skull and upper Jaw.
div.p:
HItherto of the Bones proper to the Skull: Now follow thoe which are common to it and the upper Jaw. Thee are three: Firt, the wedgelike Bone,Os cuneiforme. Sphenoides or Cuneiforme; o called, not that it is like a Wedge, but that it is eated betwixt the Bones of the Skull and the upper Jaw. Before, it is joined with the Forehead-bone; behind, to the Os occipitis. At the ides it doth accompany a good way the Os petroum. Above, it doth touch the firt, fourth, and ixth Bone of the upper Jaw; and below, the Bones of the Palate of the Mouth by the wing-like Procees. It is thick in the middle, but thinner at the edges, and in the adult it conits of two Laminae and a Diploe, like the other Bones proper to the Skull. In Infants it conits of three or four. It has four external Procees, of which two, that are contiguous to the upper Jaw, are called Aliformes Wing-like; and four internal alo, that compoe the ella Turcica, upon which the Glandula pituitaria lieth, that receiveth the pituitous excrements falling from the Brain by the Infundibulum. But this ella Turcica is not perforated, as we intimated from Dr. Lower in Book 3. Chap. 5. though that has been generally taught, uppoing that the pituitous matter did detil through its holes upon the Palate, &c. whereas it is reorbed by the Veins, as that learned Doctor affirms. It
hath undry perforations, by which the motory and optick Nerves of the Eye, and other Nerves for the motion of other parts, as alo Veins and Arteries do pas.

The econd common Bone is Os cribriforme, Os cribriforme. becaue, like a Sieve, it hath many holes, by which mells pas to the Proceus mammillares or olfactory Nerves. It is covered with the Dura mater, and eated in the middle bais of the Forehead at the top of the Notrils, and is joined by the Sutures called Harmoniae to the Os frontis, the econd Bone of the upper Jaw and to the Cuneiforme. On its upper ide in the middle it has growing upon it a kind of triangular proces, like to the Comb of a Cock, which is therefore called Crita galli. And oppoite to this in its lower ide it has another that is thin and hard, dividing the Noe into two parts or Notrils, the right and the left, and is called Septum nai. To this Os cribriforme, in the cavity of the Notrils, there adhere two other Bones called Spongioa, becaue they are full of holes like a Pumice-tone. But mot Anatomits conider them as parts of the Os cribriforme, confounding their names one with the other, calling this, Os pongioum or cribriforme indifferently.

The third common Bone is Os jugale, or the Yoke-bone. It is placed on each ide of the Face between the Meatus of the Ear and the firt Bone of the upper Jaw, being framed of two Bones, of which the hinder is a proces of the Temple-bone that is carried from the Meatus auditorius; and the fore-bone is a proces of the firt bone of the upper Jaw, which maketh the lower ide of the leer corner of the Eye. Thee two Procees are
joined by an oblique Suture, and make the Os jugale. It utaineth the Tendon of the temporal Mucle which paeth to the lower Jaw, and that of the Mucle Maeter.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
Of the Jaws.
div.p: NOW follow the Bones of the Face, which are the Jaw-bones with their Teeth; to which we hall ubjoin the Bone of the Tongue.

The Jaws are two,The upper Jaw conits of <> bones. the upper and lower. The ubtance of the upper Jaw epecially on its inide is not olid but pongious; and unequal, becaue it is framed of undry Bones. They are ix pair, ix in each ide. The firt is Zygomaticum: this maketh up the bet part of the Os jugale, and the outer corner of the Eye. The econd is Os lachrymale. It is a round, little and thin Bone in the inner corner of the Eye, whereon the Caruncula lachrymalis reteth. In the lower part of it there is a hole which paeth to the cavity of the Noe: by this a branch of the fifth pair of Nerves paeth to the inner Membrane of the Noe. The third is thin as the former, but quadrangular. It is placed between the two former in the inner ide of the orbit of the Eye, and is continuous to the Os pongioum of the Notrils. The fourth is Os malae, the Cheek-bone, the greatet and thicket. This maketh up the greatet part of the Cheek and Palate, and containeth all the upper
Teeth in its caverns. It is joined above, on that ide next the Noe, to the Bone of the Forehead, but below with the wedge-like Bone; before with the Os lachrymale, behind with the third, and lat of all with its fellow. Under the Eye it has a hole for the paage of a branch of the fifth pair of Nerves that is betowed on the Face; and another near the bottom of the Noe, by which an Artery and a Vein pas from the Palate to the Notrils. The fifth is long, hard, and reaonable thick; it with its fellow maketh up the bony part of the Noe. It is joined with the Cartilages of the Noe below, (to which purpoe it is very rough and unequal on that ide) but to the internal proces of the Os frontis above. The ixth doth make up the Roof of the Mouth, (with its fellow.)

Six Bones then make up the orbit of the Eye. The firt is Frontale, which maketh the upper vaulted part. The econd is placed in the outide, where the leer corner is, and is a portion of the wedge-like Bone. The third is the firt Bone of the upper Jaw, and maketh up the outide, concurring with the former portion of the wedge-like Bone. The fourth and fifth are the econd and third of the aid Jaw, and make up the inide. The ixth maketh up the lower part. Thee are joined one to another partly by common, and partly by proper Sutures.

The lower Jaw in thoe of ripe age is but one Bone,The lower Jaw. but in Children, till they are a year or two old, it conits of two, which are joined together at the Chin by Synchondrois, and afterwards grow into one. This is moveable, but the upper immoveable. It reembleth in hape the Greek letter v. At both the ends of it there are
two procees, whereof the one from a broad bais grows harp, and is called Corona: this receiveth the Tendon of the temporal Mucle, which is alo the firt of the lower Jaw. The other may be called Articularis, becaue it erveth for Articulation. This has a Neck and a longih Head (called Condylus) that is covered with a Cartilage for its eaier motion. By this Head it is inarticulated into the Sinus of Os petroum that is alo lined with a Cartilage, and is knit trongly thereto by a membranous Ligament. This Bone has a cavity within, epecially in the fore part toward the Chin, which contains a marrowy juice for its nourihment. It has four Foramina; of which two are at the roots of the Procees, by which a branch of the fifth pair of Nerves together with a Vein and Artery pas to the Teeth; and two other in its fore-part by the ides of the Chin, by which two twigs of the aid fifth branch pas out again to the lower Lip and its Mucles and Skin.

Both the Jaws have Alveoli or Sockets for the Teeth, in number equal with the number of the Teeth. But when in old age the Teeth fall out, the Sockets cloe together, o that in time there remains no print of them, but the Bone becomes harp.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
Of the Teeth.
div.p: THE Teeth are called in Latin Dentes, quai Edentes, from their office; and are fixed in the Jaw-bones as a Nail into a Pot, by Gomphois. Their root is tied to the Mandible by a Nerve, by Syneurois; and the upper part as far as 'tis compaed by the flehy ubtance of the Gum, by Syarcois.

Their ubtance is the hardet of all other Bones.Their ubtance. That part of them that tands out naked above the Gums is mooth and covered with no Perioteum; but that part within the Sockets of the Jaws is rough and inveted with a thin Membrane or Perioteum that is of exquiite ene. The Grinders have a manifet cavity within, (but the Inciores and Dog-teeth but an obcure one) whereinto by the very mall holes of their roots they each receive a Capillary artery from the Carotides, a Vein from the Jugulars, and a twig of a Nerve from the fifth pair (as aboveaid) which lat being expanded through the thin Membrane that invets the aid cavity gives it a mot acute ene; but the bony ubtance of it elf is wholly inenible. The Vein, Artery and Nerve are united together and clad with a common Membrane when they enter the Jaw, within which they have a proper channel to run along in under the roots of the Teeth, ending twigs to each as they pas under them.Origine.

The rudiments or principles of the Teeth are
bred with the other parts in the Womb, but lie hid for ome months within the Jaws and Gums, in which they encreae and are perfected by degrees, ome breaking through the Gums ooner, others later, as every one may oberve in Children. But though after uch a term of man's life, no new Teeth pring; yet they grow continually as long as a Man lives, ele would they be oon worn to the tumps by their daily ue; and we ee that when a Tooth is lot out of either Jaw, that which is oppoite to it in the other Jaw, will grow longer than the ret, having none to grind againt.

When Children come to be even or eight years old,Change. they change everal of their Teeth; but very rarely, if ever, all. The Inciores or Fore-teeth, the Canini, or Eye-teeth, and the foremot Double-teeth mot change; but the ret of the Double-teeth very few. Now concerning this changing of the Teeth we mut note, that the old ones do not come out by the roots, but their upper part only drops off, their root remaining till in the Socket of the Jaw, which (being like eed for the new ones) by degrees grows up above the Gums to upply the place of that which was faln off. Commonly about the twentieth year (or upwards) there pring out two Double-teeth behind the ret, which till then had lain hid in their Sockets. Thee are called Genuine teeth, or Dentes apientiae, becaue Men are then come to years of dicretion.
As for the number of them,Number. commonly there are found ixteen in each Jaw; if there fall out any difference in number as to individual perons, it commonly falleth out in the Molares.

There are three ranks of <>
Sorts. Thoe of the firt rank (or the foremo •• ) are called Inciores, Cutters. Mot commonly <…>
found in each Jaw: they have but one root o •
phang, and o eaily fall out. Thee firt make way out of the Gums in Children, becaue the tops of them are harpet. Thoe of the econd rank are called Canini, or Dog-teeth, from their length, hardnes and harpnes above the ret. In each Jaw there are two, at each ide of the Cutters one. They are commonly called Eye-teeth, either from an opinion that their roots (viz. of the upper) reach as far as the Eyes, or that the ame Nerve that moves the Eye ends a twig to thee Teeth; neither of which conceits are true. The roots of thee are ingle as thoe of the Inciores, but they are both ometimes crooked; and if uch people in whom they are o, chance to have one of them drawn, they can hardly be pulled out without breaking off a piece of the Alveolus in which they are ixt. Thoe of the third rank are called Molares, Grinders; becaue like Miltones they grind the meat. Mot commonly they are twenty in number five in each ide of both Jaws. The two foremot that tand next to the Dog-teeth, are les than the ret, having but two knobs at the top, but the three hindmot are larger and have four, being in a manner fourquare. The two foremot alo have but two roots at mot, but the three hindmot commonly three or four. But thoe of the upper Jaw have for the mot part one root more than thoe which are oppoite to them in the lower. The reaon whereof may be, firt, becaue they hang; and econdly, becaue the ubtance
of the upper Jaw is not o firm as that of the lower.

The • e of the Teeth is principally to chew the meat to prepare it for the Stomach, e. that it may the eailier concoct it into Chyle. The Inciores bite off the morel, the Dog-teeth break it, and the Grinders make it mall; wherefore they are flat in the top, that they may the better receive and keep the meat, and rough, that they may grind it the better. The Teeth contribute alo to the formation of the Sp ••• h, epecially the Fore-teeth; for thoe that have lot them, lip as we ay, and cannot pronounce pl • inly uch yllables as have C. X. &c. in them.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
Of the Bone of the Tongue called Os hyoides.
div.p:
THIS Bone is eated under the lower Jaw, in the uppermot part of the Larynx. It is haped like the Greek vowel
• , (whence it is alo called Os Ypiloides) or to the lower Jaw; becaue it is arched before, and extended with two points like horns behind. It is commonly compounded of three Bones. That in the middle is gibbous forwards and hollowinwards, and by its gibbous ide is joined to the bais of the Tongue. The other two are lateral, and are called Cornua, or Horns. Each of thee has a Cartilage adhering to it; and the middle, two. They are all tied to the adjacent parts, partly by a flehy, partly by a nervous
ubtance. In its Sinus it receiveth the Epiglottis. It moves together with the Tongue, and erveth to keep the Throat open, that the meat may decend into the Stomach, and the air have paage to the Wind-pipe while we peak and breath.

div.head: CHAP. X.
Of the Bones of the Neck.
div.p: HItherto of the Bones of the Head, now follow thoe of the Neck.
They are of two orts, to wit, the Claviculae or Channel-bones, and the Vertebrae.

As to the Claviculae, Claviculae. ome reckon them to the Thorax, others to the Shoulder; but conidering their ituation, they may as fitly be reckoned as pertaining to the Neck. They are called Claviculae from their reembling the hape of old-fahioned Keys, which were of the figure of an Italick ; uch as Spigelius ays he has een belonging to old Houes at Padua. They are not o crooked in Women as in Men. Their ubtance is thick and pongie, but more about the heads than about the middle. In number they are two, one on each ide. Near the Throat they are round; but towards the Shoulder flattih. They are joined to two Bones, to wit, one end to the Shoulder-blade, and the other to the top of the Breat-bone. The ue of them is to uphold the Shoulder-blades, that they hould not fall upon the Breat together with the Shoulder-bone; which falleth
out, when there is a fracture in them.

The Vertebrae of the Neck are in number even.Vertebrae even.
The Bones of thee are les, but harder than thoe of the other, becaue they are more moved. Thee have firt a large hollownes to give way to the Spinalis medulla to decend by: then two holes in their tranvere Procees, one in each ide, through which Veins and Arteries pas to the Head. Their Bodies have Procees oblique, tranvere and poteriour; which lat are forked, except in the firt and lat Vertebrae.

The firt Vertebra is called Atlas, becaue the Head tands upon it, like a little World. It hath no Spine behind (only a little blunt knob) let the two mall Mucles of the Head pringing from the econd Vertebra hould be hurt, when the Head is extended. It has two acending and alo two decending Procees, (otherwie called oblique) and both of them a little hollowed; the upper receiving the tubercles of the Occiput, and the lower the acending. Procees of the econd Vertebra. Upon thee the Head is moved forwards and backwards. The ubtance of this Vertebra is harder, olider, but thinner than that of the ret, becaue it is the leat, and yet its cavity is bigget. Within on the foreide of its great Foramen, it has a emicircular Sinus lined with a Cartilage, whereby it receiveth the tooth-like Proces of the econd Vertebra.

The econd is called Vertebra dentata, becaue out of its upper ide between its two acending Procees, there prings a round, longih and hard Proces, in hape like a Tooth, which being inveted with a Cartilage is jointed into the foreaid Sinus •
of the firt Vertebra, upon which as
upon an Axis the Head turns round. And when a luxation happens here the Neck is aid to be broken. This tooth-like Proces in that part which enters not into the aid Sinus, is environed with a Ligament, by which it is knit to the Occiput. The hinder Procees of this Vertebra are cleft into two, as thoe of the four following are, for the better connexion of the Mucles and Ligaments. Its tranvere Procees are les than theirs, and have alo maller holes.

The four that lie under thee, in all things are like them, ave that their lateral Procees are larger, and divided into two as well as the hinder. The eventh is the larget of all. It is liker to the Vertebrae of the Thorax than of the Neck; for neither are its tranvere Procees like the foregoing, nor is its hinder one forked, but both are like thoe of the Thorax, to be decribed in the next Chapter.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
Of the Vertebrae of the Thorax.
div.p: THE Bones of the Thorax are the Vertebrae of the Back, the Ribs and Breat-bone.

As for the Vertebrae, Vertebrae twelve. they are twelve in number, unto which o many Ribs anwer; whereof eldom doth one abound, more eldom lack. Their Spines or hinder Procees are not divided into two as thoe of the Neck, but are olid and imple. The tranvere are hort and blunt, and have
each a hallow Sinus for the inarticulation of the Ribs; but are not perforated like thoe of the Neck. The oblique Procees are four, two acending, and two decending: thee erve for articulation. The decending are a little hollowed, and receive the (omething protuberant) heads of the acending Procees of the next Vertebra below them, ucceively. The forepart of their body next to the cavity of the Thorax is round. As for their holes, they have a large one in the middle, which containeth the marrowy ubtance; and two leer beides, on each ide one, betwixt their jointings one with another, for the egres of the Nerves, and ingres of the Veins and Arteries.

div.head: CHAP. XII.
Of the Ribs.
div.p:
THE Ribs are twelve in number. Their ubtance is partly bony, partly cartilaginous; the firt erving for firmnes, the econd for articulation, and the eaier motion of the Breat in repiration. The bony ubtance towards the Vertebrae of the Back is thick and roundih, but towards the Sternum flat and thin. Within, it is fungous or pongie, whence the Ribs being broken are more readily joined together by a Callus than mot other Bones. The Cartilages in bignes anwer the bignes of the Ribs: for the bigger Ribs have the bigger Cartilages; and on the contrary. The Ribs in the
upper ide are blunt or broadih, but in the under harper. In the lower and inner ide they have a furrow that runs along them to receive the Intercotal veels, the Veins, Arteries and Nerves.
The Ribs are of two orts; for they are either long, or hort.

The long (otherwie called the true Ribs) are even in number (being the uppermot) and by their cartilaginous productions are immediately knit to the Breat-bone by the articulation called Arthrodia;
Seven verae. for in the Breat-bone there are an equal number of Cavities, which receive their cartilaginous heads. Their bony end is covered with a Cartilage and articulated into the hallow Sinus of the tranvere Procees of the Vertebrae of the Back by Synarthrois; and is knit to the aid Vert • brae by very trong Ligaments.
Note that the Cartilages of thee true Ribs are uually oberved to be harder in Women than in Men; which may eem to be for the better utaining of the weight of their Breats that lie upon them.

The hort (otherwie called Nothae or Spuriae,
Five nothae. batards Ribs) are five in number; of which the four uppermot having their Cartilages bending upward and cleaving one to another are joined before to the lower ide of the Cartilage of the eventh true Rib: but the lat, which is the leat, grows ometimes to the Diaphragm, and ometimes to the Muculus rectus of the Abdomen, as alo ometimes does the lowet of the four next above it. Behind they are joined to the Vertebrae of the Back, like as the true Ribs were.

Their ue is firt,
e. to keep the Breat and the upper part of the Abdomen ditended, that in the
former the Heart and Lungs may have free pace for their motion; and in the latter, the Stomach and Liver might not be pret upon by the circumajacent parts. Secondly, to preerve thoe parts from external injuries, as from bruies or the like. And latly, to utain the Mucles that erve for repiration, and to promote their motions; for if the Breat had been environ'd with one continued Bone, it had not been capable of dilatation in inpiration, nor of contraction in expiration.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.
Of the Breat-bone or Sternum.
div.p: THIS Bone is eated in the middle of the Thorax before, erving as a Breat-plate, and having the cartilaginous productions of the true Ribs inarticulated into it. It is of a red fungous ubtance, and in children almot wholly cartilaginous, only its uppermot part is omewhat more bony than the ret, perhaps becaue one end of the Clavicula is jointed into it. In Infants it conits of even or eight, but after ome years they o coalece one to another, that in the adult it is compounded but of three, and in aged perons it eemeth but one Bone, yet it is ditinguihed by two tranvere lines, hewing the former diviion, which are more conpicuous in the former diviion, which are more conpicuous in the inide than outide.

The uppermot Bone is thicket and broadet;
it hath in each ide a longih cavity, lined with a Cartilage, to receive the points of the Channelbones; between thee in its middle and upper part is a pit called Jugulum. It has alo a mall cavity on the inide, to give way to the Windpipe decending. The econd bone is neither o thick nor broad, yet four times as long. It is joined to the former by an intervening Cartilage, and in each ide has five or ix cavities for the inarticulation of o many of the true Ribs. The third is leat of all, yet it is broader than the econd, unto the lower end of which it is joined. What Ribs were not jointed into the middle Bone, are received by this. To its lower end is annexed the Cartilage called Mucronata or Eniformis, Sword-like. This Cartilage is triangular, about an inch long, and on the outide of it there is formed a cavity in the Breat, called Scrobiculus cordis or Heart-pit; and the gnawing pains felt there, Cardialgiae; though thoe pains are not from any affection of the Heart, but of the upper orifice of the Stomach, which lies under this Cartilage.

div.head: CHAP. XIV.
Of the Vertebrae of the Loins.
div.p: THE Bones belonging to the Abdomen are thee; five Vert • brae of the Loins, five or ix of Os acrum, Os cocoygis and Os ichii.

The five Vertebrae of the Loins are larger than thoe of the Breat, and the lowet of them are bigget. They are jointed with the lat Vertebra of the Back and the firt of Os acrum, and with one another, by an intervening clammy Cartilage, but more looly than thoe of the Back, becaue the Body bends more upon them. They have each one large hole, to give way to the Spinalis medulla; and two mall, by which Nerves pas out to the adjacent parts, and Veins and Arteries come in. As for their Procees, their poteriour (or Spines) are horter and more blunt, but broader and thicker than thoe of the Vertebrae of the Thorax, and turn omething upwards; but their lateral are longer. They alo differ in their inarticulation, one with another; for whereas in thoe of the Thorax the upper Procees were knobby, and the lower hollow, to receive them; in thee the contrary is een; for the upper Procees are hollow, and the lower knobby. Only the lat or twelfth Vertebra of the Thorax has both its acending and decending oblique Procees hollowed to receive the heads or knobs of the Procees of the lat but one of the Thorax, and the firt of the Loins.

div.head: CHAP. XV.
Of the Os acrum, and Os coccygis or Rumpbone.
div.p:
THE Os acrum is the broadet of all the Bones of the Back, and doth utain all the other Vertebrae. On the inide it is mooth and hollow, on the outide convex and uneven, being of omething a triangular hape. In its upper part on each ide it is knit firmly to the Oa Ilia by an intervening Cartilage. It conits of five or ix Bones, plainly ditinguihable in Infants, but more obcurely in grown perons. Thee Bones have the reemblance of (and are uually called) Vertebrae, for each of them hath a Body and Procees, and a large hole to receive the Spinalis medulla. In this, thee differ from the other Vertebrae; becaue in thoe, the lower part is bigger, but in thee the leer; wherefore the uppermot of them is the bigget, and the lowet the leat. Beides the large cavity to receive the Spinalis medulla, they have other leer for the egres of the Nerves; and thee are not in their ides, as thoe of the Vertebrae of the Neck, Thorax and Loins, but before and behind, between their jointings: of thee holes thoe before are much larger than thoe behind. As for their Procees, the oblique can hardly be dicerned, except in the firt. The tranvere are pretty long, but o united, that all eem but one. The hindermot are like the Spinae of the Loins, but les, and till the lower the leer; inomuch that the lowet
hath no Proces, but only a round Protuberance.

To the Os acrum the Os coccygis or Rump-bone is joined by a Cartilage, omewhat looly, that it may bend a little backwards in Women in travail for the freer paage of the Foetus, &c. It is compounded of thr •• or four Bones, of which the firt hath a mall • ollownes which receiveth the lat Vertebrae of Os acrum. The ret of its Bones grow each les than other, o that the lowet ends in a cartilaginous point. It is called Os coccygis, becaue in hape it reembleth the Cuckow's Bill. Its lower end bends inward, to tay the treight Gut and the phincter Mucle, which are tied to it. The Bones of it are pongious and oft, and have neither Proces nor any hollownes, for the pinal marrow decends no further than the bottom of Os acrum.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.
Of the Hip-bone.
div.p:
THIS Bone was by Galen called Os innominatum, becaue it had then no proper name impoed upon it, that he had met with. But Homer had long before him called it < in non-Latin alphabet > , from whom it is now generally known by that name. There is one on each ide, and they are knit to the ides of Os acrum (through the intervention of a Cartilage) by a mot trong Ligament, and together with it frame the Pelvis, or that cavity in which the Womb, Bladder and part of the Intetines
are contained. In Children it plainly appeareth to be framed of three Bones (called Os Ilium, Coxendicis, and Pubis) joined by a Cartilage, untill the eventh year; but in Men of ripe age thee three, the Cartilage being dried and harden'd into a Bone, eem but one entire Bone. However for the more exact decription of its parts, we mut conider it as coniting of three.

The firt is called Os Ilium, Os ilium. becaue under it lieth the mall Gut called Ilium. This is the uppermot and broadet; in figure, emicircular; arched without, within hollow. Its edge which makes the emicircle is called Spina, the arched part Dorum, the hollow part Cota. It is joined with the Os acrum by a common membranous and mot firm Ligament, with a Cartilage intervening, as aboveaid.

The econd is called Os coxendicis, Coxendix. by ome particularly Os ichium, and in Englih the Hipbone: though more commonly both thee lat names are taken in a larger ignification, and include all the three. This Bone is the lower and outer part of Os innominatum, and has a large cavity in it (which is called Acetabulum coxendicis) which receives the round head of the Thigh-bone, by the articulation called Enarthrois. The brims of this Cavity are tipt as it were with a Cartilage, called its Supercilium. Its lower end has a large Appendix which we lean or bear upon when we it.

The third Bone is called Os Pubis, Os pubis. and Pectinis, or the Share-bone. It is eated in the fore-part, and in the middle it is joined to its fellow by a Cartilage, which is much thicker, but looer and
ofter in Women than in Men. It has a very large Foramen in its middle, which makes it the lighter. And above, it has a Sinus, by which the crural Veins and Arteries pas to the Thighs. The Pelvis that is compoed by thee three Bones and the Os acrum, is bigger in a Woman than in a Man, to make the larger room for the Foetu • .

div.head: CHAP. XVII.
Of the Scapul • or Shoulder-blade.
div.p: NOW follow the Bones of the Limbs, which are the Legs and Arms. The Bones of the Arms are either above the joint of the Shoulder, or under.

Above the joint lieth the Shoulder-blade, in Greek called < in non-Latin alphabet > , in Latin, Scapula. The ubtance of it is for the greatet part thin, but hard and olid. The outide is omewhat arched, but the inide hollow. It is omewhat of a triangular figure, and joined to undry parts by means of the Mucles; which ort of union we called above, Syarchois. Thus it is joined with the Bone of the Occiput by the cucullar. Mucles or the firt pair that move the Scapula; to the Vertebrae of the Neck by its econd pair; and to the Back by the Mucle Rhomboides. It has three Procees: of which the firt is extended along its middle, and is called its Spine; and that end of it that by a hallow Sinus receives the Clavicula, Acromium, its point or tip. The econd is lower, les and
acute, omething like a Crow's Bill, whence it has the name of Coracoides; by others it is called Ancyroides, Anchor-like. The third is the hortet, called Cervix its Neck, which ends in a Sinus that in its upper part is acute, but in its lower round: this cavity being but hallow of it elf has its brims tipt with a Cartilage, which makes it the deeper, in which the head of the Shoulder-bone is jointed. This jointing is trengthened by very trong Ligaments and Tendons, and is partly hindred from luxation by the top of the econd Proces.

The Shoulder-blade hath a three-fold ue. Firt, it receiveth the Os humeri in the cavity of its third proces by the articulation called Arthrodia; as it does the Clavicula in the Sinus of its firt proces by Synarthrois. Secondly, undry Mucles pring from the Shoulder-blade, which erve for the motion of the Shoulder-bone. Thirdly, it defendeth the Back, o far as it reacheth, from external injuries, like a Shield.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.
Of the Os humeri or Shoulder-bone.
div.p: THE Bones of the Arm under the joint of the Shoulder are the Shoulder-bone, the Cubit-bones, and the Bones of the Hand.

The Shoulder-bone is but one in each Arm, reaching from the Shoulder to the Elbow. In figure it is round, only a little flattih behind towards
the Elbow; of a hard and olid ubtance. It is hollow all along like a Pipe, wherein a marrowy ubtance is contained. That end that is jointed to the Scapula has a great and round head, cover'd with a Cartilage, which is received into the cavity of the Scapula by that kind of articulation which is called Arthrodia. On the hinder ide of this head there tand two rough and uneven Prominences, into which the Ligaments are inerted. And betwixt thee two Prominences there is a round and long chink through which the nervous head of the Muculus biceps doth pas. Its lower end is articulated with two Bones, viz. the
lna and Radius, by Ginglymus, for it both receives them and is received by them, having three Procees and two Sinus betwixt them; o that by thee it reembles a Pully, whence it is called Trochlea. The lna is jointed with its inner ide, and the Radius with the outer. On its inide, beides the three foregoing, it has a large Proces or Tubercle from whence thoe Mucles arie that lie on the inide of the Cubit; and another les on its outide, from which thoe Mucles pring that lie on the outide. On the hinder ide of the Trochlea there is one deep large cavity, and on the foreide two mall ones, into which the Bones of the Cubit hit, when they are moved backward or forward, and are topped from being carried further. About the middle of this Bone in the inide, you may perceive a hole, through which Veels pas to the marrowy ubtance for nourihment.

div.head: CHAP. XIX.
Of the Bones of the Cubit.
div.p: THee are in number two; to wit, the leer above called Radius, and the larger below called lna. Their ubtance is firm and olid, all but their appendages. They are near of the ame length (but the lna is the longer of the two) and both have a cavity in which they contain a marrowy ubtance. They are omewhat rough in their uperficies by reaon of their lines that are appointed for the rie or inertion of the Mucles.

The lna is larger in its upper end that joints with the Os humeri,
• lna. and grows maller and maller towards the Hand, ending into a round Tubercle, with a round Sinus in it, (having on its hinder ide a mall harp Proces, from its hape call'd Styloides) whereby it is knit (by Arthrodia) to the little Bones of the Writ, by Ligaments, (a Cartilage intervening.) Its upper end is articulated with the Os humeri by Ginglymus, to which end it has two Procees, of which the hinder enters into the hinder cavity of the Shoulder-bone behind the Trochlea, (by which the Cubit is tayed from further extenion than to a treight poture) and is called Ancon or Olecranum. And at the ame end it has alo two Sinus, by the outer and les whereof it receives the head of the Radius, and by the hinder and larger one of the Procees of the Os humeri, which moves in it as a Rope in a Pully. As it receives the Radius in
its upper end, o is it received by it in its lower: but in the midt it bends or recedes a little from it, yet is knit to it by a long Ligament.

The econd Bone is upper and omething horter,Radius. called Radius. Its upper end is lenderer, having a round head, one ide of which is received by the lna; but its tip has a round hallow cavity in it, which receives a Proces of the Os humeri, by Diarthrois. Its lower end is thicker, which by a little Sinus in its ide receives the lna; and at its extremity it has two other mall Sinus, into which it admits the two firt and highet Bones of the Carpus.

div.head: CHAP. XX.
Of the Bones of the Hand.
div.p: THE Hand is divided into three parts: the Writ, called Carpus; the ditance between the Writ and Fingers, called Metacarpus; and the Fingers themelves.

The Bones of the Writ are eight in number,Bones of the Carpus eight. whereof there are two ranks or orders. The upper rank hath three Bones o joined together, that they eem but one; thee are articulated to the lna and Radius by Arthrodia: but the fourth being the leat of all, is placed a little out of its rank on the outide of the third. The inferior hath four Bones; they are joined to one another by Harmonia, but to the Bones of the Metacarpus by Arthrodia ynarthrodes, having ome motion
though but obcure. They are firmly knit to one another by both a membranous and cartilaginous Ligament; and beides, by another called annular, which compaing the Writ, comprehendeth both them and the Tendons of the Mucles which pas to the Fingers.

The Metacarpus hath four Bones;Of the Metacarpus four. they are of a olid ubtance, round, hollow within like a Pipe, being full of marrow. They are bigger than thoe of the Fingers: that which anwereth the Fore-finger is thicket and longet, and the ret grow each horter and lenderer than the foregoing. Between each two a ditance is left for the Muculi interoei of the Fingers. Both in their upper and lower end they have an Appendix; by the upper they are joined to the little Bones of the Writ, by the lower to the Fingers: the upper hath a cavity, and o receiveth the Bones of the Carpus; but the lower a round long head, covered with a Cartilage, and is received by the Sinus of the Fingers.
In the Palm of the Hand there is a tranvere Ligament, which doth tie the Bones of the Fingers to the Metacarpium.

The Fingers (taking in the Thumb) have fifteen Bones,Of the finger •
• ifteen. each three. The firt are larget, the econd les, and the third the leat On the outide they are round, but on the inide plain and a little hollow, that they may lay the firmer hold upon things. Each has a Proces at each end. The upper Procees are round, and thoe of the firt Bones have one round Sinus in them whereby they receive the round head of the Bones of the Metacarpus: but the upper Procees of the econd and third Bones have each two Sinus,
parted by a mall Protuberance. The lower Procees have two heads divided by a Sinus, which are received by the double Sinus of the upper Proces of thoe Bones that join to them: except only the lat or third Bone, which is received by none, but is fenced by a Nail. The econd Bone is joined to the firt, and the third to the econd by Ginglymus, and by them the Fingers are only tretched out and contracted. For as for their motion ideways, that depends only upon the articulation of the firt Bones with the Bones of the Metacarpus, which is done by Enarthrois, or at leat by Arthrodia. The jointings of the Thumb anwer to thee of the Fingers, aving that its upper appendix is not joined to any Bone of the Metacarpus (with which it has no communication) but immediately to the Writ; and its lower has but one head, whence the econd Bone has but one Sinus in its upper appendix to receive it.

Beides thee Bones there are in the inide of the Hand,Oa eamoidea. at the joints of the Fingers, ome mall Bones called from their figure and bignes eamoidea, like the Grains of Seama, (a ort of Indian Corn o called by Pliny.) They reemble in figure the Knee-pan, and eem to erve for the ame ue; for in trong extenions of the Fingers they trengthen the Tendons of the Mucles upon which they are placed and hinder the luxation of the joint. Authors differ very much as to their number, becaue being o mall they are eldom all found: but mot agree upon the number of 12 to each Hand, placing them thus. At the econd joint of the Thumb there are two. The econd and third joint of the Fore-finger have each one; but its firt joint, as alo the firt of the other three
have each two. In Children they are of a cartilaginous ubtance, but grow bony by degrees, (being inveted with a Cartilage) yet not olid but fungous or porous.

div.head: CHAP. XXI.
Of the Thigh-bone, and Patella.
div.p: THE Leg (in a large ene) is divided into three parts, the Thigh, the Shank (or Leg trictly o called) and Foot.

The Thigh hath but one Bone:Os femoris. but of all others it is the longet and thicket. Before, it is round: but behind, omething depreed and hollow. In the upper part it has a round head; the lender part under this is called its Neck, and is pretty long and oblique. The Neck is an Apophyis or proces to the Bone it elf, and the round Head an Epiphyis or Appendix to the Neck. This Head is received by the large Cavity or Acetabulum of the Coxendix, and is detained therein by two trong Ligaments; one that encompaes the brims of the Acetabulum, and another that prings out of its bottom, and is inerted into the tip of this round Head or Appendix. At the lower end of the Neck there pring two Prominences; which, becaue the Mucles called Rotatores are fatned to them, are called Trochanteres. The hinder and lower is the leer Trochanter; and the lateral or uppermot, the bigger. The lower end of the Thigh-bone growing thicker by degrees
hath two pretty large Prominences or Heads, leaving a cavity in the middle which receiveth the Apophyis of the Tibia: And again thee Prominences are received by the cavities of the Tibia, by a • ooe Ginglymus, both the Prominences and Cavi • ies being lined with Cartilages. The forepart of this articulation is called the Knee, the hindermot the Ham.

Upon the Knee appeareth a Bone,Patella. not joined with any other Bone, called the Pan, or Patella: it is roundih, about two inches broad, plain without, having many holes; but within bunched, covered with a Cartilage. It is et before the Thigh-bone and the Tibia, to trengthen the articulation; for otherwie the Thigh-bone would be in danger to lip out forward in going down a Hill, or the like. It cleaveth to the Knee by the thick Tendons of the econd, third, and fourth Mucles that extend the Tibia, which pas under the Patella to it, and are implanted into its foreknob. Two Ligaments faten the articulation of the Thigh-bone with the Tibia: the one fatens the Cartilage that environs the brims of the Sinus of the Tibia, the other ries out of the Apophyis of the Tibia, and is inerted into the Sinus of the Thigh-bone.

Behind there are two Oa eamoidea, which adhere to the two beginnings of the firt Mucles which move the Foot, to trengthen them. Great wounds of the Ham are mortal, by reaon of the great Veels which pas that way.

div.head: CHAP. XXII.
Of the Bones of the Shank.
div.p: THE Shank (or Leg trictly o called) is compoed of two Bones. The greater is called Tibia, the leer Fibula. Thee are lightly articulated into one another near each end; but in their middle they recede one from the other, yet o as they are tied together by a trong Ligament that comes between them.

The Tibia (commonly called Focile majus) is partly triangular,Tibia. by its harp edge before making what we call the Shin. It has an appendix at each end. That above is bigger, and in its upper part hath one Proces, which is received by the Sinus of the Thigh-bone; and two longih Cavities for the receiving of the two Prominences of the Thigh-bone, (o that the articulation is by Ginglymus) as was aid in the foregoing Chapter. About the brims of thee Sinus there is joined by Ligaments a moveable Cartilage, oft, lippery, and bedewed with an unctuous humour, called Cartilago lunata, the Moon-like Cartilage. It has alo a little Head behind (below the foreaid appendix) which enters into the Sinus of the upper appendix of the Fibula. Its lower appendix is les than the upper, jetting out with a notable Proces toward the inide of the Foot, making the Malleolus internus or inner Ankle. It has two Cavities; one les in its ide, by which it receives the Fibula; another greater and lower, divided as it were into two by a mall Protuberance
in the middle, and lined with a Cartilage, receiving the convex head of the Talus that lies under it; as the aid Protuberance is received by the hallow Sinus in the convex head of the Talus: the one being articulated into the other by Ginglymus, o that the Foot moves upwards and downwards upon this joint.

The leer and outer Bone of the Leg is called Fibula (or Focile minus;) Fibula. it is as long as the former, but much lenderer. This has alo an appendix at each end: the upper of which reaches not o high as the Knee, nor is it jointed to the Thigh-bone; but in its inner ide has a hallow Cavity which receives the little hinder (or lateral) Head of the Tibia, that is eated under its upper appendix which is jointed with the Thigh-bone. Below, the Fibula is received by the Sinus of the Tibia, and extends its appendix with its proces to the ide of the Talus, making the Malleolus externus or outer Ankle, which is lower than the inner.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII.
Of the Bones of the Tarus.
div.p: OF the Foot (as of the Hands) there are three parts, Tarus, Metatarus, and the Toes.

The Tarus is the ditance between the lower end of the two Focils,The Tarus hath even bones. and the beginning of the five Bones which are articulated with the Toes.
It hath even Bones much differing from one another in bignes and hape.

The firt is called Talus or Atragalus (in Englih the Ankle or Huckle-bone.)1. Talus. This is of a various figure: above, it has omething a convex head with a hallow Sinus in it, articulating with the Tibia, as is decribed in the foregoing Chapter.
