By the proces of the Tibia that makes the inner Ankle it is hedged in as it were on the inide, as it is by that of the Fibula on the outer. Before, it has a long neck, on which grows a round head that enters into the Sinus of Os naviculare; upon which jointing the Foot is moved ideways. Its hinder ide is rough, and in its upper part has a tranvere Sinus for the receipt of the Ligament of the Tibia, and in its lower a little decending Sinus, by which the Tendons of the Mucles pas. Below, it has a Sinus behind and a Protuberance before, by which it is articulated with the Heel-bone by Ginglymus. Betwixt the Sinus and Protuberance there is a long and pretty deep Cavity, and over againt it another uch in the Heel-bone. In thee is contained a mucous ubtance which moitens the cartilaginous Ligaments that join the Talus to the Heel-bone, keeping them from drying by continued motion.

The econd Bone of the Tarus is called Os calcis or Calcaneus, 2. Os calcis. the Heel-bone, and is the bigget of the even. It lies under the Talus, with which in its upper ide it is articulated in the manner jut now decribed. Behind, it receiveth the great Tendon called Nervus Hectoreus, compoed of the Tendons of three Mucles of the Shank. Its fore end is received by the Os cubiforme. On its inide it has a large Sinus, by which the Tendons and
larger Veels decend to the lower parts of the Foot; and on its outide it is uneven with everal knobs, for the firmer connexion of the Ligaments and Tendons.

The third is called Os Naviculare or Cymbiforme, 3. Os naviculare. from its figure. Behind, it receiveth the Talus in a large Sinus; but before, it is convex, with three flattih mooth heads that are admitted into the very hallow Sinus of the three Oa cuneiformia or leer Bones of the Tarus.

The remaining four are les than the three already decribed, and tand all in one rank; the firt of them articulates with the Heel-bone, the other three with the Os naviculare. There is no Cartilage betwixt them, but they are knit one to another on the outide by a cartilaginous Ligament; and are cover'd both in their hinder and fore-part with a mooth Cartilage where they are jointed with other Bones. The firt is called Cubiforme or Die-like,4. Os cubiforme. having ix ides. This is bigger than the other three that follow, and is eated on the outide of the Foot. In its foreide it is joined to the fourth and fifth Bone of the Metatarus; in the hinder with the Heel bone; and in the inide, to the third Bone of the Cuneiformia: but its other three ides, viz. the outer, upper and lower are joined to none.

The three enuing are called Cuneiformia, 5. Three Cuneiformia. or wedge-like Bones; for above they are thick, and below thinner, o that being joined, they repreent a Vault, being convex on the upper ide, but on the under hollow; in which hollownes the Tendons and Mucles are lodged, o that one does not pres upon and bruie them in going. The firt of thee Bones is the greatet, eated in
the inide of the Foot; the econd is the leat, placed in the middle; the third is in the mean between both in bignes. Thee three behind are joined to the Os naviculare, and before to the three firt Bones of the Metatarus.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV.
Of the ret of the Bones of the Foot.
div.p: THE Metatarus, The bones of the Intep five. or Intep, hath five Bones: for one is appointed for the utaining of the great Toe, as well as others for each of the ret; though in the Hand it is not o, where the Thumb has no Bone in the Metacarpus anwering to it.

They are olid without, but hollow within; and are longer than the Bones of the back of the Hand. That which tayeth the great Toe is thicket, but the longet is that which tayeth the next Toe: the other three grow each horter than other, but are almot of an equal thicknes. Their lower ends being round are inerted into the Sinus of the firt joints of the Toes: but the upper in their own hallow Sinus receive the Bones of the Tarus.

The Bones of the Toes are in number fourteen;Of the Toes fourteen. for the great Toe hath only two, but the ret three. Thee bones are olid without, and hollow within like thoe of the Intep. Their articulation is altogether like that of the Fingers, o that we hall not need here to decribe it over again.
Each Foot has twelve Oa eamoidea, as well as the Hands: but eeing they are eated wholly alike in both, the Reader may pleae to turn back to their decription in Chap. 20.

div.head: CHAP. XXV.
Of a Cartilage.
div.p: AS an Appendix to the Doctrine of Bones we will add a word or two of the Cartilages and Ligaments of the Body; becaue the former come nearet to the nature of Bones; and the latter, as they tye everal other parts one to another, o epecially the Bones.
A Cartilage is a imilar part, cold, dry and void of ene, flexible and not o hard as a Bone. But when by age its glutinous particles are dried up, it many times degenerates into a Bone.

As for the Cartilages of the Eye-brows, Ears, Noe, Larynx, &c. we hall not need here particularly to decribe them, having done it where we treated of the repective parts; only we will note in general, that all the Bones in their articulations one with another, are covered or lined with Cartilages, whereby their motion becomes more eaie and glib: and ometimes themelves are the medium by which Bones are joined, which articulation is called Synchondrois, uch as that of the Oa pubis: and latly, by tipping as it were the brims of the Cavities of the greater joints, they make the Sinus deeper.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI.
Of a Ligament.
div.p: A Ligament is a imilar part, cold and dry, of a middle ubtance betwixt a Cartilage and a Membrane, appointed for the tying of undry pa •• s together.

Note, that as it is either harder or ofter than is uitable to its proper nature, it acquires the epithets of cartilaginous or membranous repectively: o, that which proceeds out of the top of the Thigh-bone and is inerted into the cavity of the Coxendix is called a cartilaginous Ligament, for its hardnes; and that which environeth the joint of the Shoulder, is called membranous, from its oftnes.

Thoe which tye Bones together are without ene, (for otherwie upon every motion we hould have been in pain:) but thoe that knit other parts together, (as thoe that tye the Liver, Womb, &c. to the neighbouring parts) are enible.

Ligaments are found in everal parts of the Body. As firt, the Head being moved upon the firt and econd Vertebra of the Neck, there are four Ligaments to trengthen the articulation. Secondly, a common membranous Ligament begirts the whole articulation of the lower Jaw with the Temple-bone. Thirdly, the Bone at the root of the Tongue has four, by which it is tyed to the neighbouring parts; and the Tongue it elf has one trong one on its under-ide, (otherwie
called its Fraenum) which being two hort or running too near its tip, hindreth its motion. Children being o troubled, are aid to be Tonguetyed, and mut have it cut. Fourthly, both the Bodies and Procees of all the Vertebrae of the Back are knit together by Ligaments, as alo are the Ribs with the Vertebrae behind, and with the Breat-bone before. Fifthly, undry are to be een in the Abdomen. The firt tieth the Os ilium to Os acrum. The econd knitteth the Os acrum to the Coxendix. The third and fourth knit the Share-bones together, one of them compaing them circularly, and the other, which is membranous, poeing their very Foramen. As for the Ligaments of the Liver, Bladder, &c. thoe were dicoured of when we decribed thoe parts in Book 1. Sixthly, in the Arm thee appear. 1. Five tie the Os humeri to the Shoulder-blade. 2. The Bones of the Cubit, lna and Radius, are tied firt one to another; econdly, to the Shoulder-bone; and thirdly, to the Writ by (motly) membranous Ligaments. 3. There are annular Ligaments at the Writs, which being tranvere, confirm and make teady the Tendons which pas to the Fingers. They are two; one in the outide, for the Tendons of the extending Mucles; the other in the inner ide, for the Tendons of the contracting Mucles. 4. The Bones of the Writ, back of the Hand and Fingers, have membranous Ligaments. Seventhly, In the Leg are thee. 1. The Thigh-bone is tied to the Coxendix by two Ligaments. 2. The lower end of it is tied to Tibia and Fibula by ix Ligaments. 3. The Tibia is joined to the Fibula by three membranous Ligaments, viz. two common and one
proper. 4. Tibia and Fibula are joined to the Talus by three Ligaments, and there are three other for the trengthening of the Tendons. 5. The Talus is tied with the other Bones of the Foot by five Ligaments. 6. The Bones of the Intep and Toes are tied with uch Ligaments as thoe of the Hand are.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII.
Of the Nails.
div.p: IN the lat place we will ay omething of the Nails, which though they are not truly parts of the Body, yet for their uefulnes ought not to be omitted.

They are of an horny tranparent ubtance, coming nearet to that of Bones, faten'd upon the ends of the Fingers and Toes for their defence. They are endued with no ene, nor is that colour which they appear to be of upon the Fingers, owing to their proper ubtance, but to the colour of the parts that lie under them; whence they ometimes look ruddy, ometimes pale, blue or yellow, and thereby give ome intimation of the tate of the Body. They grow very firmly to the Fleh that lies under them; and to faten them the better, they are tied about their root with a Ligament, and on their ides the Skin cloes them in. The parts that lie under them are very enible, for there are everal twigs of Nerves and tendons of Mucles that run to the
very Fingers ends; o that upon handling any hard or rugged thing we hould have been continually in pain, if thee o enible parts had not been thus defended by the Nails.

They may in ome ene be reputed parts of the Body, o as that it would not be perfect and intire without them: but that is but an improper notion of a part. For if they were properly parts, they hould live by the common life of the Body; but that they do not, eeing they as well as the hair continue to grow after a Man is dead: and their growth eems meerly to be by appoition of new particles to their roots, which drive on ucceively thoe before them; as we may ee when there is a black or white peck on any of them, for it till goes forward together with the Nail, till it arrive at the Fingers end beyond the Fleh.
